description: August 20, 2016  is the last day for this exam. Those looking to complete the Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician (CCENT) certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the exam required to pass in order to receive it. The CCENT involves networking fundamentals, basic security, wireless concepts and other topics and is designed for entry level IT professionals getting ready for help desk and support type positions. Some of the exam objectives include Operation of IP Data Networks, LAN Switching Technologies, IP Addressing, Network Device Security, troubleshooting and others which provide good foundational knowledge for achieving further related certifications.
name: CCENT
subtitle: Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician

episodes.description: The CCENT covers a wide range of foundational topics and is the first step into possible Cisco certifications one can achieve. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the CCENT certification, about the Interconnecting Cisco Networking Devices (ICND) exam one will need to take and the exam objectives for implementing Cisco IP routing.
episodes.title: Overview of CCENT
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,011 --> 00:00:06,100
[NOISE] The Cisco Certified
Entry Network Technician,

2
00:00:06,100 --> 00:00:11,921
or CCENT certification,
is designed to be the first

3
00:00:11,921 --> 00:00:17,493
step on your journey into
Cisco certifications.

4
00:00:17,493 --> 00:00:20,910
In particular, their routing and
switching certifications.

5
00:00:20,910 --> 00:00:24,350
The CCENT covers a wide
range of foundational

6
00:00:24,350 --> 00:00:27,550
topics that are very important
to understand if you're gonna

7
00:00:27,550 --> 00:00:30,265
build upon them in the more advanced
certifications down the road.

8
00:00:30,265 --> 00:00:34,040
Not learning the base material
really does create that challenge.

9
00:00:34,040 --> 00:00:36,543
You can't learn advanced functionality
if you don't understand basic

10
00:00:36,543 --> 00:00:38,100
functionality first.

11
00:00:38,100 --> 00:00:42,670
Now the CCENT, well that E stands for
entry, and that describes the type of job

12
00:00:42,670 --> 00:00:47,120
that this employee, or someone certified
with the CCENT would be designed to fill.

13
00:00:47,120 --> 00:00:50,960
Entry level, typically help desk,
technical support type roles.

14
00:00:50,960 --> 00:00:54,600
These are small office,
home office type deployments.

15
00:00:54,600 --> 00:00:57,290
Environments that might have one router,
or one switch, or

16
00:00:57,290 --> 00:00:59,070
just a couple of devices.

17
00:00:59,070 --> 00:01:00,785
Not large or enterprise networks.

18
00:01:00,785 --> 00:01:03,800
That's where they start stepping
up into the higher certifications.

19
00:01:03,800 --> 00:01:06,325
In fact,
if you look at the certification path,

20
00:01:06,325 --> 00:01:09,850
it's really just increasing the amount
of devices that you're working with.

21
00:01:09,850 --> 00:01:12,190
Let's take a look at that path real
quick to get an idea of what I mean.

22
00:01:13,270 --> 00:01:17,665
This is CISCO's website for the CCENT page
and they show the different certifications

23
00:01:17,665 --> 00:01:21,108
and how they line up, and
see how they've arranged it as a pyramid.

24
00:01:21,108 --> 00:01:26,156
Each one builds on the ones from before
it, and the entry certification, that's

25
00:01:26,156 --> 00:01:31,150
that foundation, that's the base level
that everything else builds on top of.

26
00:01:31,150 --> 00:01:34,958
So very important and definitely something
that we need to make sure we grasp.

27
00:01:34,958 --> 00:01:35,740
All right.

28
00:01:35,740 --> 00:01:40,360
After that, you progress to that CCNA,
the Cisco Certified Network Associate, and

29
00:01:40,360 --> 00:01:42,500
that's one of the most
well-known certifications, and

30
00:01:42,500 --> 00:01:45,500
that's what most people
are seeking to achieve.

31
00:01:45,500 --> 00:01:49,205
Now you can skip over the CCENT, and

32
00:01:49,205 --> 00:01:53,215
go straight to the CCNA if you've already
been working with Cisco equipment,

33
00:01:53,215 --> 00:01:56,025
if you've already got some
of the requisite knowledge.

34
00:01:56,025 --> 00:01:58,875
You'll see a lot of people do that if
they already have the network plus

35
00:01:58,875 --> 00:02:00,695
certification from CompTIA.

36
00:02:00,695 --> 00:02:05,200
The CompTIA network plus actually covers
a lot of the same stuff in the CCENT.

37
00:02:05,200 --> 00:02:09,830
The big difference is with CompTIA,
it's vendor neutral training

38
00:02:09,830 --> 00:02:14,230
versus the CCENT which is all from
Cisco and Cisco does have a slightly

39
00:02:14,230 --> 00:02:17,460
different perspective on some of the
different technologies you'll learn about.

40
00:02:17,460 --> 00:02:20,475
So, they're very close,
but they're not identical.

41
00:02:20,475 --> 00:02:24,775
And if you do choose to skip the CCENT and
jump right to the CCNA,

42
00:02:24,775 --> 00:02:28,585
you'll have to take a composite exam
that's actually made up of both.

43
00:02:28,585 --> 00:02:31,197
So it's pulling questions from both pools.

44
00:02:31,197 --> 00:02:34,576
So, it's not like you get to skip that
one and not know the information.

45
00:02:34,576 --> 00:02:37,350
You do have to know the information.

46
00:02:37,350 --> 00:02:39,560
Now for most people just
getting started with Cisco,

47
00:02:39,560 --> 00:02:45,610
I do recommend that you start with the
CCENT and do it separate from the CCNA and

48
00:02:45,610 --> 00:02:49,050
we'll see why when we get to the exam
numbers here in just a moment.

49
00:02:49,050 --> 00:02:53,440
All right now, the exam covers a wide
range of topics and most of them center

50
00:02:53,440 --> 00:02:57,900
around the idea of taking a Cisco router
or a Cisco switch out of the box,

51
00:02:57,900 --> 00:03:03,270
brand new, getting it configured and
put in place in a small network.

52
00:03:03,270 --> 00:03:05,970
As you move up to the higher
end certifications like

53
00:03:05,970 --> 00:03:09,900
the CCNA which is next, it starts to
get to a slightly larger network,

54
00:03:09,900 --> 00:03:15,500
maybe 5 to 10 routers and 10 to 20
switches or something of that nature.

55
00:03:15,500 --> 00:03:16,850
Then you move up to the CCNP.

56
00:03:16,850 --> 00:03:20,350
At the CCNP level, the professional level,

57
00:03:20,350 --> 00:03:23,890
that's where we're talking about hundreds
or even thousands of routers and

58
00:03:23,890 --> 00:03:27,430
switches routing across the internet,
massive networks.

59
00:03:27,430 --> 00:03:31,250
This is where we get large,
enterprise-scale networking knowledge.

60
00:03:31,250 --> 00:03:33,688
After that,
you move into the expert level, the CCIE.

61
00:03:33,688 --> 00:03:38,590
And the CCIE is one of those
really coveted, highly respected,

62
00:03:38,590 --> 00:03:41,630
very difficult certifications
that are out there, and

63
00:03:41,630 --> 00:03:45,180
it is a level of experience that
most people aren't going to need.

64
00:03:45,180 --> 00:03:46,930
It's for enterprises.

65
00:03:46,930 --> 00:03:48,400
People that have massive networks and

66
00:03:48,400 --> 00:03:52,540
they need somebody to not just design
a stable network, but maintain and

67
00:03:52,540 --> 00:03:56,810
keep it going, upgrades and all of that,
and it's an expert level of knowledge.

68
00:03:56,810 --> 00:03:59,638
It's really in depth understanding of
all the different technologies that

69
00:03:59,638 --> 00:04:00,980
are involved.

70
00:04:00,980 --> 00:04:04,480
Each of these certifications is building
off of the knowledge from the previous

71
00:04:04,480 --> 00:04:06,960
one, so
it forms together in one nice chain.

72
00:04:06,960 --> 00:04:11,400
Now, the CCENT is one exam.

73
00:04:11,400 --> 00:04:12,690
One certification.

74
00:04:12,690 --> 00:04:16,570
So the exam for this one if we
jump over to it's exam page,

75
00:04:16,570 --> 00:04:20,540
is the 100-101, or ICND1 exam.

76
00:04:20,540 --> 00:04:21,800
Now that name, ICND1,

77
00:04:21,800 --> 00:04:27,060
Interconnecting Cisco Network Devices,
that's the official Cisco course name.

78
00:04:27,060 --> 00:04:29,050
If you were to take the official
course through Cisco,

79
00:04:29,050 --> 00:04:32,050
you'd actually be taking the ICND course.

80
00:04:32,050 --> 00:04:37,760
You'd then take the 100-101 exam, and
you'd receive the CCENT certification.

81
00:04:37,760 --> 00:04:42,220
With the ITProTV show, we cover all of
the exam objectives for the 100-101, so

82
00:04:42,220 --> 00:04:47,040
we're covering the same content, but
we don't call it ICND because, well,

83
00:04:47,040 --> 00:04:48,745
it's not the official Cisco course, right?

84
00:04:48,745 --> 00:04:51,945
They have their own set of training
that they use, and we do it differently.

85
00:04:53,015 --> 00:04:54,245
The certification that you'll get though,

86
00:04:54,245 --> 00:04:56,835
is the same CCENT that
everyone else gets and

87
00:04:56,835 --> 00:05:00,635
then you progress up to the more advanced
CCNA level certifications if you want.

88
00:05:00,635 --> 00:05:04,355
Now, notice CCENT is
kind of by itself here,

89
00:05:04,355 --> 00:05:07,975
versus CCNA has all these specializations,
routing and switching,

90
00:05:07,975 --> 00:05:11,030
security, service provider,
voice, wireless.

91
00:05:11,030 --> 00:05:14,550
Well CCENT is a prerequisite
of all of those.

92
00:05:14,550 --> 00:05:17,567
So, regardless of which
specialization you're going for,

93
00:05:17,567 --> 00:05:19,081
CCENT is that starting point.

94
00:05:19,081 --> 00:05:24,230
That's why this is the first
certification you'll pursue for Cisco.

95
00:05:24,230 --> 00:05:26,680
Now, when you're ready to take that exam,
you can sign up for it.

96
00:05:26,680 --> 00:05:29,640
Cisco administers their exams through
a company called Pearson Vue.

97
00:05:29,640 --> 00:05:36,340
You can go to their website,
it's www.pearsonvue, that's v-u-e, .com,

98
00:05:36,340 --> 00:05:39,600
forward slash Cisco, that will take you
to there page and you can go and sign up.

99
00:05:39,600 --> 00:05:42,880
If you're not familiar with Pearson Vue,
they have testing centers

100
00:05:42,880 --> 00:05:46,990
all over the world and on their website
you can find one that's near to you, so

101
00:05:46,990 --> 00:05:50,610
it's easy to jump on over and
take the exam at your leisure, right?

102
00:05:50,610 --> 00:05:52,640
So it's definitely
a convenient thing to do.

103
00:05:53,650 --> 00:05:57,190
Once you pass that exam,
you get the CCENT certification and

104
00:05:57,190 --> 00:05:59,250
you're ready to progress beyond that.

105
00:05:59,250 --> 00:06:01,190
Let's take a look at
those exam objectives.

106
00:06:01,190 --> 00:06:05,216
The exam is actually
made up of between 40 and

107
00:06:05,216 --> 00:06:09,120
45 questions and
you have 90 minutes to do it in.

108
00:06:09,120 --> 00:06:12,530
Now that sounds like you have about two
minutes per question which is really

109
00:06:12,530 --> 00:06:17,560
plenty of time, but the exam is not
just multiple choice questions.

110
00:06:17,560 --> 00:06:22,505
It's made up of multiple choice, drag and
drop, choose all that apply, right?

111
00:06:22,505 --> 00:06:25,820
Multi-answer type questions,
and simulations.

112
00:06:25,820 --> 00:06:28,920
Some questions will have
a simulated router or switch and

113
00:06:28,920 --> 00:06:31,230
you'll have to configure or
troubleshoot something.

114
00:06:31,230 --> 00:06:34,400
Those questions take a lot longer
than a normal question and

115
00:06:34,400 --> 00:06:38,770
you'll find that 90 minutes is barely
enough time to get through all of it.

116
00:06:38,770 --> 00:06:40,200
Cisco has done that on purpose.

117
00:06:40,200 --> 00:06:42,140
They want to make sure that
you know what you're doing.

118
00:06:42,140 --> 00:06:43,750
That you're not just
sitting there guessing and

119
00:06:43,750 --> 00:06:45,140
trying to figure your way through it.

120
00:06:45,140 --> 00:06:48,070
That you know the right thing to do,
and you move on.

121
00:06:48,070 --> 00:06:51,500
That does make it a pretty challenging
exam, but it's pretty rewarding, too.

122
00:06:51,500 --> 00:06:52,720
I definitely enjoy it.

123
00:06:53,760 --> 00:06:58,000
For the exam topics, the CCENT is
spread over a large area of topics,

124
00:06:58,000 --> 00:07:00,550
because it's all foundational knowledge.

125
00:07:00,550 --> 00:07:03,190
You're not expected to be an expert
on all of these things, but

126
00:07:03,190 --> 00:07:07,010
you are expected to have a basic
understanding of the concepts in each.

127
00:07:07,010 --> 00:07:09,760
We start with just operation
of IP data networks.

128
00:07:09,760 --> 00:07:12,280
How do IP base networks function?

129
00:07:12,280 --> 00:07:14,580
How do IP addresses work?

130
00:07:14,580 --> 00:07:16,250
How do we have basic communications?

131
00:07:16,250 --> 00:07:17,520
What is Ethernet?

132
00:07:17,520 --> 00:07:19,380
What is CSMA/CD?

133
00:07:19,380 --> 00:07:21,940
These are all things that
you need to understand

134
00:07:21,940 --> 00:07:25,390
just to understand how
a basic network functions.

135
00:07:25,390 --> 00:07:27,670
After that, we take a look at
LAN switching technologies and

136
00:07:27,670 --> 00:07:32,000
that's the chance for the viewer to
learn how to configure a Cisco switch.

137
00:07:32,000 --> 00:07:34,320
We take a blank brand new Cisco switch and

138
00:07:34,320 --> 00:07:36,940
we go through all the different
configuration values that you can place on

139
00:07:36,940 --> 00:07:39,470
it to get it operational
in a small environment.

140
00:07:41,000 --> 00:07:43,280
Then we tackle IP addressing specifically.

141
00:07:43,280 --> 00:07:46,970
You'll find that IP addresses are a lot
more complex than most people think, and

142
00:07:46,970 --> 00:07:48,970
there's a lot of neat stuff
you can do with them.

143
00:07:48,970 --> 00:07:50,615
So we spend a lot of
time discussing that and

144
00:07:50,615 --> 00:07:55,585
not just IPv4 but IPv6 also because that's
the way the networks are moving today.

145
00:07:56,705 --> 00:07:58,045
Then we jump into routing.

146
00:07:58,045 --> 00:08:02,045
IP routing technologies is where we take
a look at configuring a Cisco router and

147
00:08:02,045 --> 00:08:06,065
getting it in place to allow
communication between networks.

148
00:08:06,065 --> 00:08:09,235
We also look at some dynamic routing
protocols and how the routers can

149
00:08:09,235 --> 00:08:13,030
talk to each other to learn the best
route between two different locations.

150
00:08:14,480 --> 00:08:16,050
IP services is the next one and

151
00:08:16,050 --> 00:08:19,600
that expands upon the routing
services that we talked about before.

152
00:08:19,600 --> 00:08:22,820
We'll get a chance to see some of
the other things that our routers can do.

153
00:08:22,820 --> 00:08:24,370
They can do a lot of stuff.

154
00:08:24,370 --> 00:08:26,980
You'll find that routers can
actually be used as firewalls, or

155
00:08:26,980 --> 00:08:28,300
as VPN tunnel endpoints.

156
00:08:28,300 --> 00:08:31,480
There's all kinds of cool things
that a Cisco router can do,

157
00:08:31,480 --> 00:08:32,640
if you just know to turn it on.

158
00:08:34,340 --> 00:08:37,910
Next we've got security and this is
Network Device Security specifically,

159
00:08:37,910 --> 00:08:42,430
which is saying if an attacker compromises
your router or if they compromise your

160
00:08:42,430 --> 00:08:45,470
switch, there's a lot of stuff they
could do to access your data and

161
00:08:45,470 --> 00:08:46,970
you won't even know it.

162
00:08:46,970 --> 00:08:49,510
So we need to secure our routers and
switches to ensure that

163
00:08:49,510 --> 00:08:54,180
unauthorized access isn't allowed, and so
we focus on that in that sixth session.

164
00:08:54,180 --> 00:08:56,070
And then the last section
is troubleshooting.

165
00:08:56,070 --> 00:08:59,790
One of the basic troubleshooting steps for
locating issues in your network and

166
00:08:59,790 --> 00:09:02,890
resolving them as quickly and
efficiently as possible.

167
00:09:02,890 --> 00:09:06,920
All of this is great knowledge and
you'll see each topic has a certain

168
00:09:06,920 --> 00:09:11,370
percentage value of the exam and
it's pretty evenly spread.

169
00:09:11,370 --> 00:09:15,810
Some were as small as 6% or as large
as 26%, but every one of them weighs in

170
00:09:15,810 --> 00:09:19,370
a good bit, and it's all good
foundational knowledge to have.

171
00:09:20,920 --> 00:09:25,890
All right, now the ICND1 is
the first exam that you'll do,

172
00:09:25,890 --> 00:09:29,300
and when you pass that,
you get your CCENT.

173
00:09:29,300 --> 00:09:34,590
If you move onto the CCNA,
the next level, well it has its own exam.

174
00:09:34,590 --> 00:09:37,960
And if I jump back here, I'll just
switch over to the CCNA real quick so

175
00:09:37,960 --> 00:09:39,520
we can see it.

176
00:09:39,520 --> 00:09:42,616
Notice on the CCNA it has two exams.

177
00:09:42,616 --> 00:09:45,414
The 100-101 and 200-101.

178
00:09:45,414 --> 00:09:47,481
That's ICND1 and ICND2.

179
00:09:47,481 --> 00:09:53,000
Basically you have to have your
CCENT in order to get your CCNA.

180
00:09:53,000 --> 00:09:56,520
So the first one is that same CCENT exam,
and

181
00:09:56,520 --> 00:09:59,110
the second one is specifically for
the CCNA.

182
00:09:59,110 --> 00:10:00,910
You've gotta do both.

183
00:10:00,910 --> 00:10:04,114
Now I said you could skip
the CCENT if you wanted.

184
00:10:04,114 --> 00:10:08,198
If you wanna skip it, if you've already
got the base knowledge, if you've already

185
00:10:08,198 --> 00:10:11,879
got a network plus certification for
example, you might choose to skip past

186
00:10:11,879 --> 00:10:15,870
the CCENT, and if you do, you can take
this exam right here, the composite exam.

187
00:10:15,870 --> 00:10:17,645
The 200-120.

188
00:10:17,645 --> 00:10:22,640
It's one exam and
it covers both sets of knowledge.

189
00:10:22,640 --> 00:10:25,220
All of the ICND1 and 2, all right?

190
00:10:25,220 --> 00:10:28,920
That's how you would go about
skipping the CCENT, but

191
00:10:28,920 --> 00:10:31,590
I'll tell you, it's not really worth it.

192
00:10:31,590 --> 00:10:33,210
And the reason is,
you don't save any money,

193
00:10:33,210 --> 00:10:37,050
the composite exam actually costs as much
as the two individual exams combined.

194
00:10:37,050 --> 00:10:41,630
So, you don't save any money by doing
it and you open yourself up to risk.

195
00:10:41,630 --> 00:10:45,100
We always hope that we pass the exam
on the first time, but if for

196
00:10:45,100 --> 00:10:49,230
some reason you don't pass, well,
if you took them separately,

197
00:10:49,230 --> 00:10:53,980
you may have passed the first one and
not the second, you get your CCEMT, right?

198
00:10:53,980 --> 00:10:55,670
But not your CCNA.

199
00:10:55,670 --> 00:10:59,280
If you don't pass the composite exam,
you get nothing, right?

200
00:10:59,280 --> 00:11:00,740
You get no certification.

201
00:11:00,740 --> 00:11:03,610
So it's almost like a safety net to
go ahead and take them separately.

202
00:11:03,610 --> 00:11:05,450
It just costs you time, right?

203
00:11:05,450 --> 00:11:08,280
An additional 90 minutes to go and
sit the other exam, but

204
00:11:08,280 --> 00:11:09,900
that is how I recommend you do it.

205
00:11:09,900 --> 00:11:13,620
So CCENT, even if you already have
the knowledge, it's good to go ahead and

206
00:11:13,620 --> 00:11:18,210
get it cuz you'll get that certification
on your resume, and you've got

207
00:11:18,210 --> 00:11:22,900
a little bit less risk and a smaller area
of data to focus in for that second exam.

208
00:11:24,170 --> 00:11:28,935
All right well, that's what the CCENT
is designed for entry-level people

209
00:11:28,935 --> 00:11:34,160
getting ready for help desk and support
type positions, small networks, right?

210
00:11:34,160 --> 00:11:35,730
And it's a good certification,

211
00:11:35,730 --> 00:11:38,100
definitely a great way to get
your feet wet with Cisco.

212
00:11:38,100 --> 00:11:42,010
If that sounds exciting to you and
it sounds like what you need to learn,

213
00:11:42,010 --> 00:11:43,600
then you're in the right place.

214
00:11:43,600 --> 00:11:47,820
Stay tuned because we've got CCENT
episodes coming up after this.

215
00:11:47,820 --> 00:11:50,770
If that doesn't sound right for you, for
example if you wanna skip past this and

216
00:11:50,770 --> 00:11:53,270
jump to CCNA, well, be sure to do that.

217
00:11:53,270 --> 00:11:56,570
It's all part of the ITProTV library and
it's part of your subscription, so

218
00:11:56,570 --> 00:11:58,820
you can start wherever
you feel is appropriate.

219
00:11:58,820 --> 00:12:00,145
So take advantage of that.

220
00:12:00,145 --> 00:12:02,330
That's one of the nice
things about our service.

221
00:12:02,330 --> 00:12:05,098
All right well for those of you that
are sticking with me, let's go ahead and

222
00:12:05,098 --> 00:12:05,627
get started.

223
00:12:05,627 --> 00:12:09,784
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Cisco offers a handful of certifications like CCENT, CCNA, and others. Viewers will hear discussions on assorted terminology required for the CCENT exam, the Cisco exam objectives, the Open System Interconnect (OSI) model that is a cornerstone of any advanced networking topic, and on understanding the network devices one has to deal with.
episodes.title: Intro To Cisco
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,362 --> 00:00:10,362

good afternoon, and good evening.

Nate, you've been studying

27

don't use this term.

28

>> [LAUGH]
>> Because it's a Cisco term,

29

I gotta use the CompTIA generic term.

30

But in this show, the gloves are off.

31

No holds barred.

32

It is straight up Cisco time.

33

That vender neutrality
stuff out the window.

So before we get started into

39

[LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] l Good point.

Good point.

43

boy this just changed.

So the CCENT is a new certification.

45

It is the Cisco Certified
Entry Network Technician.

46

The CCNA, or
Cisco Certified Network Associate.

47

>> Yeah, Associate that's right.

49

Like I said, I got my CCNA 14 years
ago and so it's been around a while.

50

It's always been two exams
to get the certification.

51
00:02:44,538 --> 00:02:48,465
So you do one exam and
then you do the second one.

52
00:02:48,465 --> 00:02:51,810
[LAUGH] And when you pass that second
exam then you get your certification.

53
00:02:51,810 --> 00:02:55,390
You pass the first exam
you don't get anything.

54

Bragging rights I suppose.

55
00:02:56,910 --> 00:03:00,914
So, Cisco changed almost two
years ago now they changed it,

56
00:03:00,914 --> 00:03:03,277
to introduce a new certification.

57
00:03:03,277 --> 00:03:07,976
When you pass that first exam you
actually get your CCENT which is awesome.

58

You get credit for what you've done.

59
00:03:09,856 --> 00:03:13,688
>> Mm-hm.

60

Ring through some of the objectives and
everything that CCENT,

61

[COUGH] at times it looks more of, yeah,
a lot of good skill and configuring stuff.

62
00:03:25,920 --> 00:03:30,110
And rather than just an entry level,
it may be an entry level but

63
00:03:31,440 --> 00:03:34,840
yeah, I mean it's, you can do
a lot of stuff once you've got it.

64
00:03:34,840 --> 00:03:39,340
>> The way I always look at it
is if you are CCENT, certified,

65
00:03:39,340 --> 00:03:41,140
right that first certification.

66
00:03:41,140 --> 00:03:44,460
That certifies that you know
how to take a Cisco router

67
00:03:44,460 --> 00:03:45,940
>> Or a Cisco switch, brand new,

68
00:03:45,940 --> 00:03:49,110
out of the box, and get it configured and
running on a network.

69
00:03:49,110 --> 00:03:50,990
Right?
So one router or

70
00:03:50,990 --> 00:03:54,000
one switch, fired up, off you go.

71
00:03:54,000 --> 00:03:56,460
CCNA, now that's a little bit higher,
right?

72
00:03:56,460 --> 00:04:01,450
That's the next tier and if your CCNAs are
fine, that shows that you're able to take

73
00:04:01,450 --> 00:04:04,220
more than one router or
more than one switch and

74
00:04:04,220 --> 00:04:07,580
get us set up in a small office,
home office, branch office type topology.

75
00:04:07,580 --> 00:04:10,060
And then Cisco's got
their higher tier stuff.

76
00:04:10,060 --> 00:04:10,850
Like the CCNP,

77
00:04:10,850 --> 00:04:15,870
I'm a CCNP and that means you can handle
hundreds of routers and switches.

78
00:04:15,870 --> 00:04:18,340
A little more corporate size and
larger environments.

79
00:04:18,340 --> 00:04:21,140
But it all starts right here.

80
00:04:21,140 --> 00:04:23,320
With that first router or first switch.

81
00:04:23,320 --> 00:04:25,990
A lot of you guys out there,
you've probably worked with routers and

82
00:04:25,990 --> 00:04:27,200
switches before.

83
00:04:27,200 --> 00:04:30,000
If you haven't,
this may be your exposure to it.

84
00:04:30,000 --> 00:04:32,210
And so we start with the basics, right?

85
00:04:32,210 --> 00:04:36,580
And kinda getting in there, and so
that's basically where we start today.

86
00:04:36,580 --> 00:04:39,309
That we jump into our generalities, right?

87
00:04:39,309 --> 00:04:41,384
>> [LAUGH]
>> We kinda summarize everything that we

88

do in Network+.

89

But we put it in CISCO terms.

90
00:04:44,082 --> 00:04:46,450
>> Mm-hm, yeah.

91
00:04:46,450 --> 00:04:50,828
>> The other thing worth mentioning here,
not that things aren't worth mentioning,

92
00:04:50,828 --> 00:04:54,848
the other thing that I want to mention,
is that the exams did update, right.

93
00:04:54,848 --> 00:04:58,693
And so, while the CCENT has been out for
about two years,

94
00:04:58,693 --> 00:05:02,030
the exams just changed,
when did they change?

95
00:05:02,030 --> 00:05:05,320
They're in the process
of changing right now.

96
00:05:05,320 --> 00:05:08,560
>> Yeah, I think in March or

97
00:05:08,560 --> 00:05:13,680
something it was starting to
transition things over and so now.

98
00:05:14,810 --> 00:05:17,800
>> I'm just going to pull up
the Cisco page here real quick so

99
00:05:17,800 --> 00:05:20,550
I can show everybody what I mean.

100
00:05:20,550 --> 00:05:24,730
When we take a look at, and
I'm just on Cisco's website.

101
00:05:24,730 --> 00:05:28,690
If you go to like, www.cisco.com/go/ccna,

102
00:05:28,690 --> 00:05:33,190
it takes you right into there and
you can find everything.

103
00:05:34,750 --> 00:05:38,164
But basically, right on their website,

104
00:05:38,164 --> 00:05:42,464
it shows where we've got the 640-882 exam.

105
00:05:42,464 --> 00:05:46,928
That's the old exam, and
it expires September 30th, right?

106
00:05:46,928 --> 00:05:50,410
So that's like a month away.

107
00:05:50,410 --> 00:05:53,240
So you can still take that one today,
but it's going away.

108
00:05:54,260 --> 00:05:57,680
For everybody just starting out,

109
00:05:57,680 --> 00:06:02,760
it's now the 100-101 exam is the one
that you need to take to get certified.

110
00:06:02,760 --> 00:06:05,160
And so that's what the show
is going to be built around.

111
00:06:05,160 --> 00:06:07,300
We are going to be focusing
on that new stuff.

112
00:06:07,300 --> 00:06:11,610
What if, you were already
certified in the old stuff and

113
00:06:11,610 --> 00:06:13,050
you're just trying to learn the new stuff.

114
00:06:13,050 --> 00:06:16,800
Or what if you bought a bunch of books for
the old exam number.

115
00:06:16,800 --> 00:06:17,500
Are you out of luck?

116
00:06:17,500 --> 00:06:19,000
Do you need to throw them away?

117
00:06:19,000 --> 00:06:22,130
No right, there's really not
all that much that's changed.

118
00:06:22,130 --> 00:06:24,470
There's a bigger stress on IPv6,

119
00:06:24,470 --> 00:06:28,640
so we see a lot more IPv6 stuff
than what we saw previously.

120
00:06:28,640 --> 00:06:30,790
And they bumped the iOS version.

121
00:06:30,790 --> 00:06:34,162
So the operating system
running on our routers and

122
00:06:34,162 --> 00:06:38,909
switches on the old exam,
it was the 12.2 and 12.4 versions.

123
00:06:38,909 --> 00:06:46,372
On the new exam, it's the 15.0,
15.1, I think 15.2.

124
00:06:46,372 --> 00:06:49,892
They constantly release new ones.

125
00:06:49,892 --> 00:06:51,087
And millennium edition.

126
00:06:51,087 --> 00:06:51,854
>> Mm-hm.

127
00:06:51,854 --> 00:06:52,643
>> Oh, yeah!

128
00:06:52,643 --> 00:06:53,688
>> Cisco IOS millennium edition.

129
00:06:53,688 --> 00:06:54,465
The special one?

130
00:06:54,465 --> 00:06:59,492
>> [LAUGH] All right, so
that's enough of an intro all right.

131
00:06:59,492 --> 00:07:01,130
Think of anything else we
want to throw out there?

132
00:07:01,130 --> 00:07:03,311
>> No, just exam stuff.

133
00:07:03,311 --> 00:07:06,423
I mean,
the real good stuff that was coming.

134
00:07:06,423 --> 00:07:08,260
>> All right.

135
00:07:08,260 --> 00:07:09,900
So let's jump into the goods.

136
00:07:09,900 --> 00:07:12,380
Let's get right in there and
tackle some of this.

137
00:07:12,380 --> 00:07:16,440
So we're gonna start out
with our first objective.

138
00:07:16,440 --> 00:07:19,690
And basically we've got just the Cisco
exam objectives, and we make sure that we

139
00:07:19,690 --> 00:07:23,270
cover every single aspect of that so
that you're prepared for the exam.

140
00:07:23,270 --> 00:07:28,170
And the objectives start out with a nice
big general section which is Operation of

141
00:07:28,170 --> 00:07:32,860
IP Data Networks, or what I like to call,
summarizing Network+.

142
00:07:32,860 --> 00:07:34,554
That's basically what it is, so.

143
00:07:34,554 --> 00:07:39,195
>> Yeah, and you know Don,
looking through the objectives and

144
00:07:39,195 --> 00:07:44,200
whatnot preparing for this,
it really does just take everything

145
00:07:44,200 --> 00:07:49,478
from network+ stuff and just crams
it all into this first section and

146
00:07:49,478 --> 00:07:54,665
there's still a lot, so if- I would
say if some of these concepts or

147
00:07:54,665 --> 00:07:58,032
things are new, or not terribly familiar,

148
00:07:58,032 --> 00:08:03,690
then it would be beneficial then to
get a little bit more in depth, right?

149
00:08:04,930 --> 00:08:05,650
>> Absolutely.

150
00:08:05,650 --> 00:08:06,665
And that's the cool thing about.

151
00:08:06,665 --> 00:08:11,285
By ITProTV is that, if any of this
stuff is completely new to you,

152
00:08:11,285 --> 00:08:13,585
we're covering it here with an assumption
that you got that basic knowledge,

153
00:08:13,585 --> 00:08:15,175
cause that's what Cisco assumes you have.

154
00:08:15,175 --> 00:08:17,115
And if you don't have that
basic knowledge, well,

155
00:08:17,115 --> 00:08:19,125
just jump right over to
the Network Plus show.

156
00:08:19,125 --> 00:08:20,800
It's part of your subscription.

157
00:08:20,800 --> 00:08:24,330
And you can go in there and watch that,
and get caught up, or get more in depth.

158
00:08:24,330 --> 00:08:26,012
So, things that we're
going to talk about today,

159
00:08:26,012 --> 00:08:28,280
actually I don't know if we'll
get to it in today's show.

160
00:08:28,280 --> 00:08:30,572
But, like the OSI model, right?

161
00:08:30,572 --> 00:08:32,710
We're gonna talk about it in brief, but

162
00:08:32,710 --> 00:08:35,490
we go into that it in depth
in the network plus show.

163
00:08:35,490 --> 00:08:37,955
So, definitely, take advantage
of that if you haven't already.

164
00:08:37,955 --> 00:08:40,900
Network plus is a great certification.

165
00:08:40,900 --> 00:08:44,410
It doesn't have the resume
visibility that a CCNA does, right?

166
00:08:44,410 --> 00:08:48,330
People really like to see that on
a resume, but it is still good to have.

167
00:08:48,330 --> 00:08:49,848
>> Yeah, I would agree.

168
00:08:49,848 --> 00:08:50,861
>> All right.

169
00:08:50,861 --> 00:08:52,600
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now,

170
00:08:52,600 --> 00:08:53,845
that we have Nate's blessing on that.

171
00:08:53,845 --> 00:08:54,840
>> [LAUGH] So.

172
00:08:54,840 --> 00:08:57,600
>> All right, lets go ahead and
jump into some stuff, right?

173
00:08:57,600 --> 00:09:00,580
So, the very first topic
that we're gonna hit on,

174
00:09:00,580 --> 00:09:05,200
is just understanding what network devices
we're gonna be dealing with, right?

175
00:09:05,200 --> 00:09:09,190
So, we're talking about routers,
switches, bridges and hubs.

176
00:09:09,190 --> 00:09:11,880
So those are the four devices
that we need to be aware of

177
00:09:11,880 --> 00:09:14,110
to make it through this show, right?

178
00:09:14,110 --> 00:09:17,430
So, let's just start out with hubs and
kind of go from there, right?

179
00:09:17,430 --> 00:09:18,810
Do you wanna tackle that?

180
00:09:18,810 --> 00:09:19,890
>> Yeah.

181
00:09:19,890 --> 00:09:22,865
So hubs, they're pretty simple devices.

182
00:09:22,865 --> 00:09:25,455
This is in the way that they do things.

183
00:09:25,455 --> 00:09:30,425
Ports or computers plug into it and
when traffic travels

184
00:09:30,425 --> 00:09:35,035
from one computer into another,
the hub will take that traffic and

185
00:09:35,035 --> 00:09:38,405
flood it out all the other
ports to all the computers.

186
00:09:38,405 --> 00:09:40,305
And so everybody hears the traffic,

187
00:09:40,305 --> 00:09:45,290
the computers that the traffic wasn't
mean to, they'll just drop it.

188
00:09:45,290 --> 00:09:48,210
And the other computer will get it.

189
00:09:48,210 --> 00:09:51,240
And if you have multiple
hubs than that traffic, and

190
00:09:51,240 --> 00:09:53,770
that flood will start going to everyone.

191
00:09:55,470 --> 00:09:58,310
>> And
the purpose of a hub is really to be that

192
00:09:58,310 --> 00:10:00,890
first building block of a network, right?

193
00:10:00,890 --> 00:10:03,280
In the original networks,
the networks back in the 70s.

194
00:10:03,280 --> 00:10:07,230
You would have two computers which
were the size of a house, and

195
00:10:07,230 --> 00:10:10,740
you'd run a network cable from
one to the other and that was it.

196
00:10:10,740 --> 00:10:15,360
It just connected two systems, but as the
functions and network started to grow we

197
00:10:15,360 --> 00:10:19,310
needed more than two computers and
I say we, I was in diapers.

198
00:10:19,310 --> 00:10:25,360
But a so in the 80s, we really started
to see the proliferation of hubs.

199
00:10:25,360 --> 00:10:29,200
And it functions exactly like Nate
described, let me do a little picture

200
00:10:29,200 --> 00:10:34,780
because I'm a visual person myself-
>> I like your pictures.

201
00:10:34,780 --> 00:10:41,450
>> I'm the Bob Ross of network diagrams,
[INAUDIBLE] happy tree, so basically

202
00:10:41,450 --> 00:10:44,970
if we take a look at a hub it's a box,
and it'll have a series of ports on it.

203
00:10:44,970 --> 00:10:48,690
Now, the smallest hub I've
ever seen had four ports.

204
00:10:48,690 --> 00:10:52,220
If you go to the store,
most of them seem to have five ports, but

205
00:10:52,220 --> 00:10:53,600
you can get big ones.

206
00:10:53,600 --> 00:10:56,130
You can get 24 port ones, and 48 port.

207
00:10:56,130 --> 00:10:59,250
I think the biggest hub
I've seen is 48 ports, but

208
00:10:59,250 --> 00:11:02,100
basically it just has
a bunch of ports on it.

209
00:11:02,100 --> 00:11:07,780
And you take your PCs, and
you plug your PCs into that device, right?

210
00:11:07,780 --> 00:11:11,030
So each PC would have a cable, and

211
00:11:11,030 --> 00:11:15,290
that would plug it into a port on the hub,
right?

212
00:11:15,290 --> 00:11:19,350
On a hub, it doesn't really matter what
port you plug into, they're all the same.

213
00:11:19,350 --> 00:11:21,330
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

214
00:11:21,330 --> 00:11:26,886
basically when one computer wants to talk
another if PC1 wants to talk to PC4.

215
00:11:26,886 --> 00:11:31,820
Well, it sends its communication up to
the hub, and the hub just blasts it out

216
00:11:33,240 --> 00:11:38,400
to everybody, and so that communication
makes it over there to PC4 gets it.

217
00:11:38,400 --> 00:11:39,900
And off we go, right?

218
00:11:39,900 --> 00:11:44,090
So, the hub facilitates allowing multiple
people to communicate together, right?

219
00:11:44,090 --> 00:11:47,170
Here's four computers that can now
all talk to each other just fine.

220
00:11:48,380 --> 00:11:51,530
All right, so that's a hub.

221
00:11:52,720 --> 00:11:56,100
The next thing is a bridge, all right?

222
00:11:56,100 --> 00:11:58,800
It's Cisco specific, a bridge.

223
00:11:58,800 --> 00:12:04,180
Now, the first thing that I guess I need
to mention is when we talk about hubs and

224
00:12:04,180 --> 00:12:07,360
bridges, these are two devices that
Cisco calls out specifically, but

225
00:12:07,360 --> 00:12:09,290
you're not really gonna see in real life.

226

Ad on a five port hub that's not a big

235
00:12:35,275 --> 00:12:39,445

00:12:39,445 --> 00:12:42,300

00:12:45,460 --> 00:12:48,680

00:12:52,790 --> 00:12:55,250

243
00:12:58,030 --> 00:13:01,350

244
00:13:01,350 --> 00:13:04,450
And that made things
a lot more efficient and

00:13:04,450 --> 00:13:07,490

00:13:07,490 --> 00:13:10,680

00:35:43,960 --> 00:35:48,040

00:35:49,060 --> 00:35:54,990

we don't even see the down time so

can run without failure.

can we keep running?

Plugged into multiple switches.

00:42:24,100 --> 00:42:29,380
And the OSI model is
the Open System Interconnect model.

00:42:29,380 --> 00:42:33,640
And it is a framework that defines
how network communications function.

00:42:33,640 --> 00:42:36,460
So you can see why it's important
in a class like this where

00:42:36,460 --> 00:42:40,070
all we talk about

00:42:40,070 --> 00:42:44,670
Versus the RC car show that

822
00:42:44,670 --> 00:42:46,890
So anyhow the OSI model's important.

823
00:42:46,890 --> 00:42:51,070
Every single network communication
that we do, runs through this model,

824
00:42:51,070 --> 00:42:52,830
through this framework.

825
00:42:52,830 --> 00:42:54,210
And so, it is important.

826
00:42:54,210 --> 00:42:55,590
It does get used all the time.

00:42:55,590 --> 00:42:56,870
And it is on the exam.

00:42:56,870 --> 00:42:59,070
So, it's definitely something

00:43:00,620 --> 00:43:01,590

00:43:14,590 --> 00:43:18,105
Now, the OSI model,
I said is the open system interconnect,

00:43:18,105 --> 00:43:22,920
that open part means that this is an open

00:43:22,920 --> 00:43:29,450
So if you're a Mac, a Linux box,

00:43:29,450 --> 00:43:34,749
>> If you used TCP/IP, or Apple Talk,

00:43:34,749 --> 00:43:38,653
So regardless of what protocols or

00:43:38,653 --> 00:43:44,051
you are using the OSI model any time that

842
00:43:44,051 --> 00:43:46,810
a network built in the last 20 years.

00:43:49,160 --> 00:43:51,180
All right so, the OSI model, what it does,

00:43:51,180 --> 00:43:54,420
is it divides our communications
up into multiple pieces.

00:43:54,420 --> 00:43:57,550
And we see it here represented as layers.

00:43:57,550 --> 00:44:00,866
It's a seven layer model.

00:44:00,866 --> 00:44:04,510
And let me start with
the real generalities,

848
00:44:04,510 --> 00:44:05,970
because it does get confusing.

849
00:44:05,970 --> 00:44:09,750
So, there's layers, and
it starts from the bottom up.

850
00:44:09,750 --> 00:44:12,070
And the example they always
use in the textbooks and

851
00:44:12,070 --> 00:44:13,960
stuff is that it's like a cake.

852
00:44:13,960 --> 00:44:16,160
When you make a cake,
you don't start with the top.

853
00:44:16,160 --> 00:44:18,190
You got to start with the bottom right.

854
00:44:18,190 --> 00:44:20,210
So you make that first layer of the cake.

855
00:44:20,210 --> 00:44:23,138
And then you add the next one and
the next one and the next one.

856
00:44:23,138 --> 00:44:26,820
Or you can think of it as like the floors
of a building or whatever, right.

857
00:44:26,820 --> 00:44:28,390
We start at the bottom.

858
00:44:28,390 --> 00:44:31,350
And each layer represents

00:44:31,350 --> 00:44:35,350
a particular function required in
communicating on a network, right?

00:44:35,350 --> 00:44:39,180
Now, as human beings,
we don't see a lot of this stuff,

00:44:39,180 --> 00:44:41,450
it's all hidden from us in the background.

00:44:41,450 --> 00:44:45,170
We interact way up here at layer 7.

00:44:45,170 --> 00:44:47,700
Layer 7 is the Application layer.

And those are the programs and

00:44:49,680 --> 00:44:53,530
the interface that we use as human
beings to communicate with the network.

So for us, that's really all we see, and

00:44:58,330 --> 00:45:01,890
All the rest of it is really completely

So if my web browser, right?

and as a human being,

The Internet, with the World Wide Web.

00:47:52,630 --> 00:47:59,470
Now when I press enter, then we move

931
00:47:59,470 --> 00:48:04,510
The presentation layer is what
translates things from stuff,

932

that makes sense to the computer.

So when you look at a web page,

936
00:48:15,640 --> 00:48:18,370
>> [LAUGH]
>> You go to itpro.tv.

937
00:48:18,370 --> 00:48:22,480
>> When you go to our website, you see
images, and menus, and all that stuff.

938
00:48:22,480 --> 00:48:26,420
But on the back end,
it's all HTML and PHP.

939
00:48:26,420 --> 00:48:30,590
So HTML is the HyperText Markup Language,
and that's the way that,

940
00:48:30,590 --> 00:48:31,870
that page is written.

941
00:48:31,870 --> 00:48:35,980
If you were to look straight at the HTML,
it doesn't make a lot of sense,

942
00:48:35,980 --> 00:48:36,970
it's a mess.

00:48:36,970 --> 00:48:39,770
But then the computer renders it
into a way that's pretty for us, and

944
00:48:39,770 --> 00:48:42,270
that's what the presentation layer does.

945
00:48:42,270 --> 00:48:45,620
In reverse, it takes what's pretty to us,

946
00:48:45,620 --> 00:48:50,450
like me typing www.google.com
in the address bar, and

947
00:48:50,450 --> 00:48:54,200
it turns that into something,
that makes sense for the computer.

948
00:48:54,200 --> 00:48:59,140
And the computer, when you dealing with
a web browser, it is expecting what's

949
00:48:59,140 --> 00:49:04,245

950
00:49:04,245 --> 00:49:08,720

00:49:08,720 --> 00:49:12,660
that's us saying, hey,

00:49:12,660 --> 00:49:17,170
We build a Hyper Text Transport
Protocol Get Request.

00:49:17,170 --> 00:49:21,940
And you have gets, and puts, and sends,
and all sorts of various HTTP commands,

954
00:49:21,940 --> 00:49:25,420
but when you ask for a web page,
you're using a Get Request.

955
00:49:25,420 --> 00:49:29,470
So that's what's happening
at the presentation layer.

956
00:49:29,470 --> 00:49:33,870

When our data makes it

what we're communicating with?

963
00:49:53,580 --> 00:49:55,510
And the session layer's,
what's responsible here.

964
00:49:55,510 --> 00:49:57,610
It steps in, and it gets involved.

965
00:49:57,610 --> 00:50:02,010
And when we're talking about web requests,

966

we're normally talking about HTTP, or
it could be HTTPS, if it's secure.

So if I'm browsing to a non secure

server, and that might be, who knows.

EnGenX.

the other side is going to know what our

As we keep going down,

Now when you communicate on the network,
there is a limit to the size of the data

So at about 1500 bytes, that's the,

00:52:46,840 --> 00:52:50,420
So, at the transport layer,

So we have to have some kind of Transport

And with a normal Internet communication,
that protocol.

Transmission Control Protocol,

just remember the font size.

00:53:33,580 --> 00:53:37,960
It is TCP, it's what's handling,
that making sure that traffic is broken up

1030
00:53:37,960 --> 00:53:43,280
to be able to reach out there, and
be received on the other side intact.

>> All right, next, now we need to

on a different network somewhere else?

1036
00:54:01,265 --> 00:54:03,815
If I'm talking to a computer
right here on the studio,

1037
00:54:03,815 --> 00:54:05,435
they're on the same network as me.

1038
00:54:05,435 --> 00:54:07,085
That's cool.
I can talk right to them.

1039
00:54:07,085 --> 00:54:09,525
But if I'm talking to Google,
they're out there on the Internet.

1040
00:54:10,555 --> 00:54:14,545
I may have to pass through a number of
routers, to get out there to Google.

1041
00:54:14,545 --> 00:54:18,565
And if that's the case,
I need to go through a router or whatever.

1042
00:54:18,565 --> 00:54:20,365
So I need something that
helps me to determine that,

1043
00:54:20,365 --> 00:54:23,910
to know whether somebody's on
the same network as me, and

1044
00:54:23,910 --> 00:54:27,730
with a normal Internet communication,
that protocol is IP.

1045
00:54:29,170 --> 00:54:33,700
Now, a lot of people, well,
we normally refer to this as TCP/IP,

1046
00:54:33,700 --> 00:54:36,880
and it's written TCP/IP.

1047
00:54:36,880 --> 00:54:39,740
But it is two separate protocols.

1048
00:54:39,740 --> 00:54:43,770
TCP handles the transport part,
and IP handles the network part.

1049
00:54:43,770 --> 00:54:47,950

that's where our routers would sit.

1050
00:54:47,950 --> 00:54:48,530
>> Absolutely.

1051
00:54:48,530 --> 00:54:51,700
>> So routers are a layer three device.

1052
00:54:51,700 --> 00:54:52,300
>> Yes.

And you'll hear us, reference things

where every device, every router,

1055

switch, firewall, bridge, whatever, they
perform functions, that certain layers.

1056
00:55:06,180 --> 00:55:10,650
And routers are all about moving traffic,
from one network to another.

1057
00:55:10,650 --> 00:55:13,150
And at layer three,
the IP address is how we know,

1058
00:55:13,150 --> 00:55:15,070
whether somebody's on
a different network or not.

1059
00:55:15,070 --> 00:55:16,580
And how we know,
if we need to go through routers, so

1060
00:55:16,580 --> 00:55:18,180
it is a layer three device, yep.

00:55:58,550 --> 00:56:01,400
And when we go to talk on the network,
there's this whole

00:56:01,400 --> 00:56:05,630
process that happens where we find the

depth later, but basically any
time we communicate on the network

1084
00:56:14,390 --> 00:56:18,120
we use what's called a media

1085
00:56:18,120 --> 00:56:19,740
Or a MAC Address.

1086

It's an address that's burned
into your network hardware.

1087
00:56:22,340 --> 00:56:24,510
It's burned into your network card or
wireless card or whatever.

1088
00:56:25,740 --> 00:56:27,830
You're not supposed to
be able to change it.

1089
00:56:27,830 --> 00:56:30,650
There are ways but
it's supposed to be hard set.

1090
00:56:30,650 --> 00:56:33,200
And it's what you actually use
when you start to communicate.

1091
00:56:33,200 --> 00:56:37,980
So down here at layer two, that's where we
have that extra address part kicking in.

1092
00:56:37,980 --> 00:56:42,100
And so
we have things like our Mac addresses, our

1093
00:56:42,100 --> 00:56:47,030
media access control as well as something

00:56:52,360 --> 00:56:55,770
>> Yup, and so it switches,
it switches around here.

1097
00:56:55,770 --> 00:56:56,390
>> Switches do.

00:56:56,390 --> 00:57:01,590
So switches work with Mac addresses
a lot and remember when I say Mac,

1099
00:57:01,590 --> 00:57:04,800
I'm not talking Macintosh,
I'm talking about media access control.

1100
00:57:04,800 --> 00:57:09,240
And switches really deal with this and so
they are considered layer two devices.

1101
00:57:09,240 --> 00:57:12,200
And that brings us to our last one, and

1102

00:57:16,690 --> 00:57:23,740
So if we've got a 100
megabit copper cable network.

your electrical impulses that you send or

00:57:32,740 --> 00:57:35,340
if it's a wireless network

1107
00:57:35,340 --> 00:57:38,290
So it just depends on
what your network is.

1108
00:57:38,290 --> 00:57:45,380
It might be fiber, might be copper,
might be wireless,

1109
00:57:45,380 --> 00:57:50,810
or who knows whatever other technologies

1110
00:57:51,830 --> 00:57:57,500

00:57:57,500 --> 00:58:00,457
However, you're plugged in.

00:58:00,457 --> 00:58:01,030
Nice.

00:58:01,030 --> 00:58:04,840

an important function.

And the really cool part about this is,
if you decide that you wanna write

Super easy to get up and

1362

So when you had referenced
one of these right, so

1363
01:11:42,931 --> 01:11:46,772
on the command line stuff,
then you've got 0/0/0, so

1364
01:11:46,772 --> 01:11:51,766
you've got your module, your slot, and
your port, to then you can address.

1365
01:11:51,766 --> 01:11:53,427
Each one of these guys.

1366
01:11:53,427 --> 01:11:54,235
>> Yeah, absolutely and

1367
01:11:54,235 --> 01:11:56,411
we're gonna see that more when
we get into the command line.

1368
01:11:56,411 --> 01:11:59,060
It gets really confusing really fast.

1369
01:11:59,060 --> 01:12:01,370
So as you look at the switch,

1370
01:12:01,370 --> 01:12:05,050
some of these ports actually have written
on them what the name of the port is.

1371
01:12:05,050 --> 01:12:10,650
So, you'll see this one is GE0/1 and
this one is GE0/0.

1372
01:12:10,650 --> 01:12:13,523
That's letting us know the 0, the first 0,

1373
01:12:13,523 --> 01:12:17,149
is letting us know that it's
a port built into the system.

1374
01:12:17,149 --> 01:12:24,616
And then the /0 or /1, lets us know that 0
is the first port, 1 is the second port.

1375
01:12:24,616 --> 01:12:28,774
So, I have 0/0 is the first built in port.

1376
01:12:28,774 --> 01:12:32,634
And 0/1 is the second built in port.

1377
01:12:32,634 --> 01:12:36,540
But, then you start getting into these
modular cards, and it gets really

1378
01:12:36,540 --> 01:12:40,583
confusing really fast, because then
you'll usually have three numbers.

1379
01:12:40,583 --> 01:12:44,840
One number that identifies,
whether it's built in or not.

1380
01:12:44,840 --> 01:12:47,587
A second number that
identifies the module, and

1381
01:12:47,587 --> 01:12:49,939
a third number that identifies the port.

1382
01:12:49,939 --> 01:12:55,850
And so you may have a port that
is 0/0/5 or something like that.

1383
01:12:55,850 --> 01:12:59,530
So, we don't really worry about
that on the physical side of

1384
01:12:59,530 --> 01:13:00,190
installing the device.

1385
01:13:00,190 --> 01:13:02,130
But, once we get into the command line and
start configuring,

1386
01:13:02,130 --> 01:13:03,100
we'll have to pay attention to that.

1387
01:13:03,100 --> 01:13:06,390
So, we'll revisit that
when we get into it.

1388
01:13:06,390 --> 01:13:09,060
But it is challenging and
I have some little tricks,

1389
01:13:09,060 --> 01:13:12,350
I use to remember it and
be able to figure it out.

1390
01:13:12,350 --> 01:13:16,310
It doesn't help that it's different
on every device you go to it seems.

1391
01:13:16,310 --> 01:13:19,670
>> Yeah,
I just wanna throw that out to try to.

1392
01:13:19,670 --> 01:13:22,151
>> Impress with the knowledge.

1393
01:13:22,151 --> 01:13:23,940
>> [LAUGH] And it is important.

1394
01:13:23,940 --> 01:13:26,240
You'll see that when we actually
get to the command line,

1395
01:13:26,240 --> 01:13:27,110
that you've gotta know that.

1396
01:13:27,110 --> 01:13:29,330
So we'll definitely see that.

1397
01:13:29,330 --> 01:13:32,530
All right, so when we buy a Cisco switch,

1398
01:13:32,530 --> 01:13:37,360
it's important that we buy it spec'd the
way we need it from the factory, right?

1399
01:13:37,360 --> 01:13:40,170
On a router we have flexibility cuz
we can go out, and buy these cards,

1400
01:13:40,170 --> 01:13:42,780
throw them in and so on, right?

1401
01:13:42,780 --> 01:13:46,827
Let's go back to the switch, and I wanna
show you guys some of the stuff there.

1402
01:13:53,127 --> 01:13:58,648
Now there is a little bit of flexibility
here on the switch with these SFP ports.

1403
01:13:58,648 --> 01:14:01,790
SFP stands for Small Form Factor port.

1404
01:14:01,790 --> 01:14:07,330
Most Cisco switches either
have SFP ports GBic slots.

1405
01:14:07,330 --> 01:14:10,350
So, SFP is small form factor port.

1406
01:14:10,350 --> 01:14:15,640
GBIC is gigabit interface card,
or interface connector.

1407
01:14:15,640 --> 01:14:16,900
I've heard both.

1408
01:14:16,900 --> 01:14:18,770
But, here's some examples.

1409
01:14:20,010 --> 01:14:25,380
This right here is a SFP module,
and you can buy an SFP module and

1410
01:14:25,380 --> 01:14:30,520
it's either going to have a fiber
optic connector like this one does.

1411
01:14:30,520 --> 01:14:33,810
Or you can get ones that they
swell up at the end, and

1412
01:14:33,810 --> 01:14:39,280
it's got a RJ-45 connector for
a normal network cable, right?

1413
01:14:39,280 --> 01:14:41,830
So, if I had a copper
network versus a fiber one.

1414
01:14:41,830 --> 01:14:46,220
So basically you buy the one you need,
either fiber or copper.

1415
01:14:46,220 --> 01:14:48,570
And you pop it in there and
now you got a functional port.

1416
01:14:48,570 --> 01:14:51,820
The port does not work
without an SFP in it.

1417
01:14:51,820 --> 01:14:56,410
So these other three ports here,
they don't work until I put an SFP in.

1418
01:14:56,410 --> 01:14:57,260
Once I've got an SFP,

1419
01:14:57,260 --> 01:15:02,300
I can take a fiber optic cable
like this one, I can plug it in.

1420
01:15:02,300 --> 01:15:04,790
And now I've got a fiber optic connection,
and

1421
01:15:04,790 --> 01:15:07,420
this is a gigabit port here on the switch.

1422
01:15:07,420 --> 01:15:12,292
So, I can run this fiber up to
another floor in the building or

1423
01:15:12,292 --> 01:15:15,509
up linking switches right next to each
other, or whatever it is that I need.

1424
01:15:16,560 --> 01:15:18,642
>> Based on the needs of your network.

1425
01:15:18,642 --> 01:15:19,440
>> Exactly.
>> [LAUGH]

1426
01:15:19,440 --> 01:15:21,780
>> Which is what Cisco wants us to know.

1427
01:15:21,780 --> 01:15:26,270
So, the cool part about fiber is
your cables can have different ends.

1428
01:15:26,270 --> 01:15:31,190
So this one, it has the,
what is it, the LC connector?

1429
01:15:32,670 --> 01:15:33,380
Yes, LC.

1430
01:15:33,380 --> 01:15:35,210
LC on that end.

1431
01:15:35,210 --> 01:15:39,010
And on this end,
I've got the SC connector.

1432
01:15:39,010 --> 01:15:42,710
So, we've got a different
connector on this side.

1433
01:15:42,710 --> 01:15:45,580
And that's useful because you'll see
a lot of equipment that still uses this

1434
01:15:45,580 --> 01:15:46,320
connector.

1435
01:15:46,320 --> 01:15:48,961
Even new equipment manufactured today.

1436
01:15:48,961 --> 01:15:52,820
If you use a GBIC,
if your switch has that larger connector.

1437
01:15:52,820 --> 01:15:53,680
What did I?

1438
01:15:53,680 --> 01:15:55,290
>> Right over there.

1439
01:15:55,290 --> 01:15:55,865
Over on the top.

1440
01:15:55,865 --> 01:15:57,330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right in front of me.

1441
01:15:57,330 --> 01:16:00,930
So here is that GBIC that i was
talking about, and if your switch uses

1442
01:16:00,930 --> 01:16:05,360
this is one of these, well it'll be
a wider slot that you pop it in.

1443
01:16:05,360 --> 01:16:09,480
And you'll notice this one has the fiber
connector that I've got in my hand,

1444
01:16:09,480 --> 01:16:13,980
I've got it upside down,
there we go, so we just pop that in.

1445
01:16:13,980 --> 01:16:17,790
And then I can run this to another switch
that had a g big slot, pop it in there,

1446
01:16:17,790 --> 01:16:19,760
and off we go.

1447
01:16:19,760 --> 01:16:22,440
Or maybe it's not another
switch that I'm running to.

1448
01:16:22,440 --> 01:16:22,990
Maybe.

1449
01:16:24,800 --> 01:16:28,460
I have some other device that's out
there that I need to connect to.

1450
01:16:28,460 --> 01:16:30,300
So, just keep in mind that while a switch.

1451
01:16:30,300 --> 01:16:31,810
We can't add ports to it.

1452
01:16:31,810 --> 01:16:36,230
We do normally have some flexible
ports down here at the end, and

1453
01:16:36,230 --> 01:16:39,720
they'll take either a small
form factor adapter this,

1454
01:16:39,720 --> 01:16:41,260
which what almost what
all the new ones do.

1455
01:16:42,320 --> 01:16:48,500
Or they'll take the larger gigabit ones.

1456
01:16:48,500 --> 01:16:52,240
With both of these, just keep in mind that
they usually come in two flavors, so for

1457
01:16:52,240 --> 01:16:52,849
example.

1458
01:16:55,030 --> 01:17:01,540
So the one I was holding in my hand a
moment ago, this guy right here is an SX.

1459
01:17:01,540 --> 01:17:06,160
Or a single mode module which means

1460
01:17:06,160 --> 01:17:09,570
the fiber cable coming out of this
can go up to 10 kilometers away.

1461
01:17:09,570 --> 01:17:14,449
The one over here, is an LX and it's multi
mode and that means it can only go like,

1462
01:17:15,740 --> 01:17:21,340
it's under a kilometer, it's something
like 700 meters or something like that.

1463
01:17:21,340 --> 01:17:25,970
The distances are affected, because the
lasers are actually a part of this module.

1464
01:17:25,970 --> 01:17:28,400
So when you buy, you just have to
buy the appropriate standard for

1465
01:17:28,400 --> 01:17:29,490
whatever you're doing.

1466
01:17:29,490 --> 01:17:34,440
This one is SX, so I've got 2SX, and 1LX.

1467
01:17:34,440 --> 01:17:37,660
So, you just get the appropriate one and
you're in business.

1468
01:17:37,660 --> 01:17:38,160
>> Nice.

1469
01:17:40,560 --> 01:17:41,140
We're good.

1470
01:17:41,140 --> 01:17:41,780
>> All right.

1471
01:17:41,780 --> 01:17:45,350
Yep.
The last thing I wanna mention is,

1472
01:17:45,350 --> 01:17:48,200
our internet connection here, we have a 40
megabit internet connection here, and

1473
01:17:48,200 --> 01:17:49,640
it's fiber optic.

1474
01:17:49,640 --> 01:17:54,180
A lot of cities are starting it,
fiber optic connections for consumers, for

1475
01:17:54,180 --> 01:17:55,880
business, we've always
been able to get it.

1476
01:17:55,880 --> 01:17:57,080
It's just really expensive.

1477
01:17:57,080 --> 01:18:00,450
But for home users,
you're starting to see Verizon's FiOS or

1478
01:18:00,450 --> 01:18:03,040
Google's Fiber to the household or
whatever they call it.

1479
01:18:03,040 --> 01:18:05,280
So, you're starting to
see a lot more of that.

1480
01:18:05,280 --> 01:18:07,290
When they run fiber into your house,

1481
01:18:07,290 --> 01:18:11,140
your home grade network equipment doesn't
typically have fiber optic ports, and

1482
01:18:11,140 --> 01:18:14,730
it's rare to find a router
that has fiber optic ports.

1483
01:18:14,730 --> 01:18:17,960
So, a lot of times you'll have
to implement another device.

1484
01:18:17,960 --> 01:18:23,100
One of these guys right here,
which is called a fiber transceiver,

1485
01:18:23,100 --> 01:18:27,360
I've heard some other names for it,
but basically it's a media converter.

1486
01:18:27,360 --> 01:18:32,120
And what it does is it allows
you to run fiber into it, and

1487
01:18:32,120 --> 01:18:34,070
then converts it over to ethernet.

1488
01:18:34,070 --> 01:18:37,630
So, I've got the fiber optic that
runs into my house, or whatever.

1489
01:18:37,630 --> 01:18:39,935
Not my house, unfortunately.

1490
01:18:39,935 --> 01:18:42,310
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, it runs into our building and

1491
01:18:42,310 --> 01:18:46,370
then after that, it just becomes
a standard network connection.

1492
01:18:46,370 --> 01:18:47,760
You throw that in there, and

1493
01:18:47,760 --> 01:18:53,250
now you can run it into your consumer
grade router or firewall, or whatever.

1494
01:18:53,250 --> 01:18:58,510
So, you may need additional hardware
like this if your equipment doesn't have

1495
01:18:58,510 --> 01:19:04,260
all the necessary ports.

1496
01:19:04,260 --> 01:19:05,410
>> Yep, so let's see.

1497
01:19:05,410 --> 01:19:07,794
Am I leaving anything out?

1498
01:19:07,794 --> 01:19:13,170
I think We covered
the additional modules for

1499
01:19:13,170 --> 01:19:17,700
routers, we covered the SFPs and G bits
for switches, and I even talked a little

1500
01:19:17,700 --> 01:19:20,090
bit about the higher end devices
that have the big line cards.

1501
01:19:21,900 --> 01:19:25,560
>> Yeah, maybe in the beginning
just to glaze over it.

1502
01:19:26,770 --> 01:19:28,800
>> All right, so
like we said at the beginning of the show,

1503
01:19:28,800 --> 01:19:31,450
this was designed to be
our high level overview.

1504
01:19:31,450 --> 01:19:34,700
We didn't really get nitty gritty
into any of the details on this one.

1505
01:19:34,700 --> 01:19:36,380
Just kind of high level stuff.

1506
01:19:36,380 --> 01:19:38,930
In our next episode,
we're going to start on switches, and

1507
01:19:38,930 --> 01:19:41,210
that's when we're gonna start
getting into the nitty gritty.

1508
01:19:41,210 --> 01:19:42,990
How they work,
how they make the decisions,

1509
01:19:42,990 --> 01:19:45,190
how they know what traffic
to send to what port?

1510
01:19:45,190 --> 01:19:49,460
We're also gonna start with the command
line, actually working with the devices.

1511
01:19:49,460 --> 01:19:52,370
A lot of Cisco devices today
come with a web interface, but

1512
01:19:52,370 --> 01:19:54,720
on the exam you gotta know
the command line interface.

1513
01:19:54,720 --> 01:19:57,190
So that's what we're gonna
see as we work with those and

1514
01:19:57,190 --> 01:20:01,500
kind of manipulate them, so
that's all on the horizon.

1515
01:20:01,500 --> 01:20:04,850
You think of anything else, we need to
throw in here before we wrap it up?

1516
01:20:06,200 --> 01:20:06,790
>> No.

1517
01:20:06,790 --> 01:20:08,620
I think we're all right.

1518
01:20:08,620 --> 01:20:12,170
I do have one question though
I've been thinking about.

1519
01:20:12,170 --> 01:20:14,300
I'll ask you before we end.

1520
01:20:14,300 --> 01:20:15,550
>> Off script, this never ends well.

1521
01:20:15,550 --> 01:20:19,600
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, let me just get your opinion.

1522
01:20:19,600 --> 01:20:21,788
>> Okay.
>> If Duke Nukem and

1523
01:20:21,788 --> 01:20:26,157
Blake Stone got in a fight, who would win?

1524
01:20:26,157 --> 01:20:27,335
>> That's not even a question.

1525
01:20:27,335 --> 01:20:29,122
So it's when Duke Nukem wins?

1526
01:20:29,122 --> 01:20:31,641
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is Blake Stone

1527
01:20:31,641 --> 01:20:33,952
still recognizable or not?

1528
01:20:33,952 --> 01:20:35,280
That's what the question should have been.

1529
01:20:35,280 --> 01:20:37,431
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's all I got.

1530
01:20:37,431 --> 01:20:38,735
>> All right.

1531
01:20:38,735 --> 01:20:41,127
So, let's tie that into Cisco somehow.

1532
01:20:41,127 --> 01:20:45,192
We used to do the Network Deathmatches
with Duke Nukem, and

1533
01:20:45,192 --> 01:20:50,010
very low bandwidth requirements but
you want it to be low latency too.

1534
01:20:50,010 --> 01:20:50,880
Very important.

1535
01:20:50,880 --> 01:20:52,310
So keep that in mind.

1536
01:20:54,260 --> 01:20:58,316
So, half our viewers are like Duke who?

1537
01:20:58,316 --> 01:20:59,079
>> Man.
>> All right.

1538
01:20:59,079 --> 01:21:01,850
Well, ladies and gentleman,
as always I hope you enjoyed the show.

1539
01:21:03,540 --> 01:21:06,001
Definitely stay tuned as we
continue on with the Cisco stuff.

1540
01:21:06,001 --> 01:21:08,160
I know today was a little lecturey, but

1541
01:21:08,160 --> 01:21:11,432
we're gonna get into the exciting
stuff the next episode,

1542
01:21:11,432 --> 01:21:15,438
as we start to actually configure
the things and see how stuff gets done.

1543
01:21:15,438 --> 01:21:19,024
>> Yeah.
And a good foundation for what's to come.

1544
01:21:19,024 --> 01:21:23,410
So now, as things come up, then we can
reference those kinds of things and.

1545
01:21:23,410 --> 01:21:24,250
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

1546
01:21:24,250 --> 01:21:28,190
>> And for those of you that need more
information, you wanna go more in depth.

1547
01:21:28,190 --> 01:21:31,330
Always keep in mind that you can jump over

1548
01:21:31,330 --> 01:21:34,800
We go a little more in depth onto
some of the more foundational ideas.

1549
01:21:34,800 --> 01:21:37,250
As well as for our premium subscribers.

1550
01:21:37,250 --> 01:21:40,740
You can always go into the Q&A, post
questions there, and we'll get back to you

1551
01:21:40,740 --> 01:21:43,880
with an answer in a pretty reasonable
amount of time, typically.

1552
01:21:43,880 --> 01:21:45,300
>> Yep.
>> Depending on the week.

1553
01:21:45,300 --> 01:21:46,420
So, all right.

1554
01:21:46,420 --> 01:21:48,046
So ladies and gentlemen, as always,
I hope you enjoyed the show.

1555
01:21:48,046 --> 01:21:49,168
I'm Don Pezet.

1556
01:21:49,168 --> 01:21:50,325
>> I am Nathan Copeland.

1557
01:21:50,325 --> 01:21:51,974

1558
01:21:51,974 --> 01:22:01,974

episodes.description: It is important for people who work with Cisco equipment to understand basic infrastructure components. Viewers will hear about the initial commands and things required to setup and connect to a Cisco router or switch including, proper cables, software, and the device itself, as well as hear about the basic command line interface usage.
episodes.title: Initial Device Configuration

00:23:27,080 --> 00:23:28,600
We're going to put it in the rack here.

And we're in this noisy, noisy closet so

00:23:33,350 --> 00:23:36,470
amount that I need to, and

487
00:23:42,110 --> 00:23:43,940
>> So once we got the cable hooked up,

488
00:23:43,940 --> 00:23:47,809
then we need some kind of software

489
00:23:47,809 --> 00:23:51,449
Cisco does not make software that displays
what's going on in with the equipment,

490
00:23:51,449 --> 00:23:52,443
which is kinda funny.

491
00:23:52,443 --> 00:23:55,531
But the reason they don't is that many,
many other people do, and

492
00:23:55,531 --> 00:23:57,919
they make software that is
better in a lot of cases.

493
00:23:57,919 --> 00:24:01,161
So they leave it up to you to use
whatever terminal software you want.

494
00:24:01,161 --> 00:24:03,054
And that's what it called,
terminal software.

495
00:24:03,054 --> 00:24:07,250
Terminal software, is software's that
able to communicate on a serial port.

496
00:24:07,250 --> 00:24:10,845
And for years and years, Cisco
recommended a program called Tera Term,

497
00:24:10,845 --> 00:24:14,685
which is no longer updated,
it was abandoned years ago.

498
00:24:14,685 --> 00:24:17,945
They used to recommend Hyper Term,
which was included in Windows 95 and

499
00:24:17,945 --> 00:24:21,785
98, when did they drop that,
Windows XP I think?

500
00:24:21,785 --> 00:24:24,645
>> Yup.
>> So that one hasn't been around for

501
00:24:24,645 --> 00:24:25,275
a while, you can go out and

502
00:24:25,275 --> 00:24:30,440
buy it if you want, but
the most popular one today is PuTTY.

503
00:24:30,440 --> 00:24:33,750
It's not open source,
right, but it is free.

504
00:24:33,750 --> 00:24:34,920
And so you can go and download it.

505
00:24:34,920 --> 00:24:37,630
And let me just show you here in my
computer the way I always find it.

506
00:24:37,630 --> 00:24:40,690
I always just jump straight
into to good old Google.

507
00:24:40,690 --> 00:24:43,170
And I do a search for PuTTY download.

508
00:24:44,550 --> 00:24:48,960
And putty is P U T T Y it's
actually a play on words.

509
00:24:48,960 --> 00:24:53,430
T T Y is the teletype protocol and
that's actually what's being

510
00:24:53,430 --> 00:24:57,700
used on this serial connection,
it's a virtual teletype or a VTY, and so

511
00:24:57,700 --> 00:25:01,290
when they called it putty, P U T T Y,
that's the joke they're trying to make.

512
00:25:01,290 --> 00:25:04,360
And that's why you'll see the weird
capitalization when they write it,

513
00:25:04,360 --> 00:25:08,730
the lowercase U and
then capital TTY for teletype.

514
00:25:08,730 --> 00:25:12,540
The author is actually based out of
England, and so that very first link that

515
00:25:12,540 --> 00:25:15,920
I got right there, might look weird,
but that is the original site.

516
00:25:15,920 --> 00:25:18,490
You'll see other ones like putty.org.

517
00:25:18,490 --> 00:25:22,360
That's actually not the official site,
and so it's a little misleading.

518
00:25:22,360 --> 00:25:24,380
I'll go to this one up here.

519
00:25:24,380 --> 00:25:27,710
Yeah, that page has remained the same for
years.

520
00:25:27,710 --> 00:25:30,430
Ever since I've seen it,
which is definitely at least ten years.

521
00:25:30,430 --> 00:25:33,490
Basically you can go in here and
you can find PuTTY.

00:25:33,490 --> 00:25:37,250
If you are running Windows,
then they actually have an installer

00:25:37,250 --> 00:25:41,230

00:25:43,250 --> 00:25:47,270

you can get other terminal
software out there.

00:26:00,570 --> 00:26:01,330
There's plenty of them.

534
00:26:01,330 --> 00:26:03,450
Just anything that can
communicate over a serial port.

535

>> Yeah.
And the nice thing about PuTTY,

you don't even have to install it, right?

537
00:26:06,910 --> 00:26:09,750
You can actually download just that exe,

538
00:26:09,750 --> 00:26:10,960
Yeah.
>> So if you don't want to install it,

539
00:26:10,960 --> 00:26:11,750
you don't have to.

540

You just simply run it and
then it disappears.

541

>> But I usually install it, and
the reason is, we can use it as a serial

542
00:26:17,850 --> 00:26:21,470
communications program, which you only
need on day one for a Cisco device.

543

But after that,

>> Yeah.

545
00:26:24,570 --> 00:26:26,430
So you can use it for
your remote connections,

546
00:26:26,430 --> 00:26:27,900
and SSH is the key part, right?

>> You want a secure client.

Again, if you're running Linux,

00:26:31,990 --> 00:26:33,250

>> But in Windows,

this is a really nice GUI

>> Yep, now when you install PuTTY and

00:26:46,420 --> 00:26:48,390
fire it up the first time, so

When we fire up PuTTY,
we get a basic configuration screen, and

00:26:53,330 --> 00:26:57,660
if you missed it there, just after I

00:26:57,660 --> 00:26:59,660

00:26:59,660 --> 00:27:01,000
and when we run PuTTY,

00:27:01,000 --> 00:27:05,560

00:27:05,560 --> 00:27:11,070
By default, it goes to SSH, and

00:27:11,070 --> 00:27:12,300
All right.

566
00:27:12,300 --> 00:27:15,850
But, I'm connecting to my Cisco
router via console port, so

00:27:15,850 --> 00:27:19,140
I need to do a serial communication.

568
00:27:19,140 --> 00:27:21,300
And when you do that,
the speed is going to change,

569
00:27:21,300 --> 00:27:25,590
and it's going to list a com
port instead of an IP address.

570
00:27:25,590 --> 00:27:28,830
>> On that com port, it's important,
especially if you're doing this in Window,

571
00:27:28,830 --> 00:27:32,500
to make sure you know what
port they have now addressed,

572
00:27:32,500 --> 00:27:34,150
especially if you're using a converter.

573
00:27:34,150 --> 00:27:36,000
Okay.
So if you use a converter like we

574
00:27:36,000 --> 00:27:39,720
did here, you need to make sure that

00:27:39,720 --> 00:27:41,040
And the easiest way to find that number?

00:27:41,040 --> 00:27:41,920
>> Device manager.

577
00:27:41,920 --> 00:27:43,410
>> Device manager,
yeah that's where I'd go.

00:27:43,410 --> 00:27:45,160
>> Wasn't sure if you
would know an easier way.

579
00:27:45,160 --> 00:27:48,140
>> No, I don't have an easier way,

580
00:27:48,140 --> 00:27:51,640
So easily go under device manager,
look under the COM Ports or

581
00:27:51,640 --> 00:27:54,290
Ports, and
then whatever number that they list there,

00:27:54,290 --> 00:27:56,556
hopefully that's gonna be the one

it'll always be Com 1 or Com 2, but

585
00:28:01,810 --> 00:28:05,800
if you're using a USB adapter it changes
all the time, it's super annoying.

586
00:28:05,800 --> 00:28:11,105
So we can go into our device manager and
let me just get in there.

587
00:28:11,105 --> 00:28:14,165
And in the device manager,
you'll see ports.

588
00:28:14,165 --> 00:28:15,365
And you can expand that out.

00:28:15,365 --> 00:28:17,915
And I can see that mine

00:28:17,915 --> 00:28:18,875

00:28:18,875 --> 00:28:22,562
when I want to connect to my CISCO device,

00:28:22,562 --> 00:28:27,382

593
00:28:27,382 --> 00:28:29,542
Now, couple other things to remember.

594
00:28:29,542 --> 00:28:31,542
The author of PuTTY,

595
00:28:31,542 --> 00:28:34,822
he knows that most people are using
this to connect to Cisco equipment.

596
00:28:34,822 --> 00:28:37,632
So he's actually set it to
use all the Cisco defaults.

597
00:28:37,632 --> 00:28:39,082
So it's really ready to go.

598
00:28:39,082 --> 00:28:43,862
But if you use your own
third-party terminal software, or

599
00:28:43,862 --> 00:28:48,210
whatever, there's actually a few other
settings you might need to adjust.

600
00:28:48,210 --> 00:28:51,340
And let me just kind of
throw those over here.

601
00:28:51,340 --> 00:28:54,891
So, the first one is the com port.

602
00:29:00,670 --> 00:29:02,600
And you just set that for
whatever it is on your system.

603
00:29:02,600 --> 00:29:04,420
Whatever it is that your com port is.

604
00:29:04,420 --> 00:29:05,380
Right?

605
00:29:05,380 --> 00:29:07,070
Then there's the speed.

606
00:29:07,070 --> 00:29:08,820
That needs to be 9600bp.

607
00:29:08,820 --> 00:29:13,000
ninety-six hundred bits per second, or
Baud is what it's called in some software.

608
00:29:13,000 --> 00:29:16,580
But it needs to be 9,600, that's what
Cisco devices are set to by default.

609
00:29:16,580 --> 00:29:18,000
>> And then we need Bits.

610
00:29:18,000 --> 00:29:19,180
Is that next?

611
00:29:19,180 --> 00:29:22,230
>> Next, we have three other
values that we always do together.

612
00:29:22,230 --> 00:29:23,900
So I'm just going to pull
them up here on the screen.

613
00:29:23,900 --> 00:29:26,870
I just went down to the serial
option over here on the left.

614
00:29:26,870 --> 00:29:29,490
And you'll see the other
three options we need to set.

615
00:29:29,490 --> 00:29:36,650
We've got Data Bits, and
then we've got the Stop Bits -1,

616
00:29:36,650 --> 00:29:41,980
and we've got Parity right there.

617
00:29:41,980 --> 00:29:46,410
Now, the order of these three can be
listed differently in different software.

618
00:29:46,410 --> 00:29:49,096
A lot of people call this 9600bps 8-N-1.

619
00:29:49,096 --> 00:29:54,710
And 8-N-1, they mean 8 data
bits No parity, one stop bit.

620
00:29:54,710 --> 00:29:57,110
So, look for those options in your system.

621
00:29:57,110 --> 00:30:01,800
And what that's basically saying is,
we need to send eight bits at a time.

622
00:30:01,800 --> 00:30:05,620
And then every eight bits,
we need to send one stop bit.

623
00:30:05,620 --> 00:30:07,310
And then the next eight bits and
a stop bit.

624
00:30:07,310 --> 00:30:08,610
And the next eight and a stop bit.

625
00:30:08,610 --> 00:30:09,510
And so on.

626
00:30:09,510 --> 00:30:12,390
And then there is no error
correction going on, no parity,

627
00:30:12,390 --> 00:30:14,620
its just disabled on
Cisco devices by default.

628
00:30:14,620 --> 00:30:16,900
So, these are the default settings,

629
00:30:16,900 --> 00:30:20,350
if you use other terminal software
you have to set it yourself.

630
00:30:20,350 --> 00:30:22,206
With PuTTY it's already there and
configured.

631
00:30:22,206 --> 00:30:24,890
>> So this is the most common for us, so

632
00:30:24,890 --> 00:30:28,100
that's what we are going to end up
using the majority of the times.

633
00:30:28,100 --> 00:30:31,980
So as we go back into PuTTY now,
and we start taking a look.

We have what's called a enable secret, and
we have what's called an enable password.

940
00:44:04,800 --> 00:44:09,860

941
00:44:09,860 --> 00:44:12,790

access, it's gonna prompt you for

942
00:44:12,790 --> 00:44:13,780
a password.

00:44:13,780 --> 00:44:16,830

so what's the difference?

944
00:44:16,830 --> 00:44:20,140
>> Yeah, when we talk about
the idea of the difference here,

945
00:44:20,140 --> 00:44:23,020
the enable password for
us is gonna be stored in plain text.

946
00:44:23,020 --> 00:44:25,810
So that means if you take
a look at the configuration,

947
00:44:25,810 --> 00:44:28,570
when we use that command to show
you how the configuration looks,

948
00:44:28,570 --> 00:44:31,290
you'll actually be able to
read whatever the password is.

949
00:44:31,290 --> 00:44:34,550
When you actually put in
the enable secret here.

950
00:44:34,550 --> 00:44:38,270
That means that the password's
gonna be stored in a hidden way.

951
00:44:38,270 --> 00:44:39,910
So in other words, you'll see a password,

952
00:44:39,910 --> 00:44:42,320
but it'll actually be
a hash of a password.

953
00:44:42,320 --> 00:44:43,780
So you can't take the hash and

954
00:44:43,780 --> 00:44:46,580
reverse engineer it to get
the real password out of it.

955
00:44:46,580 --> 00:44:49,410
You have to actually have the real
password so it can match the hash.

956
00:44:49,410 --> 00:44:51,240
>> And for those of you that are out
there that are cryptologists,

957
00:44:51,240 --> 00:44:52,970
it's just an MD5 hash.

958
00:44:52,970 --> 00:44:54,520
And so it's non-reversable encryption.

959
00:44:54,520 --> 00:44:55,270
It's very secure.
