00:54:08,310 --> 00:54:10,780
So where the question mark
is makes a difference.

1168
00:54:10,780 --> 00:54:15,460
I know that I want to get to privilege
mode, and so I might be looking for

1169
00:54:15,460 --> 00:54:17,390
a command that can do that.

1170
00:54:17,390 --> 00:54:21,660
So if I want to see the commands
that are available,

1171
00:54:21,660 --> 00:54:23,940
we can just do a question mark and
we get a bunch, right?

1172
00:54:23,940 --> 00:54:27,740
And I can start reading down the line
until I find one, like this guy right

1173
00:54:27,740 --> 00:54:34,140
here, that says enable, and
then it says turn on privileged commands,

1174
00:54:34,140 --> 00:54:39,050
but let's say that I sort of remember that
it's a command and it starts with an e.

1175
00:54:39,050 --> 00:54:42,100
Right, I'm like, I know it starts with
an e but I can't remember what it is.

1176
00:54:42,100 --> 00:54:45,020
I could use that context
sensitive help and

1177
00:54:45,020 --> 00:54:50,080
type E followed by a question mark and
it will give me a list,

1178
00:54:50,080 --> 00:54:54,200
not of all the commands,
just the commands that start with an E.

1179
00:54:54,200 --> 00:54:57,040
That's that context sensitive help.

1180
00:54:57,040 --> 00:55:00,950
>> This helps you to filter and
limit down what you may be looking for,

1181
00:55:00,950 --> 00:55:03,320
especially if you know what
the beginning is here, too, 'kay?

1182
00:55:03,320 --> 00:55:06,740
And the other nice thing about Cisco, even
though we don't really wanna emphasize

1183
00:55:06,740 --> 00:55:10,300
that too much here, is that accepts
abbreviations relatively easily, too.

1184
00:55:10,300 --> 00:55:11,570
>> Oh yeah.

1185
00:55:11,570 --> 00:55:13,339
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, you take a look at a command

1186
00:55:13,339 --> 00:55:15,009
>> like enable.

1187
00:55:15,009 --> 00:55:17,262
If I run enable.

1188
00:55:17,262 --> 00:55:19,355
If I run that fold command.

1189
00:55:19,355 --> 00:55:22,075
When I press Enter,
see how my prompt changed?

1190
00:55:22,075 --> 00:55:24,215
It just moved me to the privileged mode.

1191
00:55:24,215 --> 00:55:26,790
I'm not in an administrative mode.

1192
00:55:26,790 --> 00:55:31,030
I can run the opposite of that
command which is disable, and

1193
00:55:31,030 --> 00:55:33,830
now I'm back to the unprivileged user.

1194
00:55:33,830 --> 00:55:37,000
But I didn't have to
type the entire command.

1195
00:55:37,000 --> 00:55:40,586
For example, if I typed enab and

1196
00:55:40,586 --> 00:55:45,848
It knows what I'm talking about and
it moved me in to the enable prompt.

1197
00:55:45,848 --> 00:55:49,342
Now, how did it know
what I was talking about?

1198
00:55:49,342 --> 00:55:55,903
Well, the way it does it is when I
typed in enab, it basically looks for

1199
00:55:55,903 --> 00:56:01,410
commands that start with enab,
and there's only one.

1200
00:56:01,410 --> 00:56:04,020
The only one is enable.

1201
00:56:04,020 --> 00:56:08,800
You can shorten any command as much
as you want, even down to one letter.

1202
00:56:08,800 --> 00:56:12,340
As long as it's the only command
that starts with that letter.

1203
00:56:12,340 --> 00:56:13,450
Good luck finding that.

1204
00:56:13,450 --> 00:56:16,360
>> Yeah.
But it is something that we have to

1205
00:56:16,360 --> 00:56:17,190
actually be aware of,

1206
00:56:17,190 --> 00:56:20,300
especially in the production environment

1207
00:56:20,300 --> 00:56:22,970
One the exam though,
even though sometimes you will

1208
00:56:22,970 --> 00:56:25,840
get to where you are doing
the simulation that will accept these.

There is no guarantee it will accept it.

1210
00:56:28,130 --> 00:56:31,920
So if you try picker abbreviation and
it doesn't accept it, and you go,

00:56:31,920 --> 00:56:33,670
I know this worked when I tried that.

1212
00:56:33,670 --> 00:56:35,810
Well again it means you have
to know the actual command,

1213
00:56:35,810 --> 00:56:38,810
so as much as we want to tell

1214
00:56:38,810 --> 00:56:42,620
you have to know what the commands
are as well, so please pay attention.

1215
00:56:42,620 --> 00:56:44,670
>> You know on the exam you'll have,

1216
00:56:44,670 --> 00:56:47,000
the bulk of your exam is gonna
be multiple choice questions.

1217
00:56:47,000 --> 00:56:47,820
>> Right.
>> And so the command's

1218
00:56:47,820 --> 00:56:51,040
view right there on the screen, as long

00:56:51,040 --> 00:56:53,690
some of the questions
are simulation questions.

1220
00:56:53,690 --> 00:56:56,690
You'll be in a router or

1221
00:56:56,690 --> 00:56:59,610
And it does accept most abbreviations.

1222
00:56:59,610 --> 00:57:03,310
Some, it may not, and
the question mark does work.

1223
00:57:03,310 --> 00:57:05,570

00:57:05,570 --> 00:57:06,740

if you can't remember the exact command,

fire up that question mark and

00:57:10,880 --> 00:57:12,510
>> Yep.

00:57:12,510 --> 00:57:13,690

Instead you want to make sure

right now what.

00:58:06,220 --> 00:58:07,590
>> Right.
>> Because there was only

So you can abbreviate commands

That's really handy if you're gonna

Here, we don't have enough

Disable got me back out again.

Those commands are just single commands,

01:37:41,630 --> 01:37:45,800
your switch to have more or less you can,
there's not really a need for it, but

2069
01:37:45,800 --> 01:37:48,880
they do have a slightly different
number based on the device by default.

2070
01:37:50,140 --> 01:37:53,180
>> So for us that's our next configuration
that we want to be able to get

2071
01:37:53,180 --> 01:37:54,310
in and do here.

2072
01:37:54,310 --> 01:37:58,630
So for us to access those
virtual lines for us, and

2073
01:37:58,630 --> 01:38:03,230
to only affect those virtual lines with
this, we have to get into that command.

2074
01:38:03,230 --> 01:38:05,390
So for us here,
Don is ready to type it in.

2075
01:38:05,390 --> 01:38:10,638
Notice the command is line vty 0 4.

2076
01:38:10,638 --> 01:38:14,315
And that means affect all five
teletype lines at this point.

2077
01:38:14,315 --> 01:38:16,250
>> Now Cisco starts numbering with 0.

2078
01:38:16,250 --> 01:38:17,930
Everything starts with 0.

2079
01:38:17,930 --> 01:38:20,630
So your first interface is interface 0.

2080
01:38:20,630 --> 01:38:23,120
Your first VTY line is VTY 0.

2081
01:38:23,120 --> 01:38:26,140
So I'm saying VTY 0 through 4,

2082
01:38:26,140 --> 01:38:29,190
that's the five lines that
we have built in by default.

2083
01:38:29,190 --> 01:38:31,860
On a switch, it would be 0, 15, right.

2084
01:38:31,860 --> 01:38:34,120
Remember I said there were 16 by default.

2085
01:38:34,120 --> 01:38:36,850
If we start numbering at 0, it's 0 to 15.

2086
01:38:36,850 --> 01:38:40,620
>> Yeah, so at this point if we go ahead
and press Enter, we now let's go ahead and

2087
01:38:40,620 --> 01:38:42,530
use a question mark here.

2088
01:38:42,530 --> 01:38:45,560
For us, we wanna set up a password here.

2089
01:38:45,560 --> 01:38:49,860
Okay, so that we can log on using
these virtual teletype lines, so

2090
01:38:49,860 --> 01:38:52,620
the good thing is I can
actually just use my,

2091
01:38:52,620 --> 01:38:56,510
again the question mark here
until I see how I set a password.

2092
01:38:56,510 --> 01:38:59,400
And look at that, it's fairly easy for me.

2093
01:38:59,400 --> 01:39:01,290
Now what if I forget to set a password?

2094
01:39:01,290 --> 01:39:04,370
Well it will prompt me for it,
if I actually do another command here.

2095
01:39:04,370 --> 01:39:08,010
But let's go ahead and
set our password at this point.

2096
01:39:10,420 --> 01:39:14,320
And you'll see here the password
followed by line and

2097
01:39:14,320 --> 01:39:17,130
it says the unencrypted
cleartext line password.

2098
01:39:17,130 --> 01:39:19,360
So I can just say password and
whatever I want it to be.

2099
01:39:19,360 --> 01:39:20,220
I'll do Cisco123.

2100
01:39:20,220 --> 01:39:23,060
>> And so this is actually a very
important point for us to too.

2101
01:39:23,060 --> 01:39:25,710
Whenever you see that word LINE and
it's all in capital letters.

2102
01:39:25,710 --> 01:39:27,780
That doesn't mean you type in the word,
line.

2103
01:39:27,780 --> 01:39:31,840
As much as I think I remember trying to do
that, why the heck isn't it working here,

2104
01:39:31,840 --> 01:39:36,250
it actually means for you to make a word
or to actually create a different word for

2105
01:39:36,250 --> 01:39:37,710
you, to actually type it in.

2106
01:39:37,710 --> 01:39:39,400
So don't be confused by it.

2107
01:39:39,400 --> 01:39:42,332
So when I use it that in all capital
letters it means create a work, okay,

2108
01:39:42,332 --> 01:39:42,850
and paste here.

2109
01:39:42,850 --> 01:39:46,670
So now that we have the patchwork,
we're not really done yet, are we?

2110
01:39:46,670 --> 01:39:50,190
>> Yeah, this is where ti gets really

You also need to tell the router

01:39:57,810 --> 01:39:59,190
Some of them do it by default.

01:39:59,190 --> 01:40:00,300
Yeah.
>> Some don't.

2115
01:40:00,300 --> 01:40:02,620
>> I make it a rule of thumb
to just assume they don't.

2116
01:40:02,620 --> 01:40:04,650
>> Yeah.
>> And the way you tell it to ask for

2117
01:40:04,650 --> 01:40:07,110
the password is to issue
the login command.

2118
01:40:07,110 --> 01:40:07,620
All right?

2119
01:40:07,620 --> 01:40:10,810
It's a simple command just login,
it's got no modifiers.

2120
01:40:10,810 --> 01:40:12,555
I don't think it has any modifiers,
does it?

2121
01:40:12,555 --> 01:40:13,310
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, it can!

2122
01:40:13,310 --> 01:40:14,790
>> It does have local, yeah.

2123
01:40:14,790 --> 01:40:17,570
All right, but
log in by itself is the one that we want.

2124
01:40:17,570 --> 01:40:22,480
And that tells it if somebody
connects to a VTY, make them log in,

2125
01:40:22,480 --> 01:40:27,110
require them to provide some kind of a
password to be able to get into the system

2126
01:40:27,110 --> 01:40:28,050
and to work with it.

2127
01:40:28,050 --> 01:40:30,900
>> And the nice thing about the way
that Cisco does this here too.

2128
01:40:30,900 --> 01:40:33,030
Is that if we were to
just enter in login and

2129
01:40:33,030 --> 01:40:36,910
forgot to actually have set a password,
it will tell us.

2130
01:40:36,910 --> 01:40:39,200
It's not gonna actually set
until you create a password.

2131
01:40:39,200 --> 01:40:43,260
So it's kind of nice to remind

2132
01:40:43,260 --> 01:40:46,080
>> So once we've got that in place
>> Now I've done

01:40:46,080 --> 01:40:49,660

2134
01:40:49,660 --> 01:40:50,840
>> Right
>> I'm gonna get

out of the config by typing end.

2136
01:40:53,080 --> 01:40:56,890
Now the end command takes you all the way

2137
01:40:56,890 --> 01:40:59,770
If I just did exit,

2138
01:40:59,770 --> 01:41:02,000
I'll do ending it all the way out.

01:41:02,000 --> 01:41:03,450

01:41:03,450 --> 01:41:06,580
>> And that is one of the most important

01:41:06,580 --> 01:41:10,210
So, if we do the whole thing,

01:41:10,210 --> 01:41:11,345

01:41:11,345 --> 01:41:12,460

>> I'm in trouble here.

01:41:14,040 --> 01:41:16,660
So make sure that when you do

2146
01:41:16,660 --> 01:41:18,950

2147
01:41:18,950 --> 01:41:22,580
And so this is where Don issued the Copy.

2148
01:41:22,580 --> 01:41:23,730
Okay.
Just wanna make sure.

2149
01:41:23,730 --> 01:41:28,550
The copy-run-start here, and

2150
01:41:28,550 --> 01:41:31,270
We should end up seeing the idea of the,
ok,

2151
01:41:31,270 --> 01:41:34,780
and that tells that everything was
copied from the running config,

2152
01:41:34,780 --> 01:41:39,580
which is in our RAM into the nv RAM

2153
01:41:39,580 --> 01:41:42,720
This means that this should
persist through the reboot.

2154
01:41:42,720 --> 01:41:44,330
>> Now we are all saved.

2155
01:41:44,330 --> 01:41:47,487
And the cool part here is that now

01:41:47,487 --> 01:41:50,938

01:41:59,020 --> 01:42:01,630
I can start looking for

01:42:01,630 --> 01:42:05,540

01:42:05,540 --> 01:42:10,940

01:42:10,940 --> 01:42:12,560

01:42:17,085 --> 01:42:23,640
Here's interface Gigabitethernet0/0 and

01:42:23,640 --> 01:42:25,180

01:42:25,180 --> 01:42:27,937
If you actually are examining this and

01:42:27,937 --> 01:42:31,400

01:42:42,247 --> 01:42:44,140
it doesn't show up here, does it?

01:42:44,140 --> 01:42:45,300

When a command is like that,

01:42:50,730 --> 01:42:53,670
So the default for

01:42:53,670 --> 01:42:55,140
So when I ran no shutdown.

2178
01:42:55,140 --> 01:42:56,620
It's not showing up.

01:42:56,620 --> 01:42:59,720
Now I did not type shutdown

01:42:59,720 --> 01:43:04,040
that's because it is part of the factory

2181
01:43:04,040 --> 01:43:06,740
And if I did did no shutdown,

2182
01:43:08,110 --> 01:43:11,400
All right, and
if I keep advancing forward,

I can see where we set our password of

Maybe eight foot long or

It's probably seven since that's

that means I've gotta be right

01:43:50,091 --> 01:43:54,234
Now that I've got this basic configuration

01:43:54,234 --> 01:43:58,140

We've now set it up to now where we can

So as long as my particular

able to connect into that gigabit

ethernet zero port using the ip address

01:44:43,410 --> 01:44:46,301
So what Don is doing right now is

01:44:46,301 --> 01:44:48,855

2212
01:44:48,855 --> 01:44:51,570
because we're actually on

01:44:51,570 --> 01:44:56,059
And if anybody can do it quickly as Don-

So at this bigger point here,

We could use a PC,

We configured enough for

01:45:42,240 --> 01:45:44,320

01:45:44,320 --> 01:45:45,570

01:45:45,570 --> 01:45:48,570
I can enable, and

01:45:48,570 --> 01:45:52,470
I set it also to Cisco123, and here I am.

01:45:52,470 --> 01:45:57,390

And I can see that if I do like a,

Show users with an s.

So I can see that I am connected on VTY 0,

I could unplug my console cable and

01:46:58,630 --> 01:47:03,380
Assigning more advanced authentication,

So

episodes.description: The configurations between a router and a switch are almost identical. Viewers will get the chance to hear about the initial configuration of Cisco switch devices, the differences between them, and about connecting to a device via Telnet verses SSH.
episodes.title: Basic Switch Configuration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,134 --> 00:00:22,584
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,584 --> 00:00:33,384
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,384 --> 00:00:34,334
All right we're good.

5
00:00:34,334 --> 00:00:36,431
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good morning, good afternoon and

6

good evening, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

7

I'm your host Don Pezet.

8

Today I've got Ronnie Wong with me.

9
00:00:41,811 --> 00:00:42,620
How is it going Ronnie?

10
00:00:42,620 --> 00:00:43,700

11

Ready to get started on another

12
00:00:47,910 --> 00:00:50,130
>> Excellent, excellent, excellent.

13

In the last episode, we took a stab at
our initial router configuration and

14

connect to a device the first time.

15
00:00:59,310 --> 00:01:02,580
We did some crazy exciting things, right?

16
00:01:02,580 --> 00:01:04,680
We set a host name.

17
00:01:04,680 --> 00:01:05,950
We assigned some IP's, didn't we?

18
00:01:05,950 --> 00:01:07,340
>> I think we assigned an IP address.

19
00:01:07,340 --> 00:01:09,130
>> So we did some basic things.

20
00:01:09,130 --> 00:01:10,360
We got some tele-networking.

21

We remotely connected to the device.

22

We do have some more things to configure,

23
00:01:14,520 --> 00:01:17,620
some more advanced topics

24
00:01:17,620 --> 00:01:20,050
But today what we're gonna do is we're
gonna shuffle things around a bit,

25
00:01:20,050 --> 00:01:23,850
and we're gonna move from
a router to a switch.

26
00:01:23,850 --> 00:01:28,100
And one of the last things I said in
the last episode, if i recall correctly,

27
00:01:28,100 --> 00:01:30,740
was [LAUGH] that the configurations

28
00:01:30,740 --> 00:01:33,260
that we did were almost identical
between a router and a switch.

29
00:01:33,260 --> 00:01:37,330
So I thought it'd be a good idea today
to fire up a switch and go through and

30
00:01:37,330 --> 00:01:38,330
get a chance to see that.

31
00:01:38,330 --> 00:01:41,840
To see those same commands
working in a switch environment.

32
00:01:41,840 --> 00:01:45,610
>> So in our switch environment here,
remember that what we are talking about.

33
00:01:45,610 --> 00:01:49,310
At least at the CCNT level, is that we're
gonna be working with a single router and

34
00:01:49,310 --> 00:01:53,530
a single switch configuring for
a small network environment for us.

35
00:01:53,530 --> 00:01:57,122
And so, the basic configurations
here at this level are normally so

36
00:01:57,122 --> 00:02:00,482
that we can get things set up and
get it ready and working for us.

37
00:02:00,482 --> 00:02:03,700
And so, the first thing that we have to do
of course is we need to connect to it and

38
00:02:03,700 --> 00:02:05,780
just put in the most basic
configurations possible.

39
00:02:06,910 --> 00:02:09,620
>> Yeah, and just like in the last
episode, I've got my trusty,

40
00:02:09,620 --> 00:02:11,990
actually it's your trusty console cable.

41
00:02:11,990 --> 00:02:15,210
Which I've got plugged into my
laptop using one of those USB serial

42
00:02:15,210 --> 00:02:16,950
port adapters we talked about.

43
00:02:16,950 --> 00:02:22,210
And I've got it running back to a switch
that is just barely off-camera here.

44
00:02:22,210 --> 00:02:26,790
This switch is a Cisco catalyst
3560 it is the switch on the exam.

45
00:02:26,790 --> 00:02:32,910
So, just like we used the 2800 router last
time which is the router on the exam.

46
00:02:32,910 --> 00:02:35,400
So, we've got this turkey
sitting back here.

47
00:02:35,400 --> 00:02:39,320
It has a plain basic
configuration on it and

48
00:02:39,320 --> 00:02:43,310
what I mean is the configuration that's on
it is the same one you'd find if you took

49
00:02:43,310 --> 00:02:45,860
a brand new switch out of the box.

50
00:02:45,860 --> 00:02:48,590
And just applied power which
is effectively what we did,

51
00:02:48,590 --> 00:02:53,050
just not exactly brand new but
it's a wiped configuration.

52
00:02:53,050 --> 00:02:56,100
So sometimes getting it start
is actually the key, right?

53
00:02:56,100 --> 00:02:56,960
Every once and a while,

54
00:02:56,960 --> 00:03:01,580
you might not buy a switch right out of
the actual, right directly from Cisco.

55
00:03:01,580 --> 00:03:05,250
You might end up getting it a used switch,
and remember that for us here.

56
00:03:05,250 --> 00:03:09,350
Starting off with nobody else's
configurations or starting off brand new,

57
00:03:09,350 --> 00:03:10,680
and that's really the key for us here.

58
00:03:10,680 --> 00:03:13,870
So, we don't have to worry about anybody
else's configuration at this point.

59
00:03:13,870 --> 00:03:14,870
>> Yep.
>> Yep.

60
00:03:14,870 --> 00:03:18,410
>> Now, how do you know if your
switch has been factory reset or not?

61
00:03:18,410 --> 00:03:19,130
>> That's right.

62
00:03:19,130 --> 00:03:22,700
Well, just like on the router, when you
fire up a switch for the first time,

63
00:03:22,700 --> 00:03:24,850
you'll get a prompt asking whether or

64
00:03:24,850 --> 00:03:27,360
not you wanna do the initial
switch configuration.

65
00:03:27,360 --> 00:03:29,710
And that's where we're at, so
let's take a look at this.

66
00:03:29,710 --> 00:03:33,850
I've got my trusty PuTTY
fired up here and,

67
00:03:33,850 --> 00:03:36,100
let me make this screen
a little bit bigger.

68
00:03:36,100 --> 00:03:39,780
And it basically went through
the initial boot process and

69
00:03:39,780 --> 00:03:43,230
showed all the various iOS stuff
that you see when a system boots up.

70
00:03:43,230 --> 00:03:46,620
It does its hardware check and
all of that.

71
00:03:46,620 --> 00:03:50,271
So I can see this is a Cisco 3560 switch,

72
00:03:50,271 --> 00:03:56,440
it's got 48 Fat at the net ports,
and let me move that, there we go.

73
00:03:56,440 --> 00:03:59,640
So we can see it's got all those ports,
which is exciting and fun.

74
00:03:59,640 --> 00:04:00,250
>> Yep.

75
00:04:00,250 --> 00:04:01,350
>> Yeah.

76
00:04:01,350 --> 00:04:03,820
But at the end of the day what I'm
looking for is this right here,

77
00:04:03,820 --> 00:04:07,970
where it says, would you like to enter
the initial configuration dialogue.

78
00:04:07,970 --> 00:04:10,740
When you see that message,
that's your clue, that says hey,

79
00:04:10,740 --> 00:04:12,680
the configuration on this
switch has been erased.

80
00:04:12,680 --> 00:04:16,830
This is not an active switch
that's been configured.

81
00:04:18,570 --> 00:04:22,020
Now with a router out of the box,
not very useful, right?

82
00:04:22,020 --> 00:04:25,370
You plug in a router right out of
the box and it doesn't do anything.

83
00:04:25,370 --> 00:04:29,170
But a switch is a different story,
we don't have to configure a switch.

84
00:04:29,170 --> 00:04:33,010
We could leave it just the way it is,
it's a 48 port switch in this example, any

85
00:04:33,010 --> 00:04:37,220
PCs I plug into any port should be able to
see each other, communicate, and be happy.

86
00:04:37,220 --> 00:04:41,240
>> Now, that for us is a huge advantage
for a lot of small companies that don't

87
00:04:41,240 --> 00:04:44,760
have anybody that could come in and
configure the device, right?

88
00:04:44,760 --> 00:04:47,490
You pull it right out of the box,
you plug the power in.

89
00:04:47,490 --> 00:04:51,440
Let the light settle down, as soon as you
plug the devices in, they're ready to go.

90
00:04:51,440 --> 00:04:57,310
Even so it is designed to do that it's
not the best thing that we can do.

91
00:04:57,310 --> 00:05:00,880
So that's what we're learning about
is that we want to get this device

92
00:05:00,880 --> 00:05:02,640
ready to be put into our network here.

93
00:05:02,640 --> 00:05:06,200
And so, we wanna make sure that we
go over the same configurations,

94
00:05:06,200 --> 00:05:08,160
pretty much just about the same here.

95
00:05:08,160 --> 00:05:12,310
So that we have a, well,
a secured device for us.

96
00:05:12,310 --> 00:05:13,640
>> Yeah, absolutely.

97
00:05:13,640 --> 00:05:17,080
>> And that way we're not just putting
a device in that somebody can just simply

98
00:05:17,080 --> 00:05:19,940
plug in another device into, and
be able to take over control.

99
00:05:19,940 --> 00:05:22,150
>> Yeah, and the reality is if
you take the box right out of,

100
00:05:22,150 --> 00:05:26,085
if you take the switch right
out of the box and hook it up.

101
00:05:26,085 --> 00:05:29,355
If you leave it like that, you are missing
out on all the bells and whistles.

102
00:05:29,355 --> 00:05:32,195
There are a ton of features inside
of these devices that you can't take

103
00:05:32,195 --> 00:05:34,155
advantage of unless you get in and
configure it.

104
00:05:34,155 --> 00:05:38,390
So if you're just gonna take it out of
the box and use it with the base config.

105
00:05:38,390 --> 00:05:40,840
You probably should have
just bough a cheaper switch

106
00:05:40,840 --> 00:05:42,890
because you do waste a lot of money.

107
00:05:42,890 --> 00:05:43,640
All right,

108
00:05:43,640 --> 00:05:48,160
so just like on the routers, I'm gonna
say no to this configuration dialogue.

109
00:05:48,160 --> 00:05:51,990
On the exam, you need to know the dialogue
exists, but you're not gonna use it.

110
00:05:51,990 --> 00:05:54,619
And so, they want you to be able to
do all the configurations by hand.

111
00:05:56,430 --> 00:05:59,200
>> So as a little bit of review here,
remember that what we're looking for

112
00:05:59,200 --> 00:06:01,850
here, since we've already gone
through the router configuration.

113
00:06:01,850 --> 00:06:05,620
Notice that the prompts are relatively
the same here, instead of the word

114
00:06:05,620 --> 00:06:10,580
router that we generically have here,
we have the word switch instead.

115
00:06:10,580 --> 00:06:12,511
And you see that greater than symbol for
us,

116
00:06:12,511 --> 00:06:15,580
and that tells us we're in user mode,
is that right?

117
00:06:15,580 --> 00:06:16,670
>> Yep, unprivileged user mode.

118
00:06:16,670 --> 00:06:17,900
>> Unprivileged user mode here.

119
00:06:17,900 --> 00:06:23,910
And so, Don has actually entered in the
first command for us here which is enable.

120
00:06:23,910 --> 00:06:28,420
Which actually bring us now into
the privileged mode, is what we have.

121
00:06:28,420 --> 00:06:31,870
>> And once we're here, there's not all
that much we can configure on the device.

122
00:06:31,870 --> 00:06:36,250
Although, we can jump into
the configuration mode,

123
00:06:36,250 --> 00:06:39,840
with configure terminal and
now we can do some damage.

124
00:06:39,840 --> 00:06:41,550
>> Don't forget that when we're here,

125
00:06:41,550 --> 00:06:44,630
this is technically called
the global configuration mode.

126
00:06:44,630 --> 00:06:48,790
And so, for us anything that we said
here affects the entire switch.

127
00:06:48,790 --> 00:06:52,730
There's 48 ports on it,
it's gonna affect all 48 ports, and

128
00:06:52,730 --> 00:06:54,920
in other words the entire switch here.

129
00:06:54,920 --> 00:06:57,530
So we do have some different
things on here as well.

130
00:06:58,910 --> 00:07:01,870
>> So on the router, we jumped in and
we configured a few basic things, so

131
00:07:01,870 --> 00:07:04,220
let's run through those again.

132
00:07:04,220 --> 00:07:05,430
We did a host name,

133
00:07:05,430 --> 00:07:08,990
because if we're connected to multiple
devices we want to remember which one.

134
00:07:08,990 --> 00:07:11,510
So, I just renamed this one
using the host name command.

135
00:07:11,510 --> 00:07:14,780
Host name and then ITProTV- switch
is what I wanted to call mine,

136
00:07:14,780 --> 00:07:16,012
and now it's renamed.

137
00:07:16,012 --> 00:07:20,470
>> And so, on the router we actually
did the ITProTV- rtr for router,

138
00:07:20,470 --> 00:07:21,310
is what I think we did.

139
00:07:21,310 --> 00:07:23,530
>> Oh, we did, I used the shorter name.

140
00:07:23,530 --> 00:07:27,720
All right, we also assigned a password
by doing enable secret, and

141
00:07:27,720 --> 00:07:28,800
then setting a password.

142
00:07:28,800 --> 00:07:29,640
I'll do Cisco123.

143
00:07:30,740 --> 00:07:32,040
>> Incredibly secure password for us.

144
00:07:32,040 --> 00:07:33,538
>> Absolutely and I use it on everything.

145
00:07:33,538 --> 00:07:34,603
>> That's right.

146
00:07:34,603 --> 00:07:38,150
>> [LAUGH] So enable secret Cisco123.

147
00:07:38,150 --> 00:07:42,800
Now, anytime someone types enable, they're
gonna be prompted for that password.

148
00:07:42,800 --> 00:07:46,518
Don't forget that for us,
a lot of times, just like on the router,

149
00:07:46,518 --> 00:07:48,880
we have enable secret or enable password.

150
00:07:48,880 --> 00:07:52,604
Enable secret means that when we go and
store everything,

151
00:07:52,604 --> 00:07:57,170
this password's gonna be stored
encrypted already with an MD5 hash.

152
00:07:57,170 --> 00:08:00,709
>> All right, now some of the other things
that we configured, we got the Cisco

153
00:08:00,709 --> 00:08:04,330
router setup so that we could telnet
into it over the network, right?

154
00:08:04,330 --> 00:08:07,630
And I may wanna get the switch
set up that same way, right?

155
00:08:07,630 --> 00:08:10,270
There's a couple little
differences in the way it's done

156
00:08:10,270 --> 00:08:12,410
on a router versus the way
it's done on a switch.

157
00:08:12,410 --> 00:08:15,280
On the router, I mentioned how,
in order to Telnet into it,

158
00:08:15,280 --> 00:08:17,870
you've got to have a Telnet password set.

159
00:08:17,870 --> 00:08:20,500
And the password was set on the vty lines.

160
00:08:20,500 --> 00:08:23,560
And on a router, you have five vty lines.

161
00:08:23,560 --> 00:08:27,090
But on a switch, you have 16,
so you have more.

162
00:08:27,090 --> 00:08:32,880
So on a router,
I went into line vty 0 4, like that.

163
00:08:32,880 --> 00:08:35,520
But on a switch,
we go all the way up to 15.

164
00:08:35,520 --> 00:08:41,580
Now that's important, as people connect,
they connect to 0 and then 1 and then 2.

165
00:08:41,580 --> 00:08:44,320
If you only do 0 through 4,

166
00:08:44,320 --> 00:08:49,110
well, then lines 5 through 15
don't have a password now.

167
00:08:49,110 --> 00:08:51,620
The switch will not allow you
to connect without a password.

168
00:08:51,620 --> 00:08:55,120
So it will effectively limit you
to just those five connections.

169
00:08:55,120 --> 00:08:57,870
So we need to make sure we get all of
them which is what I'm doing here,

170
00:08:57,870 --> 00:08:59,938
and then I'll set that password.

171
00:08:59,938 --> 00:09:03,450
And I'm gonna use the same password,
it doesn't have to be the same one.

172
00:09:03,450 --> 00:09:06,670
You can use any variation that we want.

173
00:09:06,670 --> 00:09:08,970
>> And
then setting in the word password here,

174
00:09:08,970 --> 00:09:11,230
notice the prompt change
on the config line.

175
00:09:11,230 --> 00:09:14,790
Means we will be prompted for
the password at this point too.

176
00:09:14,790 --> 00:09:20,110
>> And that's on the vty's, so we got
a config- line, so that's set there.

177
00:09:20,110 --> 00:09:24,270
The other thing that we did on the router,
was we assigned some IP addresses to it so

178
00:09:24,270 --> 00:09:27,075
that we could tone that
to it over the network.

179
00:09:27,075 --> 00:09:31,930
It's been long enough that I don't
remember what IQ we assigned

180
00:09:31,930 --> 00:09:33,988
to the router but
we'll assign a different one here now.

181
00:09:33,988 --> 00:09:39,040
This is gonna lead us to probably the
biggest difference between a switch and

182
00:09:39,040 --> 00:09:39,690
a router.

183
00:09:39,690 --> 00:09:44,290
On a router you have physical
interfaces that plug into networks, and

184
00:09:44,290 --> 00:09:45,860
each interface gets its own IP.

185
00:09:46,900 --> 00:09:50,000
On a router, you do not, I mean a switch.

186
00:09:50,000 --> 00:09:50,860
Now I'm screwing up.

187
00:09:50,860 --> 00:09:54,050
On a switch,
you do not have physical interfaces.

188
00:09:54,050 --> 00:09:56,010
Now you might say, wait a minute,
Don, you're crazy.

189
00:09:56,010 --> 00:09:58,510
I look at the front of the switch,
there's ports all over.

190
00:09:58,510 --> 00:10:02,630
Well, those are switch ports,
their layer two port.

191
00:10:02,630 --> 00:10:07,760
Layer two ports don't have layer
three IP addresses, right?

192
00:10:07,760 --> 00:10:12,500
So, although you've got a ton of ports on
the switch, none of them get addresses.

193
00:10:12,500 --> 00:10:16,340
So on a switch,
we have to use a virtual interface.

194
00:10:16,340 --> 00:10:22,270
There's a virtual interface on the switch
that we can use to define that IP address.

195
00:10:22,270 --> 00:10:26,820
>> When Don starts talking about
this idea of the virtual interface.

196
00:10:26,820 --> 00:10:29,600
All of a sudden, we've already gone
through like fast ethernet 0/0, or

197
00:10:29,600 --> 00:10:30,460
something like that.

198
00:10:30,460 --> 00:10:35,180
But when we start talking about a virtual
interface here, we're gonna actually see,

199
00:10:35,180 --> 00:10:37,030
s Don actually typed in here.

200
00:10:37,030 --> 00:10:40,710
That on the switch, the virtual interface
that we're gonna assign is actually

201
00:10:40,710 --> 00:10:41,810
the one called VLAN one.

202
00:10:41,810 --> 00:10:44,702
And so, the idea of that
that virtual address is that

203
00:10:44,702 --> 00:10:47,620
you're not really plugging
a cable in to it.

204
00:10:47,620 --> 00:10:51,740
We're using this particular interface here
for management, it's what we are doing.

205
00:10:51,740 --> 00:10:53,646
And so, this is the address
that we are gonna connect to,

206
00:10:53,646 --> 00:10:55,060
it's what we're gonna do.

207
00:10:55,060 --> 00:11:00,400
>> Yes, so on the router I went into
interface gigabyte ethernet 0/0, right?

208
00:11:00,400 --> 00:11:03,030
GI00, or you know if it is
a fast ethernet, or whatever,

209
00:11:03,030 --> 00:11:04,000
you go into that one.

210
00:11:04,000 --> 00:11:08,750
But here on this switch,
I'm going into interface VLAN one, and

211
00:11:08,750 --> 00:11:10,300
VLAN means virtual LAN.

212
00:11:10,300 --> 00:11:14,570
It's a virtual network that spans
across all of these interfaces.

213
00:11:14,570 --> 00:11:19,210
We'll talk more about VLAN in another
episode, but this one is special.

214
00:11:19,210 --> 00:11:23,610
VLAN one is defined as the one that you're
supposed to assign the IP address for

215
00:11:23,610 --> 00:11:25,400
management purposes.

216
00:11:25,400 --> 00:11:28,400
>> The nice thing about this is
that once we get pass that strange

217
00:11:28,400 --> 00:11:32,270
naming of the interface, you actually
see as Don's typing this here.

218
00:11:32,270 --> 00:11:34,770
The interface or
the IP address command for

219
00:11:34,770 --> 00:11:39,190
us, is almost exactly if not exactly
the same as what we did on the router.

220
00:11:39,190 --> 00:11:41,290
So the good thing is,
if you paid attention to the router here.

221
00:11:41,290 --> 00:11:45,430
You're starting to see some commands
that are again, starting to repeat which

222
00:11:45,430 --> 00:11:47,330
is really good for us,
because it means you have to learn a lot.

223
00:11:48,610 --> 00:11:49,920
>> So I'm gonna sign that.

224

Now on some switches,

We even get to pick
seconds if we choose to.

1140
00:57:23,200 --> 00:57:23,850
>> Yeah.

1141
00:57:23,850 --> 00:57:27,560
If I wanna set it to five minutes,
I can just say exec dash timeout Five.

1142
00:57:27,560 --> 00:57:28,290
>> Five.

1143
00:57:28,290 --> 00:57:29,740
And I'm done, right.

1144
00:57:29,740 --> 00:57:31,350
If I want it to be five minutes and

1145
00:57:31,350 --> 00:57:34,730
30 seconds, you'll see where I
can specify seconds also, and so

1146
00:57:34,730 --> 00:57:39,630
I can say, exec-timeout 5 30, and
that would be 5 minutes and 30 seconds.

1147
00:57:39,630 --> 00:57:41,470
I don't know anybody who's that specific.

1148
00:57:41,470 --> 00:57:42,780
>> Yeah, I was gonna say, wow.

1149
00:57:42,780 --> 00:57:43,860
>> But maybe I'll bump mine up to 15.

1150
00:57:43,860 --> 00:57:46,780
>> Yeah.
So I'm gonna say exec-timeout 15.

1151
00:57:46,780 --> 00:57:49,940
Now, that applies to the vty lines.

1152
00:57:49,940 --> 00:57:54,840
I also want to apply that to my console.

1153
00:57:54,840 --> 00:58:00,270
And so I'll get in here and
set that to 15 minutes, too.

1154
00:58:00,270 --> 00:58:02,490
The console is even more important.

1155
00:58:02,490 --> 00:58:06,910
With SSH, if I close my session,
the session is gone, and that's it.

1156
00:58:06,910 --> 00:58:10,560
With your console connections,
if you unplug your console cable,

1157
00:58:10,560 --> 00:58:16,110
this light blue cable right here, if we
unplug that, your session is still live.

1158
00:58:16,110 --> 00:58:17,680
>> Yeah.
>> Somebody else could come behind with

1159
00:58:17,680 --> 00:58:21,460
their own cable and plug in, and
it's still logged in and going.

1160
00:58:21,460 --> 00:58:23,960
So on a console connection,
you may even want to set it shorter.

1161
00:58:23,960 --> 00:58:26,230
>> Right
>> Or just some interval so

1162
00:58:26,230 --> 00:58:30,500
that if you walk away, it'll lock itself
in a certain, decent amount of time.

1163
00:58:30,500 --> 00:58:33,830
>> So setting a timeout is one of
the security features that we do have

1164
00:58:33,830 --> 00:58:34,970
that is something important.

1165
00:58:34,970 --> 00:58:37,465
And I really was going there and
I don't know why my mind just,

1166
00:58:37,465 --> 00:58:42,180
it merged logging synchronous with
time and I was like, that's not right.

1167
00:58:42,180 --> 00:58:43,350
I don't know what happened there.

1168
00:58:43,350 --> 00:58:44,870
>> Well you mentioned logging so

1169
00:58:44,870 --> 00:58:48,710
this is a good lead in to another command
that I like to do on new equipment.

1170
00:58:48,710 --> 00:58:52,480
And I keep saying these
are commands I like to do.

1171
00:58:52,480 --> 00:58:56,850
They show up on the exam [LAUGH],
they are good to know for that.

1172
00:58:56,850 --> 00:59:00,100
But, one thing you might have
noticed with the log messages.

1173
00:59:00,100 --> 00:59:01,600
So lets wait for this one to come up.

1174
00:59:01,600 --> 00:59:02,540
There we go.

1175
00:59:02,540 --> 00:59:05,220
Notice it's saying that
this event just happened.

1176
00:59:05,220 --> 00:59:06,870
We were configured from console.

1177
00:59:06,870 --> 00:59:07,420
Right.

1178
00:59:07,420 --> 00:59:10,050
And it occurred on March 1st.

1179
00:59:10,050 --> 00:59:12,190
Well, today is not March 1st.

1180
00:59:12,190 --> 00:59:14,580
Today is September 12th.

1181
00:59:14,580 --> 00:59:18,900
So the date is wrong in the message.

1182
00:59:18,900 --> 00:59:23,320
And we can actually manipulate several
things when it comes to date and time.

1183
00:59:23,320 --> 00:59:26,490
The first thing that we need to do,
and this is good for security purposes

1184
00:59:26,490 --> 00:59:29,730
because you may need to synchronize
your logs across multiple devices,

1185
00:59:29,730 --> 00:59:34,110
the first thing we need to do is make
sure the clock is correct on our system.

1186
00:59:34,110 --> 00:59:36,150
And the clock is one
of those weird things.

1187
00:59:36,150 --> 00:59:40,290
It's one of the only things that we
configure outside of configuration.

1188
00:59:42,120 --> 00:59:43,300
So if I wanna set the clock,

1189
00:59:43,300 --> 00:59:45,530
the first thing I need to do is
figure out what time it is, right.

1190
00:59:45,530 --> 00:59:51,010
So right now, it is 4:15 PM and
so what we do, is we say clock,

1191
00:59:52,190 --> 00:59:56,660
set, and then we specify the time, right.

1192
00:59:56,660 --> 00:59:58,400
Afterwards, we specify the date.

1193
00:59:58,400 --> 01:00:01,570
And you can specify the date in
all sorts of different formats.

1194
01:00:01,570 --> 01:00:02,630
>> Yeah.
>> So, really whatever makes

1195
01:00:02,630 --> 01:00:03,720
sense for you.

1196
01:00:03,720 --> 01:00:05,890
So, I'm gonna go in here and
just say clock, set.

1197
01:00:05,890 --> 01:00:06,640
And I'll set it to.

1198
01:00:06,640 --> 01:00:08,450
You need to do it in military times.

1199
01:00:08,450 --> 01:00:13,230
So, it's actually 16:15,
actually it's 16:16 now.

1200
01:00:13,230 --> 01:00:13,730
16 now.
>> Yep.

1201
01:00:15,280 --> 01:00:19,360
>> And 00 seconds and
it is September 12 1013.

1202
01:00:19,360 --> 01:00:22,099
>> Yeah.

1203
01:00:22,099 --> 01:00:22,777
>> Okay.
>> Now remember,

1204
01:00:22,777 --> 01:00:24,860
you have to actually set all of that,
don't you?

1205
01:00:24,860 --> 01:00:27,260
You can't just kind of, can you
just set the time and not the date?

1206
01:00:27,260 --> 01:00:29,430
>> I think you can set just the time.

1207
01:00:29,430 --> 01:00:30,740
>> I can't remember.

1208
01:00:30,740 --> 01:00:31,760
No, no-
>> Oh yeah.

1209
01:00:31,760 --> 01:00:34,180
>> It does require you to specify.

1210
01:00:34,180 --> 01:00:37,920
>> So remember, you have to set
everything if you're gonna do this.

1211
01:00:37,920 --> 01:00:42,780
>> Now I did just think of something that
I forgot, and it's gonna cause a problem.

1212
01:00:42,780 --> 01:00:43,475
>> Oh.
[LAUGH]

1213
01:00:43,475 --> 01:00:44,326
>> We set the time.

1214
01:00:44,326 --> 01:00:45,710
And as soon as I set the time,

1215
01:00:45,710 --> 01:00:47,410
I got a nice little message
letting me know it was set.

1216
01:00:47,410 --> 01:00:49,020
>> Oh, there we go.
>> And look what it says.

1217
01:00:49,020 --> 01:00:55,070
It set it, and it set it for 02:14,
UTC, that's what time it was.

1218
01:00:55,070 --> 01:00:56,830
Now we have it set for 16:16 UTC.

1219
01:00:56,830 --> 01:01:00,420
UTC is the Universal Time Code,
it's also called Zulu Time,

1220
01:01:00,420 --> 01:01:04,740
Greenwich Mean Time,
any of the the numbers numerous names.

1221
01:01:04,740 --> 01:01:07,740
I'm not in UTC,
we're in the Eastern Time Zone.

1222
01:01:07,740 --> 01:01:09,640
So the time zone is wrong.

1223
01:01:09,640 --> 01:01:12,510
When I go and fix the time zone,
it's gonna mess my time up.

1224
01:01:12,510 --> 01:01:13,620
I'll have to come and set it again.

1225
01:01:13,620 --> 01:01:15,910
So I should have set the time zone first.

1226
01:01:15,910 --> 01:01:19,050
But this command is the one
that we run outside of config,

1227
01:01:19,050 --> 01:01:21,060
everything else is done inside of config.

1228
01:01:21,060 --> 01:01:22,705
So let's go fix that time zone.

1229
01:01:22,705 --> 01:01:28,490
[SOUND] So in our global configuration
terminal, once we're actually in here

1230
01:01:28,490 --> 01:01:34,104
we are now ready to set the time zone,
and do we set the daylight in here too?

1231
01:01:34,104 --> 01:01:35,320
>> Yup, we can set them both right here.

1232
01:01:35,320 --> 01:01:37,620
>> All right-
>> So I just ran clock?, and so

1233
01:01:37,620 --> 01:01:39,670
we've got time zone and summer time.

1234
01:01:39,670 --> 01:01:41,780
Summer time is Daylight Saving Time.

1235
01:01:41,780 --> 01:01:46,470
So we can set these values in here for
clock time zone,

1236
01:01:46,470 --> 01:01:50,730
we basically give it a name, so
I'm gonna say my time zone is called EST,

1237
01:01:50,730 --> 01:01:54,010
Eastern Standard Time, you can type in
whatever name you want, call it Bob,

1238
01:01:54,010 --> 01:01:57,740
if you want, and
I'll say that it is GMT-5.

1239
01:01:57,740 --> 01:01:58,240
>> Right.

1240
01:01:59,330 --> 01:02:04,050
>> So clock, time zone EST-5,
I'll get a message,

1241
01:02:04,050 --> 01:02:08,000
there it is, telling me that we're
now in Eastern Standard Time.

1242
01:02:08,000 --> 01:02:11,700
And CL went ahead and subtracted the time
for me and so now my clock is wrong.

1243
01:02:11,700 --> 01:02:13,750
>> Right.
>> So we'll fix that in a second.

1244
01:02:13,750 --> 01:02:18,869
The other thing I need to do is say,
clock summer-time,

1245
01:02:18,869 --> 01:02:22,550
EDT and you can call this one whatever,
you can call it Fred if you want.

1246
01:02:22,550 --> 01:02:26,630
I'm gonna call it EDT for Eastern
Daylight Time, so now I'm gonna say

1247
01:02:26,630 --> 01:02:29,680
that we do observe daylight savings,
because not everybody does,

1248
01:02:29,680 --> 01:02:34,399
like I think the entire state of Arizona,
some city in Ohio so not everybody does.

1249
01:02:34,399 --> 01:02:38,272
And then I'll say, 'EDT,' and then,

1250
01:02:38,272 --> 01:02:43,525
'recurring,' which means
we observe it every year.

1251
01:02:43,525 --> 01:02:45,170
>> Right.
>> This isn't a one time thing.

1252
01:02:45,170 --> 01:02:47,250
It is something we always observe.

1253
01:02:47,250 --> 01:02:49,900
Now it knows that Daylight Saving Time
is one hour back so

1254
01:02:49,900 --> 01:02:53,660
I didn't have to do the minus four or
whatever.

1255
01:02:53,660 --> 01:02:56,130
So it sorts that out.

1256
01:02:56,130 --> 01:02:59,370
So now my time zones are right but
I do need to go and fix my clock.

1257
01:02:59,370 --> 01:03:04,959
So I'm gonna get out of config and,
let's see, it is now 04:19.

1258
01:03:08,080 --> 01:03:09,520
And now it'll be correct.

1259
01:03:10,540 --> 01:03:15,380
So now it shows that it is 04:19
Eastern Daylight time, Thursday,

1260
01:03:15,380 --> 01:03:16,330
September 12, 2013.

1261
01:03:16,330 --> 01:03:22,750
>> This is a very good command for us
because this now actually helps us then,

1262
01:03:22,750 --> 01:03:27,880
as you're starting to see on the screen,
is now allowing the logging to match up to

1263
01:03:27,880 --> 01:03:29,820
>> To the true time, okay?

1264
01:03:29,820 --> 01:03:31,710
Well, why is that beneficial, Don?

1265
01:03:31,710 --> 01:03:35,460
Why does it matter if I show March
1st at 02:30 in the morning,

1266
01:03:35,460 --> 01:03:37,000
even though it just happened?

1267
01:03:37,000 --> 01:03:39,010
>> If I've got logs across 15 different

1268
01:03:39,010 --> 01:03:39,840
devices
>> Mm-hm.

1269
01:03:39,840 --> 01:03:42,074
>> I may want to see one event
happened at a certain time and

1270
01:03:42,074 --> 01:03:45,000
be able to identify it across all
those different pieces of equipment.

1271
01:03:45,000 --> 01:03:48,500
So having synchronized
clocks is very handy.

1272
01:03:48,500 --> 01:03:51,174
And if you have a network time
server you can use those to,

1273
01:03:51,174 --> 01:03:53,830
Cisco doesn't really push
into it on this exam.

1274
01:03:53,830 --> 01:03:56,350
But in like the CCNA security they do.

1275
01:03:56,350 --> 01:03:59,040
So it does support time
servers if you want, but

1276
01:03:59,040 --> 01:04:01,850
manually setting it here is what
shows up on the CCENT exam.

1277
01:04:03,340 --> 01:04:06,500
Now one other thing I
want to point out is in

1278
01:04:06,500 --> 01:04:09,920
every log message there will
be this time stamp right here.

1279
01:04:09,920 --> 01:04:11,960
There's a couple of problems
with the timestamp.

1280
01:04:11,960 --> 01:04:15,990
All right, first off, actually let me
show you what it normally looks like.

1281
01:04:15,990 --> 01:04:19,160
If I get into config and
get out, all right.

1282
01:04:20,310 --> 01:04:23,581
All right, so here would be
a normal log message right there.

1283
01:04:23,581 --> 01:04:27,660
September 12, 2012 0.519, right?

1284
01:04:27,660 --> 01:04:32,670
So it's telling me that
this happened at 8:20 PM,

1285
01:04:32,670 --> 01:04:36,720
and 12 seconds, and
519 milliseconds, right?

1286
01:04:36,720 --> 01:04:38,510
Very specific time.

1287
01:04:38,510 --> 01:04:40,470
But it also doesn't tell me the time zone.

1288
01:04:40,470 --> 01:04:42,860
I don't know which time zone this is in,
okay.

1289
01:04:42,860 --> 01:04:44,050
So is this Eastern?

1290
01:04:44,050 --> 01:04:45,000
Is it whatever?

1291
01:04:45,000 --> 01:04:47,260
Well, by default, it's UTC.

1292
01:04:47,260 --> 01:04:49,740
It's actually showing it still in UTC,

1293
01:04:49,740 --> 01:04:54,080
even though it knows my time
zone is Eastern Daylight.

1294
01:04:54,080 --> 01:04:57,750
So there's some additional things that
we may want to configure as far as it

1295
01:04:57,750 --> 01:04:59,932
just being this timestamp.

1296
01:04:59,932 --> 01:05:03,530
The timestamp is actually part of
your configuration by default.

1297
01:05:03,530 --> 01:05:07,750
If we do our show running dash config,
it's one of the first commands.

1298
01:05:08,890 --> 01:05:15,570
Here is service, timestamps,
log, datetime and msec.

1299
01:05:15,570 --> 01:05:20,150
So, that means on any log,
include a timestamp of the date and

1300
01:05:20,150 --> 01:05:22,160
time, all the way down to milliseconds.

1301
01:05:22,160 --> 01:05:23,720
>> Right
>> Now, I don't like that.

1302
01:05:23,720 --> 01:05:28,300
I don't like seeing the milliseconds,
cuz, it's not that terrible useful.

1303
01:05:28,300 --> 01:05:31,030
And I like to include
things like the timezone.

1304
01:05:31,030 --> 01:05:32,602
So we're gonna go in and configure that.

1305
01:05:35,760 --> 01:05:38,345
So I'm just gonna say
service timestamps log and

1306
01:05:38,345 --> 01:05:41,130
then we can use the question
mark to kind of guide us.

1307
01:05:41,130 --> 01:05:43,290
What is some of the stuff that we can see?

1308
01:05:43,290 --> 01:05:45,840
Date time is what we normally want.

1309
01:05:45,840 --> 01:05:49,490
On really old Cisco devices,
they used to use the uptime.

1310
01:05:49,490 --> 01:05:51,520
>> Yeah.
>> How long it had been since the device

1311
01:05:51,520 --> 01:05:52,350
rebooted.

1312
01:05:52,350 --> 01:05:53,920
It was a near useless number.

1313
01:05:53,920 --> 01:05:55,680
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I always hated that.

1314
01:05:55,680 --> 01:05:57,950
But we'll go with date time.

1315
01:05:57,950 --> 01:06:00,020
And then you'll see that we can specify.

1316
01:06:00,020 --> 01:06:03,060
Do I want it to be at local time or not?

1317
01:06:03,060 --> 01:06:03,700
Right?

1318
01:06:03,700 --> 01:06:06,290
I want my logs to be in local time.

1319
01:06:06,290 --> 01:06:08,900
But if I have devices in
more than one area, so

1320
01:06:08,900 --> 01:06:13,560
if you have offices in
the Eastern time zone and

1321
01:06:13,560 --> 01:06:18,160
the Pacific time zone,
you may want it to show the time zone,

1322
01:06:18,160 --> 01:06:23,320
also, as part of that time stamp so
that you know what time zone it was in.

1323
01:06:24,620 --> 01:06:26,790
And then lastly we could go
down to the milliseconds.

1324
01:06:26,790 --> 01:06:30,501
I don't normally do that because I
think that it's somewhat of a waste.

1325
01:06:30,501 --> 01:06:31,955
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right so,

1326
01:06:31,955 --> 01:06:35,245
now that I've adjusted that,
when we get log messages,

1327
01:06:35,245 --> 01:06:38,755
there gonna have much more meaningful
information attached to them and so

1328
01:06:38,755 --> 01:06:43,360
I'm gonna get out of config, and we'll
see one of those log messages appear.

1329
01:06:43,360 --> 01:06:44,050
>> Hey, look at that.

1330
01:06:44,050 --> 01:06:44,770
September 12th.

1331
01:06:44,770 --> 01:06:46,930
4:22 PM, Eastern daylight time.

1332
01:06:46,930 --> 01:06:48,268
>> Yep.

1333
01:06:48,268 --> 01:06:49,400
>> Nice.
>> And now it's in our actual time where

1334
01:06:49,400 --> 01:06:52,820
it makes sense, and it lets me know that
it's eastern daylight, so that, again,

1335
01:06:52,820 --> 01:06:57,030
helps with synchronizing other equipment
that may be in different time zones.

1336
01:06:57,030 --> 01:07:00,720
>> Now Don is the best place for a,
we're not gonna get too deep in this,

1337
01:07:00,720 --> 01:07:05,150
but how can I get those messages
where I can see them differently?

1338
01:07:05,150 --> 01:07:07,630
Can I send them off to someplace?

1339
01:07:07,630 --> 01:07:11,890
>> Yeah, you know as far as the CCENT
is concerned your logs right here on

1340
01:07:11,890 --> 01:07:13,130
the router and that's it.

1341
01:07:13,130 --> 01:07:17,350
In the advanced certifications,
they want you to learn some other ways.

1342
01:07:17,350 --> 01:07:17,920
>> Yep.
>> And

1343
01:07:17,920 --> 01:07:20,580
one of the common ways is to use
what's called a syslog server.

1344
01:07:20,580 --> 01:07:23,740
And a syslog server is where
you take these log messages and

1345
01:07:23,740 --> 01:07:25,240
you send them off somewhere else.

1346
01:07:25,240 --> 01:07:30,050
And the reason Ronnie brings it up is
If you're supporting 50 Cisco devices,

1347
01:07:30,050 --> 01:07:32,990
you can set up a single
centralized server.

1348
01:07:32,990 --> 01:07:37,450
All those messages get sent back to
that one place, stored right there, and

1349
01:07:37,450 --> 01:07:40,280
you can then just look in one place
instead of having to go to 50 devices.

1350
01:07:40,280 --> 01:07:44,900
That's where it becomes really important
to synchronize those times because

1351
01:07:44,900 --> 01:07:45,940
you got all the different devices.

1352
01:07:45,940 --> 01:07:46,570
Coexisting.

1353
01:07:47,680 --> 01:07:48,310
>> Yeah.

1354
01:07:48,310 --> 01:07:50,770
You hear that term quite
often a lot of times.

1355
01:07:50,770 --> 01:07:54,000
Even in just regular networking,
they talk about check the syslog server.

1356
01:07:54,000 --> 01:07:57,020
So at least even at this point, even
though we aren't getting in to configuring

1357
01:07:57,020 --> 01:07:59,500
one or how to send our messages to one.

1358
01:07:59,500 --> 01:08:01,940
We do want to at least know that
that term exists at this point.

1359
01:08:01,940 --> 01:08:03,200
>> Yeah.
Basically everything except

1360
01:08:03,200 --> 01:08:04,910
Microsoft Windows uses syslog.

1361
01:08:04,910 --> 01:08:06,000
Right?
So Linux.

1362
01:08:06,000 --> 01:08:12,310
OSX, Unix, BSD, Cisco routers, Juniper
routers, you know, they all use sys log.

1363
01:08:12,310 --> 01:08:14,850
Microsoft is the only one that uses
their own little event viewer,

1364
01:08:14,850 --> 01:08:20,110
which even that you could output to

It means, that I have actually

00:11:37,670 --> 00:11:41,040
All right, now that kinda ran under my

00:11:41,040 --> 00:11:44,650
When Cisco writes a MAC address,
they write it this way.

00:11:44,650 --> 00:11:47,500
Four digits and a period,
four more digits and a period, and

230
00:11:47,500 --> 00:11:49,030

231
00:11:49,030 --> 00:11:53,620
So in Windows, I saw it as two digits and
a hyphen, two and a hyphen.

232
00:11:53,620 --> 00:11:57,020
Different vendors write it different ways,
but Cisco writes it this way.

233
00:11:57,020 --> 00:12:00,708
And so what I'm doing, is I'm saying,
show me the MAC address table for

00:12:00,708 --> 00:12:02,110

00:12:02,110 --> 00:12:04,280
I'm looking for
this MAC address, specifically.

00:12:05,870 --> 00:12:08,050
Right now,
the switch doesn't know about it.

00:12:08,050 --> 00:12:10,300

00:12:10,300 --> 00:12:11,870

00:12:11,870 --> 00:12:14,465

00:12:14,465 --> 00:12:18,880
is because of the way that Cisco
switches learn about the MAC addresses.

00:12:18,880 --> 00:12:22,460
Now, this is very important for you,

00:12:22,460 --> 00:12:27,990
Cisco switches learn about the MAC

243
00:12:27,990 --> 00:12:31,220
So, if you're sending data, you're
gonna have a source MAC address, and

244
00:12:31,220 --> 00:12:32,900
destination MAC address.

245
00:12:32,900 --> 00:12:35,641
When you actually send data,
that is the one that it learns and

246
00:12:35,641 --> 00:12:38,766
associates with that port, so
the source MAC address is the key here.

247
00:12:38,766 --> 00:12:44,089
>> So I'm gonna plug my cable in, and once
I plug in, within the first 30 seconds,

248
00:12:44,089 --> 00:12:47,730
the switch will learn about
my MAC address, all right?

249
00:12:47,730 --> 00:12:48,427
So, I'm gonna do that.

250
00:12:48,427 --> 00:12:51,617
I'm plugged into port number,
what is this, port number 2, so

251
00:12:51,617 --> 00:12:53,647
I'm just gonna plug into port number 2,

252
00:12:53,647 --> 00:12:57,520
we should get a message here in
a second about port number 2 coming up.

253
00:12:57,520 --> 00:13:01,450
Now, this switch is running something
called Spanning Tree Protocol.

254
00:13:01,450 --> 00:13:03,520
And we haven't covered
that in our show yet.

255
00:13:03,520 --> 00:13:05,780
It's a loop protection mechanism.

256
00:13:05,780 --> 00:13:09,590
While the port is gonna come up, it may
actually stay down for a little bit.

257
00:13:09,590 --> 00:13:11,780
Looking at the front of me,
here I see an orange light.

258
00:13:11,780 --> 00:13:15,240
So, I have to wait 30 seconds for
the loop detection to finish.

259
00:13:15,240 --> 00:13:17,276
So I am just going to give it a moment,
while it does that.

260
00:13:17,276 --> 00:13:21,270
So while it says the port is up, I'm
not actually allowed to talk right now.

261
00:13:21,270 --> 00:13:23,520
Not until this port goes green back here.

262
00:13:23,520 --> 00:13:25,090
And it does take 30 seconds.

263
00:13:25,090 --> 00:13:30,150
Basically, for 15 seconds, it listens to
see if there's a switch on the other side,

264
00:13:30,150 --> 00:13:32,250
if there's a switch that
might be creating a loop.

265
00:13:32,250 --> 00:13:36,416
If there isn't, then for the next 15
seconds, it tries to learn my MAC address,

266
00:13:36,416 --> 00:13:38,330
and still verify there's no switch.

267
00:13:38,330 --> 00:13:43,788
After 30 seconds of loop-free
connectivity, the port actually comes up.

268
00:13:43,788 --> 00:13:50,950
If I did create a loop, it would shut my
port down, and I'd never be able to talk.

269
00:13:50,950 --> 00:13:53,250
So loop detection is a good thing.

270
00:13:53,250 --> 00:13:55,050
Am I still, nope, I'm green.

271
00:13:55,050 --> 00:13:56,760
So now I'm actually up.

272
00:13:56,760 --> 00:14:01,970

00:14:01,970 --> 00:14:04,030

00:14:04,030 --> 00:14:06,230

00:14:06,230 --> 00:14:09,690
The switch has learned that I'm there,
there's my MAC address, and

276
00:14:09,690 --> 00:14:10,760

00:14:10,760 --> 00:14:11,260

00:14:12,430 --> 00:14:14,820

I filtered the output on this command.

00:14:14,820 --> 00:14:16,280

>> And I did that,

00:14:16,280 --> 00:14:18,455
because if I just tried

00:14:18,455 --> 00:14:21,670

>> If I just looked at the full address

00:14:21,670 --> 00:14:25,250
table, right, I would have to go
through this screen by screen, and say,

00:14:25,250 --> 00:14:27,630
all right, where is 1770?

284
00:14:27,630 --> 00:14:28,820
Trying to find 1770.

And you could be here a while, right?

It's actually sorted by MAC address,

This particular command, show MAC

00:22:10,440 --> 00:22:11,090

00:22:11,090 --> 00:22:13,200
Is the very beginning of networking for

443
00:22:13,200 --> 00:22:17,170
We either have the idea here,
of what we call, a contentious networks.

444
00:22:17,170 --> 00:22:21,120
In which all the devices are either
competing for access on the wire.

445
00:22:21,120 --> 00:22:23,250
Or we have the idea of deterministic,

446
00:22:23,250 --> 00:22:28,640
in which a single device, says who gets
access to use that wire at any one point.

447
00:22:28,640 --> 00:22:32,570
In switching technology, and in the basic
networking that we would've done at

448
00:22:32,570 --> 00:22:36,660
the very beginning here, we would have
actually used the idea of the competitive

449
00:22:36,660 --> 00:22:40,875
model, especially in terms of Ethernet and
switches and hubs.

450
00:22:40,875 --> 00:22:43,029
[COUGH] Excuse me as well, okay?

451
00:22:43,029 --> 00:22:47,660
And so that for us means that we had
to have some type of technology right?

452
00:22:47,660 --> 00:22:54,226
And that would be what
we called CSMA .Carrier.

453
00:22:54,226 --> 00:22:55,440
>> Carrier sense multiple access.

454
00:22:55,440 --> 00:22:57,630
>> Multiple access with
collision detection.

455
00:22:57,630 --> 00:22:58,830
I couldn't remember what the M.

456
00:22:58,830 --> 00:23:01,640
>> That's it, so that's what I
just put on my whiteboard here,

457
00:23:01,640 --> 00:23:06,000
so CSMACD, carrier sense multiple
access/collision detection.

458
00:23:06,000 --> 00:23:06,680
So what is that?

459
00:23:06,680 --> 00:23:08,630
Let's take it in pieces, right?

460
00:23:08,630 --> 00:23:14,210
So first off, if we have a bunch of
computers that are plugged into a switch,

461
00:23:14,210 --> 00:23:19,750
right, so if I take these computer, and
I'll just kinda virtually plug them in.

462
00:23:21,610 --> 00:23:25,954
And basically, when I have
these computers plugged in, and

463
00:23:25,954 --> 00:23:28,607
they wanna talk, well, with a hub.

464
00:23:28,607 --> 00:23:30,798
>> Mm-hm.
>> Two people can't talk at the same time.

465
00:23:30,798 --> 00:23:32,764
>> Right.
>> If two people talk, they collide, and

466
00:23:32,764 --> 00:23:34,370
we have a problem, right?

467
00:23:34,370 --> 00:23:36,590
With a switch, that MAC address table,

468
00:23:36,590 --> 00:23:39,760
that technology really helps
us to avoid that situation.

469
00:23:39,760 --> 00:23:42,000
So, when a PC goes to talk.

470
00:23:42,000 --> 00:23:43,520
So let's take.

471
00:23:43,520 --> 00:23:46,485
Each of these, I should give them names so
I can tell them apart.

472
00:23:46,485 --> 00:23:49,870
>> [LAUGH]
>> So like if this is PC1,

473
00:23:49,870 --> 00:23:53,790
and then the other guys are out there.

474
00:23:53,790 --> 00:23:54,761
So we'll say.

475
00:23:54,761 --> 00:23:59,289
We'll make this guy down here PC4.

476
00:23:59,289 --> 00:24:00,472
Whoops.

477
00:24:00,472 --> 00:24:02,007
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not gonna go crazy with here.

478
00:24:02,007 --> 00:24:02,545
All right.

479
00:24:02,545 --> 00:24:04,898
So if PC1 goes to talk to PC4,

480
00:24:04,898 --> 00:24:11,000
when it goes to talk that communication
is going to pass into the switch.

481
00:24:11,000 --> 00:24:14,850
The switch is gonna look at it and say,
that's destined for a MAC address that I

482
00:24:14,850 --> 00:24:19,330
know, it's gonna send it along to the port
where it knows that MAC address is.

483
00:24:19,330 --> 00:24:21,650
And it's gonna go on down to that client.

484
00:24:21,650 --> 00:24:26,140
The cool part about this,
is that it frees up the other PCs.

485
00:24:26,140 --> 00:24:32,850
So, if I have PC2 and PC3,
that these guys are available and

486
00:24:32,850 --> 00:24:36,661
ready to communicate without

487
00:24:36,661 --> 00:24:42,180
having to interfere or
wait with PC1 and PC4.

488
00:24:43,200 --> 00:24:48,880
So on a switch based network, I can
have more than one pair of PCs talking.

489
00:24:49,960 --> 00:24:54,100
But, if two of them were to
talk at the same time and

490
00:24:54,100 --> 00:24:57,920
their traffic were to cross paths,
we end up with a collision.

491
00:24:57,920 --> 00:25:01,380
So, on hubs it was real important that
the PCs were able to detect that.

492
00:25:01,380 --> 00:25:04,650
And I say PCs, any ethernet device.

493
00:25:04,650 --> 00:25:07,310
This was a part of the ethernet standard.

494
00:25:07,310 --> 00:25:09,270
So CSMA, let's start with that.

495
00:25:09,270 --> 00:25:11,240
Carrier Sense Multiple Access.

496
00:25:11,240 --> 00:25:15,900
If PC1 is about to talk,
the first thing it does is, listen.

497
00:25:15,900 --> 00:25:20,780
It says let me listen to the line,
and see if somebody else is talking.

498
00:25:20,780 --> 00:25:25,160
If PC1 is talking,
PC2 would listen and hear, and say,

499
00:25:25,160 --> 00:25:28,220
all right, I'm not gonna talk, I'm just
gonna stay quiet until PC1 is done.

500
00:25:30,420 --> 00:25:33,280
>> So, when we take a look at this then,
the idea of multiple access is that

501
00:25:33,280 --> 00:25:37,390
we have multiple devices sharing,
essentially, that same medium.

502
00:25:37,390 --> 00:25:42,440
Or that same domain, I guess is probably
the proper way to think about this.

503
00:25:42,440 --> 00:25:48,020
So, every device that's on this type of
technology that we're using, CSMACD, here.

504
00:25:48,020 --> 00:25:51,270
Is, again,
all of them are actually listening, okay?

505
00:25:51,270 --> 00:25:55,020
So, every single one is
listening to see who's talking.

506
00:25:55,020 --> 00:25:58,720
If somebody else is talking, they say I'm
gonna be quiet at this particular point.

507
00:25:59,800 --> 00:26:03,410
>> Then when they do talk, there's
still the risk that maybe two people

508
00:26:03,410 --> 00:26:06,840
were listening at the same time,
maybe PC2 and three were both listening,

509
00:26:06,840 --> 00:26:09,690
they heard that it was silent and
they both try to talk at the same time.

510
00:26:09,690 --> 00:26:13,760
So then, once they talk,
they do collision detection.

511
00:26:13,760 --> 00:26:16,060
That just means they continue to listen,

512
00:26:16,060 --> 00:26:20,890
because if there is a collision
the electrical signals will collide.

513
00:26:20,890 --> 00:26:25,610
>> Yeah, they'll centrally form
a voltage spike is what will happen.

514
00:26:25,610 --> 00:26:27,780
Once that voltage spike ends up happening,

515
00:26:27,780 --> 00:26:31,770
those two devices sense that
voltage spike had to be mine.

516
00:26:31,770 --> 00:26:36,270
So that means, I had a collision, so
let me try and do something else.

517
00:26:36,270 --> 00:26:38,399
>> And so
they'll wait a random amount of time.

518
00:26:38,399 --> 00:26:39,360
Now it's got to be random,

519
00:26:39,360 --> 00:26:41,580
cuz otherwise they would both just
wait the same amount of time.

520
00:26:41,580 --> 00:26:43,980
So, they wait a random amount of time and
then they retransmit, all right?

521
00:26:43,980 --> 00:26:47,960
It's very inefficient switches
help us to avoid that.

522
00:26:47,960 --> 00:26:50,500
>> All right, and this is why we're
circling back to this is you're not gonna

523
00:26:50,500 --> 00:26:52,420
use hubs in real life anymore.

524
00:26:52,420 --> 00:26:54,490
Switches help us to avoid this,

525
00:26:54,490 --> 00:27:00,210
because on a switch PC1 isn't
actually talking to PC4 at all.

526
00:27:00,210 --> 00:27:02,490
PC1 never truly touches PC4.

527
00:27:03,500 --> 00:27:08,510
PC1 instead, is talking to
a memory buffer on the switch.

528
00:27:08,510 --> 00:27:13,780
On the switch, every single port
has a little memory buffer on it,

529
00:27:13,780 --> 00:27:16,030
and so when PC1 goes to talk.

530
00:27:16,030 --> 00:27:18,530
When it goes to send
that communication along.

531
00:27:18,530 --> 00:27:22,180
It's actually writing to a memory
buffer on that first port.

532
00:27:22,180 --> 00:27:25,580
Now, is anybody else
able to talk on port one?

533
00:27:25,580 --> 00:27:29,425
No, and that means that PC1
cannot possibly collide.

534
00:27:29,425 --> 00:27:31,960
PC1 cannot get a collision.

535
00:27:31,960 --> 00:27:34,750
The only person it can
collide with itself.

536
00:27:34,750 --> 00:27:39,280
And so we do still have CSMACD, but

537
00:27:39,280 --> 00:27:42,980
it doesn't really serve much purpose,
unless something's wrong with the switch,

538
00:27:42,980 --> 00:27:46,530
and the switch has to
flip over into hub mode.

539
00:27:46,530 --> 00:27:47,260
>> Yeah and

540
00:27:47,260 --> 00:27:51,680
so, when we start taking a look at this
here, this is why we wanna use switches.

541
00:27:51,680 --> 00:27:55,480
If you get a choice between a switch and
a hub, a switch is a clear choice.

542
00:27:55,480 --> 00:28:00,939
Because it really does help us to not have
to worry, about the idea of CSMA/CD here.

543
00:28:02,050 --> 00:28:05,550
With only one device needed to
communicate on that one port.

544
00:28:05,550 --> 00:28:07,408
Essentially that's what
ended up happening here.

545
00:28:07,408 --> 00:28:11,990
Is that we've limited any collisions,
that may happen to that one port.

546
00:28:11,990 --> 00:28:13,880
We only have one device attached to it.

547
00:28:13,880 --> 00:28:15,620
So, it's gonna climb with itself.

548
00:28:15,620 --> 00:28:17,800
Don't get me wrong, there's probably
[LAUGH] ways we can make it happen.

549
00:28:17,800 --> 00:28:23,160
If you did something like plug a hub into
the switch and then plug two devices in

550
00:28:23,160 --> 00:28:28,600
that one hub, but we're probably not gonna
do and hopefully we'll never see that.

551
00:28:28,600 --> 00:28:33,598
>> Yeah, now here's the other cool part,
let's say that PC1, 2,

552
00:28:33,598 --> 00:28:37,660
and 3 all want to talk
to PC4 at the same time.

553
00:28:37,660 --> 00:28:40,890
Well, PC1, PC2, and
PC3 can send their communication.

554
00:28:40,890 --> 00:28:43,620
They're gonna go to the memory
buffers on the switch, and

555
00:28:43,620 --> 00:28:47,190
what the switch is gonna do is it's gonna
move them across what's called the back

556
00:28:47,190 --> 00:28:49,700
plane, the circuitry on
the back of the switch.

557
00:28:49,700 --> 00:28:53,290
Now, because of the switch handling that,

558
00:28:53,290 --> 00:28:56,240
it's basically viewed as traffic
from the same person at that point.

559
00:28:56,240 --> 00:28:58,970
You can't have collisions
on the back plain either.

560
00:28:58,970 --> 00:29:02,600
So, this data is all able
to move simultaneously.

561
00:29:02,600 --> 00:29:04,980
And then this switch does
what is called queueing.

562
00:29:04,980 --> 00:29:08,630
Puts all this data in line, and then
starts to send it on the rest of the way.

563
00:29:08,630 --> 00:29:12,370
So, maybe PC3 was first, so
it gets to come through.

564
00:29:12,370 --> 00:29:15,920
And then after that maybe PC2 was next,
and it gets to come through.

565
00:29:15,920 --> 00:29:18,730
And then finally PC1 gets its chance.

566
00:29:18,730 --> 00:29:23,420
And all that data makes it over to PC4,
without a collision.

567
00:29:23,420 --> 00:29:26,890
So, back in the day when you bought a hub
there was usually a little light on it

568
00:29:26,890 --> 00:29:29,660
that said collision, and
you could see it flashing.

569
00:29:29,660 --> 00:29:33,290
In the days of switches today,
there are no collision lights.

570
00:29:33,290 --> 00:29:35,230
There's no collision light
on the switch behind me, and

571
00:29:35,230 --> 00:29:37,940
that's because they just don't
have collisions like before.

572
00:29:37,940 --> 00:29:40,150
Now, they do still have collisions,
it can happen.

573
00:29:40,150 --> 00:29:45,150
But it's not very common, and that's
because your PC is talking to the port.

574
00:29:45,150 --> 00:29:50,090
So, each port is said to
be a collision domain.

575
00:29:50,090 --> 00:29:53,710
A collision domain is simply a group
of computers that are able to collide

576
00:29:53,710 --> 00:29:54,278
with each other.

577
00:29:54,278 --> 00:29:58,466
In a hub based network,
the whole network is one collision domain.

578
00:29:58,466 --> 00:30:04,575
In a switch based network, every single
port is its own collision domain.

579
00:30:04,575 --> 00:30:08,135
So, I drew a five port switch,
it's got five collision domains.

580
00:30:08,135 --> 00:30:12,135
I've got a 48 port switch behind me,
it's got 48 collision domains.

581
00:30:12,135 --> 00:30:13,445
Remember that for the exam.

582
00:30:13,445 --> 00:30:14,130
>> Yeah.

583
00:30:14,130 --> 00:30:16,910
And so that, don't forget,
in going backwards with that.

584
00:30:16,910 --> 00:30:17,760
With a hub,

585
00:30:17,760 --> 00:30:23,330
if you get a 12 port hub, all 12 ports
are in one collision domain as well.

586
00:30:23,330 --> 00:30:24,790
So, just the opposite here.

587
00:30:24,790 --> 00:30:27,085
So again, good thing to remember for
the exam here.

588
00:30:27,085 --> 00:30:28,145
>> Yep.

589
00:30:28,145 --> 00:30:30,725
All right,
looks like we're right up on break time.

00:30:30,725 --> 00:30:32,245

591
00:30:32,245 --> 00:30:35,935

but let's stop and take a break.

592

When we get back,
we're gonna dive a little bit more into

I wanna talk a little bit more about,
those memory buffers on the switch.

So, we need to tackle that

600
00:31:03,719 --> 00:31:05,600
