601
00:31:05,600 --> 00:31:10,450
So before the break, I did forget to
mention one thing that was important.

602
00:31:10,450 --> 00:31:13,160
We were talking about
the MAC address table.

603
00:31:13,160 --> 00:31:16,210
And as you read through various books and
things like that, that are out there and

604
00:31:16,210 --> 00:31:19,660
you'll hear or
refer to the MAC address table.

605
00:31:19,660 --> 00:31:23,470
And you'll MAC,
all capital Media Access Control.

606
00:31:23,470 --> 00:31:24,420
MAC address table.

607
00:31:25,570 --> 00:31:28,880
Then you'll hear sometimes
be refered to the CAM table.

608
00:31:28,880 --> 00:31:32,100
And if you're [LAUGH] like me the first
time I read it a long time ago.

609
00:31:32,100 --> 00:31:34,440
I remember reading and I'm like,
why did they write it backwards?

610
00:31:34,440 --> 00:31:35,710
What's wrong with these people?

611
00:31:35,710 --> 00:31:40,610
But, they're not referring to
the logical table like we think of.

612
00:31:40,610 --> 00:31:45,881
The CAM table, is actually referring
to the actual hardware chip,

613
00:31:45,881 --> 00:31:51,720
the little memory chip that's embedded
on the motherboard of the switch.

614
00:31:51,720 --> 00:31:54,367
And that's where the MAC
address table is stored.

615
00:31:54,367 --> 00:31:56,827
But that chip that CAM table.

616
00:31:56,827 --> 00:31:59,219
Well it's called the CAM table so.

617
00:31:59,219 --> 00:32:02,191
It actually stands for
content addressable memory.

618
00:32:02,191 --> 00:32:04,340
And so that's exactly what it is.

619
00:32:04,340 --> 00:32:07,680
The memory module,
that's actually on the motherboard itself.

620
00:32:07,680 --> 00:32:09,936
And so
a lot of times when you do read about,

621
00:32:09,936 --> 00:32:13,578
especially in older Cisco writings,
you see CAM table everywhere,

622
00:32:13,578 --> 00:32:17,570
most of the books today seem to
just refer to the address table.

623
00:32:17,570 --> 00:32:18,970
>> But on the exam you can see either,

624
00:32:18,970 --> 00:32:21,700
that's why it was important
that we bring it up here?

625
00:32:21,700 --> 00:32:23,070
So yeah, that is out there.

626
00:32:23,070 --> 00:32:25,360
So just be aware that really,
the MAC address table and

627
00:32:25,360 --> 00:32:27,090
the CAM table are basically
the same thing.

628
00:32:27,090 --> 00:32:30,880
The CAM table talking about the physical
hardware that stores the data,

629
00:32:30,880 --> 00:32:34,070
the MAC address table being
the logical data that is in it.

630
00:32:34,070 --> 00:32:36,970
>> Now, before the break Don, you had
mentioned the idea of actually taking

631
00:32:36,970 --> 00:32:40,260
a look at each of the ports and
we had talked about that buffer content.

632
00:32:40,260 --> 00:32:42,950
And so that's actually really
important for us isn't it?

633
00:32:42,950 --> 00:32:45,740
>> There is another thing,
that can show up on the exam,

634
00:32:45,740 --> 00:32:47,755
although in real life we don't
worry about it so much anymore.

635
00:32:47,755 --> 00:32:53,618
Back in the day, [CROSSTALK] you
have to know it to build onto it.

636
00:32:53,618 --> 00:32:57,174
So back in the day,
when you bought a Cisco switch,

637
00:32:57,174 --> 00:33:01,940
you could pick one of three
different operating modes for it.

638
00:33:01,940 --> 00:33:04,560
Today's switches,
we don't really have that anymore,

639
00:33:04,560 --> 00:33:06,900
because the technology's gotten so
much more advanced.

640
00:33:06,900 --> 00:33:11,730
But, there's actually three different
modes that a Cisco switch can function in.

641
00:33:13,110 --> 00:33:19,040
The original switches way back in the day,
that didn't really have buffers

642
00:33:19,040 --> 00:33:22,080
on their ports that were just trying
to move data as quickly as possible.

643
00:33:22,080 --> 00:33:24,410
They were what were called
cut-through switches.

644
00:33:24,410 --> 00:33:25,801
They did cut-through switching.

645
00:33:25,801 --> 00:33:30,530
And cut-through switching just meant, if
I started to send a frame, and remember,

646
00:33:30,530 --> 00:33:33,960
a frame is gonna be less than 1518 bytes.

647
00:33:33,960 --> 00:33:37,770
And usually your operating system
will cap it at about 1500,

648
00:33:37,770 --> 00:33:42,600
so when I send data on a switch network,
I'm usually sending about 1500 bytes.

649
00:33:42,600 --> 00:33:46,680
When the first byte hits the switch,
it's immediately sending it

650
00:33:46,680 --> 00:33:49,465
to it's destination as soon as it can,
just forwarding it along.

651
00:33:49,465 --> 00:33:53,640
Cut-through switches are very fast and
that first byte,

652
00:33:53,640 --> 00:33:56,860
maybe the first couple of bytes before
it can see the destination MAC address.

653
00:33:56,860 --> 00:33:59,130
It's got to at least see
the destination MAC address, and

654
00:33:59,130 --> 00:34:03,070
it is forwarding right of just
bat as quickly as it can.

655
00:34:03,070 --> 00:34:05,690
The second type of switch that
we wanna talk about here,

656
00:34:05,690 --> 00:34:10,050
is also gonna be the idea of what we
call the fragment free switching, okay?

657
00:34:10,050 --> 00:34:12,220
Now when we talk about
the idea of fragment free,

658
00:34:12,220 --> 00:34:15,180
unlike the cut through which is just
really wanting for that destination MAC

659
00:34:15,180 --> 00:34:20,590
address, I've gotta assume this is
done off the idea of statistics.

660
00:34:20,590 --> 00:34:23,680
I'm gonna say that Cisco and a whole bunch
of other companies, what they've done is,

661
00:34:23,680 --> 00:34:28,230
over billions of frames that have come
across, is that they've noticed something.

662
00:34:28,230 --> 00:34:31,110
That they said look, when we actually
take a look at all this stuff,

663
00:34:31,110 --> 00:34:35,420
the first 64 bytes of the frame
is what's actually important.

664
00:34:35,420 --> 00:34:41,680
Because that's where they found 99.97%,
of all fragmentation that tends to happen.

665
00:34:41,680 --> 00:34:46,620
>> And by fragmentation, we mean
corruption and slowdowns and everything.

666
00:34:46,620 --> 00:34:49,650
And so once it actually started doing
that, then they started actually building

667
00:34:49,650 --> 00:34:52,280
and saying,
look maybe this is what we need to do.

668
00:34:52,280 --> 00:34:55,910
If we can examine the first
64 bytes of data, and

669
00:34:55,910 --> 00:34:59,910
there is no corruption, no fragmentation
anything, let's go ahead and

670
00:34:59,910 --> 00:35:02,490
forward that on to
the destination port itself.

671
00:35:02,490 --> 00:35:04,860
And what that means to us,
is those switches,

672
00:35:04,860 --> 00:35:09,020
the switches that do fragment free
switching, they need a buffer of at least

673
00:35:09,020 --> 00:35:14,650
64 bytes to be able to store
that first bit of data.

674
00:35:14,650 --> 00:35:17,510
To be able to look at it,
make sure that it wasn't corrupted, and

675
00:35:17,510 --> 00:35:18,450
then start to send along.

676
00:35:18,450 --> 00:35:20,830
Cut-through didn't need that,
cuz it was sending immediately.

677
00:35:20,830 --> 00:35:24,220
So, even if the frame was damaged,
cut-through would still forward it.

678
00:35:24,220 --> 00:35:25,680
Even though it was bad data,

679
00:35:25,680 --> 00:35:29,210
fragment free would detect where
the bulk of that error was.

680
00:35:29,210 --> 00:35:35,120
And stop it if it was damaged or
forward along it's 64 path.

681
00:35:35,120 --> 00:35:36,950
>> Now,
when we start taking a look at this,

682
00:35:36,950 --> 00:35:40,590
on both of those there's a chance
that fragments can still happen.

683
00:35:40,590 --> 00:35:44,010
There's a chance that corruption
can still continue to happen here.

684
00:35:44,010 --> 00:35:47,860
So with the cut-through, it means that
the receiving devices, the one that

685
00:35:47,860 --> 00:35:51,570
has to notice it, and then transmit
a message back to the sender and say,

686
00:35:51,570 --> 00:35:56,320
you need to retransmit this particular
frame, because something is wrong with it.

687
00:35:56,320 --> 00:35:59,130
So it has to go the whole path, and
essentially what has to happen then is

688
00:35:59,130 --> 00:36:02,630
that, that same frame has to
be sent a couple of times.

689
00:36:02,630 --> 00:36:06,520
With the fragment free there's
a possibility, but it's less likely, okay?

690
00:36:06,520 --> 00:36:08,860
And so these are actually fairly common.

691
00:36:08,860 --> 00:36:12,140
Now, Don's gonna actually tell us about
this last one, which is more hefty here.

692
00:36:12,140 --> 00:36:14,786
>> The last one, back in the day.

693
00:36:14,786 --> 00:36:16,850
>> [LAUGH]
>> Was extremely cost-prohibitive.

694
00:36:16,850 --> 00:36:18,050
Very, expensive.

695
00:36:18,050 --> 00:36:20,260
It was called Store and Forward.

696
00:36:20,260 --> 00:36:25,850
Store and Forward switches, would receive
the entire frame, the whole 1500 bytes.

697
00:36:25,850 --> 00:36:28,920
It would receive that whole frame, and

698
00:36:28,920 --> 00:36:33,030
stick it into a memory buffer, and look at
it to make sure that it wasn't corrupt.

699
00:36:33,030 --> 00:36:35,120
And if it wasn't corrupt,
it would send it along.

700
00:36:35,120 --> 00:36:36,590
If it was corrupt it would stop it.

701
00:36:36,590 --> 00:36:41,290
So a Store and
Forward switch would actually ensure,

702
00:36:41,290 --> 00:36:43,810
that corrupted frames are never
sent along that's great.

703
00:36:43,810 --> 00:36:47,130
But, you needed a lot of memory for
each port on the switch.

704
00:36:47,130 --> 00:36:48,860
And so it was extremely cost prohibitive.

705
00:36:48,860 --> 00:36:54,650
Well, today, that kind of memory is
extremely cheap, pennies on the dollar.

706
00:36:54,650 --> 00:36:56,700
So, it was not an expensive thing.

707
00:36:56,700 --> 00:36:59,790
The technology is far less
expensive than it used to be.

708
00:36:59,790 --> 00:37:04,670
So when you buy a switch today,
you don't really pick the modes any more.

709
00:37:04,670 --> 00:37:09,222
Now, you buy the switch and it'll
usually either be hard set as Store and

710
00:37:09,222 --> 00:37:13,399
Forward or it'll hard set as
fragment free, but you don't pick,

711
00:37:13,399 --> 00:37:18,782
its not something software configurable,
its just a function of the switch itself.

712
00:37:18,782 --> 00:37:22,442
It's burned in, hard-coded, and
that's just kind of the end of it.

713
00:37:22,442 --> 00:37:25,971
But, on the exam,
understand that switches can operate,

714
00:37:25,971 --> 00:37:29,403
Cisco switches,
can operate in three different modes.

715
00:37:29,403 --> 00:37:33,180
Cut-through, for
the data as fast as we can.

716
00:37:33,180 --> 00:37:36,020
Fragment free,
check out the first 64 bytes,

717
00:37:36,020 --> 00:37:38,230
make sure it's okay, then send it along.

718
00:37:38,230 --> 00:37:42,210
Storing forward, check out the entire
frame, and then send it along,

719
00:37:42,210 --> 00:37:43,300
those are our three.

720
00:37:43,300 --> 00:37:45,900
A lot of times when people are concerned
about the idea of performance,

721
00:37:45,900 --> 00:37:48,650
they may go, let's go with
a cut-through switch if we can.

722
00:37:48,650 --> 00:37:51,130
And even though that seems
like a good idea, but

723
00:37:51,130 --> 00:37:54,140
remember, if there's a fragment
it has to be retransmitted.

724
00:37:54,140 --> 00:37:57,940
The idea of the, of fragment free,

725
00:37:57,940 --> 00:38:02,430
the Store and
Forward may seem relatively slow.

726
00:38:02,430 --> 00:38:06,670
But the nice thing about it is that
it actually checks the entire thing.

727
00:38:06,670 --> 00:38:08,550
So, it's only gonna transmit it one time.

728
00:38:08,550 --> 00:38:11,454
So there's trade offs but
content, or the Store and

729
00:38:11,454 --> 00:38:14,231
Forward is probably the way
that we'd rather go.

730
00:38:14,231 --> 00:38:15,623
>> And we say relatively slow,

731
00:38:15,623 --> 00:38:19,516
we're talking about the difference of
5 nanoseconds versus 2 nanoseconds.

732
00:38:19,516 --> 00:38:24,281
So it's not really a significant
number to us as humans,

733
00:38:24,281 --> 00:38:27,889
to computers it's
>> [LAUGH]

734
00:38:27,889 --> 00:38:29,740
>> All right, so those were,

735
00:38:29,740 --> 00:38:33,800
I think the last of the general switching

736
00:38:33,800 --> 00:38:35,980
topics that I can think of-
>> Sounds good.

737
00:38:35,980 --> 00:38:39,040
>> I'm trying to think if there's
anything else that I'm leaving out here?

738
00:38:39,040 --> 00:38:40,880
I think that really does it,

739
00:38:42,290 --> 00:38:45,240
the other that I do wanna
mention are broadcast domains.

740
00:38:45,240 --> 00:38:50,430
We talked about how on a switch, every
single port is its own collision domain.

741
00:38:50,430 --> 00:38:52,220
But broadcasts are broadcasts.

742
00:38:52,220 --> 00:38:55,220
When you send a broadcast it is
flooded out every other port for

743
00:38:55,220 --> 00:38:56,710
the other devices to see.

744
00:38:56,710 --> 00:39:01,680
So, even though every port of
a switch is its own collision domain,

745
00:39:01,680 --> 00:39:05,250
the whole switch is still
one broadcast domain.

746
00:39:05,250 --> 00:39:08,540
So, when you read that question on
the exam, make sure you do a double-check.

747
00:39:08,540 --> 00:39:11,240
Are they asking about broadcast domains or
collision domains?

748
00:39:11,240 --> 00:39:15,400
Because on a hub or a switch,
it's just one broadcast domain.

749
00:39:15,400 --> 00:39:20,330
On a hub, it's one collision domain, on
a switch, it's multiple collision domains,

750
00:39:20,330 --> 00:39:21,420
one for every single port.

751
00:39:21,420 --> 00:39:22,800
So, be aware of that.

752
00:39:22,800 --> 00:39:23,700
>> Yep, sounds good.

>> All right,
the next thing we wanna tackle on,

00:39:26,790 --> 00:39:31,190
is something that Ronnie mentioned
briefly earlier, and I mentioned earlier.

755
00:39:31,190 --> 00:39:32,210
VLANs.

756
00:39:32,210 --> 00:39:34,680
VLANs are virtual local area networks, and

757
00:39:34,680 --> 00:39:38,580
they're really cool, when I first
started learning Cisco myself.

758
00:39:38,580 --> 00:39:41,502
So, I started working with
Cisco equipment in 1998.

759
00:39:41,502 --> 00:39:46,300
And the devices back then, a lot of
the Cisco switches didn't support VLANs,

760
00:39:46,300 --> 00:39:49,513
and so it was a new feature
that we're just getting.

761
00:39:49,513 --> 00:39:52,183
Wasn't even on the CCNA exam back then.

762
00:39:52,183 --> 00:39:53,203
Today.

763
00:39:53,203 --> 00:39:54,759
Every Cisco switch supports them.

764
00:39:54,759 --> 00:39:57,128
It's all over the place,
and it's all over the exam.

765
00:39:57,128 --> 00:39:58,289
So we need to be familiar with it.

766
00:39:58,289 --> 00:40:01,180
>> Yeah, there's a lot of times
when people say that, hey,

767
00:40:01,180 --> 00:40:03,620
my network doesn't
support any VLANs at all.

768
00:40:03,620 --> 00:40:04,980
We don't worry about that.

769
00:40:04,980 --> 00:40:08,830
Now, even though what they are really
saying is that all of their switches

770
00:40:08,830 --> 00:40:13,030
are on one network, which is fine,
they really are on a VLAN whether or

771
00:40:13,030 --> 00:40:14,100
not they know it or not.

772
00:40:14,100 --> 00:40:15,954
Especially if they're
using Cisco switches here.

773
00:40:15,954 --> 00:40:19,960
So we wanna make sure that we understand
this concept of a virtual LAN,

774
00:40:19,960 --> 00:40:22,265
that's what VLAN stands for for us here.

775
00:40:22,265 --> 00:40:24,960
And so we're gonna actually just
talk about that a little bit here.

776
00:40:24,960 --> 00:40:28,390
>> Yeah, so normally when you get
a switch, you get one physical switch.

777
00:40:28,390 --> 00:40:31,440
And it has a bunch of ports on it,
like this one with 48 ports, right?

778
00:40:31,440 --> 00:40:35,866
So I've got 48 ports that are all in one
network and that's the end of it, right?

779
00:40:35,866 --> 00:40:40,750
What a VLAN allows us to do is to
take that one physical switch.

780
00:40:40,750 --> 00:40:43,701
And break it up into
multiple virtual switches.

781
00:40:43,701 --> 00:40:46,789
So I could take my 48-port switch and
divide it in half.

782
00:40:46,789 --> 00:40:52,670
And I could have one 24-port virtual
switch and another 24-port virtual switch.

783
00:40:52,670 --> 00:40:54,650
It's one physical switch but
it's divided up.

784
00:40:54,650 --> 00:40:56,495
And it doesn't have to
be evenly like that.

785
00:40:56,495 --> 00:41:00,577
And I could break it up into five
virtual switches, one with two ports,

786
00:41:00,577 --> 00:41:02,970
one with ten ports, one with 13 ports.

787
00:41:02,970 --> 00:41:04,636
However you wanna mix and match.

788
00:41:04,636 --> 00:41:07,388
I think the lowest that you
can go is just one port.

789
00:41:07,388 --> 00:41:08,050
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

790
00:41:08,050 --> 00:41:09,730
there's not a lot of point in doing that.

791
00:41:09,730 --> 00:41:13,600
So normally you're gonna do two ports or
more, but you can divide it up.

792
00:41:13,600 --> 00:41:15,272
>> Now, speaking of that, right,

793
00:41:15,272 --> 00:41:19,039
where Don actually just described
the idea of actually using one switch and

794
00:41:19,039 --> 00:41:24,300
being that actually chop the switch up and
treat them as they're multiple switches.

795
00:41:24,300 --> 00:41:27,730
The neat thing about VLAN is
as we go further into it, so

796
00:41:27,730 --> 00:41:32,715
even beyond the CCNT here, a little bit,
when we actually have multiple switches,

797
00:41:32,715 --> 00:41:37,500
okay, we can actually take those
multiple switches then, with VLANs, and

798
00:41:37,500 --> 00:41:42,200
actually treat them as if they're one big,
gigantic switch, if we want to.

799
00:41:42,200 --> 00:41:47,780
Or, if I have three switches,
I could treat 15 switches if I chose to.

800
00:41:47,780 --> 00:41:50,780
So, it's an incredibly versatile,

801
00:41:50,780 --> 00:41:54,020
I guess is the right term here,
technology that we can use.

802
00:41:54,020 --> 00:41:56,960
Now, the whole goal behind this is simple,
right?

803
00:41:56,960 --> 00:42:01,710
I may actually think that, hey, buying
a 48-port switch is the way to go, okay,

804
00:42:01,710 --> 00:42:02,930
for right now.

805
00:42:02,930 --> 00:42:04,160
Because I have the money for it.

806
00:42:04,160 --> 00:42:07,210
I don't wanna actually buy a whole
bunch of little switches here.

807
00:42:07,210 --> 00:42:10,902
Well, again, that means that I can
actually use it very efficiently and

808
00:42:10,902 --> 00:42:13,050
then subdivide it later on if I need to.

809
00:42:13,050 --> 00:42:15,340
So it's a really neat technology for us.

810
00:42:15,340 --> 00:42:19,580
>> Now, why would we want to divide our
physical switch up into virtual switches?

811
00:42:19,580 --> 00:42:22,460
And there's two main reasons.

812
00:42:22,460 --> 00:42:24,130
Reason number one is,

813
00:42:24,130 --> 00:42:27,570
remember how I mentioned the entire
switch is one broadcast domain?

814
00:42:27,570 --> 00:42:29,780
Right, every port is its
own collision domain.

815
00:42:29,780 --> 00:42:32,400
But the whole switch is
still one broadcast domain.

816
00:42:32,400 --> 00:42:35,090
If you divide it up into virtual switches,

817
00:42:35,090 --> 00:42:38,360
each virtual switch is
its own broadcast domain.

818
00:42:38,360 --> 00:42:42,550
So instead of having a 48-port broadcast
domain, if I divided it in half,

819
00:42:42,550 --> 00:42:45,720
I could have two 24-port
broadcast domains, right?

820
00:42:45,720 --> 00:42:48,480
So we start to make our network
a little smaller as far as

821
00:42:48,480 --> 00:42:50,170
the broadcasts, all right?

822
00:42:50,170 --> 00:42:52,990
The second reason is security.

823
00:42:52,990 --> 00:42:55,860
I might have some PCs that I don't
want to communicate with others.

824
00:42:55,860 --> 00:42:58,160
Maybe I have my accounting machines and

825
00:42:58,160 --> 00:43:01,640
I have my sales machines and
I don't want the two to mix.

826
00:43:01,640 --> 00:43:07,310
So I divide the switch up logically to put
them on two separate networks, all right?

827
00:43:07,310 --> 00:43:11,380
>> And it's all about the idea of design
and keeping the efficiency that we can.

828
00:43:11,380 --> 00:43:14,396
If we don't have this ability
to do what Don is talking about,

829
00:43:14,396 --> 00:43:17,470
separating it from our accounting and
our marketing, right,

830
00:43:17,470 --> 00:43:21,704
this means that accounting information,
even accidentally in terms of a broadcast,

831
00:43:21,704 --> 00:43:24,660
can overflow into
the accounting department.

832
00:43:24,660 --> 00:43:27,500
And that means those accounting machines
can pretty much see everything that's

833
00:43:27,500 --> 00:43:28,760
being sent across.

834
00:43:28,760 --> 00:43:31,650
So that may be something we
don't want to have happen.

835
00:43:31,650 --> 00:43:33,551
And if I don't have enough
money to buy another switch,

836
00:43:33,551 --> 00:43:35,255
this is the perfect way for
us to be able to do that.

837
00:43:35,255 --> 00:43:36,265
>> Yeah, absolutely.

838
00:43:36,265 --> 00:43:41,441
And once they're divided up like that,
machines on two different VLANs cannot

839
00:43:41,441 --> 00:43:46,190
see each other, cannot talk at all,
can't ping, can't do anything.

840
00:43:46,190 --> 00:43:50,470
If you want them to communicate,
you're gonna have to take a firewall or

841
00:43:50,470 --> 00:43:55,640
a router, and plug it into both VLANs to
be able to route between them, all right?

842
00:43:55,640 --> 00:43:59,570
So you then have full control over what
traffic is allowed to pass from one VLAN

843
00:43:59,570 --> 00:44:03,325
to another, great way to implement
security protocols in your network.

844
00:44:03,325 --> 00:44:09,048
Now, you can also use what's
called a Layer 3 switch.

845
00:44:09,048 --> 00:44:14,500
And a Layer 3 switch is a switch
that has a router built into it.

846
00:44:14,500 --> 00:44:16,560
And, most of Cisco's mid-tier,

847
00:44:16,560 --> 00:44:21,320
and all of Cisco's high-tier switches have
that router functionality built into them.

848
00:44:21,320 --> 00:44:22,811
Even some of the low end
switches do nowadays.

849
00:44:22,811 --> 00:44:26,456
So that's a pretty common thing, but
again you still have control over it.

850
00:44:26,456 --> 00:44:33,780
Now for the CCENT exam, you need to know
how to route between VLANs using a router.

851
00:44:33,780 --> 00:44:35,850
And we haven't really set up routing yet
in the show.

852
00:44:35,850 --> 00:44:36,867
We haven't really gotten to that point.

00:44:36,867 --> 00:44:40,350
So we're gonna tackle that in the routing
shows that happen a little bit later,

probably in the next two weeks and

So for right now we're just gonna

00:44:46,690 --> 00:44:47,210
>> Right.

857
00:44:47,210 --> 00:44:50,060
>> For
those of you that go on to do your CCNA,

00:44:52,812 --> 00:44:58,210
All right, so let's take a look
at VLANs and how they work.

00:44:58,210 --> 00:45:00,080
Now Ronnie mentioned something earlier.

00:45:00,080 --> 00:45:03,449
He said when you buy a brand new switch,
even if you don't set it up,

862
00:45:03,449 --> 00:45:06,836
you may say you're not using a VLAN,
but you actually are, right?

863
00:45:06,836 --> 00:45:15,260
>> Now, every Cisco switch by default has
one VLAN on it and we call that VLAN 1.

864

Now when we talk about this, right,

865
00:45:17,497 --> 00:45:22,960
every port is automatically associated
with that very first VLAN that's there.

866
00:45:22,960 --> 00:45:25,280
It doesn't mean that's

867

But they automatically associate
it because they assume

868
00:45:28,250 --> 00:45:33,250

869
00:45:33,250 --> 00:45:36,350
into the separate VLANs that you want to,
okay?

870
00:45:36,350 --> 00:45:41,580
Remember that, for us, a VLAN is
gonna help us to limit the broadcast.

871
00:45:41,580 --> 00:45:45,890
So usually what we might do again is using
business functions such as marketing and

872
00:45:45,890 --> 00:45:47,460
sales that we mentioned here.

00:45:47,460 --> 00:45:50,640
We might also do it by separating
out functions of machines,

00:45:50,640 --> 00:45:52,290
so I have a data center.

And then to have, maybe branch offices.

00:45:54,480 --> 00:45:55,980
Whatever it might be here, but

at the beginning every single port's

And then we can re-assign
the ports they wanted.

The good thing is we can either assign

I can pick and

When you buy a brand new Cisco switch,

And if I look at my list, I've got

That's the default VLAN and

00:47:48,313 --> 00:47:51,148

Now here it looks like that Don

And then those

Oh yeah, that's right.

When we decide we want

Well, on a Windows PC or a Linux box, you

00:50:37,170 --> 00:50:41,860

00:50:41,860 --> 00:50:44,620
The first time you

00:50:44,620 --> 00:50:47,900

Yeah, at layer 3, I know the layer 3

in order to talk to that switch,

00:50:56,290 --> 00:50:56,790

00:50:56,790 --> 00:51:00,050

00:51:00,050 --> 00:51:03,170
And I had to send out what's
called an ARP request.

977
00:51:04,340 --> 00:51:05,980
ARP if you're not familiar with it,

00:51:05,980 --> 00:51:10,530
we talk about it in detail in the network
plus show, but here's a recap.

979
00:51:10,530 --> 00:51:13,220
ARP is address resolution protocol.

980
00:51:13,220 --> 00:51:15,300
And we use it to find
someone else's Mac address.

981
00:51:15,300 --> 00:51:19,310
Basically we send out a broadcast.

982
00:51:19,310 --> 00:51:20,330
And we say, hey.

983
00:51:20,330 --> 00:51:21,650
Who is 192.168.8.0.10?

984
00:51:21,650 --> 00:51:26,500
And then we get a response back from
192.1680.10 saying hey, that's me.

985
00:51:26,500 --> 00:51:27,630
Here's my Mac address.

986
00:51:27,630 --> 00:51:28,560
Right?

987
00:51:28,560 --> 00:51:31,340
And we learn it, and
we add it to our ARP table.

988
00:51:31,340 --> 00:51:32,750
So I just did a show, ARP.

989
00:51:32,750 --> 00:51:37,460
And right there,
I can see where I learned 192.1680.10,

990
00:51:37,460 --> 00:51:39,796
the switch, has this Mac address.

991
00:51:39,796 --> 00:51:42,826
>> 0018.198e.dbc0.

992
00:51:42,826 --> 00:51:43,854
All right.

993
00:51:43,854 --> 00:51:49,660
And if I ping it now,
all the pings go through immediately,

994
00:51:49,660 --> 00:51:51,240
because I already know it, right?

995
00:51:51,240 --> 00:51:53,730
I didn't have to do the ARP request.

996
00:51:53,730 --> 00:51:58,963
If I were to clear the ARP
table [SOUND] there we go.

997
00:51:58,963 --> 00:52:00,640
And then do the ping again.

998
00:52:01,950 --> 00:52:05,220
Oh, it's going to learn it much
faster this time and not do it.

999
00:52:05,220 --> 00:52:07,610
But basically if you lose the first two or

1000
00:52:07,610 --> 00:52:10,470
the first one ping,
you don't normally need to worry about it.

1001
00:52:10,470 --> 00:52:13,480
Just run the ping again and
make sure that all 5 go through.

1002
00:52:13,480 --> 00:52:14,340
And you'll be in business.

1003
00:52:14,340 --> 00:52:17,930
So, I should of checked to make sure
the arc table actually emptied,

1004
00:52:17,930 --> 00:52:18,980
it might not of.

1005
00:52:18,980 --> 00:52:21,220
But anyhow, the point being,

1006
00:52:21,220 --> 00:52:25,970
port 1 on this router is plugged
in to port 1 on the switch.

1007
00:52:25,970 --> 00:52:27,840
And so, if I jump back over to the switch.

1008
00:52:31,280 --> 00:52:32,210
Jump over to it, there we go.

1009
00:52:36,980 --> 00:52:38,560
And I take a look at the VLAN.

1010
00:52:38,560 --> 00:52:43,780
There's port number one, fa0/1,
and it is currently on VLAN 1,

1011
00:52:43,780 --> 00:52:49,380
and my switch has an IP address
of 192.168.0.10 on VLAN 1, right?

1012
00:52:49,380 --> 00:52:52,520
Everything is happening on vlan 1.

1013
00:52:52,520 --> 00:52:56,500
Now, if I create a new VLAN, and

1014
00:52:56,500 --> 00:53:00,480
we do that just by typing VLAN and
a number, what we get in config.

1015
00:53:00,480 --> 00:53:02,220
And we say VLAN and a number.

1016
00:53:02,220 --> 00:53:06,040
We can create a new VLAN,
I'll create VLAN 2, all right?

1017
00:53:06,040 --> 00:53:10,650
So now I just made VLAN 2, and
I can give it a name if I want.

1018
00:53:10,650 --> 00:53:16,611
I'll call it show VLAN.

1019
00:53:16,611 --> 00:53:18,100
All right.

1020
00:53:18,100 --> 00:53:21,980
So now,
I've got a brand new VLAN called VLAN 2.

1021
00:53:21,980 --> 00:53:26,800
>> And if Don actually goes ahead and
now does a show command for us.

1022
00:53:26,800 --> 00:53:29,480
>> The do show VLAN, here.

1023
00:53:29,480 --> 00:53:33,010
Notice that what we see is,
VLAN 2 has showed up, but

1024
00:53:33,010 --> 00:53:36,695
we don't have an actual port
assigned to that VLAN yet.

1025
00:53:36,695 --> 00:53:38,150
>> Hm-mm.
>> So we're gonna be doing that.

1026
00:53:38,150 --> 00:53:39,740
Are we gonna do that now, or
are we gonna do that later?

1027
00:53:39,740 --> 00:53:40,250
>> Yeah, sure.

1028
00:53:40,250 --> 00:53:41,600
Okay.
So we need to move a port over to it.

1029
00:53:41,600 --> 00:53:45,240
At least one, but
normally you're going to move 2 or more.

1030
00:53:45,240 --> 00:53:48,620
So I want to move that router
port over to this VLAN to.

1031
00:53:48,620 --> 00:53:52,090
So I'm going into interface FA0/1,

1032
00:53:52,090 --> 00:53:56,248
that's where the routers plugged into
that port and I'll say switch port.

1033
00:53:56,248 --> 00:54:01,180
Access VLAN and a number right.

1034
00:54:01,180 --> 00:54:04,370
And this could be whatever VLAN it is that
i'm gonna plug into, i'll pick VLAN 2.

1035
00:54:04,370 --> 00:54:06,230
All right.

1036
00:54:06,230 --> 00:54:11,340
So, when I say switch port access VLAN 2,
now that port has been moved over.

1037
00:54:11,340 --> 00:54:18,120
And if I say show VLAN, I can see
that port one is now the only port,

1038
00:54:18,120 --> 00:54:23,050
all by itself here in VLAN 2 now,
there's another way for

1039
00:54:23,050 --> 00:54:28,390
us to also create another VLAN, but
we can do it differently as well.

1040
00:54:28,390 --> 00:54:33,690
We can do it directly from
the interface command as well.

1041
00:54:33,690 --> 00:54:38,618
So, if we choose another interface,

1042
00:54:38,618 --> 00:54:42,490
here with interface here.

1043
00:54:42,490 --> 00:54:45,120
What we want to do is actually go to the
switch port and we want to make sure that

1044
00:54:45,120 --> 00:54:49,565
this is gonna be an access VLAN and
then we can pick VLAN 3.

1045
00:54:50,958 --> 00:54:53,340
>> Now VLAN 3 doesn't exist so

1046
00:54:53,340 --> 00:54:57,660
we get a message letting us know access
VLAN does not exist creating VLAN 3.

1047
00:54:57,660 --> 00:55:01,790
>> Now, this is very important for
us cuz there are 2 ways for us to do this.

1048
00:55:01,790 --> 00:55:07,155
Now, if we do it this way right, we have
to do each individual port that we want.

1049
00:55:07,155 --> 00:55:07,770
>> Hm-mm.
>> And

1050
00:55:07,770 --> 00:55:10,690
then we can actually assign
them in that particular way.

1051
00:55:10,690 --> 00:55:14,650
Or later on, have y'all done the interface
range command in the previous show?

1052
00:55:14,650 --> 00:55:15,340
>> We haven't.

1053
00:55:15,340 --> 00:55:16,350
Good point for it.

1054
00:55:16,350 --> 00:55:17,660
>> There you go.

1055
00:55:17,660 --> 00:55:19,130
>> So
we mentioned normally you're gonna move.

1056
00:55:19,130 --> 00:55:20,230
>> Several ports over.

1057
00:55:20,230 --> 00:55:20,790
Right?

1058
00:55:20,790 --> 00:55:23,970
So I might wanna move not just port 10 but
maybe port 10 through 15.

1059
00:55:23,970 --> 00:55:26,570
To create a 5 port switch.

1060
00:55:26,570 --> 00:55:27,900
So I could say.

1061
00:55:27,900 --> 00:55:29,740
>> 11 through 15.

1062
00:55:29,740 --> 00:55:35,150
>> Interface range FA0/,
eh, 10's already done.

1063
00:55:35,150 --> 00:55:38,790
We can say 11 through 15.

1064
00:55:38,790 --> 00:55:39,980
All right.

1065
00:55:39,980 --> 00:55:40,940
See how I wrote that?

1066
00:55:40,940 --> 00:55:44,940
Interface range, that lets the switch
know I'm about to do a range of ports.

1067
00:55:44,940 --> 00:55:51,578
fa0/11, that's the first port, and
then The spaces are important.

1068
00:55:51,578 --> 00:55:54,085
15, that means 11 through 15.

1069
00:55:54,085 --> 00:55:55,664
I'm now modifying.

1070
00:55:55,664 --> 00:55:58,080
More than one port at a time.

1071
00:55:58,080 --> 00:56:01,100
And notice the command prompt
change that we see right here?

1072
00:56:01,100 --> 00:56:04,310
We are now in the range
interface configuration prompt.

1073
00:56:04,310 --> 00:56:07,240
And now all we have to do is actually
assign that same command to whatever

1074
00:56:07,240 --> 00:56:09,650
interface, or
whatever VLAN we want to, and

1075
00:56:09,650 --> 00:56:12,270
that affects all those
ports in that range.

1076
00:56:12,270 --> 00:56:17,000
So, we actually have a way to assign
multiple interfaces to a particular VLAN.

1077
00:56:17,000 --> 00:56:21,080
Or we can do one at a time, or the way
Don did earlier we create the VLAN first,

1078
00:56:21,080 --> 00:56:23,880
and then we can go back through and
assign them to the same VLAN.

1079
00:56:25,070 --> 00:56:28,420
>> So now when I get out,
and I do a show VLAN,

1080
00:56:30,300 --> 00:56:34,130
I can see that I've got VLAN2
with just one port in it.

1081
00:56:34,130 --> 00:56:36,863
And I can see VLAN3 exists.

1082
00:56:36,863 --> 00:56:38,650
And it's got, what is that?

1083
00:56:38,650 --> 00:56:39,417
Six ports.

1084
00:56:39,417 --> 00:56:41,860
>> Yeah.
>> Now, notice the name that VLAN3 got.

1085
00:56:41,860 --> 00:56:44,735
When you create it,
creating it that way is called on the fly.

1086
00:56:44,735 --> 00:56:49,346
>> When you create an on the fly VLAN,
that's the official name.

1087
00:56:49,346 --> 00:56:50,889
>> I feel like I should say trademark,
copyright.

1088
00:56:50,889 --> 00:56:52,305
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyhow,

1089
00:56:52,305 --> 00:56:54,131
when you create a VLAN on the fly.

1090
00:56:54,131 --> 00:56:58,858
It gets a name like this VLAN, and then
a four-digit number representing the VLAN.

1091
00:56:58,858 --> 00:57:04,946
And I'm glad I mentioned this,
because the VLAN numbers.

1092
00:57:04,946 --> 00:57:09,333
>> The way they're stored inside a frame,
there's not a lot of room.

1093
00:57:09,333 --> 00:57:13,668
>> So, you're really only given a couple
of bytes to be able to use to store

1094
00:57:13,668 --> 00:57:14,700
the data.

1095
00:57:14,700 --> 00:57:21,400
And as a result your VLAN number is going
to be a number between 1 and 4,094.

1096
00:57:21,400 --> 00:57:23,880
And 95, and 96 are reserved.

1097
00:57:23,880 --> 00:57:25,450
And so you end up with 1 through 4,094,

1098
00:57:25,450 --> 00:57:28,460
actually there's a couple of reserved
numbers we should point out, but

1099
00:57:28,460 --> 00:57:31,780
that means that you'll never
have a five digit VLAN number.

1100
00:57:31,780 --> 00:57:34,370
Cuz there's just not enough
room in the frame to store it.

1101
00:57:34,370 --> 00:57:37,690
So, it will be 1 through 4094.

1102
00:57:37,690 --> 00:57:42,220
Old switches might only go 1 through 1024.

1103
00:57:42,220 --> 00:57:44,720
There's a lot of them that do that,
the old ones.

1104
00:57:44,720 --> 00:57:47,740
But any switch made in
probably the last ten years.

1105
00:57:47,740 --> 00:57:50,400
Should be able to do one to 1094.

1106
00:57:50,400 --> 00:57:53,090
So, that VLAN is created.

1107
00:57:53,090 --> 00:57:55,090
I could go and rename it if we wanted to.

1108
00:57:55,090 --> 00:58:01,310
We would just go back into config and
say VLAN3 name RONNIE_VLAN.

1109
00:58:01,310 --> 00:58:03,140
>> There you go.
>> This is your network.

1110
00:58:03,140 --> 00:58:06,470
All right, so when I do that,
now when I do a show VLAN,

1111
00:58:06,470 --> 00:58:10,200
if I spell it right, then we'll see
that it's got a nice little name.

1112
00:58:10,200 --> 00:58:12,126
So, that's really the only
negative of doing it on the fly.

1113
00:58:12,126 --> 00:58:12,683
>> Yep.

1114
00:58:12,683 --> 00:58:13,751
>> Is that it just doesn't get a name.

1115
00:58:13,751 --> 00:58:14,494
>> Yeah.

1116
00:58:14,494 --> 00:58:17,310
The nice thing is now,
what we talked about a little bit earlier.

1117
00:58:17,310 --> 00:58:21,730
Let's remember that what we've
now done is that on VLANs 2 and

1118
00:58:21,730 --> 00:58:25,140
3, we have created two
separate broadcast domain.

1119
00:58:25,140 --> 00:58:28,960
So, we have our original broadcast domain,
which is the default one.

1120
00:58:28,960 --> 00:58:30,310
So on this switch right now,

1121
00:58:30,310 --> 00:58:34,160
we have three separate broadcast domain
where originally we'd have only had one.

1122
00:58:35,360 --> 00:58:37,890
>> Yeah, and
we never did follow up with our router.

1123
00:58:37,890 --> 00:58:40,750
Our router has been moved over to VLAN2,

1124
00:58:40,750 --> 00:58:43,320
let's see how that affects
the router all right?

1125
00:58:43,320 --> 00:58:45,600
Let me move my console cable over.

1126
00:58:45,600 --> 00:58:47,810
Because we're moving the VLANs around.

1127
00:58:47,810 --> 00:58:49,748
I can't connect via the network.

1128
00:58:49,748 --> 00:58:52,190
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it's like moving the ports, so

1129
00:58:52,190 --> 00:58:55,470
I'm using a console cable to ensure
that I can constantly connect to it.

1130
00:58:55,470 --> 00:59:00,405
So now, I'm on that router now,
and if I look at its IP address

1131
00:59:00,405 --> 00:59:05,400
its 192 2.168.0.1 that
network is still up.

1132
00:59:05,400 --> 00:59:09,150
Before I disconnect it,
I was able to ping the switch and

1133
00:59:09,150 --> 00:59:11,750
let me just see if my ARP
cache is still there.

1134
00:59:11,750 --> 00:59:13,284
Let me clear the ARP cache.

1135
00:59:19,853 --> 00:59:21,138
That did not clear the ARP cache, did it?

1136
00:59:21,138 --> 00:59:22,845
That will explain why it.

1137
00:59:25,161 --> 00:59:26,334
It didn't work earlier.

1138
00:59:29,472 --> 00:59:30,440
There we go.

1139
00:59:30,440 --> 00:59:31,150
Okay.

1140
00:59:31,150 --> 00:59:36,970
So, the switch was 192.168.0.10 and
I just cleared it out of the ARP cache.

1141
00:59:36,970 --> 00:59:42,612
So it's out, and I'm gonna try and
ping 192.168.0.10.

1142
00:59:42,612 --> 00:59:44,830
I was able to ping it before but

1143
00:59:44,830 --> 00:59:48,170
now my router has been moved,
into a brand new VLAN.

1144
00:59:48,170 --> 00:59:49,890
Remember what I said earlier?

1145
00:59:49,890 --> 00:59:54,910
When you get moved into a separate VLAN,
you're cut off from the original VLAN.

1146
00:59:54,910 --> 00:59:58,120
The router can no longer see VLAN1,

1147
00:59:58,120 --> 01:00:03,820
it only sees VLAN2 and so my pings
are gonna fail if I do a show ARP,

1148
01:00:03,820 --> 01:00:07,920
I'll see where I got
an incomplete response.

1149
01:00:07,920 --> 01:00:12,720
I sent out an ARP broadcast to get the MAC
address, I never got an answer back.

1150
01:00:12,720 --> 01:00:14,530
So I never found out.

1151
01:00:14,530 --> 01:00:15,520
>> Yep.

1152
01:00:15,520 --> 01:00:18,110
And so the way that we're gonna end
up taking care of this is by doing

1153
01:00:18,110 --> 01:00:20,530
what later on,
which we'll call inter VLAN routing.

1154
01:00:20,530 --> 01:00:27,010
>> Where we will need the ID of a router
to help us get past, this limitation here.

1155
01:00:27,010 --> 01:00:30,750
>> And I got so, involved in our VLAN
action I lost track of the time.

1156
01:00:30,750 --> 01:00:32,020
I think we've blown past our limit.

1157
01:00:32,020 --> 01:00:32,520
>> Yeah.
>> Yep.

1158
01:00:32,520 --> 01:00:34,220
>> So let's stop here, and take a break.

1159
01:00:34,220 --> 01:00:37,070
When we get back,
we got more about VLANs to cover.

1160
01:00:37,070 --> 01:00:38,950
Right now, we've just seen
how it can break our network.

1161
01:00:38,950 --> 01:00:40,800
We need to show some
of the good stuff too.

1162
01:00:40,800 --> 01:00:41,950
So, let's stop here.

1163
01:00:41,950 --> 01:00:42,550
We'll take a break.

1164
01:00:42,550 --> 01:00:45,417

All right, welcome back everybody.

So before the break, we took the router
and we moved it off to its own VLAN.

1168
01:00:59,820 --> 01:01:00,790
And when we did that,

1169
01:01:00,790 --> 01:01:03,250
the router is now no longer able
to see the rest of the devices.

1170
01:01:03,250 --> 01:01:05,618
It's isolated,
it's in its own little world.

1171
01:01:05,618 --> 01:01:09,980
What I wanna do now is, I wanna move
my laptop over to that same VLAN as

1172
01:01:09,980 --> 01:01:13,420
the router to show you how that
Kind of brings it full circle?

1173
01:01:13,420 --> 01:01:16,220
So, let's take just a moment
here at the beginning,

1174
01:01:16,220 --> 01:01:19,290
and take a look at my

1175
01:01:19,290 --> 01:01:22,870
If I do a quick IP config, there we go.

1176
01:01:22,870 --> 01:01:28,960
So, my network card is 192.168.0.2,

1177
01:01:28,960 --> 01:01:32,150
that's the IP address that
I've got on my interface.

1178
01:01:32,150 --> 01:01:34,250
And I'm plugged into VLAN1.

1179
01:01:34,250 --> 01:01:36,130
So, I should be able to ping the switch.

1180
01:01:36,130 --> 01:01:40,710
The switch is 192.168.0.10 so
I'm just gonna try and ping that.

1181
01:01:40,710 --> 01:01:45,520
And there it is I can see
the switch because I'm on VLAN1,

1182
01:01:45,520 --> 01:01:47,220
the switch is on VLAN1.

1183
01:01:47,220 --> 01:01:53,007
If I try and ping the router,
which was 192.168.0.1,

1184
01:01:53,007 --> 01:01:57,880
I'm on VLAN1,
the router's on VLAN2 I cannot ping.

1185
01:01:59,560 --> 01:02:03,504
So what I want to do is I want
to move my laptop over to VLAN2,

1186
01:02:03,504 --> 01:02:07,366
so that I can see the router.

1187
01:02:07,366 --> 01:02:10,140
Now, I know that my laptop

1188
01:02:10,140 --> 01:02:12,740
If I didn't know that, I could use

1189
01:02:12,740 --> 01:02:16,120
but I know it is let me
get over to the switch.

1190
01:02:16,120 --> 01:02:18,520
I guess that'll make a difference for me.

1191
01:02:18,520 --> 01:02:23,210
>> So, what Don's gonna do at this point
here, is we're gonna actually take

1192
01:02:23,210 --> 01:02:26,940
whatever port that his particular
laptop is plugged into.

1193
01:02:26,940 --> 01:02:29,780
And he's gonna reassign that
particular port into VLAN2,

1194
01:02:29,780 --> 01:02:33,640
which is gonna be on the same
VLAN as the router itself.

1195
01:02:33,640 --> 01:02:38,490
So here he is, actually going into
the interface configuration, and

1196
01:02:38,490 --> 01:02:41,400
now he's gonna reassign
the actual VLAN here.

1197
01:02:41,400 --> 01:02:43,610
And remember,
that what Don did right here,

1198
01:02:43,610 --> 01:02:47,290
he didn't have to do a,
no switch port access VLAN1,

1199
01:02:47,290 --> 01:02:52,150
he simply just typed in switch port access
VLAN2, and there's a reason for that.

1200
01:02:52,150 --> 01:02:57,860
A single port can only be in one VLAN,
especially in access port here.

1201
01:02:57,860 --> 01:03:00,290
>> So we're only in one VLAN,
we're now in VLAN2.

1202
01:03:00,290 --> 01:03:04,140
That means that the port I'm plugged into,
and the port the router is plugged into

1203
01:03:04,140 --> 01:03:09,180
are both on VLAN2, and I can see

If I do a show VLAN,

The port the router's plugged into,
and port two,

01:03:17,740 --> 01:03:20,070
the port my laptop is plugged into.

Now, that we're both

01:03:22,720 --> 01:03:26,240
remember back here where I
wasn't able to ping the router?

1209
01:03:26,240 --> 01:03:28,340
Now, I should be able to ping the router.

1210
01:03:28,340 --> 01:03:29,900
Let's see what happens.

1211
01:03:29,900 --> 01:03:31,120
A moment of anticipation.

1212
01:03:31,120 --> 01:03:31,650
>> That's right.
>> And

1213
01:03:31,650 --> 01:03:34,190
remember, the ARP broadcast
thing has to happen.

1214
01:03:34,190 --> 01:03:36,309
I gotta try to find that MAC address.

1215
01:03:36,309 --> 01:03:40,744
And [LAUGH] it's that
moment of anticipation.

1216
01:03:40,744 --> 01:03:41,706
>> I know.
>> [LAUGH]

1217
01:03:41,706 --> 01:03:43,112
>> Is it going to get through?

1218
01:03:43,112 --> 01:03:44,621
>> [CROSSTALK] It may take a moment.

1219
01:03:44,621 --> 01:03:45,817
>> And it does appear to be stalling,
doesn't it?

1220
01:03:45,817 --> 01:03:47,674
>> Yep.

1221
01:03:47,674 --> 01:03:48,533
>> You know what?

1222
01:03:48,533 --> 01:03:49,364
Loop detection.

1223
01:03:49,364 --> 01:03:51,454
Is loop detection still going on?

1224
01:03:51,454 --> 01:03:52,940
No, it seems to be happy.

1225
01:03:52,940 --> 01:03:54,171
So, let's try that again.

1226
01:03:54,171 --> 01:03:55,912
>> Yep.

1227
01:03:55,912 --> 01:03:58,373
That's routeris.1 isn't it?

1228
01:03:58,373 --> 01:04:00,022
>> [LAUGH] I think so.

1229
01:04:00,022 --> 01:04:01,800
>> There it goes, yep.

1230
01:04:01,800 --> 01:04:04,960
It's happening, it happened while I wasn't
focused on the window, let me try again.

1231
01:04:04,960 --> 01:04:07,250
>> Apparently, it took a little
while to learn the Mac address.

1232
01:04:07,250 --> 01:04:08,590
>> Oh, you know,
I didn't think about it, but

1233
01:04:08,590 --> 01:04:12,140
the
>> The ARP table on the switch.

1234
01:04:12,140 --> 01:04:15,870
When records get written into the ARP
table, they stay there for a while, and

1235
01:04:15,870 --> 01:04:20,360
so it probably had me cached on VLAN 1,
and that cache just had to age out.

1236
01:04:20,360 --> 01:04:21,490
Now it sees me VLAN 2.

1237
01:04:21,490 --> 01:04:24,480
So So now I am able to see that router.

1238
01:04:24,480 --> 01:04:27,178
I can ping 192.168.0.1.

1239
01:04:27,178 --> 01:04:32,230
Now, when I started I was on VLAN 1 and
I could ping the switch.

1240
01:04:32,230 --> 01:04:34,300
Now I'm on VLAN 2, so if I try and

1241
01:04:34,300 --> 01:04:38,570
ping the switch even though I'm plugged
right in to the front of the switch.

1242
01:04:38,570 --> 01:04:39,840
I'm on a different VLAN.

1243
01:04:39,840 --> 01:04:43,430
I'm on VLAN 2 the switch's
IP address is on VLAN 1.

1244
01:04:43,430 --> 01:04:48,360
So I'm now isolated, split off,
and not able to ping that switch.

1245
01:04:48,360 --> 01:04:50,840
Right, yep, sounds good.

1246
01:04:50,840 --> 01:04:54,320
So pretty cool, neat way to divide
up your system for security.

1247
01:04:54,320 --> 01:04:58,030
Like Ronnie mentioned In another
episode when we start tackling routes,

1248
01:04:58,030 --> 01:05:00,400
we'll show how to route
between these VLANs,

1249
01:05:00,400 --> 01:05:03,140
cuz you might want your two VLANs
to be able to talk to each other.

1250
01:05:03,140 --> 01:05:05,440
As it is right now though,
they're completely isolated.

1251
01:05:05,440 --> 01:05:06,530
>> Yep.

1252
01:05:06,530 --> 01:05:10,440
>> Now there was another cool thing you
mentioned earlier in the episode Ronnie.

1253
01:05:10,440 --> 01:05:15,900
Which is, we've divided this one physical
switch into multiple virtual switches.

1254
01:05:15,900 --> 01:05:18,430
I can take these VLANs that we made, and

1255
01:05:18,430 --> 01:05:23,010
I can stretch them across multiple
physical interfaces, all right?

1256
01:05:23,010 --> 01:05:27,810
Now, in the Cisco books or whatever,
they'll usually give this one example.

1257
01:05:27,810 --> 01:05:29,309
Let me get to my little drawing board,
here.

1258
01:05:30,440 --> 01:05:34,120
And the example that
they'll give a lot times.

1259
01:05:34,120 --> 01:05:35,660
Is they'll show a building right.

1260
01:05:35,660 --> 01:05:36,990
Let me draw a building.

1261
01:05:38,640 --> 01:05:42,890
So I'll draw a building and
it'll have a couple of floors, right.

1262
01:05:42,890 --> 01:05:44,980
Like five floors or something.

1263
01:05:44,980 --> 01:05:48,420
and on each floor, they'll have a switch.

1264
01:05:48,420 --> 01:05:52,840
So there will be a physical switch here
on this floor, and a physical switch on

1265
01:05:52,840 --> 01:05:56,570
this floor, and each floor in
the building will have its own switch.

1266
01:05:57,660 --> 01:06:02,950
And all of these switches will run back
to some kind of central data center,

1267
01:06:02,950 --> 01:06:07,200
and that data center may be they're
on the ground floor, or somewhere.

1268
01:06:07,200 --> 01:06:10,260
But they basically all run
back to this central location.

1269
01:06:10,260 --> 01:06:16,480
So we have a topology
that looks like this.

1270
01:06:16,480 --> 01:06:20,670
So see how all the switches are uplinked
together so they can all see each other.

1271
01:06:20,670 --> 01:06:23,230
Well, I might have a sales department, and

1272
01:06:23,230 --> 01:06:27,130
if my entire sales department is on the
fifth floor, right up there at the top.

1273
01:06:27,130 --> 01:06:29,890
Then it may make sense for
me to just leave them on a VLAN and

1274
01:06:29,890 --> 01:06:31,920
leave them separated out.

1275
01:06:31,920 --> 01:06:35,970
But what if I have sales
people up here and

1276
01:06:35,970 --> 01:06:40,280
I've got sales people on the fourth
floor and the third floor and so on.

1277
01:06:40,280 --> 01:06:43,670
If I have sales people spread across
the building or accounting people spread

1278
01:06:43,670 --> 01:06:49,268
across the building, I may need that VLAN
to stretch across more than one switch.

1279
01:06:49,268 --> 01:06:54,640
All right nif you want to do that,
the easiest way is to

1280
01:06:54,640 --> 01:06:59,810
run a crossover cable from one port on
one switch to a port on the other switch.

1281
01:06:59,810 --> 01:07:02,200
That creates an uplink
like we said earlier.

1282
01:07:02,200 --> 01:07:06,820
The problem with an uplink is it
only carries traffic for one VLAN.

1283
01:07:06,820 --> 01:07:11,250
So if I two VLANs, I can run two uplink
cables between the switch, one for

1284
01:07:11,250 --> 01:07:13,900
VLAN one, one for VLAN Two,
and be done with it.

1285
01:07:13,900 --> 01:07:17,730
But what if I have 15 VLANs, or 30 VLANs?

1286
01:07:17,730 --> 01:07:21,930
I'm gonna run a port to my switch just for
the uplinks, not even counting my PCs.

1287
01:07:21,930 --> 01:07:22,760
>> Yep.

1288
01:07:22,760 --> 01:07:24,820
>> So
that's where our next technology comes in,

1289
01:07:24,820 --> 01:07:27,890
which is what's called a VLAN trunk.

1290
01:07:27,890 --> 01:07:30,380
Everything we've done so
far is with an access port.

1291
01:07:30,380 --> 01:07:32,800
And Ronnie, I think you even
called them access ports earlier.

1292
01:07:32,800 --> 01:07:34,420
But you guys have seen
the commands I've done.

1293
01:07:34,420 --> 01:07:37,380
Switchport, access, blah-blah-blah.

1294
01:07:37,380 --> 01:07:40,500
And access port can only be on one VLAN.

1295
01:07:40,500 --> 01:07:43,340
Another type of port is a trunk port.

1296
01:07:43,340 --> 01:07:47,170
And and trunk port is specifically
designed for this right here.

1297
01:07:47,170 --> 01:07:50,790
For connecting multiple switches together,
and carrying traffic for

1298
01:07:50,790 --> 01:07:53,030
more than one VLAN.

1299
01:07:53,030 --> 01:07:55,810
I can have one VLAN or five VLANs or

1300
01:07:55,810 --> 01:08:00,290
50 VLANs all going over the same
cable if it's a trunk port.

1301
01:08:02,240 --> 01:08:04,170
Now, we'd never want a trunk
port to run to a PC.

1302
01:08:04,170 --> 01:08:06,840
It's always gonna be switch to switch.

1303
01:08:06,840 --> 01:08:08,210
You always want it that way.

1304
01:08:08,210 --> 01:08:12,160
If a PC was plugged into a trunk port,
that one PC could have access to more than

1305
01:08:12,160 --> 01:08:14,450
one network, and
that's a hacker's dream, right.

1306
01:08:14,450 --> 01:08:16,370
That's what an attacker on
your network really wants.

1307
01:08:17,720 --> 01:08:21,270
So let's take a look at
this idea of trunk ports.

1308
01:08:21,270 --> 01:08:24,940
Now I've got one switch
sitting here behind us, and

1309
01:08:24,940 --> 01:08:29,140
It's connected to our big switch
in the server room in there, and

1310
01:08:29,140 --> 01:08:31,760
when I plugged that port
in right before the show.

1311
01:08:31,760 --> 01:08:35,300
It got really angry at me,
and it shut the port off, and

1312
01:08:35,300 --> 01:08:38,080
the reason was it saw
that it was a switch, and

1313
01:08:38,080 --> 01:08:41,560
that it should have been a trunk port,
and not an access port, right?

1314
01:08:41,560 --> 01:08:44,140
So the thing about trunk ports,

1315
01:08:44,140 --> 01:08:48,750
a normal access port only carries
traffic for one VLAN, right?

1316
01:08:48,750 --> 01:08:51,510
Let me go back to my other drawing.

1317
01:08:51,510 --> 01:08:52,480
Where is my other drawing?

1318
01:08:54,550 --> 01:08:55,170
>> There it is.
>> Whoops.

1319
01:08:55,170 --> 01:08:55,797
I just had it.

1320
01:08:55,797 --> 01:08:57,215
Here, pull it up this way.

1321
01:08:57,215 --> 01:09:01,975
All right.
Let me just take this switch here.

1322
01:09:01,975 --> 01:09:04,342
We'll try and
illustrate this the best way I can.

1323
01:09:09,300 --> 01:09:11,220
Oh, I didn't bring my ports over.

1324
01:09:11,220 --> 01:09:11,720
Wonderful.

1325
01:09:13,230 --> 01:09:13,960
Oh, nope, there they are.

1326
01:09:13,960 --> 01:09:16,529
>> Nice.
>> There we go.

1327
01:09:21,301 --> 01:09:26,411
Okay, let's say that I've
got some switches like this,

1328
01:09:26,411 --> 01:09:30,820
and I decide that I want
to Uuplink them together.

1329
01:09:30,820 --> 01:09:31,510
All right.

1330
01:09:31,510 --> 01:09:36,520
Well by default, when you get a new
switch, every port is on VLAN 1.

1331
01:09:36,520 --> 01:09:40,370
So all I have to do is go out and
buy a crossover cable.

1332
01:09:40,370 --> 01:09:43,310
And I run that crossover cable
from one port on one switch

1333
01:09:43,310 --> 01:09:44,680
to one port on the other.

1334
01:09:44,680 --> 01:09:49,870
And now any VLAN 1 traffic
generated here hits this cable,

1335
01:09:49,870 --> 01:09:52,380
jumps over, then it gets over here.

1336
01:09:52,380 --> 01:09:55,750
VLAN 1 spread everywhere,
everybody is nice and happy

1337
01:09:55,750 --> 01:09:58,120
>> As long as everybody is on one VLAN

1338
01:09:58,120 --> 01:09:59,830
>> We're okay with this.

1339
01:09:59,830 --> 01:10:03,180
But if I have three or
four different VLANs, well,

1340
01:10:03,180 --> 01:10:06,780
what this would actually end up meaning
for me, if I don't use the idea of

1341
01:10:06,780 --> 01:10:11,100
a trunk, is that between each
particular VLAN on each switch.

1342
01:10:11,100 --> 01:10:15,350
I would need to run that same
type of uplink from each

1343
01:10:15,350 --> 01:10:17,660
all of the different VLANs
that would actually be there.

1344
01:10:17,660 --> 01:10:20,250
So for us instead, the easier and

1345
01:10:20,250 --> 01:10:24,170
the most efficient way to do this
is to take that red cable and

1346
01:10:24,170 --> 01:10:29,160
to turn it into a trunk so it can
handle the VLAN traffic from all VLANs.

1347
01:10:29,160 --> 01:10:33,600
To allow the traffic to go across
that one link instead of needing

1348
01:10:33,600 --> 01:10:39,760
a particular trunk, or not a trunk,
particular uplink between each VLAN here.

1349
01:10:39,760 --> 01:10:41,940
So that's what we wanna do, so

1350
01:10:41,940 --> 01:10:46,730
Don is actually giving us two different
VLAN's here and so by using that red

1351
01:10:46,730 --> 01:10:51,220
cable if we actually do have them
trunked all the VLANs can go across it.

1352
01:10:51,220 --> 01:10:53,240
>> Now by default all
your port turn VLAN 1, so

1353
01:10:53,240 --> 01:10:56,117
if I was to set this
up where port four and

1354
01:10:56,117 --> 01:11:00,010
five on each switch were on VLAN 2
>> The red cable is just gonna carry VLAN

1355
01:11:00,010 --> 01:11:03,610
1 traffic, so
VLAN 1 host down on the bottom switch

1356
01:11:03,610 --> 01:11:06,900
would be able to talk to VLAN
1 up here on the top switch.

1357
01:11:06,900 --> 01:11:09,260
VLAN 2 hosts would be isolated.

1358
01:11:09,260 --> 01:11:11,680
These two guys up here would
be able to see each other.

1359
01:11:11,680 --> 01:11:14,030
These two guys down here would
be able to see each other.

1360
01:11:14,030 --> 01:11:17,760
But they wouldn't be able to
see in between the switches,

1361
01:11:17,760 --> 01:11:21,730
unless we change this cable to carry both.

1362
01:11:21,730 --> 01:11:23,450
>> Right.
>> VLAN 1 and VLAN 2.

1363
01:11:23,450 --> 01:11:29,090
Now, the problem here is that normally
when traffic enters a switch.

1364
01:11:29,090 --> 01:11:33,150
It knows what VLAN to put it on
based on our port assignment, right?

1365
01:11:33,150 --> 01:11:33,790
>> Right.
>> On the port,

1366
01:11:33,790 --> 01:11:37,270
I say switch port access VLAN 2.

1367
01:11:37,270 --> 01:11:40,960
That says any traffic coming
in this port goes on VLAN 2.

1368
01:11:40,960 --> 01:11:45,868
But when I have an uplink like this
that's a trunk that's carrying more than

1369
01:11:45,868 --> 01:11:50,559
one VLAN, how does the switch know
what VLAN to put the stuff on, right?

1370
01:11:50,559 --> 01:11:55,458
And the way it does is through using
a neat little standard with a funny name.

1371
01:11:55,458 --> 01:11:59,391
But it uses What is called,

1372
01:11:59,391 --> 01:12:03,504
802.1Q VLAN Tagging.

1373
01:12:03,504 --> 01:12:09,220
All right, 802.1Q VLAN Tagging

1374
01:12:09,220 --> 01:12:14,005
is the long name for what most of
us just call .1Q trunking, right?

1375
01:12:14,005 --> 01:12:16,830
802.1Q is an IEEE standard.

1376
01:12:16,830 --> 01:12:22,180
So it's actually IEEE 802.1Q VLAN Tagging.

1377
01:12:22,180 --> 01:12:27,050
And what it is, is an open standard
that anybody vendor can support and

1378
01:12:27,050 --> 01:12:29,080
almost all of them do, that says.

1379
01:12:29,080 --> 01:12:31,240
When I send a Piece of data,

1380
01:12:31,240 --> 01:12:36,100
a frame, out of a port that's a trunk,
stick a little extra data,

1381
01:12:36,100 --> 01:12:41,460
stick a tag in there that says
this belongs on VLAN number x.

1382
01:12:41,460 --> 01:12:43,520
Right, so
we always have a little extra room.

1383
01:12:45,320 --> 01:12:48,560
One of the things I
mentioned is that a frame

1384
01:12:48,560 --> 01:12:53,430
has a maximum size of 1,518 bytes, right?

1385
01:12:53,430 --> 01:12:59,650
But that most operating systems
actually just do 1,500 okay.

1386
01:12:59,650 --> 01:13:02,810
So why do they just do 1500
if they could do 1518?

1387
01:13:02,810 --> 01:13:07,940
And the reason is they leave
a little room in the frame

1388
01:13:07,940 --> 01:13:09,780
in case we need to insert data.

1389
01:13:09,780 --> 01:13:12,340
Insert data like with an 802.1qvlan tag.

1390
01:13:12,340 --> 01:13:15,910
>> Yup.
>> So that's a part of

1391
01:13:15,910 --> 01:13:18,240
the protocol that's kinda
built into the system.

1392
01:13:18,240 --> 01:13:20,820
It's something that a lot of the vendors
out there have thought about.

1393
01:13:20,820 --> 01:13:25,600
So Windows Linus, Mac OSX,
they leave that extra room

1394
01:13:25,600 --> 01:13:28,650
knowing that our switch vendors
might need to insert some tags.

1395
01:13:28,650 --> 01:13:31,390
And this tagging process is
how we can identify that.

1396
01:13:31,390 --> 01:13:35,580
So we can build a trunk between our
switches that is then able to carry

1397
01:13:35,580 --> 01:13:39,170
traffic from VLAn 1 and able to carry
traffic from VLAN 2 and it's really cool.

1398
01:13:39,170 --> 01:13:40,960
And you get a lot of flexibility.

1399
01:13:40,960 --> 01:13:42,380
I have set this up for
a number of companies.

1400
01:13:42,380 --> 01:13:44,510
We do it right here in our own building.

1401
01:13:44,510 --> 01:13:48,230
Any time you have more than one
switch you are going to need a trunk.

1402
01:13:49,280 --> 01:13:50,800
>> The only thing to remember is for

1403
01:13:50,800 --> 01:13:53,440
us as well
>> When we do these trunk ports,

1404
01:13:53,440 --> 01:13:57,660
we want to make sure that we provide
as much bandwidth as we can.

1405
01:13:57,660 --> 01:14:00,480
We want to make sure that it's
at least a fast ethernet port.

1406
01:14:00,480 --> 01:14:03,710
If you find an old switch that
has an ethernet port on it.

1407
01:14:03,710 --> 01:14:04,388
>> Which would be a ten megabit port.

1408
01:14:04,388 --> 01:14:05,700
>> Which would be a ten megabit port,

1409
01:14:06,800 --> 01:14:09,610
you're probably not going to find
the performance that you want.

1410
01:14:09,610 --> 01:14:12,980
So you want to make sure that trunking is
done at least on a fast ethernet cord.

1411
01:14:12,980 --> 01:14:14,390
>> Yeah, now, it'll do it.

1412
01:14:14,390 --> 01:14:16,350
>> Yeah.
>> You can trunk over a ten megaport.

1413
01:14:16,350 --> 01:14:18,400
It's just ,think about what you're doing,
right.

1414
01:14:18,400 --> 01:14:21,745
We're combining the traffic
from more than one VLAN, so it-

1415
01:14:21,745 --> 01:14:23,515
>> In this topology here VLAN 1 and

1416
01:14:23,515 --> 01:14:27,865
VLAN 2 are going to be competing for
access on this one wire.

1417
01:14:27,865 --> 01:14:32,635
Now, when we turn on the tagging
what happens is if traffic for

1418
01:14:32,635 --> 01:14:36,510
VLAN 2 is generated it's gonna
travel over to this port.

1419
01:14:36,510 --> 01:14:38,920
The switch is going to add a tag.

1420
01:14:38,920 --> 01:14:43,540
It punches in a little tag that says VLAN
2, sends it along to the other side.

1421
01:14:43,540 --> 01:14:48,300
The other switch receives it, strips off
the tag and says, okay, you're on VLAN 2.

1422
01:14:48,300 --> 01:14:52,425
It removes the tag, and then sends
the traffic over to these ports.

1423
01:14:52,425 --> 01:14:53,100
Ports.

1424
01:14:53,100 --> 01:14:57,010
So the end units, the PCs that are plugged
in, they have no idea this happened,

1425
01:14:57,010 --> 01:15:01,390
it's completely invisible to them,
but the switches knew about it,

1426
01:15:01,390 --> 01:15:05,020
they added the tag, they removed the tag,
and the traffic moved along.

1427
01:15:05,020 --> 01:15:05,950
Yep all right.

1428
01:15:05,950 --> 01:15:09,060
The configuration for this is super easy.

1429
01:15:09,060 --> 01:15:10,650
All right.
Let me show you how it's done.

1430
01:15:10,650 --> 01:15:14,030
Let me get back into this switch.

1431

q used to only do VLAN 1 through 1024

Now .1q goes all the way also.

.1q, even though that's effectively

>> That says that it will talk to

and so

well negotiate and figure it out.

01:17:34,670 --> 01:17:36,940

Normally the best practice

01:18:11,200 --> 01:18:12,510

1481
01:18:12,510 --> 01:18:13,490

Your side is gonna say I

01:18:15,750 --> 01:18:19,650
And so they will negotiate and
they'll both actually end up trunking.

01:18:19,650 --> 01:18:20,170

And CISCO switches manufacture

Most of them did do what's

1487
01:18:27,580 --> 01:18:31,320
That mean they were ready build

1488
01:18:31,320 --> 01:18:33,520

1489
01:18:33,520 --> 01:18:36,860

don't do that by default.

01:18:36,860 --> 01:18:39,210
But you can configure it.

1491
01:18:39,210 --> 01:18:43,870
They call it DTP, dynamic trunking

01:18:43,870 --> 01:18:45,500
Actually, I don't know why I

01:18:45,500 --> 01:18:48,100

01:18:48,100 --> 01:18:50,880
Well, so you've got switchport mode, and

01:18:50,880 --> 01:18:54,500
we can say switchport mode access and

1496
01:18:54,500 --> 01:18:58,100
That means we carry traffic from one VLAN,
and it's usually a PC or

1497
01:18:58,100 --> 01:19:00,410
a router on the other end of that cable.

1498
01:19:00,410 --> 01:19:03,660
Switchport mode trunk means it's a switch

1499
01:19:03,660 --> 01:19:06,380
on the other end of that cable

01:19:06,380 --> 01:19:08,380
So those are the two modes

Access for one VLAN Trunk for

01:19:11,960 --> 01:19:12,680

1505
01:19:17,220 --> 01:19:23,940
>> If we say, switchport mode dynamic,
that says we can be access or trunk.

1506
01:19:23,940 --> 01:19:25,750
That we'll negotiate it
out with the other side.

1507
01:19:25,750 --> 01:19:28,930
Whatever the other side says,
will do, okay?

1508
01:19:28,930 --> 01:19:35,570
When you go dynamic, that means that
you'll try and figure it out, okay?

1509
01:19:35,570 --> 01:19:38,890
And there's actually two modes to that,
auto and desirable.

1510
01:19:38,890 --> 01:19:44,965
Auto says that if we're going to become
a trunk, the other side has to ask us.

1511
01:19:44,965 --> 01:19:48,285
If the other side asks us
to become a trunk, we will.

1512
01:19:48,285 --> 01:19:50,533
Otherwise, we'll default

01:19:50,533 --> 01:19:53,365
And that's what a lot of the newer

1514
01:19:53,365 --> 01:19:58,322
The older ones were set to desirable And

1515
01:19:58,322 --> 01:20:01,160

1516
01:20:01,160 --> 01:20:03,310
We want to be a trunk, but

1517
01:20:03,310 --> 01:20:05,700
if the other side says no,

1518
01:20:07,340 --> 01:20:09,230

01:20:09,230 --> 01:20:11,790

is, it's a good idea not to

>> Because if a hacker can gain access to

1525
01:20:28,190 --> 01:20:32,900
your VLAN's so I make it a rule of thumb

If the port is not supposed to be getting

01:26:07,680 --> 01:26:08,250
the network.

01:26:09,420 --> 01:26:13,990

one of the biggest things we can do.

Not being able to allow
somebody to plug directly

And that way our authorized PC,

But if somebody else plugs in
they're not gonna be able to get in.

Now pro's and cons of doing this, right.

01:26:58,970 --> 01:27:03,320
So let's say you statically
