01:27:03,320 --> 01:27:08,090
somebody has their, their laptop dies,
they do a warranty call and and

1654
01:27:08,090 --> 01:27:10,305
Dell or HP or
whoever replaces the motherboard, right?

1655
01:27:10,305 --> 01:27:11,790
>> Hm-mm.
>> When they replace it,

1656
01:27:11,790 --> 01:27:13,830
the Mac address of that unit just changed.

1657
01:27:13,830 --> 01:27:15,710
Now, they're not gonna be able to plug in.

1658
01:27:15,710 --> 01:27:20,130
So you're gonna get a help desk ticket
every time a network card changes or

1659
01:27:20,130 --> 01:27:21,630
a new computer comes in or whatever.

1660
01:27:21,630 --> 01:27:23,880
So there's a lot more
administrative effort involved.

1661
01:27:23,880 --> 01:27:26,325
But, you do get a degree of security.

1662
01:27:26,325 --> 01:27:27,420
>> Right.

1663
01:27:27,420 --> 01:27:30,670
And I say a degree because
MAC addresses can be spoofed.

1664
01:27:30,670 --> 01:27:36,910
Somebody can fake a MAC address, but it
would definitely deter just your average.

1665
01:27:36,910 --> 01:27:40,530
Somebody brings their kid in to work
with them one day and their kid tries.

1666
01:27:40,530 --> 01:27:44,930
Jump on the network, you know,
stop that kind of thing.

1667
01:27:44,930 --> 01:27:48,850
Let's take a look, first just
statically assigning a MAC address.

1668
01:27:48,850 --> 01:27:52,520
And then we'll show some of the ways to
save time and how it all kind of works.

1669
01:27:52,520 --> 01:27:54,280
>> Okay, sounds good.

1670
01:27:54,280 --> 01:28:00,224
>> All right, so right now,
I have a router plugged into port 1.

1671
01:28:00,224 --> 01:28:04,287
Let's take a look at port number 1.

1672
01:28:04,287 --> 01:28:07,290
If I take a look like port
number one on the switch.

1673
01:28:07,290 --> 01:28:10,980
I've got it on Vlan 2 so
I'm gonna put it on Vlan 1 so

1674
01:28:10,980 --> 01:28:13,040
it's a nice default configuration.

1675
01:28:13,040 --> 01:28:16,030
I don't want anything special here.

1676
01:28:16,030 --> 01:28:18,730
To make this more confusing
than it should be, so whoops.

1677
01:28:18,730 --> 01:28:22,570
If I get in the right port that'll help.

1678
01:28:22,570 --> 01:28:25,060
So I'm just gonna put to back to vlan 1.

1679
01:28:25,060 --> 01:28:30,200
Oh, [LAUGH]
switchport access vlan 1,

1680
01:28:30,200 --> 01:28:32,370
that's what I want.

1681
01:28:32,370 --> 01:28:32,870
All right.

1682
01:28:35,290 --> 01:28:36,790
So now if I take a look at it,
there we go.

1683
01:28:36,790 --> 01:28:38,828
Nice default configuration.

1684
01:28:38,828 --> 01:28:41,050
fa0/1 has no Special
commands attached to it.

1685
01:28:41,050 --> 01:28:41,980
Alright?

1686
01:28:41,980 --> 01:28:44,445
I can take a MAC address like
the mac address of that router.

1687
01:28:44,445 --> 01:28:45,010
>> Mm-hm.
>> And

1688
01:28:45,010 --> 01:28:47,120
I can statically assign it to this port.

1689
01:28:47,120 --> 01:28:47,790
>> Right.
>> Right?

1690
01:28:47,790 --> 01:28:52,460
Now if I do that even if I unplug
the router the mac address is

1691
01:28:52,460 --> 01:28:54,680
still assigned to that port so
it's always gonna show up there and

1692
01:28:54,680 --> 01:28:57,220
if I move it to another port
it's gonna cause problems.

1693
01:28:57,220 --> 01:29:00,850
So, we don't want to just go and
modify the MAC address table.

1694
01:29:00,850 --> 01:29:04,720
We want the switch to know that
we're doing this for security sake.

1695
01:29:04,720 --> 01:29:06,370
>> Right.
>> So Cisco switches implement what's

1696
01:29:06,370 --> 01:29:08,800
called switchboard security, and

1697
01:29:08,800 --> 01:29:14,270
it allows us to define the MAC addresses
on the port, and to statically apply that.

1698
01:29:14,270 --> 01:29:18,880
Now, if you have a big network if you
have a network with thousands of PCs,

1699
01:29:18,880 --> 01:29:22,890
you don't wanna have to go around and
catalogue all the MAC addresses and

1700
01:29:22,890 --> 01:29:24,920
write them down and map them to a port.

1701
01:29:24,920 --> 01:29:25,870
It would take forever.

1702
01:29:25,870 --> 01:29:29,830
So there's a nice little system
in here called sticky MACs.

1703
01:29:29,830 --> 01:29:33,430
And sticky MACs lets the switch see
the MAC addresses on there right now,

1704
01:29:33,430 --> 01:29:35,139
record it, and
make it part of our configuration.

1705
01:29:36,330 --> 01:29:39,900
So really the whole idea behind
us using the MAC address here,

1706
01:29:39,900 --> 01:29:44,090
is to limit the access to that port,
really to that MAC address or

1707
01:29:44,090 --> 01:29:48,670
even just to a few MAC addresses,
depending on what we want to do.

1708
01:29:48,670 --> 01:29:53,320
So here, what Don's actually
done was search port FA/1

1709
01:29:53,320 --> 01:29:58,280
is he's turned on port security with
the very first command I had she entered.

1710
01:29:58,280 --> 01:30:00,650
Actually with the-
>> I got an error, right.

1711
01:30:00,650 --> 01:30:02,650
I forgot something important.

1712
01:30:02,650 --> 01:30:06,400
Port security is for access ports only.

1713
01:30:06,400 --> 01:30:08,560
And this switch defaults to dynamic ports.

1714
01:30:08,560 --> 01:30:10,460
Ports that can be accessed or trunk.

1715
01:30:10,460 --> 01:30:13,240
So, when I did a switch port,
port security, it griped at me.

1716
01:30:13,240 --> 01:30:15,260
It said command rejected.

1717
01:30:15,260 --> 01:30:16,660
It's a dynamic port.

1718
01:30:16,660 --> 01:30:19,310
So I just had to turn around and
statically assign it and say,

1719
01:30:19,310 --> 01:30:20,700
switchport mode access.

1720
01:30:20,700 --> 01:30:23,730
I forced it to be an access port,
not trunk port.

1721
01:30:23,730 --> 01:30:25,190
And now I can turn that on.

1722
01:30:25,190 --> 01:30:27,070
You wouldn't want port
security on a trunk.

1723
01:30:27,070 --> 01:30:28,930
>> No.
>> Cuz a trunk is gonna carry

1724
01:30:28,930 --> 01:30:32,180
tons of Mac addresses, so
it's not useful at all there.

1725
01:30:32,180 --> 01:30:35,760
So, what I just did is I
turned on port security.

1726
01:30:35,760 --> 01:30:38,200
So, What did that do?

1727
01:30:38,200 --> 01:30:38,990
Nothing, really.

1728
01:30:38,990 --> 01:30:42,450
It just enabled the security commands for
me to use.

1729
01:30:42,450 --> 01:30:45,910
Now I can go in and I can say things like,

1730
01:30:45,910 --> 01:30:52,630
switchport port-security mac-address and
if I know the MAC address.

1731
01:30:52,630 --> 01:30:57,790
I can manually put it in or
I can say, sticky, which says

1732
01:30:57,790 --> 01:31:02,020
look at whatever MAC address is on this
port right now and map it in, all right?

1733
01:31:02,020 --> 01:31:05,650
So if you know the MAC address, by all
means, hard set it and there you go.

1734
01:31:05,650 --> 01:31:09,630
A lot of times it's easier, though, just
to say sticky It'll look at whatever Mac

1735
01:31:09,630 --> 01:31:13,520
address is on the port and
map that into the configuration.

1736
01:31:13,520 --> 01:31:17,050
>> The next configuration that we have
to do here is the idea of the number

1737
01:31:17,050 --> 01:31:20,060
of Mac addresses that we want
that port to also learn as well,

1738
01:31:20,060 --> 01:31:23,800
now we can actually limit it to one, but
we can actually have more than that.

1739
01:31:23,800 --> 01:31:25,820
Now Don, I don't know.

1740
01:31:25,820 --> 01:31:28,310
Is there an actual maximum number
that we can put on a particular

1741
01:31:28,310 --> 01:31:29,230
port that you know about?

1742
01:31:29,230 --> 01:31:31,410
>> You know I don't know
what the highest number is.

1743
01:31:31,410 --> 01:31:32,200
>> Yeah I don't either.

1744
01:31:32,200 --> 01:31:32,930
>> Oh apparently 6,144.

1745
01:31:32,930 --> 01:31:36,520
>> Well, [LAUGH] I can have
6,144 different MAC addresses

1746
01:31:36,520 --> 01:31:38,600
on that one particular port there.

1747
01:31:38,600 --> 01:31:42,920
But a lot of times if you know that only
one computer is supposed to be on this

1748
01:31:42,920 --> 01:31:45,370
you might limit it to
that single MAC address.

1749
01:31:45,370 --> 01:31:47,440
>> If we're trying to be hardcore, right?

1750
01:31:47,440 --> 01:31:50,750
And make it so
that only this one PC can communicate,

1751
01:31:50,750 --> 01:31:52,940
then we wanna set this maximum to one.

1752
01:31:52,940 --> 01:31:56,620
Maximum of one means, look at that MAC
address that's already there, right,

1753
01:31:56,620 --> 01:31:57,430
we did the sticky command.

1754
01:31:57,430 --> 01:32:02,040
So there's one MAC address already there
If any other Mac address shows up,

1755
01:32:02,040 --> 01:32:02,790
do something.

1756
01:32:02,790 --> 01:32:03,790
We haven't said that yet.

1757
01:32:03,790 --> 01:32:05,390
We'll get to that.

1758
01:32:05,390 --> 01:32:07,040
You might wanna set this higher.

1759
01:32:07,040 --> 01:32:11,530
If you want to allow two Mac addresses or
whatever, just so

1760
01:32:11,530 --> 01:32:14,355
you can have it where somebody
Changed out a machine and it's okay.

1761
01:32:14,355 --> 01:32:15,275
Then you can bump it up.

1762
01:32:15,275 --> 01:32:18,115
But in a high security environment
we normally want to set this to one.

1763
01:32:18,115 --> 01:32:19,635
We'll only allow one MAC address.

1764
01:32:19,635 --> 01:32:23,395
Now if we hadn't done
the sticky MAC up here.

1765
01:32:23,395 --> 01:32:27,360
Then what it would do, is it would say,
I would allow one MAC address, and

1766
01:32:27,360 --> 01:32:28,370
I don't care what MAC address it is.

1767
01:32:28,370 --> 01:32:29,880
It can be any MAC address, right?

1768
01:32:29,880 --> 01:32:33,840
That's useful if you just wanna stop
people from plugging in switches, or hubs,

1769
01:32:33,840 --> 01:32:35,520
or wireless access points, right?

1770
01:32:35,520 --> 01:32:39,600
That'll limit it so that only one
person at a time can talk on the port.

1771
01:32:39,600 --> 01:32:41,260
If somebody plugs in a switch,

1772
01:32:41,260 --> 01:32:44,530
the first person can talk,
the other people can't, right?

1773
01:32:44,530 --> 01:32:46,660
So that's useful if
that's what your goal is.

1774
01:32:46,660 --> 01:32:50,220
But if you're trying to really
lock this down to a single PC,

1775
01:32:50,220 --> 01:32:52,940
you'll say switch port
port security maximum one.

1776
01:32:52,940 --> 01:32:58,660
That locks it to one MAC address and then
switch port port security MAC address and

1777
01:32:58,660 --> 01:33:02,420
then either manually put the address in or
say sticky which will make it learn.

1778
01:33:02,420 --> 01:33:03,070
And you know what?

1779
01:33:03,070 --> 01:33:04,840
Let's make sure that's working.

1780
01:33:04,840 --> 01:33:09,155
If I get out of my configuration,
and I do a show mac

1781
01:33:09,155 --> 01:33:14,858
address-table, and
I filter it to an interface,

1782
01:33:14,858 --> 01:33:20,700
interface fa0/1,
if I look at that interface,

1783
01:33:20,700 --> 01:33:25,600
see how it's got the MAC address of
the router and it said dynamic before.

1784
01:33:25,600 --> 01:33:27,600
Now it says static.

1785
01:33:27,600 --> 01:33:30,830
Now I didn't manually type
this MAC address in, but

1786
01:33:30,830 --> 01:33:35,820
it became static because
we used that sticky option.

1787
01:33:35,820 --> 01:33:40,246
And if I look at the config for
interface FA0/1,

1788
01:33:40,246 --> 01:33:44,360
here's the sticky command that I ran, and

1789
01:33:44,360 --> 01:33:48,280
then here's the sticky
command that was added.

1790
01:33:48,280 --> 01:33:52,570
It saw that first MAC address, and
now it's part of my configuration.

1791
01:33:52,570 --> 01:33:55,540
So when I save my configuration
at the end of the day,

1792
01:33:57,640 --> 01:34:00,770
That MAC address is now
part of the configuration.

1793
01:34:00,770 --> 01:34:05,510
If I reboot the switch, it's still
there and if somebody plugs in and

1794
01:34:05,510 --> 01:34:07,420
their MAC address doesn't match this,

1795
01:34:07,420 --> 01:34:11,590
it would be a second address,
which would exceed my maximum.

1796
01:34:11,590 --> 01:34:15,180
So there clear term about stickiest,
remember, it's the first MAC address,

1797
01:34:15,180 --> 01:34:19,990
which sends information in after it's been
configured, that's it going to learn.

1798
01:34:19,990 --> 01:34:22,030
Now if we set this to a maximum of two,

1799
01:34:22,030 --> 01:34:24,610
that means the first two
devices that plug in.

1800
01:34:24,610 --> 01:34:26,340
The third one, not going to happen.

1801
01:34:27,490 --> 01:34:31,670
>> Now,
I also ran switchport port-security

1802
01:34:31,670 --> 01:34:33,340
>> Maximum one.

1803
01:34:33,340 --> 01:34:34,790
Notice it's not here in the configure.

1804
01:34:34,790 --> 01:34:35,490
What happened?

1805
01:34:35,490 --> 01:34:38,430
Well maximum one is the default.

1806
01:34:38,430 --> 01:34:40,290
So I didn't really have to run that.

1807
01:34:40,290 --> 01:34:42,250
I ran it so you guys would see it.

1808
01:34:42,250 --> 01:34:44,110
It doesn't show up here
because it's the default.

1809
01:34:44,110 --> 01:34:47,440
If I did two two or five or
ten, it would show up.

1810
01:34:47,440 --> 01:34:49,410
But, one is the default.

1811
01:34:49,410 --> 01:34:50,160
>> Even at this point.

1812
01:34:50,160 --> 01:34:54,540
Now that we've got it configured to
learn the very first Mac address and

1813
01:34:54,540 --> 01:34:58,200
we've set the Mac's number,
it's still not gonna do anything.

1814
01:34:58,200 --> 01:35:03,330
In other words, if I leave this and I set
up, it learned about the Mac address.

1815
01:35:03,330 --> 01:35:08,580
Guess what, I could probably still
connect and do other things here.

1816
01:35:08,580 --> 01:35:10,960
But what we need is
something that says what?

1817
01:35:10,960 --> 01:35:11,660
Trigger it.

1818
01:35:11,660 --> 01:35:12,340
>> What to do.

1819
01:35:12,340 --> 01:35:15,360
>> What to do if we actually
have this configured here.

1820
01:35:15,360 --> 01:35:17,840
And so that's what Don has set next here.

1821
01:35:17,840 --> 01:35:21,350
>> Yep.
So if we do a switchport port-security

1822
01:35:21,350 --> 01:35:25,970
violation, we can then pick one
of three actions to take when a,

1823
01:35:25,970 --> 01:35:27,300
well when a violation occurs.

1824
01:35:27,300 --> 01:35:30,440
So if a second Mac address or
a Mac address that doesn't match

1825
01:35:30,440 --> 01:35:33,500
the one that's hard coded shows up,
what do I do, okay?

1826
01:35:33,500 --> 01:35:38,380
Well the three choices are protect,
restrict and shut down.

1827
01:35:38,380 --> 01:35:40,200
Protect is the default, all right.

1828
01:35:40,200 --> 01:35:44,060
With protect, it actually doesn't relaly
do anything as far as the end user.

1829
01:35:44,060 --> 01:35:46,020
>> Yeah.
>> It lets that second Mac just get on and

1830
01:35:46,020 --> 01:35:47,520
communicate or whatever.

1831
01:35:47,520 --> 01:35:50,480
But what protect does,
is it creates a log entry.

1832
01:35:50,480 --> 01:35:54,435
It logs that that violation occurred,
so that we know that it happened.

1833
01:35:54,435 --> 01:35:56,175
But then, it lets the violation happen.

1834
01:35:56,175 --> 01:35:58,105
It still lets them get out there and
communicate.

1835
01:35:58,105 --> 01:36:00,678
This is a passive-agressive type thing.

1836
01:36:00,678 --> 01:36:02,604
It just logs it.

1837
01:36:02,604 --> 01:36:05,020
>> Restrict kinda,
does the same thing here.

1838
01:36:05,020 --> 01:36:08,502
It just doesn't keep the actual
Log itself does it, Don.

1839
01:36:08,502 --> 01:36:10,871
>> Well, restrict actually
goes a little bit further.

1840
01:36:10,871 --> 01:36:13,700
It does log, just like protect.

1841
01:36:13,700 --> 01:36:19,320
But, what restrict does is, it lets the
first MAC address continue to communicate,

1842
01:36:19,320 --> 01:36:23,297
but any additional Mac address
is not allowed to communicate.

1843
01:36:23,297 --> 01:36:23,970
>> Okay.
>> Let's say,

1844
01:36:23,970 --> 01:36:29,130
an attacker brought in a hub and
plugged it in between a PC in the wall.

1845
01:36:29,130 --> 01:36:32,120
The original PC would
still be able to talk.

1846
01:36:32,120 --> 01:36:33,925
But the hacker's machine would not.

1847
01:36:33,925 --> 01:36:34,540
>> Uh-huh, there you go.

1848
01:36:34,540 --> 01:36:36,850
>> Okay.
So restrict still allows the original

1849
01:36:36,850 --> 01:36:37,710
machine to function.

1850
01:36:37,710 --> 01:36:38,660
>> Yeap, yeah.

1851
01:36:38,660 --> 01:36:39,680
>> My favorite's the last one.

1852
01:36:39,680 --> 01:36:40,260
>> Yeah.

1853
01:36:40,260 --> 01:36:42,890
This is the one that I pretty
much use all the time.

1854
01:36:42,890 --> 01:36:46,770
I really don't even consider the other
two, is the idea of shut down.

1855
01:36:46,770 --> 01:36:51,180
Shut down means that if any other,
one besides the MAC

1856
01:36:51,180 --> 01:36:56,210
address that we have here is learned
to actually shut the port off.

1857
01:36:56,210 --> 01:36:58,350
So we're actually tell it that hey,

1858
01:36:58,350 --> 01:37:02,190
another MAC address comes in,
you're going to manually turn that off.

1859
01:37:02,190 --> 01:37:06,020
And we'd actually end up seeing it,
it will say administratively shut down.

1860
01:37:07,110 --> 01:37:08,740
>> Yeap.
So,

1861
01:37:08,740 --> 01:37:11,230
basically Cisco switches
have a neat little state,

1862
01:37:11,230 --> 01:37:16,200
its called Error Disabled all right, and
when they write it, it's EER Disable, so

1863
01:37:16,200 --> 01:37:20,450
you'll hear people call it air disable,
but it's actually short for error Disable.

1864
01:37:20,450 --> 01:37:25,630
And, when a security violation occurs,
the port goes into Error Disable state.

1865
01:37:25,630 --> 01:37:28,730
Alright, that means nobody can talk.

1866
01:37:28,730 --> 01:37:31,660
When a security violation happens
when we're in shutdown mode,

1867
01:37:31,660 --> 01:37:33,250
it turns the port off.

1868
01:37:33,250 --> 01:37:37,300
The port will not come back on,
until and Admin gets involved.

1869
01:37:37,300 --> 01:37:40,260
You can go and shut the port off and
turn it back on again, and

1870
01:37:40,260 --> 01:37:43,635
that clears it out and
then it's able to function.

1871
01:37:43,635 --> 01:37:45,130
So,that's a great way to do it,

1872
01:37:45,130 --> 01:37:48,230
because if a violation happens then
a Network Admin has to get involved.

1873
01:37:48,230 --> 01:37:49,730
Somebody's got to call the help desk,

1874
01:37:49,730 --> 01:37:53,830
you get that warning verses not
doing that at all, just logging.

1875
01:37:53,830 --> 01:37:55,710
Where you might not see it for
a week that it happened,

1876
01:37:55,710 --> 01:37:58,880
depending on how often
you monitor your logs.

1877
01:37:58,880 --> 01:38:02,019
All right, so let's take a look at
that running configuration now.

1878
01:38:03,854 --> 01:38:09,186
Notice that switchboard port security
violation shut down didn't show up,

1879
01:38:09,186 --> 01:38:11,655
because it is also a default right.

1880
01:38:11,655 --> 01:38:14,235
Another default command, so
it's not showing up in the Config.

Well there's a nice little show command we

Actually let me write that on here,

port-security.

And what that show port-security does is

1911
01:39:47,100 --> 01:39:51,010

what their current status is.

1912
01:39:51,010 --> 01:39:52,260
So Fa0/1 has it turned on.

1913
01:39:52,260 --> 01:39:55,540
It's got a maximum address count of 1.

1914
01:39:55,540 --> 01:40:00,980
It currently has 1 MAC address cuz

1915
01:40:00,980 --> 01:40:03,100
So it hasn't had a violation yet.

1916
01:40:03,100 --> 01:40:04,670
It's just sitting there and it's happy.

1917
01:40:05,860 --> 01:40:07,110
Let's cause a violation.

01:40:07,110 --> 01:40:08,430

Sounds good.

1922

1923

1927

And so it's coming up.

Remember, the loop detection,

1929
01:40:33,795 --> 01:40:34,790

>> And

So the port came up and

Error-disabled psecure,

1935

Security violation occurred,
caused by MAC address, and

1936

there's the MAC address of my laptop,

1937
01:40:55,260 --> 01:40:59,460
Let's me know there's a violation and

1938
01:40:59,460 --> 01:41:02,870
It shut the port down,
so I cannot communicate.

1939
01:41:02,870 --> 01:41:05,540
My laptop can no longer
communicate on the network,

1940
01:41:05,540 --> 01:41:07,100
it actually never could
in the first place.

1941
01:41:07,100 --> 01:41:08,100
It was stopped.

1942
01:41:08,100 --> 01:41:10,684
The instant it sent its first frame.

1943
01:41:10,684 --> 01:41:15,759
>> And if you take a look at
the show interface command here,

1944
01:41:15,759 --> 01:41:18,207
show interface fa0/1.

1945
01:41:18,207 --> 01:41:19,957
>> Yep.

1946
01:41:19,957 --> 01:41:20,920
Right there.
>> We can actually see

1947
01:41:20,920 --> 01:41:24,635
what we're looking for as the very
first line directly underneath it, and

1948
01:41:24,635 --> 01:41:29,235
notice that instead of seeing fast
ethernet is down, line protocol is down,

1949
01:41:29,235 --> 01:41:32,490
you also see some additional information
which Don has highlighted there.

1950
01:41:32,490 --> 01:41:35,465
Error disabled is what we actually see
here and remember what that means.

1951
01:41:35,465 --> 01:41:37,510
That means an error has occurred.

1952
01:41:37,510 --> 01:41:39,740
And was just able to because of zero,

1953
01:41:39,740 --> 01:41:43,440
once we do have that it means
somebody else has to get involved.

1954
01:41:43,440 --> 01:41:45,890
Not only do we have to contact
someone to get involved,

1955
01:41:45,890 --> 01:41:49,080
they must fix the issue first.

1956
01:41:49,080 --> 01:41:52,660
So, even if I were to go in, and this is
kinda the first thing that really got me

1957
01:41:52,660 --> 01:41:55,190
when I first started learning this right,
I always heard

1958
01:41:55,190 --> 01:41:59,050
all you have to do is actually shut
the port down and then turn it back on.

1959
01:41:59,050 --> 01:42:02,530
Well, that happened, and the port
looked like it was coming back up,

1960
01:42:02,530 --> 01:42:04,120
then it immediately shut itself off Don.

1961
01:42:04,120 --> 01:42:05,800
>> Yep, you gotta fix the problem.

1962
01:42:05,800 --> 01:42:06,980
>> Gotta fix the problem.

1963
01:42:06,980 --> 01:42:09,780
So if I leave my laptop
plugged into the port,

1964
01:42:09,780 --> 01:42:11,570
it's just gonna violate again, right.

1965
01:42:11,570 --> 01:42:13,690
And so it'll go right back into error.

1966
01:42:13,690 --> 01:42:16,960
I can also run show port-security, and

1967
01:42:16,960 --> 01:42:21,090
in the summary, now I can see I've

1968
01:42:21,090 --> 01:42:25,110
That lets me know that fa0/1 did

1969
01:42:25,110 --> 01:42:29,330
So, one of things Ronnie mentioned was,
if we want to fix the issue.

1970
01:42:29,330 --> 01:42:33,960
The way to reset an error disabled port,
is to just go into configuration,

1971
01:42:33,960 --> 01:42:36,790
get into the port, do a shut down.

1972
01:42:36,790 --> 01:42:38,330
Followed by a no shutdown.

1973
01:42:38,330 --> 01:42:40,720
That resets the port and
that brings it back up.

1974
01:42:40,720 --> 01:42:45,130
Now, my laptop is still plugged in,
so when I run that,

1975
01:42:45,130 --> 01:42:49,540
it's gonna reset it to bring it up, but
it's just gonna error right out again and

1976
01:42:49,540 --> 01:42:52,760
go back down, because my laptop
is still plugged in, all right?

1977
01:42:52,760 --> 01:42:57,030
That's the easiest way to reset a port,
though it is very manual, right?

1978
01:42:57,030 --> 01:42:59,670
As an admin,
I had to connect to the switch and do it.

1979
01:42:59,670 --> 01:43:02,370
That means that I'm aware
that the issue happened.

1980
01:43:02,370 --> 01:43:05,430
I know that there was a violation and
I'm acting on it.

1981
01:43:05,430 --> 01:43:07,120
>> Oop, there it goes again.

1982
01:43:07,120 --> 01:43:10,316
>> Now there is a way to
automatically reset the port.

1983
01:43:10,316 --> 01:43:11,189
All right.

1984
01:43:11,189 --> 01:43:14,240
And it may be that you don't wanna
just shut down the port forever,

1985
01:43:14,240 --> 01:43:15,885
cuz then you have to go and do this.

1986
01:43:15,885 --> 01:43:17,910
>> [LAUGH].
>> Maybe you only wanna shut it down for

1987
01:43:17,910 --> 01:43:18,620
five minutes.

1988
01:43:18,620 --> 01:43:20,310
>> Right.
>> Okay, you can have it

1989
01:43:20,310 --> 01:43:23,450
where the port shuts down for
five minutes and then turns back on.

1990
01:43:23,450 --> 01:43:27,290
If the attacker is still plugged in, it'll
just shut right back off again, right?

1991
01:43:27,290 --> 01:43:31,490
But if the good person is plugged back in,
the port will come up, and

1992
01:43:31,490 --> 01:43:34,540
they'll be able to function and
you didn't have to get involved in it.

1993
01:43:34,540 --> 01:43:36,330
Now you still have a log message.

1994
01:43:36,330 --> 01:43:38,330
>> All right.
>> Your network is protected but

1995
01:43:38,330 --> 01:43:40,760
you still get a log message.

1996
01:43:40,760 --> 01:43:46,070
So, the way we do that is with what's
called error recovery Cisco switches,

1997
01:43:46,070 --> 01:43:46,985
and routers.

1998
01:43:46,985 --> 01:43:48,080
>> Mm-hm.
>> But Cisco switches

1999
01:43:48,080 --> 01:43:48,830
are where we really use it.

2000
01:43:48,830 --> 01:43:53,345
They have error recovery where we can
define an interval of time to wait.

2001
01:43:53,345 --> 01:43:55,230
>> Mm-hm.
>> Before bringing the port back online.

2002
01:43:55,230 --> 01:43:56,048
All right?

2003
01:43:56,048 --> 01:43:59,831
And there's a number of things that
can cause the error disabled state.

2004
01:43:59,831 --> 01:44:00,552
>> Mm-hm.

2005
01:44:00,552 --> 01:44:02,223
>> For the exam,
we only need to know about port security.

2006
01:44:02,223 --> 01:44:02,729
>> Right.

2007
01:44:02,729 --> 01:44:04,980
>> That's the only one that
we're involved in here.

2008
01:44:04,980 --> 01:44:08,360
Basically in our config,
if we get back to our global prompt,

2009
01:44:08,360 --> 01:44:10,670
we've got the error disabled command.

2010
01:44:10,670 --> 01:44:16,570
And you'll see in here what we
can do detect and recovery, okay?

2011
01:44:16,570 --> 01:44:20,090
Detect is how we see that
an error occurred, and

2012
01:44:20,090 --> 01:44:22,550
then recovery is how we recover from it.

2013
01:44:22,550 --> 01:44:26,870
And so
I can say errordisable detect cause,

2014
01:44:26,870 --> 01:44:29,900
and then you'll see all
the different ones in here.

2015
01:44:29,900 --> 01:44:33,420
Security violation is
the one that we want, right?

2016
01:44:33,420 --> 01:44:34,400
I think that's the only one we need.

2017
01:44:34,400 --> 01:44:35,270
Yep.

2018
01:44:35,270 --> 01:44:39,610
All right, so actually,
we do need the whole thing, don't we?

2019
01:44:39,610 --> 01:44:48,300
Shut down, and, okay there we go.

2020
01:44:48,300 --> 01:44:53,350
So, basically we're saying we want
it to detect whenever a shutdown

2021
01:44:53,350 --> 01:44:57,290
happens caused by a security violation,
caused by port security, right?

2022
01:44:57,290 --> 01:45:03,480
Kind of a long command there, and
then we can say errdisable recovery and

2023
01:45:03,480 --> 01:45:09,760
we can specify the cause, so I'm gonna say
based on security violation, there you.

2024
01:45:09,760 --> 01:45:10,260
There it is.

2025
01:45:12,080 --> 01:45:16,690
And then I can say the interval, and

2026
01:45:16,690 --> 01:45:19,260
I can set it to a certain
amount of time in seconds.

2027
01:45:19,260 --> 01:45:22,080
If I want 5 minutes,
what is that, 300 seconds?

2028
01:45:23,130 --> 01:45:23,740
There we go.

2029
01:45:25,090 --> 01:45:30,490
Let me bring those commands back up,
just so we can see that.

2030
01:45:30,490 --> 01:45:31,320
There we go.

2031
01:45:31,320 --> 01:45:36,950
So we did errdisable detect cause
security-violation shutdown vlan, right?

2032
01:45:36,950 --> 01:45:39,320
So looking for when a shutdown happens.

2033
01:45:39,320 --> 01:45:43,090
Air disable recovery
caused security violation.

2034
01:45:43,090 --> 01:45:44,550
If it's a security violation.

2035
01:45:44,550 --> 01:45:47,484
And I guess five minutes is the default
because it didn't' make it in there.

2036
01:45:47,484 --> 01:45:51,810
Let me pick a different interval
maybe we'll do 1 minute, right, so

2037
01:45:51,810 --> 01:45:52,540
we'll do 60 seconds.

2038
01:45:52,540 --> 01:45:59,110
There we go, you see

2039
01:45:59,110 --> 01:46:03,020
default commands don't make it into the
config but if you go with a non standard.

2040
01:46:03,020 --> 01:46:05,960
So 60 seconds is nonstandard,
so it shows up right there.

2041
01:46:05,960 --> 01:46:08,210
So these three commands right here,

2042
01:46:08,210 --> 01:46:11,330
that makes the switch pick up
when the violation happens.

2043
01:46:11,330 --> 01:46:14,540
And if it sees it,
it'll kick into recovery and

2044
01:46:14,540 --> 01:46:17,690
after 60 seconds it'll reset the port for
you.

2045
01:46:17,690 --> 01:46:20,110
If the violation is still there,
it keeps it blocked.

2046
01:46:20,110 --> 01:46:23,630
If the violation is gone, it allows
the port to become healthy again.

2047
01:46:23,630 --> 01:46:25,420
>> And this is very good
especially when you have,

2048
01:46:25,420 --> 01:46:27,370
well, hundreds of machines, right?

2049
01:46:27,370 --> 01:46:30,320
And you don't have time a lot of times,
that you should go and fix all 100

2050
01:46:30,320 --> 01:46:35,120
if they all go into violation at the same
time, so by allowing us to set this up and

2051
01:46:35,120 --> 01:46:38,550
it makes it automated, we simply
go ahead and we fix the issue and

2052
01:46:38,550 --> 01:46:42,540
we tell them in just a few minutes it will
kick back on and they'll be ready to go.

2053
01:46:42,540 --> 01:46:46,010
>> So excellent system, pretty easy to
work with, and if you have thousands and

2054
01:46:46,010 --> 01:46:51,060
thousands of machines using sticky Macs
and using air disable auto recovery,

2055
01:46:51,060 --> 01:46:54,560
using those combined, you can get a very
secure system in just a matter of minutes,

2056
01:46:54,560 --> 01:46:56,550
just by launching these commands.

2057
01:46:56,550 --> 01:46:59,940
And we set up that port security
on one single port, but

2058
01:46:59,940 --> 01:47:02,430
we could have used
the interface range command to

2059
01:47:02,430 --> 01:47:05,009
to configure it on all of our ports and
knock this out real fast.

2060
01:47:07,620 --> 01:47:09,660
All right, Ronnie,
what else do we have on security?

2061
01:47:09,660 --> 01:47:10,630
I think we got most of it.

2062
01:47:10,630 --> 01:47:12,690
Oh some general practice things.

2063
01:47:12,690 --> 01:47:14,200
>> So let's make sure we understand too.

2064
01:47:14,200 --> 01:47:19,490
Now not only is the best practice to limit
who can access the switch itself, but

2065
01:47:19,490 --> 01:47:24,940
what if we don't really want to remove
all of those patch cables here, okay?

2066
01:47:26,110 --> 01:47:28,850
Because I know that those
ports may be used later on,

2067
01:47:28,850 --> 01:47:32,730
I don't want to have to go and find new
patch cables and connect them all back in,

2068
01:47:32,730 --> 01:47:36,410
well, one of the best practices
that we can have is to simply

2069
01:47:36,410 --> 01:47:41,710
just administratively turn off
ports that we're not using, okay.

2070
01:47:41,710 --> 01:47:44,610
Administrative shutdown means that
nothing's going to turn it on

2071
01:47:44,610 --> 01:47:46,570
until someone comes in to turn them on.

2072
01:47:46,570 --> 01:47:49,310
So that may be another way for
us to do that.

2073
01:47:49,310 --> 01:47:51,130
>> Yeah and
there's two different approaches, right?

2074
01:47:51,130 --> 01:47:53,150
The one that I recommend
is what Ronnie said, right?

2075
01:47:53,150 --> 01:47:55,850
If you have a port that you're not using,
go into the switch,

2076
01:47:55,850 --> 01:47:57,110
issue the shutdown command.

2077
01:47:57,110 --> 01:47:58,180
It turns it off.

2078
01:47:58,180 --> 01:47:59,820
Now it's actually not possible, right?

2079
01:47:59,820 --> 01:48:00,510
That's the best.

2080
01:48:00,510 --> 01:48:03,640
>> So using the interface range command,
selecting all those

2081
01:48:03,640 --> 01:48:06,930
ports that we don't actually want
to be able to or we're not using.

2082
01:48:06,930 --> 01:48:09,950
And then putting in
the id of shutdown here.

2083
01:48:09,950 --> 01:48:12,600
That will turn all of those
unused ports off for us.

2084
01:48:12,600 --> 01:48:16,715
>> Another option is you can create a,
we call it a dead VLAN.

2085
01:48:16,715 --> 01:48:18,660
>> Mm-hm.
>> A VLAN with nothing else on it.

2086
01:48:18,660 --> 01:48:19,180
>> Unused, yep.

2087
01:48:19,180 --> 01:48:22,580
>> And you can assign any
unused port to that VLAN.

2088
01:48:22,580 --> 01:48:25,640
By doing that, if somebody plugs into
the unused port, they get a link light.

2089
01:48:25,640 --> 01:48:27,040
>> Yeah.
>> But they're not on your main network.

2090
01:48:27,040 --> 01:48:29,600
They're partitioned off on a VLAN.

2091
01:48:29,600 --> 01:48:33,540
That is effective, but there are some
VLAN attacks that are out there.

2092
01:48:33,540 --> 01:48:35,970
And so it's not as good as
just shutting the port off.

2093
01:48:35,970 --> 01:48:37,250
I recommend shutting the port off.

2094
01:48:37,250 --> 01:48:41,360
But assigning the port to an unused
VLAN is another approach, and

2095
01:48:41,360 --> 01:48:44,960
it's one of the Cisco recommendations,
so it can show up on the exam.

2096
01:48:44,960 --> 01:48:48,870
>> Now Don I've heard that
people shouldn't use VLAN1.

2097
01:48:48,870 --> 01:48:50,830
Is there a particular reason for that?

2098
01:48:50,830 --> 01:48:54,650
>> Yeah so on your switch,
remember that VLAN1 is the default, right?

2099
01:48:54,650 --> 01:48:59,650
And so the admin port, when you Telnet or
SSH into a switch, that IP address.

2100
01:48:59,650 --> 01:49:01,390
That's attached to VLAN1.

2101
01:49:01,390 --> 01:49:05,830
So an attacker that's out there, they're
gonna know, hey, I wanna get on VLAN 1.

2102
01:49:05,830 --> 01:49:09,570
So the temptation that we have when we get
a new switch is to use VLAN 1 as our main

2103
01:49:09,570 --> 01:49:15,350
network, and what you should do instead is
move all your PCs to some other VLAN and

2104
01:49:15,350 --> 01:49:16,640
don't use VLAN 1.

2105
01:49:16,640 --> 01:49:18,780
You can use VLAN 1 for
management if you need to.

2106
01:49:18,780 --> 01:49:23,160
But you shouldn't have PC's and
servers and stuff like that one VLAN 1.

2107
01:49:23,160 --> 01:49:25,890
It should just be for like switch
management, or router management.

2108
01:49:25,890 --> 01:49:27,610
Everything else should
be on a different VLAN.

2109
01:49:27,610 --> 01:49:29,790
>> Now does that include trunking maybe,
even?

2110
01:49:29,790 --> 01:49:33,490
>> Well, now see on the trunking
side if you're using VLAN 1 for

2111
01:49:33,490 --> 01:49:36,860
management, you're going to need to have
that available in the various switches so

2112
01:49:36,860 --> 01:49:38,350
you'll want to truncate.

2113
01:49:38,350 --> 01:49:43,300
Switches, one of the attacks, and
we've tackled this in the security show so

2114
01:49:43,300 --> 01:49:45,270
I don't want to go too crazy on it here,
but

2115
01:49:45,270 --> 01:49:50,230
one of the attacks that you can do is
called VLAN jumping, where you can

2116
01:49:50,230 --> 01:49:55,190
basically corrupt your VLAN tag, and
end up on what's called the default VLAN.

2117
01:49:55,190 --> 01:50:00,620
Every trunk has a default or native
VLAN that untags packets going across.

2118
01:50:00,620 --> 01:50:02,630
And the default is VLAN1.

2119
01:50:02,630 --> 01:50:06,270
So most attackers know if they
can just damage their VLAN tag,

2120
01:50:06,270 --> 01:50:07,960
that they can end up on
that management VLAN.

2121
01:50:07,960 --> 01:50:09,250
That's a bad thing.

2122
01:50:09,250 --> 01:50:14,310
So one of the last things that we can do
for security is change that native VLAN,

2123
01:50:14,310 --> 01:50:20,370
so that if an attacker damages their tag,
they end up on this other VLAN instead.

2124
01:50:20,370 --> 01:50:23,480
So I set up that trunker,
let's go back to the switch.

2125
01:50:25,490 --> 01:50:29,760
I set up that trunk earlier
on port 47 where I said

2126
01:50:29,760 --> 01:50:33,130
switchboard mode trunk like that, right?

2127
01:50:33,130 --> 01:50:37,200
Well when we define a trunk, there's
actually a lot more that you can define.

2128
01:50:38,290 --> 01:50:41,280
And so you'll see some of the different
things that we can set in here.

2129
01:50:41,280 --> 01:50:45,660
The one I'm looking for is under the trunk
subsetting, which is trunk native,

2130
01:50:45,660 --> 01:50:49,260
and then you can specify a VLAN number.

2131
01:50:49,260 --> 01:50:53,440
So the default is that
the native VLAN is VLAN1.

2132
01:50:53,440 --> 01:50:56,360
And if somebody does one of
those corrupted tag attacks,

2133
01:50:56,360 --> 01:50:58,930
they could end up on that VLAN,
and that's your management VLAN.

2134
01:50:58,930 --> 01:50:59,960
>> Right.
>> Right.

2135
01:50:59,960 --> 01:51:02,370
So instead, we could pick a dummy VLAN.

2136
01:51:02,370 --> 01:51:05,119
I usually use 999,
which now I've told everybody [LAUGH].

2137
01:51:05,119 --> 01:51:06,525
>> [LAUGH].

2138
01:51:06,525 --> 01:51:07,917
>> So
>> So anyhow,

2139
01:51:07,917 --> 01:51:11,720
we say switchport trunk native VLAN 999,
right?

2140
01:51:11,720 --> 01:51:16,080
Now any untagged traffic,
any traffic that has a corrupt tag or

2141
01:51:16,080 --> 01:51:18,220
no tag will end up on VLAN 999.

2142
01:51:18,220 --> 01:51:21,896
Well, if I don't use that VLAN,
then great, have at it.

2143
01:51:21,896 --> 01:51:23,184
>> Yeah, there you go.

2144
01:51:23,184 --> 01:51:24,620
>> Welcome, go ahead.

2145
01:51:24,620 --> 01:51:29,000
So that's an extra degree of security if
somebody tries to perform a VLAN attack.

2146
01:51:29,000 --> 01:51:30,350
>> Yep.

2147
01:51:30,350 --> 01:51:30,860
>> Yeah.

2148
01:51:30,860 --> 01:51:32,090
One thing to remember.

2149
01:51:32,090 --> 01:51:35,810
That setting has to be done
on both ends of the trunk.

2150
01:51:35,810 --> 01:51:38,440
So, I just did it on
this switch behind me.

2151
01:51:38,440 --> 01:51:41,650
I now would need to do it to the switch
on the other end of that cable.

2152
01:51:41,650 --> 01:51:46,920
So real important, any trunk settings have
to be done on both ends of the cable.

2153
01:51:46,920 --> 01:51:47,540
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, and

2154
01:51:47,540 --> 01:51:49,170
that goes for any trunk setting.

2155
01:51:49,170 --> 01:51:49,850
>> Yeah.

2156
01:51:49,850 --> 01:51:50,930
Make sure of that.

2157
01:51:50,930 --> 01:51:52,560
Because it's not gonna work if you don't.

2158
01:51:52,560 --> 01:51:53,630
>> Yeah, absolutely.

2159
01:51:53,630 --> 01:51:58,680
It will wreak all sorts of havoc, so yeah,
definitely something to keep in mind.

2160
01:51:58,680 --> 01:52:01,350
All right, so
as far as our switch security,

2161
01:52:01,350 --> 01:52:04,310
we got to see statically
assigning a MAC address,

2162
01:52:04,310 --> 01:52:08,200
we got to see setting violations,
if we exceed that count.

2163
01:52:08,200 --> 01:52:11,930
We got a chance to talk a little bit
about shutting down unused boards and

2164
01:52:11,930 --> 01:52:13,520
changing the native VLANs.

2165
01:52:13,520 --> 01:52:16,950
But those are all things that we need to
be aware of when it comes to security on

2166
01:52:16,950 --> 01:52:17,716
a Cisco switch.

2167
01:52:17,716 --> 01:52:18,886
>> Sounds good.

2168
01:52:18,886 --> 01:52:23,480
>> And [COUGH] for any of you that go on
to do the CCNA Security certification,

2169
01:52:23,480 --> 01:52:25,720
there is a lot more you
can do on the switch.

2170
01:52:25,720 --> 01:52:29,020
But for the CCENT exam,
those are the ones you need to know.

2171
01:52:29,020 --> 01:52:30,300
>> Right.

2172
01:52:30,300 --> 01:52:33,440
>> All right, well ladies and gentlemen
as always we hope you enjoyed the show.

2173
01:52:33,440 --> 01:52:38,000
Definitely stay tuned for our next,
well actually, our next episode for

2174
01:52:38,000 --> 01:52:41,900
the CCNT show, we're gonna be getting into
routing, and all the routing technologies.

2175
01:52:41,900 --> 01:52:43,450
Great stuff can be found there.

2176
01:52:43,450 --> 01:52:47,420
As well as our other shows that
are filming right now, like Security+ and-

2177
01:52:47,420 --> 01:52:48,210
>> Network+.

2178
01:52:48,210 --> 01:52:49,100
>> What else is going on?

2179
01:52:49,100 --> 01:52:51,330
Windows 8, all sorts of good
stuff going on right now.

2180
01:52:51,330 --> 01:52:54,870
So check the other shows out if
you've got the time and the desire.

2181
01:52:54,870 --> 01:52:59,940
Otherwise, stay tuned for future Cisco
episodes and signing up for IT Pro TV.

2182
01:52:59,940 --> 01:53:00,980
I'm Don Pezet.

2183
01:53:00,980 --> 01:53:01,790
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

2184
01:53:01,790 --> 01:53:03,154
>> And we'll see you next time around.

2185
01:53:03,154 --> 01:53:07,579
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The primary use for SVI's is for layer 3 switching, where switches start to take on some of the routing roles. Viewers will hear about switch virtual interfaces (SVI) and discussions on various troubleshooting tools for switches.
episodes.title: Switch Technologies
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:34,045 --> 00:00:35,382
Hey!
>> All right, good morning,

3
00:00:35,382 --> 00:00:36,547
good afternoon and good evening.

4
00:00:36,547 --> 00:00:38,921
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:38,921 --> 00:00:41,462
I'm your host Don Pezet,
today with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,462 --> 00:00:42,610
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,610 --> 00:00:43,990
>> I am doing well today.

8
00:00:43,990 --> 00:00:48,940
I am doing better than any
cast member of anybody

9
00:00:48,940 --> 00:00:52,910
that ever appeared on Gilmore Girls.

10
00:00:52,910 --> 00:00:53,570
>> You know.

11
00:00:53,570 --> 00:00:54,420
>> I'm lying to you.

12
00:00:54,420 --> 00:00:55,040
I'm lying to you.

13
00:00:55,040 --> 00:00:56,626
>> I don't know the future fate
of anybody on Gilmore Girls.

14
00:00:56,626 --> 00:00:58,950
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know the grandfather was in

15
00:00:58,950 --> 00:00:59,910
The Lost Boys.

16
00:00:59,910 --> 00:01:01,120
>> Yes.
And what happened to him?

17
00:01:01,120 --> 00:01:01,730
>> He was the main.

18
00:01:01,730 --> 00:01:04,410
Oh we don't want to ruin,
no spoilers for lost boys.

19
00:01:04,410 --> 00:01:06,670
>> Yeah,
just in case you haven't seen it yet.

20
00:01:06,670 --> 00:01:10,276
>> Yeah the movie's been out for 20 years.

21
00:01:10,276 --> 00:01:12,270
[LAUGH] All right.

22
00:01:12,270 --> 00:01:14,960
>> I'm lying.
>> So today we've got another Cisco

23
00:01:14,960 --> 00:01:15,700
episode ahead for you.

24
00:01:15,700 --> 00:01:16,660
>> That's right.
>> And we are gonna

25
00:01:16,660 --> 00:01:19,410
be tackling the wonderful
world of switches.

26
00:01:19,410 --> 00:01:20,150
>> That's right.

27
00:01:20,150 --> 00:01:23,975
We actually already did, you know,
a good solid episode or two, I think,

28
00:01:23,975 --> 00:01:24,950
on switches.

29
00:01:24,950 --> 00:01:30,220
But we still have a couple of extra
little things that turn up on the exam

30
00:01:30,220 --> 00:01:34,420
that we need to make sure we cover so
that we've got you guys covered, right?

31
00:01:34,420 --> 00:01:36,630
>> Yeah,
don't forget that Cisco equipment for

32
00:01:36,630 --> 00:01:40,594
us tends to generate a ton of information,
and a lot of times when you're new to it,

33
00:01:40,594 --> 00:01:43,820
right, you start doing these
different shell commands.

34
00:01:43,820 --> 00:01:46,790
You run across and all of a sudden
it spits out like 20 lines of stuff.

35
00:01:46,790 --> 00:01:48,990
And you're going well,
I wonder what those things are about.

36
00:01:48,990 --> 00:01:53,670
Well we're gonna talk about a lot of those
little, tiny things that really should be

37
00:01:53,670 --> 00:01:59,340
part of a skill set of anybody
heading towards a CCENT track for us.

38
00:01:59,340 --> 00:02:02,080
So just to get you familiar with that and
also some

39
00:02:02,080 --> 00:02:05,910
other troubleshooting problems that tend
to pop up, just in basic configuration.

40
00:02:05,910 --> 00:02:09,210
And I know as somebody, when I started,
I had a lot of these errors and

41
00:02:09,210 --> 00:02:11,360
I was just like oh,
I gotta do something about 'em, and so

42
00:02:11,360 --> 00:02:13,542
we're gonna take a look
at some of those issues.

43
00:02:13,542 --> 00:02:16,580
>> Yeah, now the first thing
we're gonna tackle today,

44
00:02:16,580 --> 00:02:20,840
is what's called an SVI,
the switch virtual interface.

45
00:02:20,840 --> 00:02:24,630
And for those of you guys following
along in the objective list,

46
00:02:24,630 --> 00:02:29,836
SVIs are objective number,
what is it, 4.9,

47
00:02:29,836 --> 00:02:34,660
right, configure SVI interfaces
is what Cisco calls out.

48
00:02:34,660 --> 00:02:37,490
So what the heck is an SVI?

49
00:02:37,490 --> 00:02:42,386
Well, on a switch you have physical
interfaces, tons of physical interfaces,

50
00:02:42,386 --> 00:02:42,890
right.

51
00:02:42,890 --> 00:02:46,110
The switches I've got behind us,
we have two 3560s here.

52
00:02:46,110 --> 00:02:50,270
They're 48 ports each, so they've got 48
physical ports across the front of them.

53
00:02:50,270 --> 00:02:53,740
Not counting the uplinks,
the SFPs on the side.

54
00:02:55,400 --> 00:02:58,560
But, if your switch is set up to do VLANs,
right,

55
00:02:58,560 --> 00:03:03,550
Virtual Local Area Networks,
you can also have virtual interfaces.

56
00:03:03,550 --> 00:03:07,220
Virtual interfaces on each VLAN,
that aren't a physical one,

57
00:03:07,220 --> 00:03:09,940
it's not a port on the front of
the switch, it's something virtual.

58
00:03:09,940 --> 00:03:12,480
It's floating in the back
plane of the switch, right,

59
00:03:12,480 --> 00:03:15,560
the ethereal,
floating eyeball or whatever.

60
00:03:15,560 --> 00:03:19,394
>> So these are not actually ports
that match up to any physical port

61
00:03:19,394 --> 00:03:20,250
that we have.

62
00:03:20,250 --> 00:03:21,718
But the VLANs are actually
very important for

63
00:03:21,718 --> 00:03:24,520
us if we're gonna do what we
talked about in earlier episodes.

64
00:03:24,520 --> 00:03:29,010
Essentially taking one big gigantic
switch and being able to chop them,

65
00:03:29,010 --> 00:03:32,690
not physically chop them, but
logically divide up that switch and

66
00:03:32,690 --> 00:03:34,100
treat it as multiple ones.

67
00:03:34,100 --> 00:03:36,900
So, SVIs are what helps us to do that.

68
00:03:36,900 --> 00:03:41,670
>> Now, every switch has one SVI already
right out of the box, and that's what we

69
00:03:41,670 --> 00:03:46,140
saw in the other episode, was the VLAN 1
interface, and it's there for management.

70
00:03:46,140 --> 00:03:48,530
If you wanna telnet or
SSH into the switch,

71
00:03:48,530 --> 00:03:50,720
if you wanna browse to its web interface,

72
00:03:50,720 --> 00:03:54,490
that's the interface that you assign an IP
address to and you browse in to get at it.

73
00:03:54,490 --> 00:03:59,410
So that's a standard configuration and
something that we saw in the last episode.

74
00:04:00,510 --> 00:04:05,150
However, we can create as
many more SVI's as we want.

75
00:04:05,150 --> 00:04:08,750
You normally have,
well the SVIs are tied to your VLANs.

76
00:04:08,750 --> 00:04:13,270
So you can have up to one SVI for
every VLAN.

77
00:04:13,270 --> 00:04:16,410
You can't have more than
one SVI on the same VLAN.

78
00:04:16,410 --> 00:04:20,790
So if I've got 40 VLANs, I could have
40 SVIs if I wanted them to, right.

79
00:04:20,790 --> 00:04:22,640
By default it's just VLAN 1.

80
00:04:22,640 --> 00:04:26,849
And it's kind of funny that Cisco calls
this one out in the CCENT objectives,

81
00:04:26,849 --> 00:04:30,541
because the primary use for
these SVI's is for layer 3 switching,

82
00:04:30,541 --> 00:04:33,970
where our switches start to
do some of the routing roles.

83
00:04:33,970 --> 00:04:36,680
And we don't really deal with
that until the CCNA exam.

84
00:04:36,680 --> 00:04:37,370
>> Yeah.

85
00:04:37,370 --> 00:04:41,050
One of the first things that you may do,
at least at CCENT level,

86
00:04:41,050 --> 00:04:44,340
is when you start working with both
router and switches just a little bit,

87
00:04:44,340 --> 00:04:47,795
is that you think, hey,
on a router interface, I go into interface

88
00:04:47,795 --> 00:04:52,980
FA0/1 you do your IP address command and
then you type in an IP address.

89
00:04:52,980 --> 00:04:54,990
You keep doing that over and over again,

90
00:04:54,990 --> 00:04:58,420
all the sudden you switch on over to
a switch and then you do the same thing.

91
00:04:58,420 --> 00:05:03,955
Interface, fa0/1, you type in a IP address
and it tells you, you can't do it.

92
00:05:03,955 --> 00:05:05,130
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, at that point you're

93
00:05:05,130 --> 00:05:08,020
kind of like, well,
what in the world is going on?

94
00:05:08,020 --> 00:05:12,970
I know that I saw Don actually type in
an interface on a switch interface.

95
00:05:12,970 --> 00:05:17,500
Well, that's what we're typing in right
there, is that SVI is actually where we

96
00:05:17,500 --> 00:05:22,970
end up putting an IP address on
that virtual interface as well.

97
00:05:22,970 --> 00:05:26,350
So sometimes when you get confused,
that's what it might be.

98
00:05:26,350 --> 00:05:28,910
So we want to make sure that we actually
understand that a little bit better today.

99
00:05:30,210 --> 00:05:33,810
>> All right, so let's start with the one
that's built in, right, that VLAN 1.

100
00:05:33,810 --> 00:05:37,090
I'm on a switch here, this is that
same one we used in the other episode.

101
00:05:37,090 --> 00:05:42,070
And if I do a show ip interface brief,
right,

102
00:05:42,070 --> 00:05:44,230
which gives me my interface summary.

103
00:05:44,230 --> 00:05:48,600
When I look at it, right there at the top,
there's an interface VLAN1.

104
00:05:48,600 --> 00:05:52,180
That is an SVI,
a switch virtual interface.

105
00:05:52,180 --> 00:05:54,000
Now on Cisco websites every now and

106
00:05:54,000 --> 00:05:58,150
then you'll see the term BVI,
which is a bridge virtual interface.

107
00:05:58,150 --> 00:06:02,110
And technically SVI's and
BVI's are really the same.

108
00:06:02,110 --> 00:06:04,650
You can create BVI's on
routers also though,

109
00:06:04,650 --> 00:06:07,375
sometimes routers can act as a bridge and
they call them brouters.

110
00:06:07,375 --> 00:06:10,586
[CROSSTALK] It's a CompTIA thing.

111
00:06:10,586 --> 00:06:15,060
But anyhow, so this one just
has that one SVI and that's it.

112
00:06:15,060 --> 00:06:17,292
But if we start creating multiple VLANs,

113
00:06:17,292 --> 00:06:19,795
we might wanna have an IP
address on each VLAN.

114
00:06:19,795 --> 00:06:22,870
It's useful useful for management,
but more for routing, really.

115
00:06:22,870 --> 00:06:25,040
So we can go in and
create as many as we want.

116
00:06:25,040 --> 00:06:28,260
If I do a, show interface vlan 1, and

117
00:06:28,260 --> 00:06:31,940
actually look at it,
here it tells me VLAN 1 is up.

118
00:06:31,940 --> 00:06:34,380
Hardware is EtherSVI, okay.

119
00:06:35,420 --> 00:06:39,520
So right there it's letting me know
that this is a switch virtual interface.

120
00:06:39,520 --> 00:06:42,420
The VLAN 1 interface cannot be removed.

121
00:06:42,420 --> 00:06:44,690
It's part of the factory default settings.

122
00:06:44,690 --> 00:06:46,770
You can shut it down, you can turn it off.

123
00:06:46,770 --> 00:06:48,920
I'm not gonna do it now,
cuz I'd disconnect.

124
00:06:48,920 --> 00:06:52,310
But you can shut it off,
but you can't remove it.

125
00:06:52,310 --> 00:06:53,960
So it's always there.

126
00:06:53,960 --> 00:06:57,350
The rest, though, are up to you.

127
00:06:57,350 --> 00:06:59,570
So if we wanna create more
it's actually really easy.

128
00:07:00,570 --> 00:07:04,544
So let's say I've got a VLAN,
I'll say VLAN 2.

129
00:07:05,620 --> 00:07:07,750
Actually, you know what,
let's pick a VLAN that I'm not using.

130
00:07:07,750 --> 00:07:09,830
I'll do VLAN 222, all right.

131
00:07:09,830 --> 00:07:15,340
And I'll give it a name and
I'll call it the ITProTV-Show, all right.

132
00:07:15,340 --> 00:07:17,600
So I've now got a VLAN, VLAN 222, right.

133
00:07:19,010 --> 00:07:21,540
And if I wanna be able to telnet or

134
00:07:21,540 --> 00:07:27,930
SSH into the switch from that VLAN,
I'm gonna need an IP address on that VLAN.

135
00:07:27,930 --> 00:07:35,030
So, I create an SVI by typing,
interface vlan 222, all right.

136
00:07:36,510 --> 00:07:41,650
When I do that, that's going to
create the SVI right there, okay.

137
00:07:41,650 --> 00:07:46,756
So it's actually getting created,
I can assign it an IP address.

138
00:07:46,756 --> 00:07:53,752
What network do I want,
here I'll use 192.168.0.10, all right.

139
00:07:53,752 --> 00:07:57,842
Okay, and
I can issue the no shutdown command.

140
00:07:57,842 --> 00:07:58,844
You know, I don't remember offhand.

141
00:07:58,844 --> 00:08:00,730
I think they're shut down by default.

142
00:08:00,730 --> 00:08:05,040
So I'll do a no shutdown,
and now that SVI is created.

143
00:08:05,040 --> 00:08:09,103
All right, now I didn't get a status
message saying the interface is coming up,

144
00:08:09,103 --> 00:08:12,589
and that's probably because I
don't have any ports in VLAN 222.

145
00:08:12,589 --> 00:08:15,320

usually that's at least the minimal.

But if you do end up with a Cisco router

00:27:01,204 --> 00:27:05,564

the IP address, the DHCP and that will

00:29:05,098 --> 00:29:09,994

00:29:12,382 --> 00:29:14,910

00:29:14,910 --> 00:29:19,440

557
00:29:21,140 --> 00:29:24,040
In the initial switch set up episode,

558
00:29:24,040 --> 00:29:27,830
we talked about how important it was

559
00:29:27,830 --> 00:29:30,910
on our routers, so that our log
files would all be synchronized.

00:29:30,910 --> 00:29:34,037
If you're sending your log files
to a log server especially,

561
00:29:34,037 --> 00:29:35,945
you want all your clocks
to be set the same,

562
00:29:35,945 --> 00:29:38,502
so you can correlate events
between different devices.

563
00:29:38,502 --> 00:29:41,420
Unfortunately, it's not very easy
if you're manually doing it.

564
00:29:41,420 --> 00:29:45,380
But all Cisco devices
support using a time server.

565
00:29:45,380 --> 00:29:47,590
So, you can have
a centralized time server or

566
00:29:47,590 --> 00:29:51,360
an external time source,
key all your devices to use it, and

567
00:29:51,360 --> 00:29:54,620
they'll all have clocks that
are set to the exact precise time.

568
00:29:54,620 --> 00:29:55,810
It's pretty awesome stuff.

569
00:29:55,810 --> 00:29:56,550
>> Yeah.

570
00:29:56,550 --> 00:30:01,146
It really does help us, not only in things
like logging but the idea of timing and

571
00:30:01,146 --> 00:30:05,195
making sure everything's actually
coordinating the way we need to,

572
00:30:05,195 --> 00:30:09,954
is important in things like authentication
for our network and everything else.

573
00:30:09,954 --> 00:30:13,980
So, for us to bring everything under that
unified idea of time is actually very

574
00:30:13,980 --> 00:30:17,240
helpful in just about
everything we do in networking.

575
00:30:17,240 --> 00:30:20,090
And so,
we wanna make sure that we get this right.

00:30:20,090 --> 00:30:24,670
>> Now, before we jump into

00:30:24,670 --> 00:30:28,900

00:30:28,900 --> 00:30:33,525
A lot of people will use GMT

00:30:33,525 --> 00:30:36,935

00:30:36,935 --> 00:30:40,935

zones and stuff, it can be a pain to sit

00:30:40,935 --> 00:30:43,810

00:30:43,810 --> 00:30:46,680

00:30:46,680 --> 00:30:48,960

in the other episode I showed that.

00:30:54,620 --> 00:30:56,773

00:31:00,254 --> 00:31:04,290

00:31:05,910 --> 00:31:08,250

00:31:08,250 --> 00:31:09,230

00:31:12,161 --> 00:31:15,804

>> So, I need to make sure that it knows

00:31:15,804 --> 00:31:19,720
that we are in eastern time,

00:31:19,720 --> 00:31:22,910
And that it is minus five from GMT.

00:31:22,910 --> 00:31:23,620
That's our offset.

00:31:24,820 --> 00:31:27,885
But I'm also gonna tell it,

00:31:27,885 --> 00:31:32,490

00:44:46,070 --> 00:44:49,730

859
00:44:49,730 --> 00:44:53,200
When you take a switch and
you have an uplink.

860
00:44:53,200 --> 00:44:55,830
A cable that runs from
one switch to another.

00:44:55,830 --> 00:45:01,395
It's possible you could configure

00:45:01,395 --> 00:45:02,330
another VLAN on the other.

863
00:45:02,330 --> 00:45:03,240
And if there's a mismatch,

864
00:45:03,240 --> 00:45:06,600
if the VLAN numbers don't match,
then that can cause some problems.

865
00:45:06,600 --> 00:45:09,930
It can cause traffic to bleed
from one VLAN to another.

866
00:45:09,930 --> 00:45:14,170
It causes issues, but fortunately
your Cisco switches watch for that.

867
00:45:14,170 --> 00:45:14,810
They see it.

00:45:14,810 --> 00:45:19,370
They pay attention, and
they will actually warn you about it.

Cisco switches, when you buy them
from the factory they have an MTU,

1065
00:55:13,770 --> 00:55:17,110
a maximum transmission unit,
that's a sign.

1066
00:55:17,110 --> 00:55:19,390
And it can vary from switch to switch,

1067
00:55:19,390 --> 00:55:23,170
and you can configure that yourself,
but it is,

1068
00:55:23,170 --> 00:55:28,290
if you do a show interface for any of your
interfaces, the MTU is buried right here.

1069
00:55:28,290 --> 00:55:29,650
MTU 1500 bytes.

1070
00:55:30,940 --> 00:55:34,890
So it's telling us right here
that if we receive a frame,

1071
00:55:34,890 --> 00:55:36,790
that frame should not any
bigger than 1500 bytes.

1072
00:55:38,090 --> 00:55:39,890
But it is something that you can adjust.

1073
00:55:40,970 --> 00:55:43,600
And the important thing here is
if you adjust it on a switch,

1074
00:55:43,600 --> 00:55:47,150
you've actually got to adjust it on
the entire pathway from the source of

1075
00:55:47,150 --> 00:55:49,290
the communication to the end
of the communication.

1076
00:55:49,290 --> 00:55:51,750
Otherwise you're gonna have some problems.

1077
00:55:51,750 --> 00:55:52,310
All right.

1078
00:55:52,310 --> 00:55:56,999
So Cisco switches will do detection to see
when that MTU doesn't match and so again,

1079
00:55:56,999 --> 00:56:00,250
it's warning you and
letting you know about the problem.

1080
00:56:00,250 --> 00:56:01,194
All right.
Now,

1081
00:56:01,194 --> 00:56:05,630
you can adjust the MTU on
the entire switch if you want.

1082
00:56:05,630 --> 00:56:11,330
By doing the system mtu command and then
specifying what you want the size to be.

1083
00:56:11,330 --> 00:56:14,868
Now, 1500 through 1998
are considered normal size.

1084
00:56:14,868 --> 00:56:18,441
Most systems will reject anything
over about 1518 though, so

1085
00:56:18,441 --> 00:56:21,020
you don't normally go all the way up.

1086
00:56:21,020 --> 00:56:25,652
Some systems support jumbo frames, right,
and you'll see that on like storage area

1087
00:56:25,652 --> 00:56:30,174
networks, where our, iSCSI networks,
really, and they'll do like 9000.

1088
00:56:30,174 --> 00:56:33,588
We actually do that on one of ours here,
so we've got like 9000 bytes.

1089
00:56:33,588 --> 00:56:36,596
But it just depends on your network.

1090
00:56:36,596 --> 00:56:39,890
1500 is really common.

1091
00:56:39,890 --> 00:56:42,242
But if I adjust it on a switch, right?

1092
00:56:42,242 --> 00:56:45,320
Like if I take switch number two here.

1093
00:56:45,320 --> 00:56:50,100
And if I take it and I say, system mtu,
and bump it into something lower.

1094
00:56:50,100 --> 00:56:51,603
Actually, it's gonna
disconnect me isn't it?

1095
00:56:51,603 --> 00:56:56,132
If I bump into something lower,
it is gonna cause some issues.

1096
00:56:56,132 --> 00:56:58,780
Let me see.

1097
00:56:58,780 --> 00:57:01,320
Some switches will actually let
you adjust it per interface.

1098
00:57:01,320 --> 00:57:05,147
I don't think this one does,
but let me see if it'll let me.

1099
00:57:07,400 --> 00:57:09,820
No, it's not, is it?

1100
00:57:09,820 --> 00:57:10,770
Yeah, it's not gonna let me do it.

1101
00:57:10,770 --> 00:57:12,680
All right, well you know what,
I'll try it on the whole one.

1102
00:57:12,680 --> 00:57:16,080
And I might have to console into
this switch if it disconnects me.

1103
00:57:16,080 --> 00:57:17,680
But I'm gonna go ahead and say system mtu.

1104
00:57:17,680 --> 00:57:21,020
Now, this is one that does require
a reboot on most switches.

1105
00:57:21,020 --> 00:57:24,940
So if I bump this one up to say like,
1518, right?

1106
00:57:24,940 --> 00:57:25,790
So, it's gonna tell me and

1107
00:57:25,790 --> 00:57:29,000
it says, changes will take
affect after the next reload.

1108
00:57:29,000 --> 00:57:32,840
So, I'm just gonna get out of config,
we'll go ahead and save,

1109
00:57:32,840 --> 00:57:35,380
and then we'll do a reload.

1110
00:57:37,090 --> 00:57:37,800
All right.

1111
00:57:37,800 --> 00:57:40,844
So it's definitely gonna disconnect
me during the reload and

1112
00:57:40,844 --> 00:57:42,959
I guess I could fire up
the old console now.

1113
00:57:42,959 --> 00:57:48,380
Let's see here.

1114
00:57:48,380 --> 00:57:50,300
Whose going to,
Ronnie are you going to do that one?

1115
00:57:50,300 --> 00:57:50,970
>> I am.

1116
00:57:50,970 --> 00:57:52,270
>> Okay, so, you're watching the reload?

1117
00:57:52,270 --> 00:57:55,410
Let's switch over to your screen

1118
00:57:55,410 --> 00:58:00,795
and, yeah,
I've got the console to the other switch.

1119
00:58:00,795 --> 00:58:02,525
All right, so there it goes reloading.

1120
00:58:02,525 --> 00:58:08,820
It's gonna reload, and when it comes up,
it's gonna have this new MTU size of 1518.

1121
00:58:08,820 --> 00:58:12,750
Now, that's not gonna match with
what's on the other switch,

1122
00:58:12,750 --> 00:58:16,350
on switch one,
which has the default MTU of 1500.

1123
00:58:16,350 --> 00:58:18,930
Cisco discovery protocol
will pick up on that.

1124
00:58:18,930 --> 00:58:21,410
There's other protocols
that'll pick up on it too.

1125
00:58:21,410 --> 00:58:22,100
So, for example,

1126
00:58:22,100 --> 00:58:27,030
in the router world if you're running
OSPF, OSPF very sensitive about MTUs.

1127
00:58:27,030 --> 00:58:29,920
It'll pick this up and
you won't be able to build adjacencies.

1128
00:58:29,920 --> 00:58:30,840
>> Right.
>> That's one of the key things

1129
00:58:30,840 --> 00:58:31,358
that has to match.

1130
00:58:31,358 --> 00:58:33,380
If you remember from the OSPF episode,

1131
00:58:33,380 --> 00:58:36,760
there were several things that had
to match, MTU was one of them.

1132
00:58:36,760 --> 00:58:37,850
>> Yup.

1133
00:58:37,850 --> 00:58:43,095
So, there it is as the switch is actually
expanding out the operating system, on

1134
00:58:43,095 --> 00:58:49,245
into RAM, we should be just a short moment
away from hopefully seeing a mismatch.

1135
00:58:49,245 --> 00:58:52,735
>> And this is another one where it's
CDP that'll discover the mismatch, and

1136
00:58:52,735 --> 00:58:55,125
CDP runs every 90 seconds by default.

1137
00:58:55,125 --> 00:58:57,525
So you kinda have to wait and see.

1138
00:58:57,525 --> 00:59:01,585
Eventually it'll pick that up,
it kick in and recognize it.

1139
00:59:01,585 --> 00:59:03,110
So it may take a little while.

1140
00:59:03,110 --> 00:59:05,010
We'd also see the error
on the other switch too.

1141
00:59:05,010 --> 00:59:06,807
It should be detecting on both sides.

1142
00:59:06,807 --> 00:59:07,504
>> Yep.

1143
00:59:07,504 --> 00:59:12,369
>> All right, well while we're
waiting on that, what happens if my

1144
00:59:12,369 --> 00:59:17,770
maximum MTU is set to 1500, and
I receive a frame that's 1518?

1145
00:59:17,770 --> 00:59:19,550
What happens?

1146
00:59:19,550 --> 00:59:21,620
It's called a giant.

1147
00:59:21,620 --> 00:59:27,950
Our frame that comes in is too large and
so we get an error and that's detected.

1148
00:59:27,950 --> 00:59:33,199
Now, I mentioned that term because a giant
is something that the switch tracks and

1149
00:59:33,199 --> 00:59:35,646
we can detect it even if CDP doesn't.

1150
00:59:35,646 --> 00:59:38,665
If CDP fails to detect it,
we can spot it ourselves, and

1151
00:59:38,665 --> 00:59:40,800
so we'll do that here in just a moment.

1152
00:59:40,800 --> 00:59:43,920
So there's yours coming up.

1153
00:59:43,920 --> 00:59:45,620
And I got my interface just came up.

1154
00:59:45,620 --> 00:59:48,440
And haven't picked it up yet,
but it might.

1155
00:59:48,440 --> 00:59:52,500
So, let's say for a minute that
it doesn't pick it up, right?

1156
00:59:52,500 --> 00:59:55,970
Well, if you take a look
at the interface itself.

1157
00:59:55,970 --> 01:00:04,060
Ronnie, can you do a show interface,
do a show interface FAA0/3.

1158
01:00:04,060 --> 01:00:06,880
When we do the show interface command,

1159
01:00:06,880 --> 01:00:12,420
it gives us all the layer two
information about the port,

1160
01:00:12,420 --> 01:00:16,180
and at the bottom of it you'll
see a ton of numbers, right?

1161
01:00:16,180 --> 01:00:18,800
See where it's got five minute input,
five minute output rates?

1162
01:00:18,800 --> 01:00:21,070
That's how much bandwidth
the line is consuming.

1163
01:00:21,070 --> 01:00:24,080
And then after that,
you get a bunch of statistics,

1164
01:00:24,080 --> 01:00:27,420
a bunch of data about what's going on,
okay.

1165
01:00:27,420 --> 01:00:31,070
And if you look at what's in there,
you see normal stuff, right?

1166
01:00:31,070 --> 01:00:35,210
The 23 packets input or
output, that's normal stuff.

1167
01:00:35,210 --> 01:00:37,030
But you'll also see errors in there.

1168
01:00:37,030 --> 01:00:39,780
We've got runts and giants.

1169
01:00:39,780 --> 01:00:44,580
A giant is where we get a frame
that's over the MTU size, a runt

1170
01:00:44,580 --> 01:00:48,140
is where it's below the minimum, most
people don't realize there's a minimum and

1171
01:00:48,140 --> 01:00:49,310
what did you say it was running?

1172
01:00:49,310 --> 01:00:53,060
>> Usually about 46 bytes in terms
of the actual data pack itself.

1173
01:00:53,060 --> 01:00:56,060
If you include the headers,
you've about 72 bytes here.

1174
01:00:56,060 --> 01:00:57,338
So usually under 72 bytes,

1175
01:00:57,338 --> 01:01:00,678
that's when you actually start to
seeing runts come along as well.

1176
01:01:00,678 --> 01:01:03,650
Now, there was something that you told me
about that I didn't realize, which was

1177
01:01:03,650 --> 01:01:08,680
the idea of babbles, here to, on the ideal
zero interface, so that was kind of neat.

1178
01:01:08,680 --> 01:01:12,110
>> Some of these don't really
pertain to ethernet ports.

1179
01:01:12,110 --> 01:01:13,760
Some of these come from serial.

1180
01:01:13,760 --> 01:01:17,050
So ,you'll see lost carrier and
no carrier, right?

1181
01:01:17,050 --> 01:01:20,450
Those are from the serial days, and so
you're not really gonna get much here.

1182
01:01:20,450 --> 01:01:24,170
But Cisco follows a consistent interface
on these, and that's why it's included.

1183
01:01:24,170 --> 01:01:25,980
Babbles are the same way.

1184
01:01:25,980 --> 01:01:28,680
But other ones are ones that
we need to be aware of, and

1185
01:01:28,680 --> 01:01:31,045
Cisco even calls them
out in the objectives.

1186
01:01:31,045 --> 01:01:32,968
So, let's talk about the ones
that are called out, right?

1187
01:01:32,968 --> 01:01:36,440
So runts and giants, those are a couple.

1188
01:01:36,440 --> 01:01:37,460
CRC.

1189
01:01:37,460 --> 01:01:40,156
A CRC is a Cyclical Redundancy Check,

1190
01:01:40,156 --> 01:01:45,765
every frame that's sent on your network
will have a CRC attached to it.

1191
01:01:45,765 --> 01:01:50,250
It's a little has that's
done of the frame.

1192
01:01:50,250 --> 01:01:54,505
And if there's electrical interference or
anything like that on the line,

1193
01:01:54,505 --> 01:01:57,827
the frame will get changed,
and when the receiver gets it,

1194
01:01:57,827 --> 01:02:00,695
they can look at the CRC and
compare it to the frame.

1195
01:02:00,695 --> 01:02:04,790
And if they don't match up, it means the
frame was damaged and we can throw it out.

1196
01:02:04,790 --> 01:02:09,640
If you see increments here,
if you see 1 CRC or 1,000 CRCs or 10,000,

1197
01:02:09,640 --> 01:02:13,505
that's a good sign that you've
got interference on the line, or

1198
01:02:13,505 --> 01:02:17,254
like a failing cable,
loose cable connectors can do that too.

1199
01:02:17,254 --> 01:02:18,125
>> Yup.

1200
01:02:18,125 --> 01:02:19,657
>> All right, we've also got,

1201
01:02:19,657 --> 01:02:22,367
what were some of the other
ones that are called out?

1202
01:02:22,367 --> 01:02:26,174
>> Let's see, talked about drop packets.

1203
01:02:26,174 --> 01:02:27,313
>> Drop packets, yes.

1204
01:02:27,313 --> 01:02:30,065
>> So, do we see that, I don't think
we actually see that one in here?

1205
01:02:30,065 --> 01:02:34,845
Is that one of our numbers?

1206
01:02:34,845 --> 01:02:38,575
Nope, so drop packets,
you get in a few scenarios.

1207
01:02:38,575 --> 01:02:41,170
We haven't learned about
access control lists yet.

1208
01:02:41,170 --> 01:02:44,130
ACLs, that's gonna be in
another one of our shows.

1209
01:02:44,130 --> 01:02:47,680
If there's an access control
list that is blocking traffic,

1210
01:02:47,680 --> 01:02:50,990
you set up these security filters,
then those are drop packets.

1211
01:02:50,990 --> 01:02:52,700
Ones that we drop, we don't allow through.

1212
01:02:52,700 --> 01:02:56,160
But the other time we have drop packets
are when we exceed the bandwidth

1213
01:02:56,160 --> 01:02:57,310
of our line.

1214
01:02:57,310 --> 01:03:00,480
When our bandwidth is fully consumed,

1215
01:03:00,480 --> 01:03:02,700
anything else that's coming
in starts to get dropped.

1216
01:03:02,700 --> 01:03:03,270
>> Yeah.

1217
01:03:03,270 --> 01:03:04,150
>> And how do we know that?

1218
01:03:04,150 --> 01:03:08,550
Well, when you look up towards the top
you'll see the output queue and

1219
01:03:08,550 --> 01:03:11,290
how it's at 0/40 right now, right?

1220
01:03:11,290 --> 01:03:12,153
That's the output queue.

1221
01:03:12,153 --> 01:03:15,990
You don't have an incoming queue, things
are already filtered before they come in.

1222
01:03:15,990 --> 01:03:20,360
So, on the output queue,
if you see it sitting at 40/40,

1223
01:03:20,360 --> 01:03:22,990
then that means you're likely
getting drop packaged right now,

1224
01:03:22,990 --> 01:03:25,603
that you've got things that are not
making it out that interface.

1225
01:03:25,603 --> 01:03:26,103
>> Huh.

1226
01:03:27,130 --> 01:03:29,550
The other one that we wanna take
a look at was this idea what,

1227
01:03:29,550 --> 01:03:31,090
hold on, I keep copying things,

1228
01:03:31,090 --> 01:03:36,085
cuz I can't right-click or do,
is this idea of late collisions, right?

1229
01:03:36,085 --> 01:03:36,877
>> Mm-hm.
>> Yeah, for

1230
01:03:36,877 --> 01:03:38,471
us in terms of late collisions,

1231
01:03:38,471 --> 01:03:41,730
usually what that means is another
one of those mismatch errors.

1232
01:03:41,730 --> 01:03:44,700
We've already talked about the idea
of VLAN mismatch errors and

1233
01:03:44,700 --> 01:03:46,640
the native VLAN mismatch errors.

1234
01:03:46,640 --> 01:03:50,732
Usually when you see the idea of late
collisions as a duplex error is when we

1235
01:03:50,732 --> 01:03:53,900
tend to see that one side's
set to auto dup, or not auto,

1236
01:03:53,900 --> 01:03:55,561
full duplex and half duplex.

1237
01:03:55,561 --> 01:03:57,345
I was thinking auto duplex.

1238
01:03:57,345 --> 01:04:01,275
So, usually when you have something
like that, that means one side is able,

1239
01:04:01,275 --> 01:04:05,448
actually, to do as fast as they can, That
side is only able to send or receive, and

1240
01:04:05,448 --> 01:04:09,270
so it's getting what we call the idea
of late collisions happening there.

1241
01:04:09,270 --> 01:04:12,570
>> Yeah, and duplex mismatches are a lot
less common today than they used to be,

1242
01:04:12,570 --> 01:04:18,210
cuz on Gigabit networks, they are all full
duplex, they don't run in half duplex.

1243
01:04:18,210 --> 01:04:20,550
But if you still have a hundred
megabit network, that can happen.

1244
01:04:20,550 --> 01:04:21,770
>> Yep.
>> And in fact, the link between these

1245
01:04:21,770 --> 01:04:23,060
switches is 100 megabits.

1246
01:04:23,060 --> 01:04:24,730
So let's take a look at that.

1247
01:04:24,730 --> 01:04:26,660
>> Okay.
>> Ronnie, on the switch that you're on,

1248
01:04:26,660 --> 01:04:30,850
go into interface fa0/3.

1249
01:04:30,850 --> 01:04:35,439
And manually set yours to full duplex.

1250
01:04:38,430 --> 01:04:40,170
And I'm on the other end of that.

1251
01:04:40,170 --> 01:04:43,790
And I'm gonna manually
set mine to half duplex.

1252
01:04:43,790 --> 01:04:44,740
Okay?

1253
01:04:44,740 --> 01:04:47,740
When you change the duplex, the interface
will go down and come back up.

1254
01:04:47,740 --> 01:04:48,320
So there it is.

1255
01:04:48,320 --> 01:04:49,150
It's up.

1256
01:04:49,150 --> 01:04:49,840
We are now up.

1257
01:04:49,840 --> 01:04:50,460
>> Yes.

1258
01:04:50,460 --> 01:04:52,650
>> But our duplexes don't match.

1259
01:04:52,650 --> 01:04:54,270
You know,
your switch hasn't detected it yet.

1260
01:04:54,270 --> 01:04:56,240
>> Yes, I know.
>> But mine is going nuts over here.

1261
01:04:56,240 --> 01:04:58,020
So on Ronnie's side.

1262
01:04:58,020 --> 01:05:00,170
>> Yes.
>> His switch doesn't realize that

1263
01:05:00,170 --> 01:05:04,060
there is a duplex mismatched, and so it
can start to create those late collisions.

1264
01:05:04,060 --> 01:05:04,700
>> Yes.

1265
01:05:04,700 --> 01:05:07,780
>> On my side though,
let's switch over to my computer.

1266
01:05:07,780 --> 01:05:11,480
My switch is now spamming me, saying,
look, we got a duplex mismatch.

1267
01:05:11,480 --> 01:05:14,570
That on the on the end,
it's set to full duplex.

1268
01:05:14,570 --> 01:05:17,730
But on this end, we are not full duplex,
we're half duplex.

1269
01:05:17,730 --> 01:05:18,750
So we got a mismatch.

1270
01:05:18,750 --> 01:05:21,660
So it's actually gonna warn us about that.

1271
01:05:21,660 --> 01:05:24,030
And the thing about the duplex modes,

1272
01:05:24,030 --> 01:05:28,690
when I'm in half duplex,
I can only send or receive data.

1273
01:05:28,690 --> 01:05:31,170
I can only do one at a time,
but Ronnie can do both.

1274
01:05:31,170 --> 01:05:31,700
>> Yep.

1275
01:05:31,700 --> 01:05:35,640
>> And so, he might be sending
something at the same time as I am, and

1276
01:05:35,640 --> 01:05:39,210
my system won't be able to receive it,
and so it's gonna freak out.

1277
01:05:39,210 --> 01:05:41,730
Now, it would be really hard for
us to create that.

1278
01:05:41,730 --> 01:05:45,990
If we start continual pings or
whatever, we'll probably.

1279
01:05:45,990 --> 01:05:50,530
We'll probably just not be
in the right time slot.

1280
01:05:50,530 --> 01:05:54,140
So, it's really difficult to create it but
it will happen.

1281
01:05:54,140 --> 01:05:58,370
And, I guess it coulda happened
on its own by now, if I,

1282
01:05:58,370 --> 01:06:01,960
let me just pull up FA0/3 and
