But anyhow, it will happen.

1289
01:06:11,060 --> 01:06:15,060
So those duplex mismatches, it's another
one that the switch warns you about.

1290
01:06:15,060 --> 01:06:17,385
It's shouting it out and
it's CDP detecting it.

1291
01:06:17,385 --> 01:06:18,350
>> Hm-mm.
>> So the messages come up

1292
01:06:18,350 --> 01:06:19,370
pretty frequently.

1293
01:06:19,370 --> 01:06:22,930
And so you know to go in there and fix it.

1294
01:06:22,930 --> 01:06:26,150
If you're using autodetect duplex,

1295
01:06:26,150 --> 01:06:29,900
then that can happen even between
the switch and a client, and so that's why

1296
01:06:29,900 --> 01:06:35,360
they normally recommend that you manually
set your duplex to take care of that.

1297
01:06:35,360 --> 01:06:36,970
>> Yeah.
Usually when we start taking a look at

1298
01:06:36,970 --> 01:06:40,820
this idea of, well,
am I gonna set it always or not,

1299
01:06:40,820 --> 01:06:44,300
a lot of times what you hear is between
2 devices like switches to switches,

1300
01:06:44,300 --> 01:06:46,660
you wanna make sure you
manually set those.

1301
01:06:46,660 --> 01:06:50,500
If I'm only plugging in my PC
directly into that switch port,

1302
01:06:50,500 --> 01:06:52,810
you can leave the actual port at auto.

1303
01:06:52,810 --> 01:06:54,800
But it just depends on
what you choose to do.

1304
01:06:54,800 --> 01:06:57,710
Usually that's where you tend to see
it most often in terms of setting it.

1305
01:06:57,710 --> 01:07:00,770
Yep.
And then the last one that Cisco calls out

1306
01:07:00,770 --> 01:07:03,310
are the general input/output errors.

1307
01:07:03,310 --> 01:07:06,730
So here's an input error and
here's an output error.

1308
01:07:06,730 --> 01:07:09,950
And basically these
are kind of general errors.

1309
01:07:09,950 --> 01:07:13,250
They normally indicate
failures on the interface.

1310
01:07:13,250 --> 01:07:15,360
And typically hardware failures.

1311
01:07:15,360 --> 01:07:18,550
So you can have ports on
a switch that are dying.

1312
01:07:18,550 --> 01:07:22,520
As your switch gets older,
individual ports can burn out.

1313
01:07:22,520 --> 01:07:26,210
So that will normally manifest itself
here as either input or output errors.

1314
01:07:26,210 --> 01:07:29,020
The frustrating part is when
a full duplex communication,

1315
01:07:29,020 --> 01:07:30,710
you actually have 2 different.

1316
01:07:30,710 --> 01:07:33,020
Devices in there a transmitter and
a receiver.

1317
01:07:33,020 --> 01:07:36,400
And so it's very common that
just the transmitter burns or

1318
01:07:36,400 --> 01:07:38,090
just the receiver burns.

1319
01:07:38,090 --> 01:07:40,820
And in that scenario you'll start
to see errors on one of the others.

1320
01:07:40,820 --> 01:07:43,710
So, it's a good way to
spot hardware errors.

1321
01:07:43,710 --> 01:07:46,195
Cable.
Errors can manifest this way.

1322
01:07:46,195 --> 01:07:49,135
Cable errors normally show up
as CRC failures though but

1323
01:07:49,135 --> 01:07:52,085
it can show up as input and
output errors too in certain scenarios.

1324
01:07:52,085 --> 01:07:56,945
Now there's a lot of other information
tucked away in that output but

1325
01:07:56,945 --> 01:07:59,890
it's not something that we
truly need to worry about.

1326
01:07:59,890 --> 01:08:01,810
It's not on the CCNT exam.

1327
01:08:01,810 --> 01:08:05,300
So the ones that we kind of ran over there
are the ones we need to worry about.

1328
01:08:05,300 --> 01:08:07,670
Oh, you know we left off framing.

1329
01:08:07,670 --> 01:08:13,370
So CRCs, runts, giants, dropped packets,
late collision, Input output areas,

1330
01:08:13,370 --> 01:08:16,100
those are the ones that we need
to be familiar with on the exam.

1331
01:08:16,100 --> 01:08:19,930
If they give you a question and
they show you that output, and the runts

1332
01:08:19,930 --> 01:08:24,130
number is incremented, you need to know
that's a bad thing, and what causes it.

1333
01:08:24,130 --> 01:08:27,190
In this case,
frames coming in too small, or giants,

1334
01:08:27,190 --> 01:08:28,865
frames coming in over the MTU size.

1335
01:08:28,865 --> 01:08:35,530
Also, late collision, typically actually,
kind of easy to spot what the problem is.

1336
01:08:35,530 --> 01:08:37,800
Framing is a tough one.

1337
01:08:37,800 --> 01:08:38,920
Framing.

1338
01:08:38,920 --> 01:08:43,130
Our switches that we buy today are almost
always ethernet switches and so

1339
01:08:43,130 --> 01:08:45,570
they're set to use ethernet framing.

1340
01:08:45,570 --> 01:08:51,510
What if you plug into another device
that is token running or if it's set for

1341
01:08:51,510 --> 01:08:57,410
one of the older ethernet standards like
802.2 where we're doing 802.3 on these.

1342
01:08:57,410 --> 01:08:59,990
So if you're set to use one
of those older standards and

1343
01:08:59,990 --> 01:09:02,570
you plug in,
it's gonna get a framing mismatch.

1344
01:09:02,570 --> 01:09:03,870
The frames are gonna be built different.

1345
01:09:03,870 --> 01:09:05,860
Their headers are gonna be wrong.

1346
01:09:05,860 --> 01:09:09,460
And either your switch just
won't recognize it at all, and

1347
01:09:09,460 --> 01:09:12,170
your dropped packets is
gonna start climbing up, or

1348
01:09:12,170 --> 01:09:15,480
your switch will recognize it and
it'll be flagged as bad frames.

1349
01:09:15,480 --> 01:09:21,470
And so you'll start to see error messages
regarding that and for the life of

1350
01:09:21,470 --> 01:09:26,660
me I could not find a non ethernet switch
to be able to demonstrate this cuz who has

1351
01:09:26,660 --> 01:09:30,900
token equipment laying around anymore or
even the ethernet standard stuff.

1352
01:09:30,900 --> 01:09:33,430
>> So for us remember that that's
the whole idea there right.

1353
01:09:33,430 --> 01:09:37,770
So you see where they tell you that you're
running token ring or fitting on one,

1354
01:09:37,770 --> 01:09:39,770
and then ethernet on the other.

1355
01:09:39,770 --> 01:09:40,330
More than likely,

1356
01:09:40,330 --> 01:09:43,450
that's gonna be one of the framing issues
that we have to actually be aware of,

1357
01:09:43,450 --> 01:09:47,000
because essentially, the packets,
or the frames I should say,

1358
01:09:47,000 --> 01:09:49,550
technically, are built differently.

1359
01:09:49,550 --> 01:09:54,850
So a switch that only sees ethernet Is not
going to really recognize anything else.

1360
01:09:54,850 --> 01:09:57,450
So, let's make sure that we remember that.

1361
01:09:57,450 --> 01:10:00,770
>> My recommendation to everybody
is to follow the OSI model when you

1362
01:10:00,770 --> 01:10:01,680
troubleshoot stuff.

1363
01:10:01,680 --> 01:10:03,010
Especially with switches.

1364
01:10:03,010 --> 01:10:06,060
Switches are layer two devices but
I always start at layer one.

1365
01:10:06,060 --> 01:10:07,960
Look at your physical cables.

1366
01:10:07,960 --> 01:10:11,640
A loose cable will have you guessing for
days on end.

1367
01:10:11,640 --> 01:10:14,110
So, you know, look at your cables,
check them first.

1368
01:10:14,110 --> 01:10:15,680
Then move up to layer 2, right?

1369
01:10:15,680 --> 01:10:18,410
Look at just your,
do you have link lights, you know?

1370
01:10:18,410 --> 01:10:19,490
Do you have basic connectivity?

1371
01:10:19,490 --> 01:10:20,710
>> Yeah.

1372
01:10:20,710 --> 01:10:22,140
>> And then start digging in from there.

1373
01:10:22,140 --> 01:10:23,110
So, you know?

1374
01:10:23,110 --> 01:10:24,880
You can find a lot of
information that way.

1375
01:10:24,880 --> 01:10:27,710
You can discover problems,
root them out, and then get them sorted.

1376
01:10:27,710 --> 01:10:29,055
>> The key thing is, don't assume, right?

1377
01:10:29,055 --> 01:10:32,960
[LAUGH] There's so much information
that Cisco really provides for you.

1378
01:10:32,960 --> 01:10:34,980
You don't really have to
make a lot of assumptions.

1379
01:10:34,980 --> 01:10:36,740
At layer 1 or layer 2.

1380
01:10:36,740 --> 01:10:39,480
So I always hear this from people like,

1381
01:10:39,480 --> 01:10:42,670
you don't have to worry about
trouble shooting cables anymore

1382
01:10:42,670 --> 01:10:46,010
because most of the switches do
what we call auto MBIS right?

1383
01:10:46,010 --> 01:10:48,930
I don't care what type of cable you do,
but you can't always assume that

1384
01:10:48,930 --> 01:10:52,320
every single switch that you come
across that is gonna be that way.

1385
01:10:52,320 --> 01:10:56,950
So it could be just as simple
as not using the proper,

1386
01:10:56,950 --> 01:11:00,730
Cable, and we can troubleshoot
everything else in the world, and

1387
01:11:00,730 --> 01:11:05,600
literally start pulling our hair, until
we realize it's just the wrong cable.

1388
01:11:05,600 --> 01:11:09,920
Even worse, it may still be the cable,
even though it's not the wrong type of

1389
01:11:09,920 --> 01:11:13,720
cable, that somebody may
have just incorrectly made.

1390
01:11:13,720 --> 01:11:16,960
And that, I can't tell you how many hours

1391
01:11:16,960 --> 01:11:19,390
that that could cause you if you
don't start off with layer one.

1392
01:11:19,390 --> 01:11:21,850
Where you're just in there like,
I've troubleshooted everything!

1393
01:11:21,850 --> 01:11:23,240
Everything is set perfectly!

1394
01:11:23,240 --> 01:11:24,040
>> Yes.
>> But remember,

1395
01:11:24,040 --> 01:11:27,730
if that sending pin is not hooked up to
the receiving port on the other side,

1396
01:11:27,730 --> 01:11:28,730
you're in trouble.

1397
01:11:28,730 --> 01:11:29,310
>> Absolutely.

1398
01:11:29,310 --> 01:11:32,240
>> So yes, make sure you troubleshoot
even those small things.

1399
01:11:32,240 --> 01:11:32,800
>> Yes.

1400
01:11:32,800 --> 01:11:33,750
Just take advantage of the tools.

1401
01:11:33,750 --> 01:11:35,550
>> Oh yes.
>> That are built into the switch because

1402
01:11:35,550 --> 01:11:36,130
there's a lot.

1403
01:11:36,130 --> 01:11:39,440
The higher end switches have even
more tools in them like UDLD and

1404
01:11:39,440 --> 01:11:40,950
all that kind of good stuff.

1405
01:11:40,950 --> 01:11:41,850
>> Oh yes.
>> But in the lower

1406
01:11:41,850 --> 01:11:43,820
end switches you've at least
got your status counters and

1407
01:11:43,820 --> 01:11:45,950
your error messages and
you've also got your logs.

1408
01:11:45,950 --> 01:11:47,885
>> Yes.
You can see a lot in there, and

1409
01:11:47,885 --> 01:11:50,015
you can spot those and
get in there and fix the problem.

1410
01:11:50,015 --> 01:11:52,445
>> Yeah,
the only last thing I wanna mention is,

1411
01:11:52,445 --> 01:11:56,285
Don has used debug commands throughout
our episode which is great.

1412
01:11:56,285 --> 01:11:58,465
Remember though, on a production switch,

1413
01:11:58,465 --> 01:12:02,865
once you run those debug commands,
make sure you turn them off afterwards.

1414
01:12:02,865 --> 01:12:06,295
Not every single debug command
will cause problems, but

1415
01:12:06,295 --> 01:12:10,440
some of them that actually
send everything that there is,

1416
01:12:10,440 --> 01:12:14,690
it can cause enough issues to cause
performance problems on the switch itself.

1417
01:12:14,690 --> 01:12:17,400
So always make sure after
your run debug commands,

1418
01:12:17,400 --> 01:12:20,380
do your un-debug all
is usually what we do.

1419
01:12:20,380 --> 01:12:21,900
Turn them all off.

1420
01:12:21,900 --> 01:12:24,890
>> Yeah, pretty much every debug
command affects performance,

1421
01:12:24,890 --> 01:12:27,680
they all cause a slowdown on the device,
the router or the switch.

1422
01:12:27,680 --> 01:12:29,389
You always want to make sure
you turn those off, absolutely.

1423
01:12:30,560 --> 01:12:31,370
Alright well ladies and

1424
01:12:31,370 --> 01:12:35,150
gentleman I think that pretty much wraps
up troubleshooting Cisco switches and

1425
01:12:35,150 --> 01:12:39,070
it wraps up the rest of our switch
topics at least for the CCENT show.

1426
01:12:40,210 --> 01:12:45,330
Remember in the CCNA show that we all jump
right back into switches where we've got

1427
01:12:45,330 --> 01:12:47,820
layer three switching and a bunch
of other little bells and whistles.

1428
01:12:47,820 --> 01:12:50,530
Spanning tree protocol and
all that good stuff.

1429
01:12:50,530 --> 01:12:53,050
So those are all things
that we'll jump into but

1430
01:12:53,050 --> 01:12:56,150
I think that pretty much raps it up for
the switches.

1431
01:12:56,150 --> 01:12:57,550
>> Sure does.
Yeah.

1432
01:12:57,550 --> 01:13:00,730
>> Yeah.
I hope you guys enjoyed the show

1433
01:13:00,730 --> 01:13:05,690
as always remember if you have any
questions whatsoever live during the show

1434
01:13:05,690 --> 01:13:10,610
you can always jump over to itpro.tv/live
and post your questions, we've got our

1435
01:13:10,610 --> 01:13:13,270
chat room right there beneath
the video you can ask your questions.

1436
01:13:13,270 --> 01:13:15,870
We watch them and answer.

1437
01:13:15,870 --> 01:13:18,220
If you are watching this show, record it.

1438
01:13:18,220 --> 01:13:20,220
After the fact, if you have a question,

1439
01:13:20,220 --> 01:13:24,390
go to http://www.Itpro.tv at the top
of the page is a Q and A link.

1440
01:13:24,390 --> 01:13:25,210
You can hit Q and A,

1441
01:13:25,210 --> 01:13:28,730
and post your questions there we
monitor them after hours and stuff.

1442
01:13:28,730 --> 01:13:29,530
Answer whatever you have.

1443
01:13:29,530 --> 01:13:32,360
So we always wanna make sure
you guys get taken care of and

1444
01:13:32,360 --> 01:13:33,980
helped whenever possible.

1445
01:13:33,980 --> 01:13:36,720
>> And
don't forget always just tune in live.

1446
01:13:36,720 --> 01:13:37,770
You never know what you're gonna get.

1447
01:13:37,770 --> 01:13:40,255
You may get another funny story from Don.

1448
01:13:40,255 --> 01:13:41,440
>> [LAUGH].
>> You may get another

1449
01:13:41,440 --> 01:13:43,290
comment from me about Gilmore Girls.

1450
01:13:43,290 --> 01:13:44,010
Probably not.
I hope not.

1451
01:13:44,010 --> 01:13:45,380
>> Yeah you gotta keep up to
date on the Gilmore Girls.

1452
01:13:45,380 --> 01:13:46,400
>> Yeah I know.

1453
01:13:46,400 --> 01:13:48,200
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,
hope you enjoyed this show.

1454
01:13:48,200 --> 01:13:51,130
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1455
01:13:51,130 --> 01:13:52,140
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1456
01:13:52,140 --> 01:13:53,558
>> And we'll see you next time around.

1457
01:13:53,558 --> 01:14:03,558
[MUSIC].

1458
01:14:05,038 --> 01:14:11,400
[SOUND].

episodes.description: In order to route between networks, one will first need to know how to create networks. Viewers will hear about IP addressing and the network protocols of IPv4 and IPv6, as well as CIDR, VLSM and network summarization. For a more detailed review, viewers are encouraged to check out the IP subnetting episodes in the Network+ show.
episodes.title: Introduction to Routing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,160 --> 00:00:22,139
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,139 --> 00:00:33,053
[MUSIC].

4
00:00:33,053 --> 00:00:35,707
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening and

5
00:00:35,707 --> 00:00:37,555
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTv.

6
00:00:37,555 --> 00:00:38,846
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:38,846 --> 00:00:40,241
Today, with Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:40,241 --> 00:00:41,130
How is it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:41,130 --> 00:00:42,140
>> It's going well,

10
00:00:42,140 --> 00:00:46,270
we are ready to go on our way,
to the destination where we're gonna hit.

11
00:00:46,270 --> 00:00:47,660
>> Pumped up and energized.

12
00:00:47,660 --> 00:00:51,440
Today we have an action
packed double header,

13
00:00:51,440 --> 00:00:57,140
a double dose of CCENT,
straight from our friend upgrade.

14
00:00:57,140 --> 00:00:57,930
>> That's right.

15
00:00:57,930 --> 00:01:01,602
>> Anyhow.
[LAUGH] Have you seen the movie Idiocracy?

16
00:01:01,602 --> 00:01:02,245
>> Yeah.
I have.

17
00:01:02,245 --> 00:01:06,290
>> The guy upgraded with 2
D's cuz it's a double dose.

18
00:01:06,290 --> 00:01:09,810
That's what we've got for
you today, a double dose of Cisco.

19
00:01:09,810 --> 00:01:12,580
We are gonna be jumping
into some neat topics.

20
00:01:12,580 --> 00:01:16,350
In the last couple episodes,
we focused on basic configuration.

21
00:01:16,350 --> 00:01:20,120
We did a basic switch configuration,
basic router configuration.

22
00:01:20,120 --> 00:01:21,850
We saw some security features.

23
00:01:21,850 --> 00:01:22,910
We did SSA.

24
00:01:22,910 --> 00:01:24,640
Tried those kind of things.

25
00:01:24,640 --> 00:01:28,340
Now we are going to start
tackling our networks.

26
00:01:28,340 --> 00:01:31,820
Cuz if we're gonna route well you need to
route between networks, which means you

27
00:01:31,820 --> 00:01:35,810
need to know how to create networks and
so that's what we're gonna tackle today.

28
00:01:35,810 --> 00:01:38,310
>> And now that doesn't mean
that we actually take a break

29
00:01:38,310 --> 00:01:40,270
from all the stuff we've been doing.

30
00:01:40,270 --> 00:01:42,430
Keep practicing those commands.

31
00:01:42,430 --> 00:01:44,370
Keep making sure that you're
actually keeping up with it and

32
00:01:44,370 --> 00:01:46,930
getting faster each and every day.

33
00:01:46,930 --> 00:01:49,430
So once you actually do that,
also remember that there's

34
00:01:49,430 --> 00:01:53,650
foundational concepts that we have to
understand so we actually went through

35
00:01:53,650 --> 00:01:57,790
the foundational concepts of the basic
configuration on routing and switching.

36
00:01:57,790 --> 00:02:01,530
And now we're actually going into
the concepts on routing again and so

37
00:02:01,530 --> 00:02:03,650
we're taking a deeper
dive is what we're doing.

38
00:02:03,650 --> 00:02:04,550
>> Yep.

39
00:02:04,550 --> 00:02:08,570
So where we wanna start today
is we're gonna talk about IPv4,

40
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:10,790
Internet Protocol Version 4,

41
00:02:10,790 --> 00:02:14,700
which is the most popular network
protocol in the entire world.

42
00:02:14,700 --> 00:02:16,690
So when you're out in the field and

43
00:02:16,690 --> 00:02:20,844
you go to route traffic, it's typically
going to be IP version four traffic.

44
00:02:20,844 --> 00:02:25,620
Now on IPv4's heels is IPv6,

45
00:02:25,620 --> 00:02:30,920
Internet protocol version 6, which I
like to say in the next 5 to 7 years,

46
00:02:30,920 --> 00:02:35,710
some people say sooner, that it will
take over as the most common protocol.

47
00:02:35,710 --> 00:02:38,329
And so we need to know it also,
it is on the exam,

48
00:02:38,329 --> 00:02:40,760
moreso now with the new
version of the exam.

49
00:02:40,760 --> 00:02:44,320
>> So we're actually going to be
taking a little bit deeper look.

50
00:02:44,320 --> 00:02:50,000
You may have at least seen in IP version 6
address if you've been doing an IP config

51
00:02:50,000 --> 00:02:53,530
on your Windows computer or something else
like that, but you should actually start

52
00:02:53,530 --> 00:02:57,100
seeing it, we're gonna actually take
a little bit deeper understanding of it.

53
00:02:57,100 --> 00:03:00,610
That we had talked about the different
types of addresses as well and

54
00:03:00,610 --> 00:03:03,530
talked about where they are actually going
to be used the majority of time inside

55
00:03:03,530 --> 00:03:04,720
of our networking.

56
00:03:04,720 --> 00:03:06,280
So, where are we going to
get started today, Don?

57
00:03:06,280 --> 00:03:07,730
>> All right, well let's see.

An IPv4 address is a 32 bit number,

and what that means is that

We take that 32-bit number and

And what you'll notice is

Cutting it in half as we

I picked a pretty softball

00:12:22,270 --> 00:12:24,740

00:12:28,068 --> 00:12:30,395
So let's take a minute, Ronnie, and

00:12:30,395 --> 00:12:33,824
talk a little bit about

235
00:12:33,824 --> 00:12:35,490
The different types of
addresses that are out there.

236
00:12:35,490 --> 00:12:39,114
>> So when we take a look at the idea
here, again the idea of review here is

237
00:12:39,114 --> 00:12:42,821
that IP addresses were really valid
on the Internet at the beginning.

238
00:12:42,821 --> 00:12:48,073
And the organization,
IETF or ICANN or IANA.

239
00:12:48,073 --> 00:12:48,590
>> Changes over the years.

240
00:12:48,590 --> 00:12:50,950
>> Whichever one has been
changed over time here.

241
00:12:50,950 --> 00:12:54,370
They started out last year's thinking
that the Internet was really going to be

242
00:12:54,370 --> 00:12:54,980
for businesses.

243
00:12:54,980 --> 00:12:56,360
Right?
So they actually separated out

244
00:12:56,360 --> 00:12:58,030
into different classes here.

245
00:12:58,030 --> 00:13:01,235
Large businesses got what we'll
call the idea of a Class A address.

246
00:13:01,235 --> 00:13:06,090
Okay, and then we had Class B and Class C
addresses that were valid on the Internet.

247
00:13:06,090 --> 00:13:08,100
You have two other classes, Class D and E.

248
00:13:08,100 --> 00:13:11,870
A class A address for
us essentially range from

249
00:13:11,870 --> 00:13:16,290
the 1 network all the way
through the 126 network for us.

250
00:13:16,290 --> 00:13:21,850
A class B address range from
128 all the way through 191.

251
00:13:21,850 --> 00:13:26,690
And the Class C network begins at
192 going all the way through 223.

252
00:13:26,690 --> 00:13:30,615
Class D is actually for what we call
multi-cache which begins at 224.

253
00:13:30,615 --> 00:13:34,340
And then there's also Class E
addresses that are experimental.

254
00:13:34,340 --> 00:13:38,090
For us, we're really only focusing
in on those first three classes.

255
00:13:38,090 --> 00:13:40,480
And you may be saying, well,
okay, that makes sense.

256
00:13:40,480 --> 00:13:44,630
But why in the world don't we really have
to worry about the idea of subnet masks?

257
00:13:44,630 --> 00:13:48,610
Because I know that IP addresses and
subnet masks always go hand in hand.

258
00:13:48,610 --> 00:13:50,260
In classful addressing for

259
00:13:50,260 --> 00:13:55,470
us, every single class has
a default subnet mask for us here.

260
00:13:55,470 --> 00:14:01,390
And you do take a look at what Don
has actually put up here for us.

261
00:14:01,390 --> 00:14:05,680
He actually gives us the entire ranges of
his classes here, but the subnet masks for

262
00:14:05,680 --> 00:14:09,030
them are actually relatively easy again,
okay?

263
00:14:09,030 --> 00:14:12,950
>> Yep, so in the classful days
things were a lot easier, right.

264
00:14:12,950 --> 00:14:16,230
They were a lot less efficient, which
is why we're no longer in those days.

265
00:14:16,230 --> 00:14:21,040
But in the classful days, you basically
had three ranges, a Class A, Class B and

266
00:14:21,040 --> 00:14:21,590
a Class C.

267
00:14:21,590 --> 00:14:26,390
Now, the IP addresses,
the address space as

268
00:14:26,390 --> 00:14:31,390
a whole goes from 0.0.0.0 all
the way through 255.255.255.255.

269
00:14:31,390 --> 00:14:36,320
Four 0's, that is 32 zeroes in binary.

270
00:14:36,320 --> 00:14:42,850
Four sets of 255,
that is four sets of eight 1's, or 32 1's.

271
00:14:42,850 --> 00:14:46,670
So you're going from 32 0's all the way
to 32 1's, that's the lowest and

272
00:14:46,670 --> 00:14:49,620
the biggest number that you can
have in the IPv4 address space.

273
00:14:49,620 --> 00:14:55,150
Now the addresses that start with 0,

274
00:14:55,150 --> 00:14:59,160
so in other words all 0 through
0.255.255.255, those are reserved, so

275
00:14:59,160 --> 00:15:00,570
we're not allowed to use those.

276
00:15:00,570 --> 00:15:02,950
They're blocked off by the IANA and

277
00:15:02,950 --> 00:15:06,470
the IETF, the various agencies
that manage the addresses.

278
00:15:06,470 --> 00:15:09,770
But right after that,
we start our classful addresses.

279
00:15:09,770 --> 00:15:14,683
And the classful addresses started with
1.0.0.0 and went all the way up to 126.

280
00:15:14,683 --> 00:15:19,058
So, basically if you see an address
that starts with a 1 through a 126,

281
00:15:19,058 --> 00:15:20,941
that falls in the Class A range.

282
00:15:20,941 --> 00:15:25,540
Now a Class A is a pretty big network.

00:15:25,540 --> 00:15:30,250
But let me hold off on that for a just a
second, I don't wanna get ahead of myself.

284
00:15:30,250 --> 00:15:35,820
After the Class A's,
we then have 128 all the way through 191,

285
00:15:35,820 --> 00:15:42,325
those are the Class B's, and we have 192
through 223, those are the Class C's.

286
00:15:42,325 --> 00:15:46,427
Now we don't necessarily have to mention
subnet masks here because it's actually

287
00:15:46,427 --> 00:15:50,601
this first octet, this first number that
tells us whether it's a class A, B, or C.

288
00:15:50,601 --> 00:15:55,474
So what Cisco wants you to know for
the exam is a little more than what

289
00:15:55,474 --> 00:16:01,848
Network Plus or those other guys want It's
not so much that the number is one to 126.

290
00:16:01,848 --> 00:16:05,972
It really comes down to what the number
would start with if we converted it to

291
00:16:05,972 --> 00:16:07,190
binary.

292
00:16:07,190 --> 00:16:07,992
Right?

293
00:16:07,992 --> 00:16:13,765
In a class A network,
the first octet starts

294
00:16:13,765 --> 00:16:20,325
with zero followed by seven more bits,
right?

295
00:16:20,325 --> 00:16:24,215
So we can spot a class A because
that first octet starts with zero.

296
00:16:24,215 --> 00:16:28,265
In an eight bit number,
that first bit is worth 128, right?

297
00:16:28,265 --> 00:16:30,400
That's the 128 bit.

298
00:16:30,400 --> 00:16:32,420
If we don't have it, if we have a zero,

299
00:16:32,420 --> 00:16:36,850
that means the number we have
is gonna have to be beneath 128.

300
00:16:36,850 --> 00:16:39,000
So that's how we're able to spot that one.

301
00:16:39,000 --> 00:16:42,400
A class B has to be over 128, right.

302
00:16:42,400 --> 00:16:46,380
So for it the first octet, let me try and

303
00:16:46,380 --> 00:16:51,590
keep this a little neat,
starts with one zero.

304
00:16:51,590 --> 00:16:54,148
One, two, three, four,
five, six, there we go.

305
00:16:54,148 --> 00:16:57,112
All right, and here we can spot
that the first bit is 128 so

306
00:16:57,112 --> 00:17:00,790
that means if it's gotta be
a one we're gonna be over 128.

307
00:17:00,790 --> 00:17:04,150
The second bit though,
that zero, that's 64.

308
00:17:04,150 --> 00:17:06,440
128 plus 64 is 192.

309
00:17:06,440 --> 00:17:11,570
Since we've got a zero for
that second bit, we can't have the 64.

310
00:17:11,570 --> 00:17:15,470
That means that we have to be over
128 cuz we've got the one here and

311
00:17:15,470 --> 00:17:20,600
we have to be below 192 cuz
we've got the zero there.

312
00:17:20,600 --> 00:17:23,500
And that's why this range
goes from 128 to 191.

313
00:17:23,500 --> 00:17:30,371
And then the Class Cs, well they're
very similar in that they start with.

314
00:17:32,832 --> 00:17:33,410
>> A one, one, zero, yep.

315
00:17:33,410 --> 00:17:34,025
>> Oops.

316
00:17:34,025 --> 00:17:36,230
[LAUGH] Get my caps lock going on there.

317
00:17:38,440 --> 00:17:40,600
>> So these begin with the one, one, zero.

318
00:17:40,600 --> 00:17:47,610
And if you convert that again from the
binary, that's 128 plus 64, which is 192.

319
00:17:47,610 --> 00:17:54,000
And then for us here, the upper range
of that would actually be the 223.

320
00:17:54,000 --> 00:17:55,580
Now we can't go to one, one, one, so

321
00:17:55,580 --> 00:17:57,290
that's where we're gonna
also end up as well.

322
00:17:57,290 --> 00:18:00,370
>> Yep, one, one,
one would set us at 224 or higher.

323
00:18:00,370 --> 00:18:02,940
And so, that kinda locks in our Class C.

324
00:18:02,940 --> 00:18:04,260
So these are the class ranges.

325
00:18:04,260 --> 00:18:05,450
So in the early days of the Internet,

326
00:18:05,450 --> 00:18:08,950
we didn't have subnet masks because
we just looked at the first octet.

327
00:18:08,950 --> 00:18:11,290
And the first octet told us
what our subnet mask was.

328
00:18:11,290 --> 00:18:13,023
Now, when we say a subnet mask, just for

329
00:18:13,023 --> 00:18:15,040
a review we just wanna review
what are we talking about?

330
00:18:15,040 --> 00:18:18,490
Well, every IP address is
actually made up of two pieces.

331
00:18:18,490 --> 00:18:21,050
I know it looks like four pieces,
but it's really just two.

332
00:18:21,050 --> 00:18:24,030
You have a network ID, and
you have a host ID, right.

333
00:18:24,030 --> 00:18:24,870
>> That's it, yep.

334
00:18:24,870 --> 00:18:28,690
>> The network ID identifies
the entire network that you're on.

335
00:18:28,690 --> 00:18:31,280
And any computers that
are on the same network can

336
00:18:31,280 --> 00:18:33,360
talk to each other without
going through a router.

337
00:18:33,360 --> 00:18:34,410
If you're on a different network,

338
00:18:34,410 --> 00:18:36,610
you're going to have to go through
a router to get there, all right.

339
00:18:36,610 --> 00:18:38,570
>> So a lot of times you
hear about analogies, right.

340
00:18:38,570 --> 00:18:42,360
So, don't forget the basic
analogy is relatively easy.

341
00:18:42,360 --> 00:18:44,470
Multiple houses on the same street.

342
00:18:44,470 --> 00:18:46,730
Your street would actually
be your network portion,

343
00:18:46,730 --> 00:18:50,210
the houses would be the individual
nodes on that particular street,

344
00:18:50,210 --> 00:18:53,300
which means that we all have
a shared common portion, and

345
00:18:53,300 --> 00:18:54,764
then individually you have
your own house numbers.

Take our studio for example.

So if I wanted to

382

it's a different road than what I'm on.

I'm gonna have to get in my car and I'm

I'm gonna have to take one road,

two roads, ten roads, who knows,

And that's really what our routers do.

387
00:20:40,630 --> 00:20:42,286
Our routers, our Cisco routers,

388
00:20:42,286 --> 00:20:45,550
they're the ones who figure out how

389
00:20:45,550 --> 00:20:47,650
They don't really care about the hosts.

390
00:20:47,650 --> 00:20:49,520
They don't care about
the individual buildings.

391
00:20:49,520 --> 00:20:50,440
They care about the roads.

392

So they can get you to the road you

393
00:20:53,320 --> 00:20:56,540
And so
that's where these subnet masks come in.

394
00:20:56,540 --> 00:21:02,560
The subnet masks tell us which part
of this address is our network and

395
00:21:02,560 --> 00:21:04,050
which part is our host, all right?

396
00:21:05,490 --> 00:21:11,240
Now the network part is always on the left
and the host is always on the right.

397
00:21:11,240 --> 00:21:12,700
And so when we look at the address,

398
00:21:12,700 --> 00:21:15,580
it's really just telling us
where that point changes.

399
00:21:15,580 --> 00:21:20,082
In a class A network,
the address breaks down like this.

400
00:21:22,485 --> 00:21:26,101
Where the first eight bits
are the network ID, and

401
00:21:26,101 --> 00:21:29,812
the remaining 24 bits
are all part of the host ID.

402
00:21:33,945 --> 00:21:38,376
>> And so you can see where a single Class
A address would have a ton of different

403
00:21:38,376 --> 00:21:40,850
devices that we could actually put on it.

404
00:21:40,850 --> 00:21:45,110
You take those bits that are marked in H,
you start off with a one, and

405
00:21:45,110 --> 00:21:47,830
you can actually fill in
all 24 of those ones,

406
00:21:47,830 --> 00:21:52,050
you get millions of devices
per class A address.

407
00:21:52,050 --> 00:21:56,200
Class B is just about divided evenly,
right?

408
00:21:56,200 --> 00:22:00,480
What you see there is you see the first
16 bits as being the network portion, and

409
00:22:00,480 --> 00:22:05,700
you see the second 16 bits as
being the host portion as well.

410
00:22:05,700 --> 00:22:08,963
And so this particular type of network
was 16 bits as the host portion

411
00:22:08,963 --> 00:22:10,014
gives you thousands,

412
00:22:10,014 --> 00:22:14,350
actually tens of thousands of addresses
per network that we actually have there.

413
00:22:14,350 --> 00:22:15,430
And then in class A,

414
00:22:15,430 --> 00:22:19,240
you actually end up seeing where the first
24 bits are the network portion,

415
00:22:19,240 --> 00:22:22,940
and then the last eight bits
are essentially the host portion.

416
00:22:22,940 --> 00:22:25,660
So you get a couple of hundred
addresses there as well.

417
00:22:25,660 --> 00:22:29,370
So notice that in the host portion
breakdown, where the class A gives you

418
00:22:29,370 --> 00:22:33,240
the first eight bits of network,
class B, 16, and class C, 24 bits.

419
00:22:33,240 --> 00:22:40,120
>> Yep, so if I'm on a class A network and
my address is 5.0.0.1.

420
00:22:40,120 --> 00:22:43,780
All right, the five,
that is my network ID.

421
00:22:43,780 --> 00:22:46,790
And the 001 that's my host ID.

422
00:22:46,790 --> 00:22:50,700
So if I want to talk to somebody else, and

423
00:22:50,700 --> 00:22:54,636
their address is 5.223.17.49, right?

424
00:22:54,636 --> 00:22:58,160
It doesn't matter that those last three
octets are completely different than mine.

425
00:22:58,160 --> 00:23:02,800
They start with a five, I start with
a five, we're on the same network.

426
00:23:02,800 --> 00:23:08,300
All right, if my address started with 172
and I was talking to somebody else that

427
00:23:08,300 --> 00:23:14,050
was 172, that's not enough to know because
in a Class B the first two octets match.

428
00:23:15,370 --> 00:23:20,420
Matched with a network ID.

429
00:23:20,420 --> 00:23:25,400
So, if I'm 172.16.0.1 and Ronnie is
172.17.0.1, we both start with 172, but

430
00:23:25,400 --> 00:23:28,510
the second octet has to match also.

431
00:23:28,510 --> 00:23:30,360
Mine's a zero, Ronnie's is a one.

432
00:23:30,360 --> 00:23:32,330
We're not on the same network.

433
00:23:32,330 --> 00:23:35,410
So in a Class B,
the first two octets have to match.

434
00:23:35,410 --> 00:23:38,860
And in a Class C,
it's the first three octets.

435
00:23:38,860 --> 00:23:42,540
So when I threw out that very first
address at the beginning, 192.168.0.1.

436
00:23:42,540 --> 00:23:46,420
That's a Class C address,

437
00:23:46,420 --> 00:23:51,200
the first three octets
determine the network ID.

438
00:23:51,200 --> 00:23:52,040
So 192.168.0 is the network.

00:23:52,040 --> 00:23:56,240
And then .1 all the way through .254 those

440
00:23:56,240 --> 00:23:58,940

those machines can talk to each other,

00:23:58,940 --> 00:24:00,635

00:24:00,635 --> 00:24:02,394
>> Yep.
>> All right, so

It sets aside a block of class As, a block

00:51:19,338 --> 00:51:21,340
the first two numbers.

972
00:51:21,340 --> 00:51:25,790
And then 101 should be easy enough.

973
00:51:27,860 --> 00:51:33,412
Okay, so there's the two addresses and

974
00:51:33,412 --> 00:51:36,188
you know actually,

975
00:51:36,188 --> 00:51:41,412
let's write this in different ways so

976
00:51:41,412 --> 00:51:45,180
we can keep them straight.

977
00:51:45,180 --> 00:51:47,210
Okay, so there's our two addresses, and

978
00:51:47,210 --> 00:51:52,300
originally we were using
a class C subnet mask, right?

979
00:51:52,300 --> 00:51:59,407
Which would have been like this.

980
00:51:59,407 --> 00:52:00,310
All right?

981
00:52:00,310 --> 00:52:06,243
And according to a class C subnet mask, if
we just draw a line where the ones stop,

982
00:52:06,243 --> 00:52:11,410
and the zeros start in the subnet mask,
that line would be right here.

983
00:52:11,410 --> 00:52:15,374
And if we want these machines
to be on the same network, well,

984
00:52:15,374 --> 00:52:19,360
everything to the left of that
line has to match, right?

985
00:52:19,360 --> 00:52:22,460
And we can see is we look
at these that they do match

986
00:52:22,460 --> 00:52:25,920
all the way through the first octet
all the way through the second octet.

987
00:52:25,920 --> 00:52:30,775
And most of the way through the thirst
octet this last little bit,

988
00:52:30,775 --> 00:52:35,201
10.1.100 has a 0, 10.1 1.101 has a 1.

989
00:52:35,201 --> 00:52:36,071
There's our difference.

990
00:52:36,071 --> 00:52:37,930
>> Right, in two separate networks.

991
00:52:37,930 --> 00:52:40,930
>> So if we want to combine those

992
00:52:40,930 --> 00:52:45,590
we need to make everything to
the left of the line match.

993
00:52:45,590 --> 00:52:48,710
And the easiest way to do
that is to move the line.

994
00:52:48,710 --> 00:52:52,200
Move the line and
that'll save us a lot of time.

995
00:52:52,200 --> 00:52:56,440
So basically that's what we did, is we
came down here and we said all right,

996
00:52:56,440 --> 00:52:59,290
well this line is now gonna be over here.

997
00:53:02,110 --> 00:53:05,940
And by moving that line over, now

998
00:53:08,330 --> 00:53:11,940
everything to the left
of the line matches.

999
00:53:11,940 --> 00:53:14,650
And then so the right it can be different,
we're not worried about that, right?

1000
00:53:14,650 --> 00:53:17,480
The fact there's a 0 here, or
a 1 here, that's part of the host ID.

1001
00:53:17,480 --> 00:53:18,910
So we're not worried about it.

1002
00:53:18,910 --> 00:53:20,510
Everything to the left has to match.

1003
00:53:20,510 --> 00:53:23,820
Now, if we move the line, our subnet mask?

1004
00:53:23,820 --> 00:53:27,470
It's all 1s to the left of the line,
all 0s to the right.

1005
00:53:27,470 --> 00:53:31,170
So I did have to change this
one bit from a 0 to a 1.

1006
00:53:31,170 --> 00:53:36,060
But when I do that, now everything
to the left of the line matches,

1007
00:53:36,060 --> 00:53:38,430
these two networks are now
considered combined.

1008
00:53:38,430 --> 00:53:39,850
They're merged together.

1009
00:53:39,850 --> 00:53:41,210
>> For the new subnet mask.

1010
00:53:41,210 --> 00:53:46,616
>> And that new subnet mask
wouldn't be 255.255.255.0.

1011
00:53:46,616 --> 00:53:47,740
I lost that one bit.

1012
00:53:47,740 --> 00:53:52,697
So it's actually gonna be 255.255.254.0.

1013
00:53:52,697 --> 00:53:58,974
So now I've got a new range that's built
up, and any time you create a new range,

1014
00:53:58,974 --> 00:54:03,820
you need to figure out the beginning and
the ending, right?

1015
00:54:03,820 --> 00:54:08,944
The first and the last addresses, and so

1016
00:54:08,944 --> 00:54:16,640
what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
add a little bit more in here.

1017
00:54:16,640 --> 00:54:20,390
And we need to figure out
where our network starts and

1018
00:54:20,390 --> 00:54:22,940
where our network ends, all right?

1019
00:54:22,940 --> 00:54:25,600
Fortunately, figuring out the start and
the end is really easy.

1020
00:54:25,600 --> 00:54:27,870
The start, you just zero out the host ID.

1021
00:54:29,110 --> 00:54:32,080
And the end,
you just make the host ID all 1s.

1022
00:54:33,340 --> 00:54:34,140
Right.

1023
00:54:34,140 --> 00:54:37,466
>> That's it.
>> And so if we were to convert these from

1024
00:54:37,466 --> 00:54:43,832
binary back into decimal,
it would basically be 10.1.100.255.

1025
00:54:43,832 --> 00:54:45,125
>> .0.
>> No.

1026
00:54:45,125 --> 00:54:45,914
Bad, bad, bad.

1027
00:54:45,914 --> 00:54:46,540
>> [LAUGH].

1028
00:54:46,540 --> 00:54:47,570
>> All right, .0.

1029
00:54:47,570 --> 00:54:48,745
I'm getting ahead of myself.

1030
00:54:48,745 --> 00:54:52,371
Through 10.1.101.255, there we go.

1031
00:54:52,371 --> 00:54:55,270
That would be the beginning and
the end of our new range.

1032
00:54:55,270 --> 00:54:58,540
So now we're spanning across two
class C's, and that's where we get

1033
00:54:58,540 --> 00:55:02,030
over 500 addresses, and now we're able to
accommodate more guests in the building.

1034
00:55:04,260 --> 00:55:05,690
So that's an example of VLSM.

what I want to show you guys is

Right.
How we're going to use it in

1039

a Cisco world, because that's likely

But a lot of people never see how

00:55:57,760 --> 00:55:59,960
And we say things like oh,
if you have a big network and

you wanna break it up into

00:56:04,502 --> 00:56:07,835
But on Cisco routers there
is a great example of where

1062
00:56:07,835 --> 00:56:12,096
you absolutely will use this,
and it's a very beneficial thing.

1063
00:56:12,096 --> 00:56:15,154
And it's a technology
called route summarization.

1064
00:56:15,154 --> 00:56:15,816
All right.

1065
00:56:15,816 --> 00:56:20,262
Every router has to maintain a database,
right?

1066
00:56:20,262 --> 00:56:24,370
It's really a table that says what

00:56:24,370 --> 00:56:25,690
That's how it knows how to get places.

00:56:25,690 --> 00:56:26,920

00:56:26,920 --> 00:56:32,740
Your GPS has a database of all the roads

1070
00:56:32,740 --> 00:56:33,580
And if you say,

1071
00:56:33,580 --> 00:56:36,830
get me from point A to point B it looks
at all those roads to find the route.

1072
00:56:36,830 --> 00:56:37,880
Well that's what your router does.

1073
00:56:37,880 --> 00:56:41,120
Your router has to know all
those different networks.

1074
00:56:41,120 --> 00:56:43,060
The bigger that database is,

1075

the bigger that table is,
the slower your average is gonna be.

1076
00:56:47,130 --> 00:56:50,310
>> So a lot of times what you end up
seeing especially when you have a router

1077
00:56:50,310 --> 00:56:56,400
that has tons of routes, it means it has
to get an insert for every single one.

1078
00:56:56,400 --> 00:56:59,450
And even if the actual networks
are relatively the same,

1079
00:56:59,450 --> 00:57:02,020
it has to keep an entry for
every single one.

00:57:02,020 --> 00:57:06,160
What we're about to show you is how
a router actually takes entries that

1081
00:57:06,160 --> 00:57:09,740
then connect the multiple routes,
and end up summarizing them as well.

1082
00:57:09,740 --> 00:57:11,980
So what we call the idea of
route summarization there.

1083
00:57:11,980 --> 00:57:15,190
And that's where we
really do use VLSM a lot.

1084
00:57:15,190 --> 00:57:18,250
>> All right, so I wanna show you

So I've got 192 at 168.0.123456
every time I add a new network,

In my router,

And so here I would have seven

A Cisco router, even the low end ones.

So Cisco makes routers that have

If it is a three digit number like

Those guys can handle hundreds

That's why I can skip it.

1199
01:03:25,875 --> 01:03:28,055
There's no point in converting it,
I already know they're the same.

1200
01:03:29,135 --> 01:03:34,145
But in the third octet, they actually
stop right here, at the 5th bit.

1201
01:03:34,145 --> 01:03:35,920
The 5th bit, they're all zeros.

1202
01:03:35,920 --> 01:03:38,455
The 6-bit,
things start to get crazy, right?

1203
01:03:38,455 --> 01:03:40,000
>> Yep
>> We have some with zeros,

1204
01:03:40,000 --> 01:03:41,010
some with ones.

1205
01:03:41,010 --> 01:03:41,750
They're no longer the same.

1206
01:03:43,340 --> 01:03:48,000
So if I were to combine these,
I could draw my line, right.

1207
01:03:48,000 --> 01:03:50,140
Remember my line from earlier?

1208
01:03:50,140 --> 01:03:51,570
I could draw that line right here.

1209
01:03:53,510 --> 01:03:55,990
Whoops.
[LAUGH]

1210
01:03:55,990 --> 01:03:59,130
And that would make them all the same,

1211
01:03:59,130 --> 01:04:03,940
all wrapped up in a nice little bundle,
right.

1212
01:04:03,940 --> 01:04:07,160
So now they could all be shown as
being on the same network, right.

1213
01:04:07,160 --> 01:04:08,032
So all I have to do is count my bits.

1214
01:04:08,032 --> 01:04:10,731
So I've got eight bits,
eight more, that's 16.

1215
01:04:10,731 --> 01:04:13,402
Plus these five, that gets me to 21.

1216
01:04:13,402 --> 01:04:18,547
If I were to do 192.168.0.0/21,

1217
01:04:18,547 --> 01:04:23,066
that would include all of these networks.

1218
01:04:23,066 --> 01:04:23,756
Right?

1219
01:04:23,756 --> 01:04:24,960
Now what's the problem with that, Ronnie?

1220
01:04:26,610 --> 01:04:29,110
>> Problem with this-
>> On the spot quiz.

1221
01:04:29,110 --> 01:04:31,410
>> Oh.
>> If I do a /21 what am I breaking?

1222
01:04:31,410 --> 01:04:34,001
>> You're breaking the rules.

1223
01:04:34,001 --> 01:04:35,630
>> Well,

1224
01:04:35,630 --> 01:04:40,460
I'm breaking some rules especially when it
comes to what networks I'm advertising.

1225
01:04:40,460 --> 01:04:43,900
If I start telling other routers
that I have 192.68.0.0/21,

1226
01:04:43,900 --> 01:04:46,370
well that's true for these networks.

1227
01:04:47,620 --> 01:04:51,690
>> Right, but it's also true for others.

1228
01:04:51,690 --> 01:04:54,150
>> Right.
Cuz it goes all the way up.

1229
01:04:54,150 --> 01:04:57,170
If I were to really crank things up.

1230
01:04:57,170 --> 01:05:01,850
Technically, and I actually don't know
what this one is actually gonna be, so

1231
01:05:01,850 --> 01:05:02,946
I'll just put question marks in there.

1232
01:05:02,946 --> 01:05:04,437
>> [LAUGH].

1233
01:05:04,437 --> 01:05:07,110
>> Let me just show you guys.

1234
01:05:07,110 --> 01:05:11,300
When we move that line to here,
if I take and

1235
01:05:11,300 --> 01:05:17,000
do 111, to find the end,
to find the highest number, right?

1236
01:05:17,000 --> 01:05:17,870
That's gonna be 192.168.

1237
01:05:17,870 --> 01:05:22,963
and this would be 111 is seven, right?

1238
01:05:22,963 --> 01:05:23,508
>> Mm-hm.
>> Yep.

1239
01:05:23,508 --> 01:05:25,674
So that would be 7.0, right?

1240
01:05:25,674 --> 01:05:28,520
Or 7.255 the way I've written it.

1241
01:05:29,560 --> 01:05:36,370
But it would include that 7 dot network,
which I don't have in my company, okay?

1242
01:05:36,370 --> 01:05:38,600
So 192.168.7 is a network I don't have.

1243
01:05:38,600 --> 01:05:40,820
If I do a /21, I'm including that.

1244
01:05:40,820 --> 01:05:41,390
That's a problem.

1245
01:05:42,410 --> 01:05:46,230
Now, if I know that .7 is not being
used anywhere and I wanna go ahead and

1246
01:05:46,230 --> 01:05:50,860
wrap it up and advertise it, that's fine,
but if I do this, if I advertise with

1247
01:05:50,860 --> 01:05:55,190
this network here, I'm technically
advertising a network I don't have.

1248
01:05:55,190 --> 01:05:58,580
And that's against the rules
especially with internet routing.

1249
01:05:58,580 --> 01:05:59,990
If you're an internet connected router,

1250
01:05:59,990 --> 01:06:02,890
if these are public ranges,
you're not allowed to do that.

1251
01:06:02,890 --> 01:06:06,180
They'll shut you off,
your backbone is required to shut you off.

1252
01:06:06,180 --> 01:06:07,740
And then your internet access is gone.

1253
01:06:07,740 --> 01:06:08,240
>> There you go.

1254
01:06:09,830 --> 01:06:15,480
>> So when we start to divide up our
network like this, it's important that we

1255
01:06:15,480 --> 01:06:18,830
only advertise networks
that we actually have.

1256
01:06:18,830 --> 01:06:19,410
>> Right.
>> So

1257
01:06:19,410 --> 01:06:22,810
we have to be careful about
where we draw this line.

1258
01:06:22,810 --> 01:06:26,690
And in this case while it would be nice
to combine them all into one network,

1259
01:06:26,690 --> 01:06:27,590
we're not gonna be able to.

1260
01:06:27,590 --> 01:06:30,710
We're gonna have to do
separate summarizations.

1261
01:06:32,990 --> 01:06:38,283
All right, so looking at it here, if I
wanna make sure that I don't grab any un,

1262
01:06:38,283 --> 01:06:41,370
nonexisting, what's the right word there?

1263
01:06:41,370 --> 01:06:43,340
Nonexisting networks?

1264
01:06:43,340 --> 01:06:44,350
>> Any other networks.

1265
01:06:44,350 --> 01:06:45,375
>> Any other networks.

1266
01:06:45,375 --> 01:06:46,880
>> [LAUGH]
>> We need to find

1267
01:06:46,880 --> 01:06:49,460
a better place to draw our line, right?

1268
01:06:49,460 --> 01:06:52,411
If I move the line to the right one, so

1269
01:06:52,411 --> 01:06:56,420
if I just move it over one space and
go over to here.

1270
01:07:02,394 --> 01:07:04,226
So I'm actually gonna have two lines now.

1271
01:07:09,099 --> 01:07:10,903
Do I have an extra zero in there,
or something?

1272
01:07:10,903 --> 01:07:11,566
What have I done?

1273
01:07:13,437 --> 01:07:14,597
>> There you go.

1274
01:07:17,015 --> 01:07:18,363
>> There, ok.

1275
01:07:18,363 --> 01:07:20,070
So I'm gonna have two lines.

1276
01:07:20,070 --> 01:07:23,170
If I move that line to the right,
see how I've got zeros for

1277
01:07:23,170 --> 01:07:24,690
the first four networks?

1278
01:07:24,690 --> 01:07:29,460
And then I've got ones for the last three,
but to the right of it notice

1279
01:07:29,460 --> 01:07:33,770
how I've got 00, 01, 10, and 11.

1280
01:07:33,770 --> 01:07:36,710
That covers all four combinations of that.

1281
01:07:37,840 --> 01:07:40,895
So, if instead of a /21 if I did a /22,

1282
01:07:40,895 --> 01:07:44,617
in other words moving that
line to the right one more,

1283
01:07:44,617 --> 01:07:49,436
that would take these first four
networks and it would combine them.

1284
01:07:49,436 --> 01:07:54,577
192.168.0.0/22, that includes

1285
01:07:54,577 --> 01:07:59,111
192.168.0.1.2, and .3.

1286
01:07:59,111 --> 01:08:02,850
And it doesn't include any other networks,
just those four.

1287
01:08:02,850 --> 01:08:09,370
And so that would let me
collapse the first four entries.

1288
01:08:09,370 --> 01:08:13,440
So now if I did that,
my routing table would go from

1289
01:08:13,440 --> 01:08:17,940
being seven routes to just
being four routes, right?

1290
01:08:17,940 --> 01:08:20,640
So I would have four routes, yeah.

1291
01:08:20,640 --> 01:08:22,007
So then I would have,
who am I leaving out?

1292
01:08:22,007 --> 01:08:26,921
4.0/24, 5.0/24.

1293
01:08:29,244 --> 01:08:30,897
6.0/24.

1294
01:08:30,897 --> 01:08:32,513
Okay.

1295
01:08:32,513 --> 01:08:35,401
So my routing table goes from
seven routes down to four routes.

1296
01:08:35,401 --> 01:08:36,750
Now that doesn't sound
like a big difference.

1297
01:08:37,930 --> 01:08:43,070
But if you have hundreds of thousands of
routes and you do this in thousands of

1298
01:08:43,070 --> 01:08:47,560
places, you can get your internet routing
table well below a hundred thousand routes

1299
01:08:47,560 --> 01:08:51,190
and most ISPs will have routing tables
that are less than 50, 000 routes.

1300
01:08:51,190 --> 01:08:52,680
So that's huge savings.

1301
01:08:52,680 --> 01:08:54,430
Makes your routers considerably faster.

1302
01:08:56,390 --> 01:08:58,380
>> So be careful here.

1303
01:08:58,380 --> 01:09:02,360
Like Don said, if we get too many,
we may violate that idea and

1304
01:09:02,360 --> 01:09:06,970
actually end up advertising someone else's
routes underneath our summarization.

1305
01:09:06,970 --> 01:09:08,140
So we may not want to do that.

1306
01:09:08,140 --> 01:09:11,210
So sometimes you do have to compromise and
say,

1307
01:09:11,210 --> 01:09:15,740
I can't summarize everything that I want
to, you actually summarize what you can.

1308
01:09:15,740 --> 01:09:17,750
>> And we're not necessarily done.

1309
01:09:17,750 --> 01:09:19,270
>> Nope.
>> We could go a little bit

1310
01:09:19,270 --> 01:09:20,095
further, right?

1311
01:09:20,095 --> 01:09:22,780
>> Mm-hm.
>> So sure, I don't have four, five,

1312
01:09:22,780 --> 01:09:24,085
six, and seven, right?

1313
01:09:24,085 --> 01:09:25,610
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I can't get seven, but

1314
01:09:25,610 --> 01:09:27,780
that doesn't mean I'm
completely out of luck.

1315
01:09:27,780 --> 01:09:31,300
I could take these networks
here that are left over.

1316
01:09:31,300 --> 01:09:35,250
I wasn't able to subnet them.

1317
01:09:35,250 --> 01:09:39,290
And let me get rid of this extra
line cuz it'll just get confusing.

1318
01:09:39,290 --> 01:09:40,260
There.
Okay.

1319
01:09:40,260 --> 01:09:46,860
So that's where I broke those four down to
combine them into the one 192.160.0.0/22.

1320
01:09:46,860 --> 01:09:51,960
If I look down here, notice how 192.168.4,

1321
01:09:51,960 --> 01:09:58,110
and .5,
they are the same all the way up to here.

1322
01:09:58,110 --> 01:10:00,660
And then after that,
they've got a 0 and a 1.

1323
01:10:00,660 --> 01:10:03,610
That bit only has two combinations,
0 and a 1.

1324
01:10:03,610 --> 01:10:10,010
So I can actually combine these two
guys if I put their line right there.

1325
01:10:10,010 --> 01:10:12,080
So if I draw their line right there,

1326
01:10:12,080 --> 01:10:16,800
adding that one extra bit to the host ID,
then that would combine them.

1327
01:10:16,800 --> 01:10:22,210
And I could take my four and five and

1328
01:10:22,210 --> 01:10:25,240
combine them into a /23.

1329
01:10:25,240 --> 01:10:31,690
So now my routing table goes from seven
routes down to only three routes.

1330
01:10:31,690 --> 01:10:35,270
And that's important to remember on the
exam also is that you can mix and match.

1331
01:10:35,270 --> 01:10:40,100
You don't always have to do, if I do a /22
here, I've gotta do a /22 everywhere.

1332
01:10:40,100 --> 01:10:41,490
No, you can mix and match.

1333
01:10:42,650 --> 01:10:46,420
The real important thing
is in real life land.

1334
01:10:46,420 --> 01:10:48,870
This IP range right here.

1335
01:10:48,870 --> 01:10:51,370
These are three routes
that I'm advertising.

1336
01:10:51,370 --> 01:10:53,740
I have these entire routes.

1337
01:10:53,740 --> 01:10:56,485
I'm not advertising anything false.

1338
01:10:56,485 --> 01:11:04,455
If I did a 192.168.0.0/21 I would be
falsely advertising that I had 192.168.7.

1339
01:11:04,455 --> 01:11:08,630
With private address it may not matter.

1340
01:11:08,630 --> 01:11:10,130
It's easy and you're done.

1341
01:11:10,130 --> 01:11:12,950
But with public addresses
you can't do that.

1342
01:11:12,950 --> 01:11:14,400
So we do have to break it up.

1343
01:11:14,400 --> 01:11:20,110
And so in this case I had to do a /22,
a /23 and a /24.

1344
01:11:20,110 --> 01:11:25,260
This routing table right here matches
what I showed at the very beginning.

1345
01:11:25,260 --> 01:11:28,290
So where I had seven of these /24s,

1346
01:11:28,290 --> 01:11:34,175
now I'm down to just three networks,
a /22, a /23, and a /24.

1347
01:11:34,175 --> 01:11:35,429
>> Excellent.

1348
01:11:35,429 --> 01:11:38,140
>> Now,
you need to know how to do this by hand.

1349
01:11:38,140 --> 01:11:39,240
>> Right.
>> All right?

1350
01:11:39,240 --> 01:11:41,800
And like I said,
jump over to that Network+ show.

1351
01:11:41,800 --> 01:11:43,325
It's actually two episodes we did it.

1352
01:11:43,325 --> 01:11:44,810
>> Mm-hm.
>> It spanned over two episodes.

1353
01:11:44,810 --> 01:11:46,410
And so we do this by hand.

1354
01:11:46,410 --> 01:11:47,300
We show you how to work it out.

1355
01:11:47,300 --> 01:11:49,500
It's really detailed.

1356
01:11:51,050 --> 01:11:54,900
We're gonna learn later though that a lot
of our routing protocols will do this for

1357
01:11:54,900 --> 01:11:58,010
us automatically and that's pretty cool.

1358
01:11:58,010 --> 01:12:00,205
But on the exam they want you
to be able to do it by hand.

1359
01:12:00,205 --> 01:12:01,165
So, you will get questions about this.

1360
01:12:01,165 --> 01:12:05,215
They'll give you a routing table,
and they'll say what's the smallest

1361
01:12:05,215 --> 01:12:09,133
subnet mass you can use to combine
these networks without wasting IPs,

1362
01:12:09,133 --> 01:12:11,109
without falsely advertising IPs.

1363
01:12:11,109 --> 01:12:12,460
And you've gotta work that out.

1364
01:12:12,460 --> 01:12:17,940
We should probably do another example.

1365
01:12:17,940 --> 01:12:19,650
>> Sure.
>> Right.

1366
01:12:19,650 --> 01:12:22,720
Let's just take, I'll come up with some
off the wall numbers that are a pain for

1367
01:12:22,720 --> 01:12:23,308
us to convert.

1368
01:12:23,308 --> 01:12:25,810
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know

1369
01:12:25,810 --> 01:12:29,725
we could do the opposite direction
of VLSM where we break up a network.

1370
01:12:29,725 --> 01:12:30,280
Right?

1371
01:12:30,280 --> 01:12:34,720
So maybe I go out and
I buy some registered IP's from my

1372
01:12:34,720 --> 01:12:39,210
Internet service provider or directly
from the INA, I can't normally do.

1373
01:12:39,210 --> 01:12:45,110
But so I go out and I get 209.251.133.,
well maybe I get the whole class.

1374
01:12:45,110 --> 01:12:46,270
Well not the whole class C.

1375
01:12:46,270 --> 01:12:49,985
Maybe they give me half the class C right.

1376
01:12:49,985 --> 01:12:54,337
>> Yep.
>> So they give me a 25, right?

1377
01:12:54,337 --> 01:13:02,261
A /25 tells me that the first
25 bits are my subnet mask.

1378
01:13:02,261 --> 01:13:02,775
Right?
And

1379
01:13:02,775 --> 01:13:06,007
then the remaining,
what am I left with, seven bits?

1380
01:13:06,007 --> 01:13:08,627
The remaining seven bits are my host ID,
right?

1381
01:13:08,627 --> 01:13:11,916
And that gives me enough,
seven bits would give me 126?

1382
01:13:11,916 --> 01:13:12,946
>> 27?
>> 126.

1383
01:13:12,946 --> 01:13:15,111
>> Okay, so 126 usable IP's.

1384
01:13:15,111 --> 01:13:19,057
Pretty decent amount of public IP's.

1385
01:13:19,057 --> 01:13:21,970
If I have a disaster recovery site.

1386
01:13:21,970 --> 01:13:25,680
And I have a production home office site.

1387
01:13:25,680 --> 01:13:29,260
I may wanna divide this up again, so
that half the addresses can go to DR,

1388
01:13:29,260 --> 01:13:30,800
and half can stay right in production.

1389
01:13:30,800 --> 01:13:33,070
Right?
And this is a real world example.

1390
01:13:33,070 --> 01:13:35,070
I've done this at a number of places.

1391
01:13:35,070 --> 01:13:37,620
And it saves you from having
to get another address pool.

1392
01:13:37,620 --> 01:13:41,830
>> Right, so
the idea of wasting a few addresses here

1393
01:13:41,830 --> 01:13:46,590
is what we normally actually are trying
to do with variable link subnet masking.

1394
01:13:46,590 --> 01:13:49,610
Even though we may not end up working
with an ISP inside of our own businesses,

1395
01:13:49,610 --> 01:13:52,811
this is where it's gonna become critical,
right here.

1396
01:13:52,811 --> 01:13:56,940
>> And this network is already
somewhat small, it's a slash 25 right.

1397
01:13:56,940 --> 01:14:01,450
So that tells me the first three octets,
209.251.133, that's the first 24 bits,

1398
01:14:01,450 --> 01:14:03,770
they're entirely in the network ID.

1399
01:14:03,770 --> 01:14:04,600
Right?

1400
01:14:04,600 --> 01:14:06,230
So, what I was saying earlier was,

1401
01:14:06,230 --> 01:14:10,070
when it comes to converting this stuff,
we don't really care what

1402
01:14:10,070 --> 01:14:14,510
that is in binary cuz we're not going
to have to work with those octets.

1403
01:14:14,510 --> 01:14:18,050
Those octets are not really
involved in our operation.

1404
01:14:19,730 --> 01:14:20,522
And then I know zero.

1405
01:14:20,522 --> 01:14:21,486
Right?

1406
01:14:21,486 --> 01:14:24,035
So I like to call it the action octet.

1407
01:14:24,035 --> 01:14:24,730
Right?
All

1408
01:14:24,730 --> 01:14:27,490
of the action is happening
here in this last octet.

1409
01:14:27,490 --> 01:14:30,330
The first three, I'm not so worried about.

1410
01:14:30,330 --> 01:14:33,202
So this is,
as far as I'm concerned on the exam,

1411
01:14:33,202 --> 01:14:36,605
this is what 209.251.133.0 is in binary.

1412
01:14:36,605 --> 01:14:38,990
Okay?

1413
01:14:38,990 --> 01:14:41,110
And again, I'm doing this to save time,

1414
01:14:41,110 --> 01:14:44,490
I don't want to convert
stuff I don't need to.

1415
01:14:44,490 --> 01:14:50,900
Now they told me it's a /25,
so a /25 subnet mask,

1416
01:14:50,900 --> 01:14:54,160
again, I'm not going to convert that
to decimal, because I don't care right?

1417
01:14:54,160 --> 01:14:56,630
>> Yeah.
>> But I know it's 25 ones.

1418
01:14:56,630 --> 01:15:01,690
So when I write out that network mask
that they gave me I need to do 25 ones.

1419
01:15:01,690 --> 01:15:03,930
And I'm just hitting one and
counting them in my head.

1420
01:15:03,930 --> 01:15:04,846
So I got to 25 ones.

1421
01:15:04,846 --> 01:15:07,858
Actually, I didn't even really do
that because I knew that there

1422
01:15:07,858 --> 01:15:11,390
were 24 ones in the first three octets and
I only needed one more.

1423
01:15:11,390 --> 01:15:12,960
So there's the subnet mask.

1424
01:15:12,960 --> 01:15:20,740
So that tells me that according to my
ISP my line gets drawn right here.

1425
01:15:20,740 --> 01:15:21,300
Okay?

1426
01:15:21,300 --> 01:15:26,420
So that's where my line is drawn, and that
is my network as far as I'm concerned.

1427
01:15:26,420 --> 01:15:27,050
Okay?

1428
01:15:27,050 --> 01:15:32,330

01:28:04,131 --> 01:28:04,712

01:28:04,712 --> 01:28:07,812

>> But anyhow, so it is Massive.

01:28:07,812 --> 01:28:10,063
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, when you have an address that big,

1658
01:28:10,063 --> 01:28:10,575
all right?

1659
01:28:10,575 --> 01:28:15,507
To write out 128 bits in ones and zeroes,
it would just wrap around your screen and

1660
01:28:15,507 --> 01:28:16,970

1661
01:28:16,970 --> 01:28:21,285
So, with IPB 6,
we use hexidecimal numbers, all right?

1662
01:28:21,285 --> 01:28:24,315
In decimal, we have zero through nine, and

1663
01:28:24,315 --> 01:28:27,845
each place in the number
is a value of ten,right?

1664
01:28:27,845 --> 01:28:29,825
So zero through nine has ten values.

1665
01:28:29,825 --> 01:28:31,109
In binary, you have zero and one.

1666
01:28:31,109 --> 01:28:33,105
>> Right.
>> You just have two values.

1667
01:28:33,105 --> 01:28:38,097
But in Hexadecimal, you have zero
through nine, and then A through F,

1668
01:28:38,097 --> 01:28:39,807
so you actually have 16 values.

1669
01:28:39,807 --> 01:28:41,997
It's base 16 mathematics.

1670
01:28:41,997 --> 01:28:44,937
So, when you look at a hexadecimal number,
it's not really a number anymore.

1671
01:28:44,937 --> 01:28:50,050
It's numbers and letters that
are represented to us as human beings.

1672
01:28:50,050 --> 01:28:51,650
So the address is big, right?

1673
01:28:51,650 --> 01:28:56,490
And the way it's normally
represented is eight blocks of

1674
01:28:56,490 --> 01:29:02,190
four hexadecimal digits each and
they're separated by a colon, okay?

1675
01:29:02,190 --> 01:29:05,750
So let me give some examples here.

1676
01:29:05,750 --> 01:29:07,120
>> Yep.

1677
01:29:07,120 --> 01:29:10,980
Now, while Don is talking about this,
let's talk about what

1678
01:29:10,980 --> 01:29:13,891

01:29:13,891 --> 01:29:19,510
We would actually have 16 separate octets,
is what we would actually have.

1680
01:29:19,510 --> 01:29:22,610
So instead of seeing the four octets
that we've been seeing in IP version 4.

1681
01:29:22,610 --> 01:29:27,600
We tried to report this in that .decimal,
16 .sections.

1682
01:29:27,600 --> 01:29:31,940
To make it easier,
the IETF actually ended up saying hey

1683
01:29:31,940 --> 01:29:34,350
we need to actually report this
as something that is shorter.

1684
01:29:34,350 --> 01:29:36,990
So the very first time I read about this
it said they shortened the format and

1685
01:29:36,990 --> 01:29:38,590
I didn't understand why.

1686
01:29:38,590 --> 01:29:40,990
But because we have a base 16 here,

1687
01:29:40,990 --> 01:29:45,720
what they did is that they made

1688
01:29:45,720 --> 01:29:48,385
And for us, we needed the way
to report that easily, and

1689
01:29:48,385 --> 01:29:50,810
that's were hexidecimal comes in.

1690
01:29:50,810 --> 01:29:56,160
So Don is now typing out what

1691
01:29:56,160 --> 01:29:58,330
up looking like for us here.

01:29:58,330 --> 01:30:02,210

So anyhow, so

01:30:26,350 --> 01:30:28,430
That is an IPv6 address.

01:30:28,430 --> 01:30:31,240
If I were to convert that into binary,
into ones and

01:30:31,240 --> 01:30:34,620

01:30:37,710 --> 01:30:40,210

01:30:40,210 --> 01:30:43,850
Now when they developed IPv6,
they said, we need a big address, and

1708
01:30:43,850 --> 01:30:48,380
we're gonna give the most possible
address space, room, that they could.

1709
01:30:48,380 --> 01:30:50,650
So they went with a big number like this.

1710
01:30:50,650 --> 01:30:54,690
But they built in some shorthand
methods to help us out,

1711
01:30:54,690 --> 01:30:56,280
to make things a little bit easier.

1712
01:30:56,280 --> 01:30:58,640

Makes it more humanly readable for us.

1713
01:30:58,640 --> 01:31:02,680
>> First off,
we can leave off any trailing zeroes.

1714
01:31:02,680 --> 01:31:06,460
So here, where we've got 07b8, right?

1715
01:31:06,460 --> 01:31:10,990
The very first digit is a zero and
you can leave that zero off and

1716
01:31:10,990 --> 01:31:12,050
just write it as 7b8.

1717
01:31:12,050 --> 01:31:14,766
We actually do that with IP V4 addresses.

1718
01:31:14,766 --> 01:31:19,586
>> Yep.
>> So like 192.168.0.1, that's actually

1719
01:31:21,933 --> 01:31:28,540
192.168.000.001, but we leave off
the leading zeros cuz they're meaningless.

1720
01:31:28,540 --> 01:31:29,180
Right?

1721
01:31:29,180 --> 01:31:31,140
So we end up writing it as192.168.0.1.

1722
01:31:31,140 --> 01:31:33,410
IPv6 you can do the same thing.

1723
01:31:33,410 --> 01:31:36,180
If you have 07b8 you can
just write it as 7b8.

1724
01:31:36,180 --> 01:31:39,295
That makes it a little bit shorter.

1725
01:31:39,295 --> 01:31:40,630

1726
01:31:40,630 --> 01:31:43,950
>> Also,
if you have one that's all zeroes,

1727
01:31:43,950 --> 01:31:47,940
you can leave off the leading zeroes and

1728
01:31:47,940 --> 01:31:49,490
So that way it becomes really short.

1729
01:31:49,490 --> 01:31:50,340

1730
01:31:50,340 --> 01:31:55,530
But then when you have sets of

1731
01:31:55,530 --> 01:31:58,320
And so normally when you

1732

you can shorten them up in to what we

1733
01:32:02,600 --> 01:32:04,430

So you'll see here where I took this where

01:32:06,810 --> 01:32:09,920

That is a shortcut,
a little shorthand notation.

1737
01:32:12,885 --> 01:32:16,085
And this says everything between

1738

Now, important fact here.

01:32:17,845 --> 01:32:21,605

1740
01:32:21,605 --> 01:32:24,455
So here, what happens is that

01:32:24,455 --> 01:32:26,520

I've got one, two, three,

And a colon, colon.

1744
01:32:32,970 --> 01:32:35,190
I should have eight sets of numbers.

1745
01:32:35,190 --> 01:32:38,940
So, that means there's three more sets

1746
01:32:38,940 --> 01:32:40,190
all right.

1747
01:32:40,190 --> 01:32:41,920
If I did that twice.

1748
01:32:41,920 --> 01:32:44,470
If I did it again right
here with the other zero.

1749
01:32:44,470 --> 01:32:46,120
Right?
Now it would say all right,

1750
01:32:46,120 --> 01:32:50,260
you gave me one, two, three,
four sets of numbers, I need four more.

1751
01:32:50,260 --> 01:32:53,090
Is it one here and three here?

1752
01:32:53,090 --> 01:32:54,670
Is it two here and two here?

1753
01:32:54,670 --> 01:32:56,360
Is it three here and one there?

1754
01:32:56,360 --> 01:32:58,220
We don't know.
>> Too ambiguous, yeah.

1755
01:32:58,220 --> 01:33:00,660
>> That's why you can only
do it once per number.

1756
01:33:00,660 --> 01:33:03,000
And so I'll have to put in a zero there,
just so

1757
01:33:03,000 --> 01:33:06,190
it knows that there's only one
set of zeros in that spot.

1758
01:33:06,190 --> 01:33:06,870
>> Yeah.

1759
01:33:06,870 --> 01:33:09,020
So that double colon
notation only appears once.

1760
01:33:09,020 --> 01:33:10,240
>> Yeah.
>> Make sure you remember that.

1761
01:33:10,240 --> 01:33:13,400
>> So these are nice little shortcuts that
make the numbers a little more manageable.

1764

>> So it doesn't roll any easier,

fe80::a0ac:0:86ba, I'm bored already,
:7b8.

1766

we're not gonna memorize it.

But just looking at the numbers here,

1771

Now, with the IPv6 address,

as soon as we wrap our minds around the

it's just written hexidecimal.

Everything else is basically

1776

You have a subnet mask, but

1777

/64 is very common.

1778

That means the first 64
bits of the network id and

1779
01:34:02,160 --> 01:34:03,480

1780
01:34:03,480 --> 01:34:04,170
Right?
>> Now one of

1781
01:34:04,170 --> 01:34:06,510
the things that I do
appreciate about this Don,

1782
01:34:06,510 --> 01:34:11,140
is I don't even have to have

1783
01:34:11,140 --> 01:34:13,820
What we see right here is

1784

And a lot of times you hear this as

1785
01:34:17,280 --> 01:34:23,474

Obviously it's really long and

1790
01:34:34,870 --> 01:34:39,260
And so they pretty much always use

1791
01:34:39,260 --> 01:34:40,650
just that prefix.

1792
01:34:40,650 --> 01:34:45,050
So once we've got that it really

And just like in the world of

01:34:50,160 --> 01:34:52,160
IPv6 completely classless.

01:34:52,160 --> 01:34:53,960
So there are no classes.

1796

They kind of learned their lesson on that

So all we really have to

That means 2,000 followed by 7 sets of

much any number that starts with 2 is 0.

That means a Public registered IP that

01:36:17,600 --> 01:36:20,300

>> All right, some of

1823
01:36:20,300 --> 01:36:23,020
the other ones that we need to know let

1824
01:36:23,020 --> 01:36:26,750
oh they actually don't show

Let me go down even further.

1826
01:36:30,260 --> 01:36:34,326
So down here I've got FF00::/8.

1827
01:36:34,326 --> 01:36:39,052
So FF0, FF00: and

1828
01:36:39,052 --> 01:36:43,265
Anything that starts with ff0,

1829
01:36:43,265 --> 01:36:44,175

1830
01:36:44,175 --> 01:36:44,713

1831
01:36:44,713 --> 01:36:45,720
Right?

1832

In IPv6 we no longer have broadcasts.

1833
01:36:48,585 --> 01:36:50,195
Broadcasts are completely gone, right?

1834
01:36:50,195 --> 01:36:52,005
Which they're inefficient anyway.

1835

So we don't want that.

1836
01:36:53,140 --> 01:36:58,150
So instead multi-casts become

1837
01:36:58,150 --> 01:37:00,920
That's what replaces the old broadcast.

1838
01:37:00,920 --> 01:37:02,160
Much more efficient.

1839
01:37:02,160 --> 01:37:03,570
Much more important.

So, where as you could almost

It's used every single moment in IPv6.

01:37:12,320 --> 01:37:18,460
All right, the other one I wanna point

Here fe80::/10.

Any time you see fe8, like in my
example where I showed my address here,

1846

fe8 means link local.

1847
01:37:28,980 --> 01:37:32,840
This is a non routable IP that is

1848

It's used solely on your local network.

1849
01:37:35,950 --> 01:37:39,470

01:37:39,470 --> 01:37:41,265

1851
01:37:41,265 --> 01:37:45,020

01:37:46,950 --> 01:37:48,400
These are kind of like private IP's,

01:37:48,400 --> 01:37:51,420

1855
01:37:51,420 --> 01:37:54,800
you can't even use them like the normal

01:37:54,800 --> 01:37:56,670
We have other ranges that

01:37:59,020 --> 01:38:01,330
And that's the other range that I

01:38:01,330 --> 01:38:03,970
It was on a different standard, here.

1859
01:38:03,970 --> 01:38:09,390
In IPv6, we have a set of private

1860

1862

But if you want to set up a private IPv6

us are the IP addresses that
