01:39:11,215 --> 01:39:18,490
>> And so multicast is being used for
Discovery, for DHCP, for ARP.

1879
01:39:18,490 --> 01:39:19,560
ARP is technically gone.

1880
01:39:19,560 --> 01:39:24,389
It's replaced by Link Layer Discover
Protocol, LLDP and all that good stuff.

1881
01:39:25,630 --> 01:39:30,200
So anyhow, so you have that kind of stuff
going on there on the multicast side.

1882
01:39:30,200 --> 01:39:33,130
We have our Global Unicast,
our Local Unicast.

1883
01:39:33,130 --> 01:39:36,820
We also have some other special ones
like the loopback address, right?

1884
01:39:36,820 --> 01:39:39,750
In IPv4,
the loopback address is 127.0.0.1.

1885
01:39:39,750 --> 01:39:41,575
That's a weird IP, right?

1886
01:39:41,575 --> 01:39:42,080
>> Yeah.

1887
01:39:42,080 --> 01:39:46,660
>> In IPv6, they said forget that, let's
just go with the very first first IP.

1888
01:39:46,660 --> 01:39:51,955
The loopback address in IPv6,
if I write the whole thing out,

1889
01:39:51,955 --> 01:39:58,545
it's a bunch of zeros followed by one.

1890
01:39:58,545 --> 01:40:02,220
Right?
It's the very first IP and since we've got

1891
01:40:02,220 --> 01:40:07,450
all these zeros here and we've got three
leading zeros here, the cool part about

1892
01:40:07,450 --> 01:40:12,548
the loopback, is we can abbreviate
it all the way down to just ::1.

1893
01:40:12,548 --> 01:40:17,137
Right?
If I wanna ping my loopback in IPv6,

1894
01:40:17,137 --> 01:40:21,577
I just say ping ::1, and-
>> There you go.

1895
01:40:21,577 --> 01:40:22,349
>> That's pinging loopback.

1896
01:40:22,349 --> 01:40:23,067
I'm pinging myself.

1897
01:40:27,314 --> 01:40:28,080
All right.

1898
01:40:29,150 --> 01:40:31,020
Ronnie, can you think of?

1899
01:40:31,020 --> 01:40:32,360
>> We left off fe80.

1900
01:40:32,360 --> 01:40:33,060
>> Good point.

1901
01:40:33,060 --> 01:40:34,170
We need that one on here.

1902
01:40:36,160 --> 01:40:36,660
Whoops.

1903
01:40:41,509 --> 01:40:43,410
And it is a /10?

1904
01:40:43,410 --> 01:40:43,910
>> /10.

1905
01:40:46,764 --> 01:40:47,300
It's our Link Local.

1906
01:40:47,300 --> 01:40:51,500
>> Let me get my alignment back.

1907
01:40:51,500 --> 01:40:52,050
There we go.

1908
01:40:52,050 --> 01:40:52,900
All right.

1909
01:40:52,900 --> 01:40:56,440
So for the exam,
these are the ones you want to memorize.

1910
01:40:56,440 --> 01:40:59,100
When you're on the exam and
you see a two zero zero type address,

1911
01:40:59,100 --> 01:41:04,280
that's a global unicast, that's a public
IP that was registered with IANA.

1912
01:41:04,280 --> 01:41:06,290
It might be 2001, 2003,

1913
01:41:06,290 --> 01:41:10,520
2002, those are the ones that you see
out there on the Internet right now.

1914
01:41:10,520 --> 01:41:13,290
But they're adding more
as they issue them.

1915
01:41:13,290 --> 01:41:18,000
If you see fc0 something, then that
tells you it's a private address.

1916
01:41:18,000 --> 01:41:19,690
It's internal use only.

1917
01:41:19,690 --> 01:41:21,890
FE80, it's link local.

1918
01:41:21,890 --> 01:41:23,450
It's not even routable.

1919
01:41:23,450 --> 01:41:24,450
FF00 is that multicast.

1920
01:41:24,450 --> 01:41:26,150
And ::1, that's the loopback, right.

1921
01:41:26,150 --> 01:41:28,450
>> All right.

1922
01:41:28,450 --> 01:41:29,840
So now that we have these addresses,

1923
01:41:29,840 --> 01:41:34,520
Don, and we can identify them,
how is this gonna effect me?

1924
01:41:34,520 --> 01:41:39,481
Do I have to now take a single
computer and type out an IP version 6

1925
01:41:39,481 --> 01:41:42,670
address to actually to get an IP
address on my own computer?

1926
01:41:42,670 --> 01:41:44,590
>> Well, yes and no.

1927
01:41:44,590 --> 01:41:47,010
Right?
So if you want to be routed, yes.

1928
01:41:47,010 --> 01:41:49,340
You've gotta punch in an address, right?

1929
01:41:49,340 --> 01:41:50,580
If you don't want to be routed though,

1930
01:41:50,580 --> 01:41:53,350
if you're just trying to talk locally,
if my laptop wants to talk to yours.

1931
01:41:53,350 --> 01:41:55,170
>> Yeah.
>> We're on the same network.

1932
01:41:55,170 --> 01:41:56,970
We can use our Link Local address.

1933
01:41:56,970 --> 01:42:00,990
Your system will automatically generate
a Link Local address and did I?

1934
01:42:00,990 --> 01:42:02,801
You know, I powered this router off.

1935
01:42:02,801 --> 01:42:04,057
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me power this router back on.

1936
01:42:04,057 --> 01:42:05,960
I'll show you guys on the actual router.

1937
01:42:05,960 --> 01:42:09,380
Give that a second to fire up.

1938
01:42:09,380 --> 01:42:14,419
But I'll show you on the router
that if you have IPv6 enabled it

1939
01:42:14,419 --> 01:42:20,830
will automatically generate a IPv6
address that is a link local, an FE80.

1940
01:42:20,830 --> 01:42:22,470
It does that for you.

1941
01:42:22,470 --> 01:42:23,070
Right.

1942
01:42:23,070 --> 01:42:24,405
But it's non-routable.

1943
01:42:24,405 --> 01:42:25,450
>> Right.
>> If you wanna be routed,

1944
01:42:25,450 --> 01:42:27,320
you've got two choices.

1945
01:42:27,320 --> 01:42:31,560
Choice number one, you statically
assign an IP address, an IPv6 address,

1946
01:42:31,560 --> 01:42:36,370
and you statically assign
a default gateway, just like IPv4.

1947
01:42:37,490 --> 01:42:44,400
The other option, though, is to Discover
or learn a network and an address to use.

1948
01:42:44,400 --> 01:42:47,650
And for those of you that go
on to do the CCNT you'll get

1949
01:42:47,650 --> 01:42:49,710
to see how to set all that stuff up.

1950
01:42:49,710 --> 01:42:53,840
We might even do it in the CCNA class,
just for fun during that show.

1951
01:42:53,840 --> 01:42:58,420
But basically the way it works is you have
a router that is advertising the PC's and

1952
01:42:58,420 --> 01:43:01,110
says hey here's our network ID.

1953
01:43:01,110 --> 01:43:03,020
You pick your host ID,
I don't care about that.

1954
01:43:03,020 --> 01:43:05,270
Here's the network ID and I'm a router.

1955
01:43:05,270 --> 01:43:07,420
If you wanna route through me,
you can get to the Internet.

1956
01:43:07,420 --> 01:43:12,130
And so, just like DHCP,
our routers can, or our PCs and so on,

1957
01:43:12,130 --> 01:43:15,580
can get their address, and
jump on the network and be routed.

1958
01:43:15,580 --> 01:43:18,290
And for that,
we would hand out usually public IPs.

1959
01:43:18,290 --> 01:43:20,044
Usually, the global unique, unicast.

1960
01:43:20,044 --> 01:43:22,610
>> Yeah.
There's a lot of different ways that

1961
01:43:22,610 --> 01:43:23,170
this can be done.

1962
01:43:23,170 --> 01:43:26,410
So we can statically assign an IP address
just like we're doing in an IP version 4

1963
01:43:26,410 --> 01:43:31,782
though, we may also be able to generate
a portion of our address as well.

1964
01:43:31,782 --> 01:43:33,980
And so do you wanna talk about the EUI?

1965
01:43:33,980 --> 01:43:35,710
Now?
Are we going to do it?

1966
01:43:35,710 --> 01:43:37,260
>> Yeah, yeah.
So you know, DHCP in IPv4,

1967
01:43:37,260 --> 01:43:41,030
you need a DHCP server to dynamically
get your address on the network and

1968
01:43:41,030 --> 01:43:43,560
make sure you don't have duplicates.

1969
01:43:43,560 --> 01:43:46,300
In IPv6, they actually worked
out a neat little idea that said

1970
01:43:46,300 --> 01:43:47,880
we can do away with DHCP.

1971
01:43:47,880 --> 01:43:51,990
Since we discover our router anyway,
and we can discover name servers,

1972
01:43:51,990 --> 01:43:56,890
that we can make it where PCs
generate their own address also.

1973
01:43:56,890 --> 01:43:59,756
A /64 network is really common with IPv6.

1974
01:43:59,756 --> 01:44:01,914
Let me get back to my notes here,
while that router is booting up.

1975
01:44:01,914 --> 01:44:06,802
So, if we take a /64, right?

1976
01:44:06,802 --> 01:44:12,790
That's gonna be 64 bits for the network ID
and then 64 bits for the host ID, right?

1977
01:44:12,790 --> 01:44:18,370
So 128 bit address, 64 bits for

1978
01:44:18,370 --> 01:44:23,020
network ID, and 64 bits for host ID.

1979
01:44:23,020 --> 01:44:25,710
Now it doesn't have to be this way right?

1980
01:44:25,710 --> 01:44:30,790
This is just how most people set it up
because you have so many addresses so

1981
01:44:30,790 --> 01:44:34,390
if we set it up this way,
the first 64 bits, that's our network.

1982
01:44:34,390 --> 01:44:36,070
And our router can advertise that out.

1983
01:44:36,070 --> 01:44:38,310
Hey, here's the first 64 bits for you.

1984
01:44:38,310 --> 01:44:40,970
You're left to come up with
the remaining 64 bits.

1985
01:44:40,970 --> 01:44:44,210
Well, what they said is,
hey, we need a 64 bit,

1986
01:44:44,210 --> 01:44:47,310
hexadecimal number that's unique
to each machine on our network.

1987
01:44:47,310 --> 01:44:48,980
And they said boy,

1988
01:44:48,980 --> 01:44:54,410
wouldn't it be nice if there was already
a hexadecimal number that we could use.

1989
01:44:54,410 --> 01:44:56,580
Well, there is, right?

1990
01:44:56,580 --> 01:45:00,690
Every network adaptor has a MAC address,
a media access control address.

1991
01:45:00,690 --> 01:45:03,510
And it's a 48 bit hexadecimal number.

1992
01:45:03,510 --> 01:45:04,010
Right.

1993
01:45:04,010 --> 01:45:05,944
So if I look on my laptop here.

1994
01:45:05,944 --> 01:45:09,574
And I take a look, whoops, and

1995
01:45:09,574 --> 01:45:14,610
I take a look at my
adapter Bluetooth here.

1996
01:45:14,610 --> 01:45:17,220
This is my physical network adapter.

1997
01:45:17,220 --> 01:45:18,865
So here is my MAC address.

1998
01:45:18,865 --> 01:45:19,680
Right?

1999
01:45:19,680 --> 01:45:25,370
Now my MAC address is only 64 bits,
I mean 48 bits.

2000
01:45:25,370 --> 01:45:26,180
I need it to be 64 bits.

2001
01:45:26,180 --> 01:45:26,797
>> Right.

2002
01:45:26,797 --> 01:45:30,510
>> So that's where EUI 64 comes in.

2003
01:45:30,510 --> 01:45:38,140
If you've never head of it, EUI 64,
it's a standard for address definition.

2004
01:45:38,140 --> 01:45:43,310
And it basically says what you do is
you take somebody's MAC address and

2005
01:45:43,310 --> 01:45:43,820
you modify it.

2006
01:45:45,470 --> 01:45:49,610
And basically you divide it up like this,
okay?

2007
01:45:49,610 --> 01:45:53,870
And actually, let me put it back here so
we still have the original, and

2008
01:45:53,870 --> 01:45:58,170
you pad it to add some bits
to it to make it 64 bit.

2009
01:45:58,170 --> 01:46:03,330
And the way they do it is they take the 48
bit address, they divide it in half,

2010
01:46:03,330 --> 01:46:07,655
and they add in FFFE, to the middle.

2011
01:46:07,655 --> 01:46:09,391
FFFE.

2012
01:46:09,391 --> 01:46:11,500
Right?

2013
01:46:11,500 --> 01:46:17,584
Writing it out this way,
that would be more like there,

2014
01:46:17,584 --> 01:46:21,630
so just in the middle I stick in FFFE.

2015
01:46:21,630 --> 01:46:25,300
That pads it and gets us to 64 bits.

2016
01:46:25,300 --> 01:46:28,360
So if I have a router advertising out.

2017
01:46:29,750 --> 01:46:36,690
If a router is advertised as,
let's say it's 2001.

2018
01:46:36,690 --> 01:46:40,950
So this is a registered network
that I've registered with the IANA.

2019
01:46:46,302 --> 01:46:47,750
There.

2020
01:46:47,750 --> 01:46:49,430
So this is similar to what
a router would advertise.

2021
01:46:49,430 --> 01:46:50,690
It would advertise to the network.

2022
01:46:50,690 --> 01:46:55,212
It would do a multicast on the network,
and say here's the first 64 bits,

2023
01:46:55,212 --> 01:47:04,070
2001 :1b3d:0:48:: that means
the remainders are all zeroes, /64.

2024
01:47:04,070 --> 01:47:09,165
My PC can then take it's MAC address,
pad it with that

2025
01:47:09,165 --> 01:47:14,130
FFFE, and
then add on these 64 bits right here,

2026
01:47:17,690 --> 01:47:22,915
which would result in a 128
bit address that's unique.

2027
01:47:22,915 --> 01:47:25,080
Right?
The network address we

2028
01:47:25,080 --> 01:47:29,020
got from the router, the remaining 64
bits were calculated on my MAC address.

2029
01:47:29,020 --> 01:47:32,040
There should be no two computers in my
building with the same MAC address.

2030
01:47:32,040 --> 01:47:33,190
There might be computers somewhere

2031
01:47:33,190 --> 01:47:34,224
else in the world
>> [LAUGH]

2032
01:47:34,224 --> 01:47:35,755
>> But there shouldn't be, right?

2033
01:47:35,755 --> 01:47:40,185
So this guarantees that I get
a unique 128 bit address,

2034
01:47:40,185 --> 01:47:42,315
it's public in this case and
I'm ready to rock.

2035
01:47:42,315 --> 01:47:46,585
And there's no DHCP server so
I'll always have this same address and

2036
01:47:46,585 --> 01:47:48,046
I don't have to statically set it.

2037
01:47:48,046 --> 01:47:50,107
Right?
Super convenient,

2038
01:47:50,107 --> 01:47:52,357
makes it where we don't have to work
with these addresses very much.

2039
01:47:54,117 --> 01:47:56,087
>> Sounds like our router's
actually ready to go, Don.

2040
01:47:56,087 --> 01:47:57,757
>> It certainly is.

2041
01:47:57,757 --> 01:47:58,947
There we go.

2042
01:47:58,947 --> 01:48:02,013
All right, so
let me show you guys how this works.

2043
01:48:02,013 --> 01:48:05,153
This is a router that has
a stock configuration on it.

2044
01:48:05,153 --> 01:48:07,023
Right?
I haven't done anything crazy to it.

2045
01:48:07,023 --> 01:48:12,248
And I definitely haven't
assigned any IPv6 addresses.

2046
01:48:12,248 --> 01:48:14,093
Right?
So if I look at the two interfaces here.

2047
01:48:14,093 --> 01:48:15,903
See where it says no IP address?

2048
01:48:15,903 --> 01:48:18,243
There's no addresses assigned.

2049
01:48:18,243 --> 01:48:18,991
Right?

2050
01:48:18,991 --> 01:48:24,930
But if I do a show IPv6 interface brief.

2051
01:48:24,930 --> 01:48:29,990
Show IPv, now I love show IP
interface brief, but that's for IPv4.

2052
01:48:29,990 --> 01:48:31,875
>> [LAUGH]
>> So show IPv6 interface brief,

2053
01:48:31,875 --> 01:48:33,920
that'll show me the addresses for IPv6.

2054
01:48:33,920 --> 01:48:34,690
>> Right.

2055
01:48:34,690 --> 01:48:39,530
>> It's cool with Cisco anytime
you go from IPv4 to IPv6,

2056
01:48:39,530 --> 01:48:43,800
you just take the letters IP and you add
V6 to it and now it's the V6 command.

2057
01:48:43,800 --> 01:48:45,210
So when I do that.

2058
01:48:45,210 --> 01:48:47,643
None of my interfaces are on,
that's gonna slow things down isn't it.

2059
01:48:51,257 --> 01:48:52,999
Let me turn these on real quick.

2060
01:48:57,223 --> 01:49:00,015
I didn't turn that switch on either.

2061
01:49:00,015 --> 01:49:02,290
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's just see,

2062
01:49:02,290 --> 01:49:04,260
it may power up in time.

2063
01:49:04,260 --> 01:49:09,000
So if I run a show IPv6 interface brief,
as soon as those interfaces come up,

2064
01:49:09,000 --> 01:49:12,170
they'll actually have addresses
attached to them, okay.

2065
01:49:12,170 --> 01:49:13,070
So they'll have that.

2066
01:49:13,070 --> 01:49:18,101
Actually let me make sure that
>> [LAUGH]

2067
01:49:25,525 --> 01:49:26,750
>> Yup, it's all there.

2068
01:49:26,750 --> 01:49:27,280
Okay.

2069
01:49:27,280 --> 01:49:29,557
So as soon as those interfaces come up,

2070
01:49:29,557 --> 01:49:34,720
we'll see,
We'll see addresses show up there.

2071
01:49:34,720 --> 01:49:39,420
But basically, they'll have FEA addresses,
the link local addresses.

2072
01:49:39,420 --> 01:49:40,690
They'll get those automatically, and

2073
01:49:40,690 --> 01:49:43,840
that allows them to talk non-routed,
just locally, right.

2074
01:49:43,840 --> 01:49:46,210
Then, we need to add the addresses.

2075
01:49:46,210 --> 01:49:49,350
So if I want to configure that,
I can do it in one of two ways.

2076
01:49:49,350 --> 01:49:52,440
I can do it manually or
I can do it with EUI 64, right.

2077
01:49:52,440 --> 01:49:58,110
So I might go into interface gi0/0 and
say IPv6

2078
01:50:00,000 --> 01:50:05,200
address and then specify what my
full address is going to be, right?

2079
01:50:06,830 --> 01:50:11,110
So maybe it's like this and I don't wanna
overlap with my laptop or anything.

2080
01:50:11,110 --> 01:50:15,217
So I'll just say,
punch it in like this /64.

2081
01:50:15,217 --> 01:50:19,340
So there is my address, and
now it's attached to that interface.

2082
01:50:19,340 --> 01:50:21,330
I've now got an IPv6 address, right.

2083
01:50:22,330 --> 01:50:27,610
I could also say, let me get into 0/1.

2084
01:50:27,610 --> 01:50:34,180
And I'll just go up to
the next network in line.

2085
01:50:34,180 --> 01:50:37,380
So I did 48 for the first one,
I'll do 49 for this one.

2086
01:50:38,380 --> 01:50:40,920
Right, and see how I did ::/64?

2087
01:50:40,920 --> 01:50:43,640
Saying zero out the rest of the address.

2088
01:50:43,640 --> 01:50:49,570
So 2001, 1B3D, 0 and
then 49 everything else is a 0.

2089
01:50:49,570 --> 01:50:53,060
And I just add to the end of that, EUI-64.

2090
01:50:53,060 --> 01:50:57,082
And that says figure out the last 64,
use your MAC address.

2091
01:50:57,082 --> 01:51:00,060
Add FFFE to it, and then off you go.

2092
01:51:00,060 --> 01:51:01,610
All right.

2093
01:51:01,610 --> 01:51:03,470
So I'm gonna punch that in there.

2094
01:51:03,470 --> 01:51:04,590
It's gonna change.

2095
01:51:04,590 --> 01:51:06,530
My switch is apparently booting up now so

2096
01:51:06,530 --> 01:51:09,970
we should see some better
stuff with our interfaces.

2097
01:51:09,970 --> 01:51:10,720
All right.
And

2098
01:51:10,720 --> 01:51:12,740
I did do a no shut down on that one,
didn't I?

2099
01:51:12,740 --> 01:51:13,370
Yes.

2100
01:51:13,370 --> 01:51:13,870
Okay.

2101
01:51:15,210 --> 01:51:21,010
Now, if I do a show IP interface brief,
I didn't assign any IPv4 addresses.

2102
01:51:21,010 --> 01:51:21,810
I could've, right?

2103
01:51:21,810 --> 01:51:26,210
It's called dual stack when you run both,
IPv4 and IPv6, but

2104
01:51:26,210 --> 01:51:32,230
if I just add my IPv6 to that command,
there we go.

2105
01:51:32,230 --> 01:51:36,010
I only assigned one address, but
notice how I have two right?

2106
01:51:36,010 --> 01:51:42,730
I have FE80, those are those link locals
and I've got the ones that I assigned.

2107
01:51:42,730 --> 01:51:46,020
Here's the one that it assigned.

2108
01:51:46,020 --> 01:51:51,315
And oh, you know what, shoot,
I manually put FFFE in there, dadgummit.

2109
01:51:51,315 --> 01:51:57,112
Let me change that cuz

2110
01:51:57,112 --> 01:52:02,117
When I assigned that IP,
I manually put FFFE in there.

2111
01:52:02,117 --> 01:52:04,107
So let me fix that.

2112
01:52:08,180 --> 01:52:09,986
I'll just stick zeros in there instead.

2113
01:52:14,028 --> 01:52:14,653
Okay.

2114
01:52:20,570 --> 01:52:21,532
There we go.

2115
01:52:21,532 --> 01:52:24,700
All right, so now I can see,
here's the one that I statically assigned.

2116
01:52:24,700 --> 01:52:26,720
Right?
There's the one that I manually put in

2117
01:52:26,720 --> 01:52:30,380
there, and
it's abbreviated it as best as it could.

2118
01:52:30,380 --> 01:52:35,000
It's also got that FE80 right there,
so that's that link local address, and

2119
01:52:35,000 --> 01:52:38,892
then beneath it,
here's the one where I used EUI 64,

2120
01:52:38,892 --> 01:52:44,130
so 2001:ib3D/0/49, that's the network ID.

2121
01:52:44,130 --> 01:52:49,269
Everything else it figured out
based on its MAC address, and

2122
01:52:49,269 --> 01:52:56,848
so I can see where it's got that where
your 0217E0, FFFE, 696669, right?

2123
01:52:56,848 --> 01:53:01,661
So if I delete that FFFE,
the rest of that, 0217E0,

2124
01:53:01,661 --> 01:53:07,370
696669 that's the MAC address for
that network adapter.

2125
01:53:07,370 --> 01:53:10,700
So, pretty cool,
easy way to get that address on there.

2126
01:53:10,700 --> 01:53:13,330
The link locals
are automatically generated.

2127
01:53:13,330 --> 01:53:18,160
The actual address is like these unicast
addresses that we have attached here,

2128
01:53:18,160 --> 01:53:19,160
we have to manually input in.

2129
01:53:20,430 --> 01:53:21,450
>> Sounds good.

2130
01:53:21,450 --> 01:53:22,240
>> All right.

2131
01:53:22,240 --> 01:53:27,170
Now, there is a lot more to IPv6, all the
crazy security features, and things like

2132
01:53:27,170 --> 01:53:31,990
that, but for the CCENT exam, they really
don't drill you on that very much.

2133
01:53:31,990 --> 01:53:34,830
We are going to see a little bit more of
it later on as we get into our routing

2134
01:53:34,830 --> 01:53:35,720
protocols.

2135
01:53:35,720 --> 01:53:39,700
But the main thing that you wanna focus
on for the exam is basically the general

2136
01:53:39,700 --> 01:53:45,340
concepts, the idea of what those IPv6
addresses look like, memorize that list.

2137
01:53:45,340 --> 01:53:46,840
Let me, Jason can we bring that list?

2138
01:53:46,840 --> 01:53:48,070
There we go perfect.

2139
01:53:48,070 --> 01:53:51,840
Memorize this list right here, the special
address ranges, because those will pop up,

2140
01:53:51,840 --> 01:53:54,060
you'll get questions on that.

2141
01:53:54,060 --> 01:53:57,500
So, these are things that you'll see,
definitely keep that in mind.

2142
01:53:57,500 --> 01:54:00,410
Like I said there is a ton about IPv6.

2143
01:54:00,410 --> 01:54:02,880
We'll delve more into it in the CCNA show.

2144
01:54:04,990 --> 01:54:08,840
All right, Ronnie I think I blathered
a little too long and ran past our time.

2145
01:54:08,840 --> 01:54:10,090
Can you think of anything I left out?

2146
01:54:10,090 --> 01:54:11,150
>> I don't think so.

2147
01:54:11,150 --> 01:54:13,860
I think we are done for this episode.

2148
01:54:13,860 --> 01:54:14,570
>> Okay.

2149
01:54:14,570 --> 01:54:17,070
Well let's wrap it up here.

2150
01:54:17,070 --> 01:54:20,920
I know looking at IP address is
not the most exciting thing.

2151
01:54:20,920 --> 01:54:22,140
>> Yep.
>> In the next episode,

2152
01:54:22,140 --> 01:54:23,070
we're gonna start routing.

2153
01:54:23,070 --> 01:54:24,460
>> That's right.
>> We're gonna start learning about our

2154
01:54:24,460 --> 01:54:27,480
routing protocols and actually
moving traffic across the network.

2155
01:54:27,480 --> 01:54:29,945
We're also gonna get back
into the IPv4 world, so

2156
01:54:29,945 --> 01:54:34,940
if that sounds exciting to you and I hope
it does, definitely stay tuned for that.

2157
01:54:34,940 --> 01:54:38,000
Remember, we are doing a double header
today, so the next episode starts in,

2158
01:54:38,000 --> 01:54:39,050
well, a little over an hour.

2159
01:54:39,050 --> 01:54:40,040
>> All right.
>> So

2160
01:54:40,040 --> 01:54:42,740
we'll be seeing that one after
we get food in our bellies.

2161
01:54:42,740 --> 01:54:44,990
So stay tuned for that.

2162
01:54:44,990 --> 01:54:47,860
As always, if you have any questions,
you're not on your own.

2163
01:54:47,860 --> 01:54:49,465
Make sure you jump on over to ITPro.TV.

2164
01:54:49,465 --> 01:54:52,550
You've got our Q and
A where you can post questions.

2165
01:54:52,550 --> 01:54:55,550
We monitor and
then answer back all the time.

2166
01:54:55,550 --> 01:54:59,922
Also, you've got the live chat during
the show if you're watching us live.

2167
01:54:59,922 --> 01:55:04,690
On itpro,tv/live, you've got the chat
screen as long as you're logged in.

2168
01:55:04,690 --> 01:55:09,570
You can punch in questions and
we monitor that throughout the show.

2169
01:55:09,570 --> 01:55:11,910
So keep all that in mind.

2170
01:55:11,910 --> 01:55:14,220
Good luck with your studies and
we'll see you next episode.

2171
01:55:14,220 --> 01:55:14,903
>> Yep.

2172
01:55:14,903 --> 01:55:24,903
[MUSIC]

2173
01:55:26,611 --> 01:55:33,480
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In order for one to jump into the realm of routers, one has to have an idea of how routers work, how they do what they do, and what goes on behind the scenes as routers work. Viewers will hear about the first steps into IP routing, the IP routing process, what happens to data as it passes across the network, as well as see demonstrations on configuring routing on Cisco routers.
episodes.title: IP Routing Technologies
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,122 --> 00:00:22,260
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,260 --> 00:00:32,260
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,685 --> 00:00:34,812
All right.
Good morning.

5
00:00:34,812 --> 00:00:35,544
Good afternoon.

6
00:00:35,544 --> 00:00:36,205
And good evening.

7
00:00:36,205 --> 00:00:37,031
Welcome back.

8
00:00:37,031 --> 00:00:38,711
To another episode of ITProTV.

9
00:00:38,711 --> 00:00:40,660
I'm your host Don Pezet.

10
00:00:40,660 --> 00:00:42,200
Coming at you live with Mr Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:42,200 --> 00:00:43,090
How's it going Ronnie?

12
00:00:43,090 --> 00:00:44,340
>> It's going well.

13
00:00:44,340 --> 00:00:47,880
We are ready for
a exciting episode in CCNT today.

14
00:00:47,880 --> 00:00:49,920
>> As exciting as they get.

15
00:00:49,920 --> 00:00:53,460
Today we are finally going to
dive into what the bulk of

16
00:00:53,460 --> 00:00:55,010
the CCNT exam is based on.

17
00:00:55,010 --> 00:00:56,530
Which is routing, right?

18
00:00:56,530 --> 00:00:58,140
In our other episodes so far,

19
00:00:58,140 --> 00:01:02,890
we've tackled things like basic switch
configuration, basic router configuration.

20
00:01:02,890 --> 00:01:07,230
We talk about IP subnetting,
which is bubbling over with excitement.

21
00:01:08,380 --> 00:01:09,090
>> That's right.

22
00:01:09,090 --> 00:01:10,535
>> Yeah, its kind of lame.

23
00:01:10,535 --> 00:01:13,490
[LAUGH] Today,
we're going to jump into routing.

24
00:01:13,490 --> 00:01:16,860
We can't just jump straight into our
routers and start routing stuff around,

25
00:01:16,860 --> 00:01:21,940
we need to have an idea of how routers
work, how they do what they do, and

26
00:01:21,940 --> 00:01:26,800
what all goes on behind the scenes
as routers make up their decisions.

27
00:01:26,800 --> 00:01:30,170
>> Yeah, whereas packets are actually
gonna be moving across our network,

28
00:01:30,170 --> 00:01:32,540
one of the key ideas of course,
is so that.

29
00:01:32,540 --> 00:01:35,640
When we actually understand the concepts,
it helps us to be able to troubleshoot

30
00:01:35,640 --> 00:01:38,740
when the packets don't arrive
where they actually need to go.

31
00:01:38,740 --> 00:01:41,600
So for us we're actually going
by those basic concepts today.

32
00:01:41,600 --> 00:01:45,880
Wanna make sure that you have a good
understanding of how a router

33
00:01:45,880 --> 00:01:50,670
processes a packet here, and what we
call the idea of forwarding as well.

34
00:01:50,670 --> 00:01:53,310
>> So the first thing I wanna tackle is

35
00:01:53,310 --> 00:01:56,840
what happens to our data as
it passes across the network?

36
00:01:56,840 --> 00:01:57,440
>> All right.

37
00:01:57,440 --> 00:01:59,000
>> That's a basic concept.

38
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:02,330
It's how layer three
routing actually operates.

39
00:02:02,330 --> 00:02:06,330
And I wanna take a look at that first,
and then once we're done with that,

40
00:02:06,330 --> 00:02:08,450
then it'll probably be the next segment,
at that point.

41
00:02:08,450 --> 00:02:12,280
We'll take a look at how routing tables
work, and then we'll be ready to jump

42
00:02:12,280 --> 00:02:15,110
right into the routers, and actually
get a chance to see routing in action.

43
00:02:16,180 --> 00:02:20,530
So let's start off with a diagram that
I worked up right before the show.

44
00:02:20,530 --> 00:02:22,856
And see my producer's frustration.

45
00:02:22,856 --> 00:02:26,710
And [LAUGH] kinda give you
guys demonstration now,

46
00:02:26,710 --> 00:02:30,746
when you look at this,
it does look kinda complex and

47
00:02:30,746 --> 00:02:35,794
probably because it is, but
really its pretty simple drawing and

48
00:02:35,794 --> 00:02:40,379
what I'm doing is I'm throwing where,
I got a PC or PC1 and

49
00:02:40,379 --> 00:02:45,096
PC1 has an IP address of 172.19.1.28,
right?

50
00:02:45,096 --> 00:02:50,800
And it wants to browse across
the network to another machine.

51
00:02:50,800 --> 00:02:53,370
Now, when I say browse
maybe it's a web browsers,

52
00:02:53,370 --> 00:02:55,320
maybe it's FTP, email, who knows?

53
00:02:55,320 --> 00:02:59,110
Whatever client it is I'm not
really concerned about that.

54
00:02:59,110 --> 00:03:03,530
PC1 just wants to contact
PC2 all the way over here.

55
00:03:03,530 --> 00:03:10,433
Now, PC2 has an IP address of
209.251.133.16, all right?

56
00:03:10,433 --> 00:03:12,964
So PC1 is on one network.

57
00:03:12,964 --> 00:03:14,400
PC2 is on another network.

58
00:03:14,400 --> 00:03:19,140
Now I didn't put any subnet masks on here,
but these networks are so different.

59
00:03:19,140 --> 00:03:21,360
No matter what the subnet mask was,

60
00:03:21,360 --> 00:03:23,170
these two guys are gonna
be on different networks.

61
00:03:23,170 --> 00:03:24,510
I think even if it was like a slash two,

62
00:03:24,510 --> 00:03:26,900
they'd still be on different networks,
wouldn't they?

63
00:03:26,900 --> 00:03:28,040
>> Yeah pretty much.

64
00:03:28,040 --> 00:03:30,980
Now don't forget that what we have
here now is concepts that we've

65
00:03:30,980 --> 00:03:33,200
already gone over a little bit.

66
00:03:33,200 --> 00:03:38,230
If both of the devices were on the same
network, we wouldn't need routers at all.

67
00:03:38,230 --> 00:03:41,530
But now because both of the devices
are on different networks

68
00:03:41,530 --> 00:03:43,430
we need to pass through routers.

69
00:03:43,430 --> 00:03:46,470
We're going to actually pass
through routers here, for our data.

70
00:03:46,470 --> 00:03:49,720
That means we have to understand
the basic concept of how a router

71
00:03:49,720 --> 00:03:52,920
processes the packet, and
then forwards it out the other side.

72
00:03:52,920 --> 00:03:53,930
Yeah.
>> Yup.

73
00:03:53,930 --> 00:03:57,920
>> So think back to our very first CCE and
T episode,

74
00:03:57,920 --> 00:03:59,920
where we talked about the OSI model.

75
00:03:59,920 --> 00:04:02,440
>> Right.
>> When a PC, or any device goes to

76
00:04:02,440 --> 00:04:07,530
communicate on a ethernet network, it's
starts at layer seven, the Application.

77
00:04:07,530 --> 00:04:08,850
So let's say this is web browsing.

78
00:04:08,850 --> 00:04:10,880
Let's say that PC2 is a web server and

79
00:04:10,880 --> 00:04:16,730
PC1 is me firing up Google Chrome or
Internet Explorer or Firefox or whatever.

80
00:04:16,730 --> 00:04:21,000
So in my web browser I type in a name,
right?

81
00:04:21,000 --> 00:04:23,730
www.amazon.com, right?

82
00:04:23,730 --> 00:04:27,060
And it's going to do a DNS
lookup to get an IP address, and

83
00:04:27,060 --> 00:04:30,570
that's how I know what
IP I want to contact.

84
00:04:30,570 --> 00:04:34,730
PC1 is going down the OSI model now,
and it goes down to layer 6,

85
00:04:34,730 --> 00:04:40,410
where it figures out that it's going to
be doing a HTML, or an HTTP get request.

86
00:04:40,410 --> 00:04:44,280
Then it goes down to layer 5 where
it says hey, this is web traffic.

87
00:04:44,280 --> 00:04:46,620
So it's gonna have
a destination port of port 80,

88
00:04:46,620 --> 00:04:51,210
a source port of something random
40,000 to 60,000, somewhere in there.

89
00:04:51,210 --> 00:04:55,910
Then it gets down to layer 4 and
it says is this packet,

90
00:04:55,910 --> 00:04:59,190
is this data, gonna be over 1500 bytes?

91
00:04:59,190 --> 00:05:00,650
Right?
And if it is,

92
00:05:00,650 --> 00:05:02,240
then we need to break it up into segments.

93
00:05:02,240 --> 00:05:03,554
Otherwise we can just leave it as one.

94
00:05:03,554 --> 00:05:04,360
>> Mm-hm.

95
00:05:04,360 --> 00:05:06,400
>> Then we get down to layer three.

96
00:05:06,400 --> 00:05:11,590
At layer three, that's where PC1 sets
up the source and the destination.

97
00:05:11,590 --> 00:05:14,640
Where this traffic is coming and
where it's going to, right.

98
00:05:14,640 --> 00:05:19,050
And that's what I want to show you guys,
is as it builds that packet right.

99
00:05:19,050 --> 00:05:21,360
And in layer three we're
dealing with packets.

100
00:05:21,360 --> 00:05:25,870
The information that it provides us with,
well, it's gonna have a source IP.

101
00:05:25,870 --> 00:05:27,564
And the source IP is going to be itself.

102
00:05:27,564 --> 00:05:34,116
So PC one's source IP
would be 172.19.1.28 okay.

103
00:05:34,116 --> 00:05:35,576
So it's gonna whoops.

104
00:05:35,576 --> 00:05:36,854
Dag gonnit.

105
00:05:36,854 --> 00:05:39,560
So it's gonna fill that in
as it goes down its line.

106
00:05:39,560 --> 00:05:43,880
I'll get a nice little type text
here on my screen there we go.

107
00:05:43,880 --> 00:05:47,390
So it's gonna fill that
information in at layer three.

108
00:05:47,390 --> 00:05:52,050
The destination IP is gonna be PC2
the person we're trying to get to.

109
00:05:52,050 --> 00:05:55,640
This is the beginning and
the end of the communication.

110
00:05:55,640 --> 00:06:01,596
So the end of this communication is
going to be that 209.251.133.16.

111
00:06:01,596 --> 00:06:04,380
Right.
Where are traffic is coming from and

112
00:06:04,380 --> 00:06:05,610
where are traffic is going to.

113
00:06:06,630 --> 00:06:11,080
Think of this in terms when you
address a letter to send to somebody.

114
00:06:11,080 --> 00:06:13,000
You have the return address.

115
00:06:13,000 --> 00:06:16,110
And the to address,
who it's from and who it's to.

116
00:06:16,110 --> 00:06:19,140
That's what we're doing here at layer
three, who it's from and who it's to.

117
00:06:19,140 --> 00:06:19,750
>> Yeah.

118
00:06:19,750 --> 00:06:22,330
Now, remember that this is
an important concept for us because,

119
00:06:22,330 --> 00:06:26,390
a lot of times, we still have more to
go before we can send the packet along.

120
00:06:26,390 --> 00:06:30,620
so the IP address really
shows us the source, or

121
00:06:30,620 --> 00:06:33,750
where it's coming from, and
the ultimate destination.

122
00:06:33,750 --> 00:06:38,200
But that doesn't mean that the packet is
moving yet, for us it just means that now

123
00:06:38,200 --> 00:06:41,790
we know where the packet is
going to be delivered to, and so

124
00:06:41,790 --> 00:06:47,030
after we actually have this information,
then our computers have to actually add

125
00:06:47,030 --> 00:06:50,950
in more because we're only at layer three,
we still have two layers to go here.

126
00:06:50,950 --> 00:06:55,100
>> Yeah, now at layer two is where
something really interesting happens,

127
00:06:55,100 --> 00:07:00,380
all right, if PC1 and
PC2 were on the same network,

128
00:07:00,380 --> 00:07:05,320
then we would send out an ARP broadcast,
an Address Resolution Protocol broadcast

129
00:07:05,320 --> 00:07:08,500
and we would say what is
the Mac address for this IP?

130
00:07:09,560 --> 00:07:11,920
PC2 would respond with
it's Mac address and

131
00:07:11,920 --> 00:07:16,060
the Mac address would go right here
into what's going to become a frame.

132
00:07:17,450 --> 00:07:20,950
Remember at layer 3 it's a packet,
but at layer two it's a frame.

133
00:07:20,950 --> 00:07:24,800
Well in our case,
PC2 is on a different network.

134
00:07:24,800 --> 00:07:27,160
If we send a broadcast out
it's not going to make it.

135
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:30,290
Broadcasts do not pass
the routers by default.

136
00:07:30,290 --> 00:07:30,860
Right.

137
00:07:30,860 --> 00:07:33,380
So what we're gonna have to do instead,

138
00:07:33,380 --> 00:07:37,240
is say all right PCI is gonna
have to go through a router.

139
00:07:37,240 --> 00:07:39,630
It's gonna have to go
through its default gateway.

140
00:07:39,630 --> 00:07:42,820
But my source and
destination are already set.

141
00:07:42,820 --> 00:07:46,210
So how do I get this packet
go to a different destination

142
00:07:46,210 --> 00:07:48,240
other than what 's here at layer 3?

143
00:07:48,240 --> 00:07:50,160
Well we use layer 2.

144
00:07:50,160 --> 00:07:55,120
So PC1 is gonna fill in
it's layer 2 information.

145
00:07:55,120 --> 00:07:57,644
And, or
it will if I can click in the right spot.

146
00:08:00,941 --> 00:08:01,877
There we go, all right.

147
00:08:01,877 --> 00:08:04,231
So it's gonna fill in
a source MAC address,

148
00:08:04,231 --> 00:08:06,660
which is going to be its own address,
right?

149
00:08:06,660 --> 00:08:09,632
So here is the MAC address- For PC1.

150
00:08:09,632 --> 00:08:12,574
For the destination MAC address though,

151
00:08:12,574 --> 00:08:16,870
it knows if it's in our broadcast and
says hey, who is PC2?

152
00:08:16,870 --> 00:08:19,392
It's not gonna get a response back, so

153
00:08:19,392 --> 00:08:24,800
instead it sends out an ARP broadcast and
says, who is my default gateway?

154
00:08:24,800 --> 00:08:28,160
On your network card you've
manually set a default gateway, and

155
00:08:28,160 --> 00:08:30,370
it'll broadcast to find
that one's MAC address.

156
00:08:30,370 --> 00:08:31,555
It probably already has it, right?

157
00:08:31,555 --> 00:08:32,950
Cuz we use it all the time.

158
00:08:32,950 --> 00:08:33,590
But if not,

159
00:08:33,590 --> 00:08:38,210
we'll broadcast out to get it and we'll
add that as our destination MAC address.

160
00:08:38,210 --> 00:08:43,200
Now, that's kind of counter intuitive,
because the destination MAC

161
00:08:43,200 --> 00:08:47,760
address does not match
the destination IP address.

162
00:08:47,760 --> 00:08:50,200
But that's exactly what we want here.

163
00:08:50,200 --> 00:08:54,660
Because we need something to
steer this packet or this frame,

164
00:08:54,660 --> 00:08:58,180
now, across the network to the router,
right.

165
00:08:59,410 --> 00:09:03,420
>> So now, with the layer two address,
Ashley Dunn.

166
00:09:03,420 --> 00:09:07,480
We now have not only the source and
the destination IP address,

167
00:09:07,480 --> 00:09:09,600
which tells us where
it's ultimately going.

168
00:09:09,600 --> 00:09:12,100
We now have a pathway that we can take.

169
00:09:12,100 --> 00:09:13,910
We know the next device.

170
00:09:13,910 --> 00:09:18,180
In which this data packets gonna actually
leave, out of this computer to go.

171
00:09:18,180 --> 00:09:21,440
So this is where we can now
take the entire frame, and

172
00:09:21,440 --> 00:09:23,840
now put it onto the wire,
is what we can do.

173
00:09:23,840 --> 00:09:25,780
>> Yeah.
And the cool part about this is,

174
00:09:25,780 --> 00:09:28,260
when the frame hits the switch, right?

175
00:09:28,260 --> 00:09:30,130
So PC one is connected to a switch.

176
00:09:30,130 --> 00:09:33,650
And then router one is connected to
either that one or a downstream switch.

177
00:09:33,650 --> 00:09:36,300
Switches look at the source and

178
00:09:36,300 --> 00:09:39,480
destination MAC address
to move the frame along.

179
00:09:39,480 --> 00:09:42,350
Switches are layer two devices.they
don't look at layer three and

180
00:09:42,350 --> 00:09:46,590
higher the switches don't even
see this layer three data.

181
00:09:46,590 --> 00:09:49,350
They just see the source
of destination MAC.

182
00:09:49,350 --> 00:09:51,940
So, when the switch gets it,
it's gonna say oh, this is destined for

183
00:09:51,940 --> 00:09:53,070
this MAC address.

184
00:09:53,070 --> 00:09:54,380
I know where that is.

185
00:09:54,380 --> 00:09:57,390
And it's gonna send that
traffic to router one.

186
00:09:58,470 --> 00:10:03,330
Now router one is gonna receive it and
it's gonna go up the OSI model.

187
00:10:03,330 --> 00:10:06,140
We went down the OSI model on the way
out now when we get to router one,

188
00:10:06,140 --> 00:10:07,280
we're gonna go back up it.

189
00:10:07,280 --> 00:10:12,170
And as we go up that OSI model,
router one is gonna look at the source and

190
00:10:12,170 --> 00:10:14,700
destination MAC address,
it's layer two, right.

191
00:10:14,700 --> 00:10:16,530
It'll say, oh good.

192
00:10:16,530 --> 00:10:19,190
And this is where the router
begins that process, right?

193
00:10:19,190 --> 00:10:21,950
We called it decapsulation at one point.

194
00:10:21,950 --> 00:10:24,080
So it processes layer two, right?

195
00:10:24,080 --> 00:10:27,430
What it does is it takes a look
at its own MAC address, and

196
00:10:27,430 --> 00:10:29,940
it compares it to
the destination MAC address.

197
00:10:29,940 --> 00:10:33,250
If they match,
it processes the layer two header.

198
00:10:33,250 --> 00:10:35,250
Once the layer two header
is processed it says,

199
00:10:35,250 --> 00:10:38,000
hey, you've arrived at the right device.

200
00:10:38,000 --> 00:10:41,530
Now let's see if you're actually at
the destination device itself, and

201
00:10:41,530 --> 00:10:43,330
it takes a look at layer three.

202
00:10:43,330 --> 00:10:47,970
And you notice on router one at
the left-hand side, the IP address there

203
00:10:47,970 --> 00:10:52,250
does not match the destination IP
address in that particular frame.

204
00:10:52,250 --> 00:10:53,900
And this is where we'll have a problem.

205
00:10:53,900 --> 00:10:56,530
>> Yeah.
Now if this were a PC, it would say, oh,

206
00:10:56,530 --> 00:10:57,160
this is wrong.

207
00:10:57,160 --> 00:10:57,900
This isn't for me.

208
00:10:57,900 --> 00:10:59,730
And it would,
throw the packet away, right?

209
00:10:59,730 --> 00:11:02,820
But a router doesn't do that,
a router looks at it and

210
00:11:02,820 --> 00:11:07,300
says, oh this came to me, but
it's not destined for me.

211
00:11:07,300 --> 00:11:08,210
That means it time for

212
00:11:08,210 --> 00:11:13,460
me to my job, I need to route this
packet to get it where it needs to go.

213
00:11:13,460 --> 00:11:15,550
And so what's it's gonna
do is it's gonna look, and

214
00:11:15,550 --> 00:11:17,500
router one is gonna
maintain a routing table.

215
00:11:17,500 --> 00:11:19,530
We'll talk about the routing table later.

216
00:11:19,530 --> 00:11:22,490
But the routing table's how it
figures out where to send that data.

217
00:11:22,490 --> 00:11:26,198
So it's gonna look at the direction
it needs to send the data in.

218
00:11:26,198 --> 00:11:28,331
So router one might say oh, you know what,

219
00:11:28,331 --> 00:11:31,255
I know how to get to
the 209.251.133 network.

220
00:11:31,255 --> 00:11:31,946
I know how to get there.

221
00:11:31,946 --> 00:11:37,490
But it's not through me I'm gonna send
you over to router two all right.

222
00:11:37,490 --> 00:11:41,500
Router one is gonna take that packet,
and it's gonna re-write it.

223
00:11:41,500 --> 00:11:44,400
It's gotta reach in and
change some of the data.

224
00:11:44,400 --> 00:11:46,770
It's not gonna change layer three right,

225
00:11:46,770 --> 00:11:50,650
the layer three data is gonna stay the
same cuz that's, that's our beginning and

226
00:11:50,650 --> 00:11:55,940
our end, we can't change that or
the packet will get lost on the way.

227
00:11:55,940 --> 00:12:00,870
So what it's gonna do is it's
gonna go in there an it's going to

228
00:12:00,870 --> 00:12:05,930
punch that same data in so
that the source and

229
00:12:05,930 --> 00:12:08,800
the destination IP address stay
the same as they did originally.

230
00:12:08,800 --> 00:12:10,440
That is unchanged.

231
00:12:10,440 --> 00:12:11,110
From up here.

232
00:12:11,110 --> 00:12:11,750
>> Yeah okay.

233
00:12:11,750 --> 00:12:15,360
Now that the router actually realizes
it's gonna be routing it out.

234
00:12:15,360 --> 00:12:19,580
It's gonna now,
since we're not changing the IP address.

235
00:12:19,580 --> 00:12:22,350
When it forwards it out
the interface it says look.

236
00:12:22,350 --> 00:12:25,474
I've got to send this packet on,
but if it's coming form me,

237
00:12:25,474 --> 00:12:28,674
this is where the MAC addresses
will actually end up changing.

238
00:12:28,674 --> 00:12:33,591
So here the source MAC address is gonna
become the MAC address of the exiting

239
00:12:33,591 --> 00:12:35,318
interface on router one.

240
00:12:39,605 --> 00:12:44,546
And the destination MAC address will
now go across to router two, so

241
00:12:44,546 --> 00:12:50,110
that router two, will have a chance to
forward that packet further as well.

242
00:12:51,270 --> 00:12:52,070
>> Yeah.

243
00:12:52,070 --> 00:12:53,720
And the we basically repeat the process.

244
00:12:53,720 --> 00:12:56,040
>> Yep.
>> Router one sends the packet along this

245
00:12:56,040 --> 00:12:56,920
link right here.

246
00:12:56,920 --> 00:12:59,250
So, it goes from router one to router two.

247
00:12:59,250 --> 00:13:02,690
Once it gets to router two,
we end up with the repeat process.

248
00:13:02,690 --> 00:13:07,010
It starts down at layer one, it gets
electricity, it converts it to 1 0's,

249
00:13:07,010 --> 00:13:09,390
gets to layer two, looks at the source and

250
00:13:09,390 --> 00:13:13,490
destination MAC address, the destination
MAC address is router two so its a match.

251
00:13:13,490 --> 00:13:16,250
Then it goes to layer three, and it says,

252
00:13:16,250 --> 00:13:20,090
wait a minute,
that destination IP is not me.

253
00:13:20,090 --> 00:13:23,160
It says but, I know how to get there.

254
00:13:23,160 --> 00:13:24,780
So let me forward you along.

255
00:13:24,780 --> 00:13:28,280
Now we repeat the process once again.

256
00:13:28,280 --> 00:13:30,030
The source IP.

257
00:13:30,030 --> 00:13:34,090
The source IP, it stays the same,
as it always does.

258
00:13:34,090 --> 00:13:36,910
I'm going to punch that
back in with the same data.

259
00:13:37,990 --> 00:13:40,640
From the very beginning, and

260
00:13:40,640 --> 00:13:45,570
the destination IP stays the same, because
again, it's the beginning and the end,

261
00:13:45,570 --> 00:13:49,620
the source and the destination, and
we don't want to manipulate that.

262
00:13:49,620 --> 00:13:50,640
>> Yeah.

263
00:13:50,640 --> 00:13:53,630
But once again the layer
to address changes.

264
00:13:53,630 --> 00:13:54,370
Notice now,

265
00:13:54,370 --> 00:13:59,920
the source map address will become the
exiting interface on router two for us.

266
00:13:59,920 --> 00:14:03,660
And then the destination, well this is
actually where we will have that one

267
00:14:03,660 --> 00:14:06,668
device that will actually be
the ultimate destination address.

268
00:14:06,668 --> 00:14:10,254
>> And router two can find
that because it's plugged in

269
00:14:10,254 --> 00:14:12,384
to this same network as PC two.

270
00:14:12,384 --> 00:14:16,516
Router two can send out a broadcast and
say hey what's the MAC address for

00:14:16,516 --> 00:14:18,560
209.251.133.16.

00:14:18,560 --> 00:14:22,020
PC two will respond back and

00:14:22,020 --> 00:14:26,150
Router two will add that to its ARP cache

274
00:14:26,150 --> 00:14:29,280
The packet will make it to PC2, and

00:14:29,280 --> 00:14:33,560
PC2 will learn that it can get back

276
00:14:33,560 --> 00:14:35,640
It kind of goes full circle.

277
00:14:35,640 --> 00:14:39,420
So that packet started on PC1 and

00:14:39,420 --> 00:14:45,040

279
00:14:45,040 --> 00:14:49,900
and as it did it, the routers had to
manipulate that packet along the way,

280
00:14:49,900 --> 00:14:52,170
now here's the really
cool part about that.

281
00:14:52,170 --> 00:14:54,980
We always talk about how routers
are layer three devices.

282
00:14:54,980 --> 00:14:59,540
They use the information of layer
three to move the packet along.

283
00:14:59,540 --> 00:15:01,500
But, because that data can't change.

284
00:15:01,500 --> 00:15:02,550
They need help.

285
00:15:02,550 --> 00:15:07,005
And so what actually moves the packet
along is not the packet data at all, but

286
00:15:07,005 --> 00:15:07,988
the frame data.

287
00:15:07,988 --> 00:15:08,536
>> Right.

288
00:15:08,536 --> 00:15:10,080
>> The layer two data.

289
00:15:10,080 --> 00:15:14,240
The source and MAC address is what
actually moved that frame, or

290
00:15:14,240 --> 00:15:15,490
moved that packet.

291
00:15:15,490 --> 00:15:17,740
Hop by hop by hop down the road.

292
00:15:17,740 --> 00:15:22,520
So, all though routers are layer three
devices, they do layer three look ups, but

293
00:15:22,520 --> 00:15:25,740
the real work that they do,
the manipulation they do is at layer two.

294
00:15:26,810 --> 00:15:29,730
>> Now at destination PC2 here, right.

295
00:15:29,730 --> 00:15:32,870
We processed the layer two
header because it all matches.

296
00:15:32,870 --> 00:15:37,400
But this time instead of actually PC2
looking at the destination IP address and

297
00:15:37,400 --> 00:15:40,060
thinking it's gonna actually
need to send it somewhere else.

298
00:15:40,060 --> 00:15:43,680
it now actually takes a look at the
destination IP address and it matches, and

299
00:15:43,680 --> 00:15:46,870
it processes the layer
three header as well.

300
00:15:46,870 --> 00:15:51,510
And so that means once it processes that,
its not gonna actually send it on any more

00:15:51,510 --> 00:15:56,230

00:15:56,230 --> 00:15:59,627
We process layer two header,
we process layer three header,

00:15:59,627 --> 00:16:02,250
that means that the packet
is where it belongs.

>> And this is happening over and
over and over again on your network.

Every single packet that you send

00:33:30,870 --> 00:33:34,770
when we tell it that,
we can say oh, if you wanna get

00:33:39,300 --> 00:33:41,800
And we normally tell it
based on an IP address, so

00:33:41,800 --> 00:33:44,160
we give it the IP address of router 2.

628
00:33:44,160 --> 00:33:47,470
On router 2 we do the opposite.

629
00:33:47,470 --> 00:33:52,831
We say, hey if you wanna get to
172.19.1.0/24 you can do it via router 1,

00:33:52,831 --> 00:33:53,790
all right.

631
00:33:53,790 --> 00:33:55,710
Now that's got our return trip or

00:33:55,710 --> 00:33:59,130
you can consider it the forward
trip if it was PC2 pinging to PC1.

00:34:00,130 --> 00:34:03,580
That's going to allow us

00:34:06,260 --> 00:34:10,950
Once a PC1 tries to ping PC2,

00:34:10,950 --> 00:34:14,340
pinging all the way across

00:34:14,340 --> 00:34:19,680

00:34:19,680 --> 00:34:24,760

00:34:24,760 --> 00:34:29,030
I need to go through my default gateway,
router 1.

00:34:29,030 --> 00:34:32,019
Router 1's gonna look in
its routing table and say,

00:34:37,710 --> 00:34:41,080

I'm directly connected to that network.

00:34:46,350 --> 00:34:48,050
It's one of my built in interfaces.

00:34:48,050 --> 00:34:52,300
So I can send you and

then when PC2 goes to respond,

00:34:55,940 --> 00:34:59,121
PC2 is responding to 172.19.1,

00:34:59,121 --> 00:35:04,900
it knows it's gotta go through its default
gateway, router 2 does an lookup and

00:35:04,900 --> 00:35:10,840
says I can get to 172.19 cuz it's in
my routing table sends us to routing 1.

00:35:10,840 --> 00:35:16,520
Router 1 has that one built in and
so it's able to forward it on along.

653
00:35:18,470 --> 00:35:21,270
>> On both sides we have to
ensure we have the routes

00:35:21,270 --> 00:35:22,846
to the destinations that we want to do.

00:35:22,846 --> 00:35:27,790
Now the static run is actually

00:35:27,790 --> 00:35:32,780
Because it actually puts the entry

00:35:32,780 --> 00:35:36,060

else except for a few common entries.

>> Yeah.
>> But, once we start getting larger,

it's getting more complex now.

00:35:42,470 --> 00:35:44,450

00:35:56,820 --> 00:36:02,690

00:36:02,690 --> 00:36:06,800
That word, converged, Cisco loves it,
I would be surprised if you went

669
00:36:06,800 --> 00:36:09,670

didn't see that word at least once.

670
00:36:09,670 --> 00:36:13,520
A converge network is just where all
the routers know the same stuff,

671
00:36:13,520 --> 00:36:14,800
they all know the same routes.

00:36:14,800 --> 00:36:17,710

networks listed on router 2.

675
00:36:25,230 --> 00:36:27,810
That is a converged network.

676
00:36:27,810 --> 00:36:31,880
When you add a new network and start
populating your systems, your network is

677
00:36:31,880 --> 00:36:35,840
not converged and your routers
are said to be undergoing convergence.

678
00:36:35,840 --> 00:36:38,300
Which is you bringing
everything back in line.

679
00:36:38,300 --> 00:36:41,020
It's a funny term, Cisco loves it.

680
00:36:41,020 --> 00:36:44,980
And so it is one you'll see

681
00:36:44,980 --> 00:36:51,220
But basically it's a pretty simple concept
and it makes sense, it's like if you

00:36:51,220 --> 00:36:56,390

as the map data that you've downloaded.

683
00:36:56,390 --> 00:37:00,220
If it doesn't know about a road it's
not gonna suggest that you take it.

684
00:37:00,220 --> 00:37:01,370

685
00:37:01,370 --> 00:37:02,850
They've got to know about the road.

00:37:02,850 --> 00:37:05,760

00:37:05,760 --> 00:37:07,120

well designed network That

So, our manual in the process is like

00:38:01,290 --> 00:38:03,610

00:38:03,610 --> 00:38:06,350
Dynamic entries are really cool

00:38:06,350 --> 00:38:08,610
When the routers come up,

00:38:08,610 --> 00:38:11,390

00:38:11,390 --> 00:38:16,328

00:38:16,328 --> 00:38:20,880
And they chitchat back and forth and just
kind of determine what each other knows.

00:38:20,880 --> 00:38:24,080
They do an exchange of ideas,
and once they're all in sync and

00:38:24,080 --> 00:38:26,640
in line, then off they go and
they're happy.

00:38:26,640 --> 00:38:27,220

The nice thing about the dynam routes,

I, pretty much all we have to do is

They will do,

00:38:36,150 --> 00:38:40,460

line, right from one router to another.

00:46:10,240 --> 00:46:12,809
