00:57:07,890 --> 00:57:12,807
>> So,
if I ping 209.251.133.1 it's successful.

1080
00:57:12,807 --> 00:57:13,677
>> Yeah.

1081
00:57:13,677 --> 00:57:15,930
>> Now, why is that?

1082
00:57:15,930 --> 00:57:20,004
Because remember, in the picture
I said hey we really need to have

1083
00:57:20,004 --> 00:57:24,030
two-way routing, right, why did this work?

1084
00:57:24,030 --> 00:57:28,050
Well, the reason it worked is the way
that pings work from a router.

1085
00:57:28,050 --> 00:57:31,940
When you do a ping, a router has
more than one interface, right?

1086
00:57:31,940 --> 00:57:37,635
So, it has to pick a source IP, and the
source could be any of your interfaces.

1087
00:57:37,635 --> 00:57:40,012
It tries to pick the one
closest to your network.

1088
00:57:40,012 --> 00:57:40,628
>> Yep.

1089
00:57:40,628 --> 00:57:45,051
>> So, when it looked at router one and
it said I'm about to ping router2,

1090
00:57:45,051 --> 00:57:47,891
the closes interface was
this one right here.

1091
00:57:47,891 --> 00:57:53,347
So the ping was sourced from 51.17.33.221.

1092
00:57:53,347 --> 00:57:57,176
Router2 has a route for that network.

1093
00:57:57,176 --> 00:57:59,137
It doesn't have a route for 172.19.

1094
00:57:59,137 --> 00:58:03,099
So, if that ping was sources from that IP,
it wouldn't have worked.

1095
00:58:03,099 --> 00:58:07,126
>> Now Don, if I don't have an actual
computer plugged up to that,

1096
00:58:07,126 --> 00:58:09,225
is there a way I can test that out.

1097
00:58:09,225 --> 00:58:10,850
>> Yeah, absolutely.

1098
00:58:10,850 --> 00:58:14,500
So on a windows machine, you don't
have any control over your source.

1099
00:58:14,500 --> 00:58:15,900
See you just do a ping and that's it.

1100
00:58:15,900 --> 00:58:19,790
And even like a Linux machine is
like that, but on a Cisco router,

1101
00:58:19,790 --> 00:58:22,770
you can manipulate the source
of your ping, all right?

1102
00:58:22,770 --> 00:58:26,130
And the way you do it is
by repeating that ping, but

1103
00:58:26,130 --> 00:58:31,110
then you can continue on and you'll see
I've got the option there for source.

1104
00:58:31,110 --> 00:58:35,120
And that's where I can tell it,
where to get the source address?

1105
00:58:35,120 --> 00:58:39,400
And I'm gonna tell it to use
the source of my gigabit,

1106
00:58:39,400 --> 00:58:41,550
actually I think it makes
me type it all the way out.

1107
00:58:41,550 --> 00:58:46,500
I'm gonna do the source based on gigabit
0/0 and I've got this thing in the back of

1108
00:58:46,500 --> 00:58:48,230
my mind that tells me I'm supposed
to type it all the way out, but

1109
00:58:48,230 --> 00:58:50,220
let's see if it'll does it works.

1110
00:58:50,220 --> 00:58:51,850
All right, it works with the abbreviation.

1111
00:58:51,850 --> 00:58:54,860
They're some commands where it
won't take the abbreviation, and

1112
00:58:54,860 --> 00:58:56,770
I thought this was one but it's not.

1113
00:58:56,770 --> 00:59:02,450
So I'm trying to ping now, and notice how
it says, packet sent with a source address

1114
00:59:02,450 --> 00:59:08,230
of 172.19.1.1, that's my address for
this interface right here.

1115
00:59:08,230 --> 00:59:12,560
And when I source it that way,
I'm not able to get through.

1116
00:59:12,560 --> 00:59:19,810
And that's because router 2 has no route
for 172.19.1, I need to give it one.

1117
00:59:19,810 --> 00:59:22,207
>> Right.

1118
00:59:22,207 --> 00:59:24,509
>> All right, so let's go fix that.

1119
00:59:24,509 --> 00:59:27,472
I'm on a console cable,
I guess I could remote.

1120
00:59:27,472 --> 00:59:28,474
I'll just move the console cable.

1121
00:59:28,474 --> 00:59:33,218
We'll try not to get too complex here.

1122
00:59:33,218 --> 00:59:34,650
There we go.

1123
00:59:34,650 --> 00:59:36,754
So now, here I am on router2, and

1124
00:59:36,754 --> 00:59:40,467
if I do a show IP route I can see
the routes that it knows about.

1125
00:59:40,467 --> 00:59:46,958
It knows about the 51.17.33, and
it knows about the 209.251.133,

1126
00:59:46,958 --> 00:59:50,341
it does not know about the 172.19.1.

1127
00:59:50,341 --> 00:59:55,457
>> Right.
>> So I'll just add a route in for

1128
00:59:55,457 --> 01:00:00,303
that 172.19.1.0.

1129
01:00:00,303 --> 01:00:03,679
I tell it the network that
I'm gonna inform it about,

1130
01:00:03,679 --> 01:00:07,292
the subnet mask and
now I need to tell it the destination.

1131
01:00:07,292 --> 01:00:15,470
And let's see, it is 51.17.33.221.

1132
01:00:15,470 --> 01:00:19,029
That's the interface on route1
that I know I can connect to.

1133
01:00:19,029 --> 01:00:24,080
So I'm gonna give it that route and
when I look at my routing table

1134
01:00:24,080 --> 01:00:29,804
I can look in there and
sure enough I see 172.19.1.0 is there.

1135
01:00:29,804 --> 01:00:34,974
So I see it, I could test it out.

1136
01:00:34,974 --> 01:00:36,464
So, I'll just test that out.

1137
01:00:36,464 --> 01:00:40,100
Successes, right, so
I'm getting to it that's a good sign.

1138
01:00:40,100 --> 01:00:42,142
And I can jump back over to router one.

1139
01:00:48,217 --> 01:00:52,053
And remember the ping over
here on router1 that failed?

1140
01:00:52,053 --> 01:00:54,430
Now, I can try it again.

1141
01:00:54,430 --> 01:00:54,934
>> And there you go.

1142
01:00:54,934 --> 01:00:56,261
>> This time we get successes.

1143
01:00:56,261 --> 01:00:57,350
>> Right.
All right?

1144
01:00:57,350 --> 01:01:01,953
So, reaching out from one system
to another works out great, and

1145
01:01:01,953 --> 01:01:03,720
now we're in business.

1146
01:01:03,720 --> 01:01:07,960
What we needed was a converged network,
we had to teach the routers about it,

1147
01:01:07,960 --> 01:01:10,890
now Ronnie you said it earlier,
with two routers?

1148
01:01:10,890 --> 01:01:14,120
Not a big deal, with a thousand routers?

1149
01:01:14,120 --> 01:01:14,730
Bit of a problem.

1150
01:01:15,830 --> 01:01:19,610
Now on the CCENT exam,
you really are dealing with just one or

1151
01:01:19,610 --> 01:01:22,600
two routers,
even in the simulations on the exam

1152
01:01:22,600 --> 01:01:25,180
you'll never really have more
than like three routers.

1153
01:01:25,180 --> 01:01:32,570
So, it's not a big thing using static
routes like this perfectly fine,

1154
01:01:32,570 --> 01:01:35,692
but in real life land we're really
gona want this to be automatic.

1155
01:01:35,692 --> 01:01:38,450
We're gonna want the routers to
talk to each other to learn, so

1156
01:01:38,450 --> 01:01:41,280
that we don't have to do crazy amounts of
maintenance to keep all this in place.

1157
01:01:42,990 --> 01:01:45,638
>> Now, when we talk about crazy amounts
of information you might now think

1158
01:01:45,638 --> 01:01:47,949
>> That changing one route would

1159
01:01:47,949 --> 01:01:48,970
affect you.

1160
01:01:48,970 --> 01:01:52,515
On a 1000 routers, if all 1000
routers have to get to that one.

1161
01:01:52,515 --> 01:01:54,679
It may affect you, more than you realize.

1162
01:01:54,679 --> 01:01:56,006
So be careful.

1163
01:01:56,006 --> 01:01:58,556
>> I work for
a bank out in Seattle Washington.

1164
01:01:58,556 --> 01:02:03,056
And we had 90 bank branches
spread across four states.

1165
01:02:03,056 --> 01:02:05,890
And each branch had four networks.

1166
01:02:05,890 --> 01:02:11,722
So, four routes at each branch
times 90 branches is, what is that?

1167
01:02:11,722 --> 01:02:12,511
>> 360.

1168
01:02:12,511 --> 01:02:14,004
>> 360 routes right.

1169
01:02:14,004 --> 01:02:16,178
So 360 routes at each branch.

1170
01:02:16,178 --> 01:02:22,304
Stack on top of that that each branch
had a dsl line and a t1, a point t1.

1171
01:02:22,304 --> 01:02:26,544
So, you had two routes to each to
get to these four networks, so

1172
01:02:26,544 --> 01:02:28,920
you really had 720 routes.

1173
01:02:28,920 --> 01:02:31,480
That's a lot of routes and

1174
01:02:31,480 --> 01:02:36,350
if those were all static,
boy you'd be entering in a ton of routes.

1175
01:02:36,350 --> 01:02:40,690
So you try and find anything, that you
can to make the process more streamlined,

1176
01:02:40,690 --> 01:02:41,880
more efficient.

1177
01:02:41,880 --> 01:02:44,560
If you could summarize routes you do it.

1178
01:02:44,560 --> 01:02:46,730
If you can use dynamic routing protocols,
you do it.

1179
01:02:46,730 --> 01:02:51,010
Whatever you can to make that traffic,
easier to maintain,

1180
01:02:51,010 --> 01:02:53,310
easier to support, and
more stable for the end user.

1181
01:02:55,580 --> 01:02:57,150
>> Right.
>> All right, well Ronnie,

1182
01:02:57,150 --> 01:03:00,620
I'm somewhat tapped out on knowledge for
static routes.

1183
01:03:00,620 --> 01:03:05,470
The logical next step is to jump
into dynamic routes, and the CCNT,

1184
01:03:05,470 --> 01:03:10,050
if any of you guys study the older
materials before Cisco updated this year.

1185
01:03:10,050 --> 01:03:12,470
In the older materials,
this is where we would jump into RIP,

1186
01:03:12,470 --> 01:03:14,380
the routing information protocol.

1187
01:03:14,380 --> 01:03:19,770
They bumped that off the exam and replaced
it with OSPF, which is a great protocol,

1188
01:03:19,770 --> 01:03:22,412
it's the most popular
dynamic routing protocol.

1189
01:03:22,412 --> 01:03:23,920
It's gonna take a lot more time,

1190
01:03:23,920 --> 01:03:26,240
than we have on this show to
be able to dive into that.

1191
01:03:26,240 --> 01:03:30,010
So, this is a pretty good spot
to wrap up for us for the day.

1192
01:03:30,010 --> 01:03:33,490
And what we'll do is,
in our next episode, which,

1193
01:03:33,490 --> 01:03:34,830
when's our next Cisco episode, Ronnie?

1194
01:03:34,830 --> 01:03:35,730
Is it Friday?

1195
01:03:35,730 --> 01:03:36,640
>> It was Monday.

1196
01:03:36,640 --> 01:03:37,335
>> Monday, okay.

1197
01:03:37,335 --> 01:03:40,400
>> Yeah.
>> So tune back in on Monday, and

1198
01:03:40,400 --> 01:03:44,160
we're gonna dive into the wonderful world
of OSPF, and get to see dynamic routing,

1199
01:03:44,160 --> 01:03:45,620
which is awesome.

1200
01:03:45,620 --> 01:03:46,840
It's a lot of fun.

1201
01:03:46,840 --> 01:03:50,190
And you'll get a chance to see complex
networks, and how they can become so

1202
01:03:50,190 --> 01:03:53,780
much more easy for us, when they're
configured with a dynamic protocol.

1203
01:03:53,780 --> 01:03:54,880
>> Sounds good.

1204
01:03:54,880 --> 01:03:59,070
>> All right, well [COUGH] as always,
we hope you enjoyed the show.

1205
01:03:59,070 --> 01:04:02,750
Keep in mind if you have any questions,
anything we didn't answer on the show,

1206
01:04:02,750 --> 01:04:06,200
make sure you jump on over
to our website at itpro.tv.

1207
01:04:06,200 --> 01:04:08,560
And jump into that Q&A session,
post your questions.

1208
01:04:08,560 --> 01:04:10,730
>> Yep.
>> We monitor it and reply back, and

1209
01:04:10,730 --> 01:04:12,490
help you out as much as we can.

1210
01:04:12,490 --> 01:04:14,680
Also, make sure that, during the show,

1211
01:04:14,680 --> 01:04:17,620
if you have a question,
catch that live chat, right?

1212
01:04:17,620 --> 01:04:18,400
>> That's right.

1213
01:04:18,400 --> 01:04:22,196
>> If you're watching the show live
right now, it's itpro.tv/live,

1214
01:04:22,196 --> 01:04:23,597
will take you right to us.

1215
01:04:23,597 --> 01:04:24,477
You've got your video.

1216
01:04:24,477 --> 01:04:26,932
And if you're logged in,
the chat is right beneath it.

1217
01:04:26,932 --> 01:04:28,337
>> Right.
>> And you can post your stuff.

1218
01:04:28,337 --> 01:04:29,756
We've got our little chat screen here.

1219
01:04:29,756 --> 01:04:30,730
>> Mm-hm.
>> So we see it, and

1220
01:04:30,730 --> 01:04:32,850
we answer questions live on the show.

1221
01:04:32,850 --> 01:04:33,557
>> Right.

1222
01:04:33,557 --> 01:04:37,139
>> So definitely take advantage of
those resources and, like I said.

1223
01:04:37,139 --> 01:04:37,643
>> Yeah.

1224
01:04:37,643 --> 01:04:38,635
>> The shows are always going on.

1225
01:04:38,635 --> 01:04:42,018
We've got more shows tomorrow, but
the next Cisco show is Monday.

1226
01:04:42,018 --> 01:04:44,933
So, if that's the track that you're on,
definitely tune in on Monday.

1227
01:04:44,933 --> 01:04:47,760
>> Right.
>> And we will see you guys then.

1228
01:04:47,760 --> 01:04:48,843
You got anything else for us Ronnie?

1229
01:04:48,843 --> 01:04:50,099
>> No, I'm trying to cover all the bases.

1230
01:04:50,099 --> 01:04:53,092
>> I think we got it,
alright signing out for ITProTV.

1231
01:04:53,092 --> 01:04:54,342
I am Don Pozet.

1232
01:04:54,342 --> 01:04:55,469
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1233
01:04:55,469 --> 01:04:56,719
And, we'll see you next time around.

1234
01:04:56,719 --> 01:05:00,929
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: There are different categorizations for routing protocols that have different internal priority over each other and different ways that they function. Viewers will hear about the variations between distance vector protocols and link state protocols, as well as hear how Cisco routers use administrative distance to select the route.
episodes.title: Intro to Routing Protocols
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,378 --> 00:00:22,628
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,628 --> 00:00:33,253
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,253 --> 00:00:35,588
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening..

5
00:00:35,588 --> 00:00:37,703
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV,

6
00:00:37,703 --> 00:00:40,501
coming at you live from
beautiful Gainesville, Florida.

7
00:00:40,501 --> 00:00:45,540
I am your host, Don Pezet,
accompanied by, well nobody.

8
00:00:45,540 --> 00:00:50,380
We're doing a short episode today,
in the last Cisco episode,

9
00:00:50,380 --> 00:00:53,070
we started to cover things like Routing.

10
00:00:53,070 --> 00:00:56,450
We show the routing process and so on.

11
00:00:56,450 --> 00:01:00,960
The next episode is supposed to
be us diving right into OSPF,

12
00:01:00,960 --> 00:01:02,920
Open Shortest Path First, or whatever.

13
00:01:02,920 --> 00:01:04,730
I shouldn't say whatever,

14
00:01:04,730 --> 00:01:08,330
it's the most popular interior
routing protocol in the world.

15
00:01:08,330 --> 00:01:12,810
But before we did that show I realized
just kind of looking through my notes

16
00:01:12,810 --> 00:01:15,610
there were a couple of things
we really needed to talk about

17
00:01:16,610 --> 00:01:18,940
before we dived right into
a dynamic routing protocol.

18
00:01:18,940 --> 00:01:20,620
A couple of things kind of went unsaid.

19
00:01:20,620 --> 00:01:22,300
So I wanted to film a special, right?

20
00:01:22,300 --> 00:01:27,620
This is a one hour special season premier
ending whatever I don't know or something.

21
00:01:27,620 --> 00:01:30,600
And like the little little
claps in the background.

22
00:01:30,600 --> 00:01:34,760
But just a little special to be
able to cover some of those topics

23
00:01:34,760 --> 00:01:36,140
that are important.

24
00:01:36,140 --> 00:01:39,800
Just to help us understand exactly
how these routing protocols work.

25
00:01:39,800 --> 00:01:40,470
All right.

26
00:01:40,470 --> 00:01:44,550
So in the last episode, we really
only saw one way to route things.

27
00:01:44,550 --> 00:01:46,630
And that was with Static route, all right?

28
00:01:47,730 --> 00:01:51,610
I fired up a router our trusty
2800 in the background here and

29
00:01:51,610 --> 00:01:53,850
I manually put a route in place.

30
00:01:53,850 --> 00:01:56,020
So lets, lets review that real quick and

31
00:01:56,020 --> 00:01:58,000
then we'll kind of talk
about the alternative.

32
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:01,770
So actually here,
I'll just pull up that router again,

33
00:02:01,770 --> 00:02:06,140
which a smarter me would have
done before the show went live.

34
00:02:06,140 --> 00:02:07,050
But I'll pull it up now,

35
00:02:07,050 --> 00:02:10,508
see if I can guess mine,
I'll play guess the com port number.

36
00:02:10,508 --> 00:02:15,506
And we have a winner,

37
00:02:15,506 --> 00:02:18,950
all right.

38
00:02:18,950 --> 00:02:22,710
When a router boots up,
it looks at its interfaces and it says,

39
00:02:22,710 --> 00:02:27,335
"Okay, I've a couple of interfaces." and
as long as those interfaces are up

40
00:02:27,335 --> 00:02:32,095
it adds their routes to the routing table
and that's what we saw last episode.

41
00:02:32,095 --> 00:02:34,100
So if I use a command,

42
00:02:34,100 --> 00:02:36,976
this is really of all the Cisco
commands this is my most favorite.

43
00:02:36,976 --> 00:02:42,980
Show IP interface brief.

44
00:02:42,980 --> 00:02:46,710
I use this command anytime I sit
down on a new piece of equipment or

45
00:02:46,710 --> 00:02:48,700
a piece of equipment I
haven't worked with recently.

46
00:02:48,700 --> 00:02:52,050
Because it gives me the summary
of all the interfaces.

47
00:02:52,050 --> 00:02:56,540
It tells me their IP addresses if they
have one and it tells me if they're up or

48
00:02:56,540 --> 00:02:58,940
down, so it's real useful stuff and

49
00:02:58,940 --> 00:03:01,610
every time I sit down at equipment it's
one of the first commands that I run.

50
00:03:01,610 --> 00:03:03,960
Show IP interface brief.

51
00:03:03,960 --> 00:03:07,680
And when I run that,
I can see this router has four interfaces,

52
00:03:07,680 --> 00:03:14,268
two of which are down so I'm going to
ignore those, but two of which are up.

53
00:03:14,268 --> 00:03:19,680
One is 172.19.1.1 and
the other is 51.17.33.221, all right.

54
00:03:19,680 --> 00:03:25,350
When I fire up my router,
it sees these two interfaces,

55
00:03:25,350 --> 00:03:28,870
and those two interfaces
are directly connected.

56
00:03:28,870 --> 00:03:32,100
And so routes get added to the routing
tables directly connected.

57
00:03:32,100 --> 00:03:33,420
We saw that in the last episode.

58
00:03:34,550 --> 00:03:38,190
To see the routing table,
we can do show IP route.

59
00:03:38,190 --> 00:03:41,960
And if you run it just like that,
it shows you the whole routing table.

60
00:03:41,960 --> 00:03:45,860
But you can actually add on to that
command to filter what you're seeing.

61
00:03:45,860 --> 00:03:48,940
And so, I'm going to add on
to it the word connected.

62
00:03:48,940 --> 00:03:50,788
Show IP route connected.

63
00:03:50,788 --> 00:03:55,870
That's going to give me my routing table
and just show the directly related routes.

64
00:03:55,870 --> 00:03:59,350
So, I can see these two routes
they're directly connected,

65
00:03:59,350 --> 00:04:02,280
they're part of the routing table,
I didn't have to enter those in.

66
00:04:02,280 --> 00:04:03,540
That happens automatically.

67
00:04:05,040 --> 00:04:10,280
The routing that we showed you
last episode was this as well as

68
00:04:10,280 --> 00:04:15,400
a static route, and a static route is
where we teach the router a route.

69
00:04:15,400 --> 00:04:17,940
We tell it how to get somewhere, right?

70
00:04:17,940 --> 00:04:21,380
And I use the IP route command to do that.

71
00:04:21,380 --> 00:04:23,340
And so if I do a show IP route,

72
00:04:23,340 --> 00:04:29,060
I can see that static route right there
that we put in in the last episode.

73
00:04:29,060 --> 00:04:29,680
All right?

74
00:04:29,680 --> 00:04:34,280
And if I do a show run and I filter it.

75
00:04:34,280 --> 00:04:35,210
For the IP route command.

76
00:04:35,210 --> 00:04:36,650
I can find a command we used.

77
00:04:36,650 --> 00:04:37,750
Here it is.

78
00:04:37,750 --> 00:04:40,390
So here's that command we
used to put that route in.

79
00:04:40,390 --> 00:04:44,780
We said IP route and then the network and

80
00:04:44,780 --> 00:04:48,000
the subnet mask for the network
that we're teaching the router.

81
00:04:48,000 --> 00:04:48,900
And then how to get there.

82
00:04:48,900 --> 00:04:53,340
Here's the destination IP or
how to get to that network.

83
00:04:53,340 --> 00:04:54,590
Right here.

84
00:04:54,590 --> 00:04:56,790
Okay, so pretty simple command.

85
00:04:56,790 --> 00:05:00,950
But the comment we left you guys hanging
with at the end of the episode was how

86
00:05:00,950 --> 00:05:06,260
while this works, if you've got one or
five devices its a great solution.

87
00:05:06,260 --> 00:05:09,580
But what if you have 100 or
1000 routers, right?

88
00:05:09,580 --> 00:05:13,540
Having to go and enter in static
routes in all 1000 routers,

89
00:05:13,540 --> 00:05:14,476
that's going to take a lot of time.

90
00:05:14,476 --> 00:05:17,440
So,static routes like
this,while they're viable,

91
00:05:17,440 --> 00:05:20,170
while they do work, they're not ideal.

92
00:05:20,170 --> 00:05:22,290
So, we need some kind
of other solution and

93
00:05:22,290 --> 00:05:26,425
that's where dynamic routing
protocols like OSPF come in.

94
00:05:26,425 --> 00:05:29,810
CIsco doesn't change this to the exam,
so the exam for

95
00:05:29,810 --> 00:05:34,030
the CCENT is now the 100-101 exam.

96
00:05:34,030 --> 00:05:38,690
It used to be that was 640-801 or
whatever the old number was.

97
00:05:38,690 --> 00:05:40,010
But now it's 100-101 and

98
00:05:40,010 --> 00:05:44,350
when they did that they started
moving around some of the topics.

99
00:05:44,350 --> 00:05:47,120
Some topics got moved to the second
exam versus the first one.

100
00:05:48,470 --> 00:05:52,010
They really put a lot less emphasis on

101
00:05:52,010 --> 00:05:57,720
multiple routing protocols instead
of focusing primarily on OSPF alone.

102
00:05:57,720 --> 00:06:02,710
Now, that's fine for the CCENT,
OSPF is the protocol that you're going to

103
00:06:02,710 --> 00:06:05,820
encounter in the real world the most
often, so it kind of works out.

104
00:06:05,820 --> 00:06:09,100
But I want a little more generally for a
moment, just to make sure that everybody,

105
00:06:09,100 --> 00:06:13,480
all you guys out there in TV land
have a good understanding of exactly

106
00:06:13,480 --> 00:06:17,470
what these protocols are and
what's the variation between them.

107
00:06:17,470 --> 00:06:22,230
Now when we do a static, we are teaching
the router how to get there.

108
00:06:22,230 --> 00:06:24,460
And we're doing it by hand,
so it's not ideal.

109
00:06:24,460 --> 00:06:28,650
You never want to have to go in and
teach a computer how to do things.

110
00:06:28,650 --> 00:06:33,210
Wouldn't it be better if instead, the
routers could just learn from each other.

111
00:06:33,210 --> 00:06:35,220
If I have two routers come up,

112
00:06:35,220 --> 00:06:39,240
that they could talk to each other,
learn the routes that they have.

113
00:06:39,240 --> 00:06:42,600
And make it where I don't have
to manually put them in there.

114
00:06:42,600 --> 00:06:45,350
That's what a dynamic
routing protocol does.

115
00:06:45,350 --> 00:06:49,760
A static protocol is where we
tell the router how to get there.

116
00:06:49,760 --> 00:06:54,470
A dynamic protocol is where
the routers learn from each other.

117
00:06:54,470 --> 00:06:57,370
The cool thing about a dynamic protocol,

118
00:06:57,370 --> 00:07:00,130
not only are they learning
the routes from each other,

119
00:07:00,130 --> 00:07:04,890
if they learn more than one route to
the same place the dynamic routing

120
00:07:04,890 --> 00:07:09,470
protocols will actually make a decision
over which route is better than the other.

121
00:07:09,470 --> 00:07:11,400
They'll figure it out for us and

122
00:07:11,400 --> 00:07:14,690
that's where the real value of
a dynamic routing protocol comes in.

123
00:07:14,690 --> 00:07:17,060
Is it,
they make some real intelligent decisions.

124
00:07:17,060 --> 00:07:18,480
Very, very cool stuff.

125
00:07:18,480 --> 00:07:21,900
So that's what I want to talk about, I
want to take a look at some of those, and

126
00:07:21,900 --> 00:07:24,290
make sure that we've got a good
understanding of all that.

127
00:07:25,680 --> 00:07:30,900
All right, so let's take a look here, I've
got a little drawing that I brought up.

128
00:07:30,900 --> 00:07:32,250
This guy right here.

129
00:07:32,250 --> 00:07:32,750
All right.

130
00:07:34,190 --> 00:07:39,240
I've got two networks the 192.168.0
network over here on the left,

131
00:07:39,240 --> 00:07:41,900
and the 172.16 over here on the right.

132
00:07:41,900 --> 00:07:43,930
And they're connected to
some various routers, right?

133
00:07:43,930 --> 00:07:49,950
Router 1, directly plugged into 192 2168
Router two directly plugged into 172.16.

134
00:07:49,950 --> 00:07:52,830
Router 3 not directly
plugged into any of those.

135
00:07:52,830 --> 00:07:53,552
Right?

136
00:07:53,552 --> 00:07:55,764
So, when these routers fire up,

137
00:07:55,764 --> 00:07:59,404
router 1 already knows about
this network over here.

138
00:07:59,404 --> 00:08:02,352
Router two already knows
about this network over here.

139
00:08:02,352 --> 00:08:07,899
But if I want router two to be able
to get all the way over to 192.168 or

140
00:08:07,899 --> 00:08:12,302
if I want router one to get
all the way over to 172.16,

141
00:08:12,302 --> 00:08:16,330
I'm gonna have to put static routes in for
that.

142
00:08:16,330 --> 00:08:18,700
So, I'm going to have to go and

143
00:08:18,700 --> 00:08:21,570
update my routers to teach
them about these networks.

144
00:08:21,570 --> 00:08:26,430
And with the static,
just to review static one more time, I

145
00:08:28,990 --> 00:08:33,546
would have to take 172.16 and I would
have to manually add it to router 1,

146
00:08:33,546 --> 00:08:34,840
and I would have to manually
add it to router 3.

147
00:08:34,840 --> 00:08:39,540
And then I would need to take 192.168.0,
and

148
00:08:39,540 --> 00:08:44,130
manually add it to router 2 and
manually add it to router 3.

149
00:08:44,130 --> 00:08:47,940
And every time I added another new
network, I would have to go and

150
00:08:47,940 --> 00:08:49,662
manually add it to these routers.

151
00:08:49,662 --> 00:08:53,270
All right, the other thing to think about,
though, is that there is really

152
00:08:53,270 --> 00:08:57,130
is that three is really more than one way
to get between these networks, right?

153
00:08:57,130 --> 00:09:01,290
So, for example, let me, let me just
undo all of my crazy lines there.

154
00:09:01,290 --> 00:09:07,785
For example, if router 2 wants
to get to the 168.1.0 network,

155
00:09:07,785 --> 00:09:13,320
it can go through router 1 and
over to that network.

156
00:09:13,320 --> 00:09:18,410
But it could also go through router
three over to router one and

157
00:09:18,410 --> 00:09:19,240
to that other network.

158
00:09:19,240 --> 00:09:20,460
Right, so it's got two different ways,

159
00:09:20,460 --> 00:09:22,990
two different paths to
get to that destination.

160
00:09:22,990 --> 00:09:27,600
Now you might ask yourself, why would it
ever want to go through router 3, right?

161
00:09:27,600 --> 00:09:29,440
Well, most of the time it
probably wouldn't, right,

162
00:09:29,440 --> 00:09:32,810
it's an extra leg in the journey,
why do that?

163
00:09:32,810 --> 00:09:34,890
But what if there was a failure,

164
00:09:34,890 --> 00:09:38,350
what if something happened
where this link right here,

165
00:09:38,350 --> 00:09:43,540
the link that runs through router 2 to
router 1, what if that link went offline?

166
00:09:43,540 --> 00:09:45,260
What if it failed?

167
00:09:45,260 --> 00:09:47,760
It's nice that router 2 has a backup,
as a backup

168
00:09:47,760 --> 00:09:51,090
plan it can go through router 3 over to
router 1, and on over to that network.

169
00:09:51,090 --> 00:09:53,530
So that's pretty cool.

170
00:09:53,530 --> 00:09:59,240
If we're doing static routes,
I would have to manually go in and

171
00:09:59,240 --> 00:10:03,860
tell it which route to prefer
to get to which destination.

172
00:10:03,860 --> 00:10:05,810
That's where things start to get tricky.

173
00:10:05,810 --> 00:10:09,940
And if we're doing it by hand,
it requires a lot of thought.

174
00:10:09,940 --> 00:10:15,510
By default, In a Cisco router, if we have
two routers to the same destination,

175
00:10:15,510 --> 00:10:17,610
they both go in the routing table.

176
00:10:17,610 --> 00:10:19,250
And they get load balanced across.

177
00:10:19,250 --> 00:10:20,870
We balance across them.

178
00:10:20,870 --> 00:10:24,950
That's not what we want in the event
that one path is better than the other.

179
00:10:24,950 --> 00:10:26,720
So we have something called a metric.

180
00:10:26,720 --> 00:10:33,830
And a metric is a number that identifies
which path we prefer over another one.

181
00:10:33,830 --> 00:10:34,430
Okay?

182
00:10:34,430 --> 00:10:40,270
So for example,
let's take our topology here,

183
00:10:40,270 --> 00:10:45,535
and let me get rid of our failure,
hide our failure.

184
00:10:45,535 --> 00:10:51,250
[LAUGH] So, let me say, say that
the red link, maybe I give that a,

185
00:10:51,250 --> 00:10:58,410
a metric of 10 Like that, all right,

186
00:10:58,410 --> 00:11:04,940
and I take that green link and I give
the green link a metric of 20, all right.

187
00:11:04,940 --> 00:11:09,260
By doing that,
I'm defining the preference,

188
00:11:09,260 --> 00:11:11,810
the link that I prefer over the other one.

189
00:11:11,810 --> 00:11:16,040
I didn't match that green at all,
but anyhow, ten versus 20.

190
00:11:16,040 --> 00:11:18,870
So when router two tries to
figure out which one to use.

191
00:11:18,870 --> 00:11:20,900
It says, okay.
Well, I could go through router one, or

192
00:11:20,900 --> 00:11:22,840
I could go roundabout
through router three.

193
00:11:22,840 --> 00:11:24,260
Which one do I want?

194
00:11:24,260 --> 00:11:27,820
It's gonna pick the one with
the lowest metric number.

195
00:11:27,820 --> 00:11:30,550
Now, remember that for the exam,
'cuz it does get confusing.

196
00:11:30,550 --> 00:11:32,390
The lowest metric number.

197
00:11:32,390 --> 00:11:33,490
The way I remember this.

198
00:11:33,490 --> 00:11:35,260
It's like running a race.

199
00:11:35,260 --> 00:11:40,780
In a race first place is the winner,
100th place is not so good.

200
00:11:40,780 --> 00:11:41,750
That's how metrics are.

201
00:11:41,750 --> 00:11:43,850
Metrics are like running a race.

202
00:11:43,850 --> 00:11:45,420
The lower number is the better.

203
00:11:45,420 --> 00:11:47,415
You want to be number one, all right.

204
00:11:47,415 --> 00:11:50,275
Number one is the winner,
that's the one you want.

205
00:11:50,275 --> 00:11:54,395
If you're number 100, well,
you're probably in last place or far back.

206
00:11:54,395 --> 00:11:57,665
So that's kind of how these metrics work
and router 2 is gonna look at it and

207
00:11:57,665 --> 00:12:01,755
it's gonna say, well tenth place
is better than 20th place so

208
00:12:01,755 --> 00:12:04,995
I'm gonna go through router 1 and
that the way I want it.

209
00:12:04,995 --> 00:12:09,880
But if the link to router one fails,
if it goes offline.

210
00:12:09,880 --> 00:12:14,500
It says, well 20th place is better
than nothing, so I'll go that way and

211
00:12:14,500 --> 00:12:16,380
there's our other path all right.

212
00:12:16,380 --> 00:12:21,160
So if I wanted to create this topology,
now things get a lot more complex okay.

213
00:12:21,160 --> 00:12:24,910
Let's count all the static routes that
we would have to put in to setup this

214
00:12:24,910 --> 00:12:25,880
environment right here.

215
00:12:25,880 --> 00:12:29,950
Let me get rid of all this
extra stuff on my diagram.

216
00:12:34,420 --> 00:12:37,610
There we go.
All right, so, whoops,

217
00:12:37,610 --> 00:12:40,970
if we think about all of the various
static routes, all right.

218
00:12:40,970 --> 00:12:45,000
First off, router 3 is not
directly connected to anybody.

219
00:12:45,000 --> 00:12:45,660
Okay.

220
00:12:45,660 --> 00:12:49,290
So on router three I would
have to add one static route

221
00:12:49,290 --> 00:12:51,480
teaching it how to get to 192.168.

222
00:12:51,480 --> 00:12:56,460
I would have to give it another
static route teaching it the second

223
00:12:56,460 --> 00:12:57,450
path to 192.168.

224
00:12:57,450 --> 00:13:04,210
I would then have to give it a static
route telling it how to get to 172.16,

225
00:13:04,210 --> 00:13:10,028
as well as another static route telling
it the other path to get to 172.16.

226
00:13:10,028 --> 00:13:14,810
I would have to add four static routes
to accommodate the different scenarios

227
00:13:14,810 --> 00:13:15,418
that are right there.

228
00:13:15,418 --> 00:13:17,880
All right.

229
00:13:17,880 --> 00:13:22,710
On router 1, it already knows how
to get to 192.168.0.0, so on it,

230
00:13:22,710 --> 00:13:27,400
I would have to add a static route
of how to get to 172.16, and

231
00:13:27,400 --> 00:13:31,800
a second route to teach it the alternate
path to that same network.

232
00:13:31,800 --> 00:13:33,980
And then on router 2, same basic thing.

233
00:13:33,980 --> 00:13:38,760
I gotta do one route to 192.168,
and another route for

234
00:13:38,760 --> 00:13:43,380
it's alternate path, I'm kinda running
out of room here, to get to it.

235
00:13:43,380 --> 00:13:48,110
So to set up this topology with just
three routers, it would take me,

236
00:13:48,110 --> 00:13:49,550
what is that seven static routes?

237
00:13:49,550 --> 00:13:51,250
Let's see, four, five, six, seven, eight.

238
00:13:51,250 --> 00:13:55,070
Eight static routes [COUGH] to be
able to have a converged network

239
00:13:55,070 --> 00:13:58,240
where everybody knew all the paths
to get to the destination and

240
00:13:58,240 --> 00:14:01,050
that's not even counting the fact

241
00:14:01,050 --> 00:14:03,369
I have to set preferences for these.

242
00:14:03,369 --> 00:14:05,090
Now, let me show you an example of that.

243
00:14:05,090 --> 00:14:07,280
I'm gonna go back into my router.

244
00:14:07,280 --> 00:14:08,110
Let me pull that one up.

245
00:14:10,010 --> 00:14:15,370
Let me just remove this route that
we put in, in the last episode.

00:14:15,370 --> 00:14:17,245
Let me just get that one out of there.

247
00:14:17,245 --> 00:14:18,450
Okay.

248
00:14:18,450 --> 00:14:24,280
When you put in a route, that metric
value is automatically assigned.

249
00:14:24,280 --> 00:14:26,170
In fact,
if I put that route right back in.

250
00:14:26,170 --> 00:14:28,290
I know, I just took it out,

251
00:14:28,290 --> 00:14:35,710
If I put that route back in, and I look

00:14:35,710 --> 00:14:39,540
And there's this number,

00:14:39,540 --> 00:14:40,780
See that 1/0.

00:14:40,780 --> 00:14:46,450
That first number is what's called

00:14:46,450 --> 00:14:49,660
And the second number is your metric.

00:14:49,660 --> 00:14:53,160
With the static route,
the metric is always zero, or

257
00:14:53,160 --> 00:14:55,550
at least by default it's a zero.

258
00:14:55,550 --> 00:14:59,880
The administrative distance of
that first number is a one.

259
00:14:59,880 --> 00:15:03,620
Let me hold off on that administrative
distance, I do want to talk about that,

260
00:15:03,620 --> 00:15:07,010
but let me make my other points here
first and we'll come back to that.

261
00:15:08,510 --> 00:15:12,590
But that metric is just a zero right now,
that's what it's assigned to.

262
00:15:12,590 --> 00:15:14,430
My directly connected routes,

263
00:15:14,430 --> 00:15:17,640
these guys, notice how they don't
have a number at all, all right?

264
00:15:17,640 --> 00:15:20,600
Directly connected routes
have a metric of zero.

265
00:15:20,600 --> 00:15:24,200
Zero, that's the most preferred,
that's the one that they're gonna use.

266
00:15:24,200 --> 00:15:26,470
And that means that they always win.

267
00:15:26,470 --> 00:15:29,670
It's very difficult to override and
directly connect the route because,

268
00:15:29,670 --> 00:15:33,630
how can you have a better route than

269
00:15:33,630 --> 00:15:38,030
But all the other stuff, the static, the
dynamic stuff, that's where we set it up.

270
00:15:38,030 --> 00:15:40,310
We plug into the system,
so that we can override.

271
00:15:41,410 --> 00:15:44,610
Now let me take that route back out.

272
00:15:44,610 --> 00:15:47,840
And I'm gonna add that route again,
but this time,

273
00:15:47,840 --> 00:15:51,080
I'm gonna add one extra

274
00:15:51,080 --> 00:15:53,360
If you do question mark,

275
00:15:53,360 --> 00:15:56,130
Right here, the distance metric for
this route.

276
00:15:56,130 --> 00:15:59,413
I'm gonna stick the number ten on it.

277
00:15:59,413 --> 00:16:05,090
Now, I've got that route and
I've set its metric to a ten.

278
00:16:05,090 --> 00:16:09,211
And if I look at my table,
see how that one became a ten?

279
00:16:09,211 --> 00:16:13,660
It's modified that administrative
distance, the metric in this case for

280
00:16:13,660 --> 00:16:14,444
the static.

281
00:16:14,444 --> 00:16:17,340
It's modified it to become a ten.

282
00:16:17,340 --> 00:16:21,030
By doing this, I can cause it to
prefer one route over another.

283
00:16:21,030 --> 00:16:23,680
Now, it's hard to see it here
cuz I've only got one route.

284
00:16:23,680 --> 00:16:24,770
Let me add another one.

285
00:16:24,770 --> 00:16:25,790
I will add another route,

286
00:16:25,790 --> 00:16:29,080
maybe there's another router on
that network that I can get too.

287
00:16:29,080 --> 00:16:32,780
Maybe I got two routers for redundancy and
so I'll add a second route.

288
00:16:32,780 --> 00:16:35,430
The first one went to
a router that ended at .43.

289
00:16:35,430 --> 00:16:36,370
This one, I'll just add .42, right?

290
00:16:36,370 --> 00:16:41,954
So there will be another router at .42
that I can go through to get there.

291
00:16:41,954 --> 00:16:44,640
All right.

292
00:16:44,640 --> 00:16:46,416
Now when I take a look
at my routing table,

293
00:16:46,416 --> 00:16:50,580
see how I've got two entries now for
that static route?

294
00:16:50,580 --> 00:16:55,448
So I've got one via the router that
ends in .43, and another that ends in

295
00:16:55,448 --> 00:17:00,840
the router that ends in .42, they both
have a metric of ten, so they're a tie.

296
00:17:00,840 --> 00:17:04,920
And when there's a tie, they both
make it in the routing table, and

297
00:17:04,920 --> 00:17:06,720
now the router starts to load balance.

298
00:17:06,720 --> 00:17:11,950
It'll send half my traffic over one line,
and half my traffic over the other line.

299
00:17:11,950 --> 00:17:13,720
Load balancing.

300
00:17:13,720 --> 00:17:14,380
All right.

301
00:17:14,380 --> 00:17:15,930
But if that's not what I want.

302
00:17:15,930 --> 00:17:20,080
If the route through 43
is my preferred route and

303
00:17:20,080 --> 00:17:26,320
the route through 42 is my backup, all I
have to do is take the route through 43.

304
00:17:26,320 --> 00:17:28,860
So I'm just gonna go and find that
command right here that I put in.

305
00:17:28,860 --> 00:17:33,240
And instead of a metric of ten,
I'm gonna lower it to a metric of five.

306
00:17:33,240 --> 00:17:34,580
All right?

307
00:17:34,580 --> 00:17:40,310
By lowering it to five, the second
route has a ten, this one has a five.

308
00:17:40,310 --> 00:17:42,800
The five will be preferred.

309
00:17:42,800 --> 00:17:46,185
And this is the one that will
make it into the routing table.

310
00:17:46,185 --> 00:17:49,831
Okay?
And so, oops, there we go.

311
00:17:49,831 --> 00:17:56,420
So once I do that, if I take a look at
my routing table, what is going on here?

312
00:17:58,010 --> 00:18:00,280
Apparently I've done
something to my screen.

313
00:18:00,280 --> 00:18:03,901
So once it does that,
now I can look at my routing table and

314
00:18:03,901 --> 00:18:07,705
see that there's only one entry,
the entry through five.

315
00:18:07,705 --> 00:18:12,950
Okay?
Now, I did these mapped on an IP address,

316
00:18:12,950 --> 00:18:14,800
so it's hard for
me to show a failure here.

317
00:18:14,800 --> 00:18:16,450
To show what happens during
a failure situation, but

318
00:18:16,450 --> 00:18:19,790
let me show you what happens
with some different routes.

319
00:18:19,790 --> 00:18:25,400
I'll do a route to
a very specific network.

320
00:18:25,400 --> 00:18:27,770
Or you know what, I'll just,
the whole class A.

321
00:18:29,930 --> 00:18:31,430
We'll go crazy on this one.

322
00:18:33,390 --> 00:18:38,160
So I'm going to route the entire 1.0 Class
A, I'm going to route that whole thing,

323
00:18:38,160 --> 00:18:41,710
out my interface gi0/0.

324
00:18:41,710 --> 00:18:42,420
All right.

325
00:18:42,420 --> 00:18:45,120
And I'm gonna give it a metric of five.

326
00:18:45,120 --> 00:18:45,830
All right.

327
00:18:45,830 --> 00:18:50,620
I'm gonna add another route
that says I can get there on my

328
00:18:50,620 --> 00:18:52,760
other interface with a metric of ten.

329
00:18:52,760 --> 00:18:56,840
All right, now,
these aren't valid routes, right.

330
00:18:56,840 --> 00:18:58,310
Cuz I'm just throwing
them out on interface and

331
00:18:58,310 --> 00:18:59,960
it's a multi access interface anyways.

332
00:18:59,960 --> 00:19:00,700
So it's not gonna work.

333
00:19:00,700 --> 00:19:04,920
But I'm doing this just to show
guys a quick example of failure.

334
00:19:04,920 --> 00:19:06,530
I've got two routes.

335
00:19:06,530 --> 00:19:09,420
The route with a metric of
five should be preferred.

336
00:19:09,420 --> 00:19:14,180
So if I do a show IP route, I should just
see the entry with a metric of five.

337
00:19:14,180 --> 00:19:17,400
I mapped it to an interface and so

338
00:19:17,400 --> 00:19:21,480
it's showing us static and the statics
don't show their metric by default.

339
00:19:21,480 --> 00:19:23,480
But see how I've only got the one entry?

340
00:19:23,480 --> 00:19:27,230
I don't have the one through gi0/1.

341
00:19:27,230 --> 00:19:29,820
It's hidden because it has
a less preferred metric, right.

342
00:19:31,090 --> 00:19:36,800
If my gi0/0 interface were
to go offline though.

343
00:19:36,800 --> 00:19:40,660
If I were to shut it down,
that route is no longer valid and

344
00:19:40,660 --> 00:19:43,630
the other route should take over.

345
00:19:43,630 --> 00:19:46,340
And so if I do a show IP route now,

346
00:19:46,340 --> 00:19:51,760
I still have a route to 1.0.0.0 except
it's on the other interface now.

347
00:19:51,760 --> 00:19:52,270
It's on gi0/1.

348
00:19:52,270 --> 00:19:56,370
It just failed over to the other
interface to find another way out there.

349
00:19:56,370 --> 00:19:57,060
Right.

350
00:19:57,060 --> 00:19:59,770
Well that required a lot of thought,
didn't it?

351
00:19:59,770 --> 00:20:02,440
I had to put two routes in,
I had to adjust their metrics.

352
00:20:02,440 --> 00:20:05,870
I had to do a lot of stuff
to get that in place.

353
00:20:05,870 --> 00:20:08,130
With static routes,
that's what you have to do.

354
00:20:08,130 --> 00:20:13,200
It's time consuming, it's a pain, it
really does take a lot of work to do it.

355
00:20:13,200 --> 00:20:16,790
With dynamic routes,
your router would just learn this stuff.

356
00:20:16,790 --> 00:20:21,050
It would learn it, you wouldn't have
to set it up yourself, you would figure

357
00:20:21,050 --> 00:20:24,445
it out and get it added in to the system
and it would all be done automatically and

358
00:20:24,445 --> 00:20:27,240
that's the real power of
a dynamic routing protocol.

359
00:20:27,240 --> 00:20:28,360
Really powerful.

360
00:20:28,360 --> 00:20:33,190
So, in our next episode,
we're gonna teach you OSPF, right?

361
00:20:33,190 --> 00:20:37,390
Open Shortest Path First,
its the most popular routing protocol for

362
00:20:37,390 --> 00:20:41,470
private businesses in the entire world,
and so you're gonna get a chance to see

363
00:20:41,470 --> 00:20:45,090
how to set that up, and how it works and
all the little bells and whistles with it.

364
00:20:45,090 --> 00:20:46,100
All right.

365
00:20:46,100 --> 00:20:49,440
But before we dive into OSPF I

366
00:20:49,440 --> 00:20:52,470
wanted to make sure that everybody had
a good understanding of this, right?

367
00:20:52,470 --> 00:20:57,340
Of the idea of the metrics and
how they work as well as

368
00:20:57,340 --> 00:21:01,388
some of the different types of dynamic
routing protocols that are out there.

369
00:21:01,388 --> 00:21:02,541
All right.

370
00:21:02,541 --> 00:21:06,830
Primarily we need to concern ourselves
with two types of routing protocols.

371
00:21:06,830 --> 00:21:10,880
There's what are called distance
vector routing protocols and

372
00:21:10,880 --> 00:21:13,860
there's link state protocols.

373
00:21:13,860 --> 00:21:18,930
All right, let me go back to my drawing
and we'll highlight some of these.

374
00:21:18,930 --> 00:21:21,590
All right let me, actually let me
get rid of my spaghetti mess here.

375
00:21:23,885 --> 00:21:25,730
Okay, so

376
00:21:25,730 --> 00:21:30,830
the first one I want to talk about is
what's called a Distance Vector Protocol.

377
00:21:30,830 --> 00:21:35,390
A Distance Vector Protocol has all of
our routers talk to each other and

378
00:21:35,390 --> 00:21:36,770
exchange routing information, right?

379
00:21:36,770 --> 00:21:39,980
They exchange routing
information with each other, and

380
00:21:39,980 --> 00:21:45,280
then they make a decision on which way
is the best based on one thing and

381
00:21:45,280 --> 00:21:48,250
one thing alone, and
it's called the hop count.

382
00:21:48,250 --> 00:21:51,120
The hop count is how many routers
we have to pass through on our

383
00:21:51,120 --> 00:21:52,780
way to a destination.

384
00:21:52,780 --> 00:21:55,730
So, for a distance vector,
let me write this up here so

385
00:21:55,730 --> 00:21:57,330
we don't forget what we're talking about.

386
00:21:57,330 --> 00:22:02,240
Distance Vector Protocols,
if I can spell it.

387
00:22:04,850 --> 00:22:05,680
There we go.

388
00:22:05,680 --> 00:22:09,070
Distance Vector Protocols
just care about hop count.

389
00:22:09,070 --> 00:22:11,140
That's their only concern.

390
00:22:11,140 --> 00:22:15,550
So if I'm on a computer, and

391
00:22:15,550 --> 00:22:20,500
I'm over here at 192.168.0 and
I need to get to 172.16.0.

392
00:22:20,500 --> 00:22:22,250
All right?

393
00:22:22,250 --> 00:22:25,650
I'm gonna go to my default gateway,
and my default gateway is router one.

394
00:22:26,670 --> 00:22:28,970
Router one then has to make a choice.

395
00:22:28,970 --> 00:22:33,913
Router one says hey,
I need to get you over to 172.16.

396
00:22:33,913 --> 00:22:36,040
I've got two paths.

397
00:22:36,040 --> 00:22:37,460
Which one do I prefer?

398
00:22:37,460 --> 00:22:41,960
Well a distance vector protocol,
it just looks at hop count.

399
00:22:41,960 --> 00:22:45,160
So it says all right,
well I've got one choice.

400
00:22:45,160 --> 00:22:49,192
One choice is I could go through router
two and then to the destination.

401
00:22:49,192 --> 00:22:50,610
All right?

402
00:22:50,610 --> 00:22:56,220
Router one has to pass through one router,
router two, to get to the destination.

403
00:22:56,220 --> 00:22:57,715
That's one hop.

404
00:22:57,715 --> 00:22:59,980
Right?
So we're hopping from router one,

405
00:23:01,230 --> 00:23:03,530
hop to router two and
then the destination.

406
00:23:03,530 --> 00:23:05,370
That last hop doesn't really count.

407
00:23:05,370 --> 00:23:09,330
So we get one hop between router one and
that destination.

408
00:23:09,330 --> 00:23:11,310
There's also another choice though.

409
00:23:11,310 --> 00:23:14,820
Router one could send us
down to router three and

410
00:23:14,820 --> 00:23:19,090
then over to router two and
then over to the destination.

411
00:23:19,090 --> 00:23:23,380
In this scenario router
one hops to router three.

412
00:23:23,380 --> 00:23:25,950
Hops to router two and
then to the destination.

413
00:23:25,950 --> 00:23:28,260
That's two hops, right.

414
00:23:28,260 --> 00:23:33,010
So the blue path versus the green path,

415
00:23:34,680 --> 00:23:39,250
we've got the green path at two hops.

416
00:23:39,250 --> 00:23:40,930
And the blue path, whoops.

417
00:23:40,930 --> 00:23:42,800
The blue path at one hop, right?

418
00:23:42,800 --> 00:23:46,960
So when we go to make this decision,
it's pretty easy, right?

419
00:23:46,960 --> 00:23:51,135
Basically the distance vector protocol
will look at this, and it'll say well, I

420
00:23:51,135 --> 00:23:55,208
could go on the blue path for one hop, the
green path is twice as long at two hops.

421
00:23:55,208 --> 00:23:56,242
I don't want to go that way.

422
00:23:56,242 --> 00:23:56,786
All right.

423
00:23:56,786 --> 00:23:58,609
So it's going to send us on the blue path.

424
00:23:58,609 --> 00:24:03,457
And so our original PC that's reaching
out It's gonna go, just like that,

425
00:24:03,457 --> 00:24:05,286
and get to our destination.

426
00:24:05,286 --> 00:24:12,850
That is how a distance vector protocol
works, it just looks at hop count.

427
00:24:12,850 --> 00:24:15,130
So, let me add that to the note here.

428
00:24:15,130 --> 00:24:16,900
Distance Vector Protocols.

429
00:24:25,560 --> 00:24:26,730
Rely on Hop Count, right.

430
00:24:26,730 --> 00:24:30,119
Hop count is all they care about,
that's all they want, and

431
00:24:30,119 --> 00:24:33,720
that's what they need to get from
point a to point b, all right.

432
00:24:33,720 --> 00:24:37,760
Now, the way they learn the hop
count is pretty straightforward.

433
00:24:37,760 --> 00:24:43,620
Router 2 is connected to 172.16.00,
so it is zero hops away.

434
00:24:43,620 --> 00:24:45,640
It's right there, it's directly connected.

435
00:24:45,640 --> 00:24:50,180
So, router 2 then tells router 1,
and it tells router 3.

436
00:24:50,180 --> 00:24:52,200
Let me clean up my arrows again.

437
00:24:54,850 --> 00:24:56,620
Let me make some messy stuff, here.

438
00:24:56,620 --> 00:24:59,980
So, router 2 starts to
talk to the other routers.

439
00:24:59,980 --> 00:25:02,800
It's teaching them about the network,
all right.

440
00:25:02,800 --> 00:25:07,908
So, router 2 builds up a routing
announcement, and it says, hey, router 3,

441
00:25:07,908 --> 00:25:12,810
whoops, I'll just move everything
around in this diagram that's my goal.

442
00:25:15,470 --> 00:25:19,473
So, router 2 tells router 3,
it says, hey, router 3,

443
00:25:19,473 --> 00:25:23,970
I know about 172.16.0.0/16,
do you know about it?

444
00:25:23,970 --> 00:25:29,094
And router 3 says, oh, no, I don't know
about it, so let me add that to my routing

445
00:25:29,094 --> 00:25:34,470
table, and it says, okay, well, router 2,
how far away are you from that network?

446
00:25:34,470 --> 00:25:36,020
And router 2 says, far away?

447
00:25:36,020 --> 00:25:38,110
I'm directly connected, I'm zero, baby.

448
00:25:38,110 --> 00:25:39,730
That's the best you can get.

449
00:25:39,730 --> 00:25:43,430
And so router 3 says, wow, that is
awesome, that's a really good connection.

450
00:25:43,430 --> 00:25:46,560
You're zero hops away, so I'm gonna
add that to my routing table, but

451
00:25:46,560 --> 00:25:50,910
I need to go through you,
and you are zero hops away.

452
00:25:50,910 --> 00:25:53,700
If I go through you,
that means I'm one hop away.

453
00:25:53,700 --> 00:25:59,346
So, when router 3 adds 172.16.0.0
to it's routing table,

454
00:25:59,346 --> 00:26:02,220
it adds it as 1 hop away, all right.

455
00:26:02,220 --> 00:26:05,640
Meanwhile router 2 is doing the same
thing with router 1, right.

456
00:26:05,640 --> 00:26:10,010
Router 2 is saying, hey router 1,
do you know about 172.16?

457
00:26:10,010 --> 00:26:11,350
And router 1 is saying, nope.

458
00:26:11,350 --> 00:26:13,350
No, I don't know about it.

459
00:26:13,350 --> 00:26:14,140
I'd love to add it to my routing table.

460
00:26:14,140 --> 00:26:15,680
How far away were you?

461
00:26:15,680 --> 00:26:18,350
And router 2 says,
well I'm 0 hops away man.

462
00:26:18,350 --> 00:26:21,384
I'm right here, and so
router 1 says, great,

463
00:26:21,384 --> 00:26:25,690
that's an awesome connection,
let me add that to my routing table.

464
00:26:25,690 --> 00:26:28,758
And it adds it and it says, well,
I've got to go through router 2, so

465
00:26:28,758 --> 00:26:29,600
I'm one hop away.

466
00:26:29,600 --> 00:26:33,505
Since he's zero hops away, I'm one hop
away, so I'll add it to the routing table,

467
00:26:33,505 --> 00:26:34,060
all right.

468
00:26:34,060 --> 00:26:39,020
So, that's the first step of how
a Distance Vector Protocol works.

469
00:26:39,020 --> 00:26:41,732
And here comes the neat part,

470
00:26:41,732 --> 00:26:47,060
router 3 now knows about 172.16.0.0/16.

471
00:26:47,060 --> 00:26:52,795
And so, it then tells router 1, hey
router 1, I learned about a new network,

472
00:26:52,795 --> 00:26:56,668
I learned about 172.16,
do you know about it?

473
00:26:56,668 --> 00:27:00,810
And router 1 says, well, yeah,
I kinda already know about it.

474
00:27:00,810 --> 00:27:04,030
I've got this route through Router 2,
I kinda like it, but what's yours?

475
00:27:04,030 --> 00:27:08,390
Maybe yours is better, and router 3 says,
oh, yeah, mine's really good.

476
00:27:08,390 --> 00:27:13,210
I'm only one hop away, if you come through
me, I can get you there in one hop.

477
00:27:13,210 --> 00:27:17,960
Well, router one says, all right, you're
one hop away, but if I go through you,

478
00:27:17,960 --> 00:27:21,420
that's one more router, so for
me it would be two hops away.

479
00:27:21,420 --> 00:27:24,230
So, Router 1 says, all right,
you're two hops away.

480
00:27:24,230 --> 00:27:26,490
I've already got a route
directly through Router 2,

481
00:27:26,490 --> 00:27:32,050
it's only one hop away, one hop versus
two hops, let's stick with the one hop.

482
00:27:32,050 --> 00:27:35,140
And so Router 1 says,
thank you, but no thank you.

483
00:27:35,140 --> 00:27:37,190
Keep your route Router 3,
you can stuff it, and

484
00:27:37,190 --> 00:27:41,355
then sticks with its original route,
but it's not forgotten.

485
00:27:42,405 --> 00:27:47,105
With Distance Vector Protocols, they have
a timer, and every so often, it's usually

486
00:27:47,105 --> 00:27:50,845
90 seconds, but every so often the routers
will continue to advertise it.

487
00:27:50,845 --> 00:27:52,155
So, Router 3 will say, hey, remember me?

488
00:27:52,155 --> 00:27:54,325
I still know that route,
do you want it now?

489
00:27:54,325 --> 00:27:56,665
And Router 1 will say,
no, I don't want it.

490
00:27:56,665 --> 00:27:59,225
And then 90 seconds later,
Router 3, hey, what about now?

491
00:27:59,225 --> 00:28:01,065
Very persistent.

492
00:28:01,065 --> 00:28:05,470
The reason it does that,
is if we ever have a failure.

493
00:28:05,470 --> 00:28:10,450
If this link in between Router 1 and
Router 2 fails, then within 90

494
00:28:10,450 --> 00:28:14,400
seconds Router 3 says, Router 1 I
still got this route do you want it?

495
00:28:14,400 --> 00:28:18,690
And Router 1 goes, gee,
I lost my one hop route.

496
00:28:18,690 --> 00:28:20,210
You're offering me a two hop route,

497
00:28:20,210 --> 00:28:23,430
that's better than nothing,
yeah, I'll take it, wonderful.

498
00:28:23,430 --> 00:28:27,810
It takes it, and
now it's able to route around the failure.

499
00:28:27,810 --> 00:28:30,070
CISCO used to have a series
of TV commercials, and

500
00:28:30,070 --> 00:28:34,990
in the TV commercials they advertised
the CISCO, self-healing network.

501
00:28:34,990 --> 00:28:36,480
This is what they were talking about.

502
00:28:36,480 --> 00:28:41,160
When you have a failure on the network,
the router's figure it out themselves, and

503
00:28:41,160 --> 00:28:44,490
if they can find a path around
the failure, they do it.

504
00:28:44,490 --> 00:28:47,910
They build that path around the failure,
and your end users,

505
00:28:47,910 --> 00:28:50,240
your PCs, these guys right here.

506
00:28:50,240 --> 00:28:54,700
They get routed around the failure,
and they have no idea that there was

507
00:28:54,700 --> 00:28:57,210
ever a failure,
it's completely invisible to them.

508
00:28:57,210 --> 00:29:02,170
The end user keeps working, everybody's
happy, it's utopia, sunshine and rainbows,

509
00:29:02,170 --> 00:29:05,400
cats living with dogs,
all sorts of good stuff.

510
00:29:05,400 --> 00:29:10,220
So, that's basically the process when
it comes to a Distance Vector Protocol.

511
00:29:11,440 --> 00:29:12,760
Now, that sounds great.

512
00:29:12,760 --> 00:29:13,520
Real easy.

513
00:29:13,520 --> 00:29:15,610
Real simple concept to understand, but

514
00:29:15,610 --> 00:29:19,080
there's one big problem with
Distance Vector Protocols.

515
00:29:19,080 --> 00:29:23,330
Let me get rid of the spaghetti
mess I've dumped on you here.

516
00:29:25,680 --> 00:29:29,220
Distance Vector Protocols
look at hop count.

517
00:29:29,220 --> 00:29:32,013
Hop count is what they care about, but

518
00:29:32,013 --> 00:29:37,350
there's some information that doesn't
get conveyed with a hop count.

519
00:29:37,350 --> 00:29:39,940
Some information that can be important,
all right.

520
00:29:39,940 --> 00:29:45,288
So for example, what if the link
between Router 1 and Router 3,

521
00:29:45,288 --> 00:29:50,850
let's say, this link between Router 1 and
Router 3 is a T1 line.

522
00:29:56,810 --> 00:30:01,794
Which is 1.544 megabit, and let's say,

523
00:30:01,794 --> 00:30:07,151
that the link between Router 3 and
Router 2 is also

524
00:30:07,151 --> 00:30:12,020
a T1 line, 1.544 megabit, all right.

525
00:30:12,020 --> 00:30:16,890
And let's say, that the link
between Router 1 and Router 2.

526
00:30:21,800 --> 00:30:25,222
Is dial-up, it's a 56K connection
between the two systems, and

527
00:30:25,222 --> 00:30:28,172
with dial-up 53K is really
the maximum that you can get,

528
00:30:28,172 --> 00:30:32,430
but we'll just say, 56k because that's
what the marketing people tell us to say.

529
00:30:32,430 --> 00:30:34,467
So, let's say, it's a dial-up line, or

530
00:30:34,467 --> 00:30:38,880
maybe I should pick something that isn't
ancient, nobody uses dial-up anymore.

531
00:30:38,880 --> 00:30:41,125
Maybe it's like a backup ISDN line,

532
00:30:41,125 --> 00:30:44,564
[LAUGH] which I just misspelled ISDN,
which is pretty amazing.

533
00:30:45,885 --> 00:30:50,255
So, it's a backup ISDN line,
which is 128K, kilobits.

534
00:30:50,255 --> 00:30:56,415
So, now that link between router 1 and
router 2 at 128K,

535
00:30:56,415 --> 00:31:02,635
that is less than 10% of
the bandwidth of a T1 line.

536
00:31:02,635 --> 00:31:11,340
So, if we compare it, even though the path
through oop, that's not what I wanted.

537
00:31:11,340 --> 00:31:16,056
Even though the path through router
3 to router 2 to the destination,

538
00:31:16,056 --> 00:31:20,929
even though that's two hops versus
the path through router 1 straight to

539
00:31:20,929 --> 00:31:24,508
router 2, to the end which is one hop.

540
00:31:24,508 --> 00:31:29,680
One hop versus two hop a Distance Vector
Protocol will prefer that one hop route.

541
00:31:29,680 --> 00:31:34,497
Even though it's less routers,
it's a slower line with less bandwidth,

542
00:31:34,497 --> 00:31:36,110
it's not as good a line.

543
00:31:36,110 --> 00:31:40,010
Your end users will have a faster
connection, if they go the longer route.

544
00:31:40,010 --> 00:31:44,307
If they go that route,
Router 1 to Router 3 to Router 2,

545
00:31:44,307 --> 00:31:46,500
if they go that longer route,

546
00:31:46,500 --> 00:31:52,400
they will get there faster because they
are going over a higher bandwidth line.

547
00:31:52,400 --> 00:31:55,610
A T1 line at 1.544 megabit.

548
00:31:55,610 --> 00:31:57,624
More bandwidth, better connection.

549
00:31:57,624 --> 00:32:00,457
So in this case,
we may prefer the T1 link,

550
00:32:00,457 --> 00:32:04,133
the longer link to the shorter link,
and in that scenario

551
00:32:04,133 --> 00:32:08,514
The Distance Vector Protocols
are gonna make bad decisions for us.

552
00:32:08,514 --> 00:32:10,390
That's a problem.

553
00:32:10,390 --> 00:32:14,160
When Distance Vector Protocols
were created back in the 80s,

554
00:32:14,160 --> 00:32:17,670
every line was slow, so it didn't
really matter, hop count was perfect.

555
00:32:17,670 --> 00:32:21,430
But in today's world,
lines vary significantly, and

556
00:32:21,430 --> 00:32:25,940
so that means we need a more
intelligent protocol.

557
00:32:25,940 --> 00:32:29,040
And the more intelligent protocols
of the Link-State Protocols, but

558
00:32:29,040 --> 00:32:31,940
I see I'm kind of running
out of time on this segment.

00:32:31,940 --> 00:32:33,720
Let's stop here, and take a break.

00:32:33,720 --> 00:32:36,940
When we get back,
we'll take link state protocols, and

00:32:36,940 --> 00:32:38,920
wrap up with a few other fine points.

00:32:38,920 --> 00:32:43,732
And then we will be all geared up and

00:32:57,067 --> 00:33:03,418
[SOUND] All right, ladies and

00:33:03,418 --> 00:33:07,200
So, before the break, I was talking
about Distance Vector Protocols.

568
00:33:07,200 --> 00:33:09,683
And the last thing I did was I
highlighted the problem with

569
00:33:09,683 --> 00:33:10,988
Distance Vector Protocols.

570
00:33:10,988 --> 00:33:13,611
The fact that they prefer hop count, and

571
00:33:13,611 --> 00:33:16,710
that's the only thing
they take into account.

572
00:33:16,710 --> 00:33:21,540
They don't look at things like bandwidth,
or whatever else on the line, and so

573
00:33:21,540 --> 00:33:25,905
you get this connection that
is just not a true reflection,

574
00:33:25,905 --> 00:33:28,710
that this map is not a true
reflection of your network, and

575
00:33:28,710 --> 00:33:30,200
it may not make the most
intelligent decisions.

576
00:33:31,280 --> 00:33:34,700
And that's where our next
solution comes into play.

577
00:33:36,220 --> 00:33:38,771
As a replacement to
Distance Vector Protocols, or

578
00:33:38,771 --> 00:33:41,500
just as an alternative to
Distance Vector Protocols,

579
00:33:41,500 --> 00:33:45,472
we have another choice which is, now I'm
just gonna move that off to the side and

580
00:33:45,472 --> 00:33:48,950
add a new one here, which is what's
called a Link-State Protocol.

581
00:33:52,330 --> 00:33:57,330
A Link-State Protocol, or Link-State
Protocols cuz there are more than one.

582
00:33:57,330 --> 00:34:05,110
These guys use additional metrics, so
that they can make better decisions.

583
00:34:06,630 --> 00:34:10,820
For example, I'll use OSPF cuz that's
the one you need to know for CCNT.

584
00:34:10,820 --> 00:34:15,130
OSPF, Open Shortest Path First,
it uses bandwidth.

585
00:34:15,130 --> 00:34:19,140
It actually uses the bandwidth of
the line, as part of it's calculation.

586
00:34:19,140 --> 00:34:22,070
And so, it says, when I'm trying to
figure out the best way to get from

587
00:34:22,070 --> 00:34:26,650
point a to point b, I don't care about
hop count cuz hops really don't matter.

588
00:34:26,650 --> 00:34:29,420
At the end of the day,
I care about bandwidth.

589
00:34:29,420 --> 00:34:34,260
Let me look at the bandwidth on each leg
of the journey, build out a total path,

590
00:34:34,260 --> 00:34:37,130
and determine whether that's
the way to go or not.

591
00:34:37,130 --> 00:34:42,590
So, Links-State is far,
I don't wanna call it far superior,

592
00:34:42,590 --> 00:34:44,930
but it's far more detail oriented.

593
00:34:44,930 --> 00:34:47,160
It does make a better
decision in most scenarios.

594
00:34:47,160 --> 00:34:48,900
Now, why don't I wanna say, it's better?

595
00:34:48,900 --> 00:34:51,860
If it makes a better decision,
why isn't the protocol better?

596
00:34:51,860 --> 00:34:54,590
And the reason is, in some scenarios,

597
00:34:54,590 --> 00:34:57,950
Distance Vector Protocols may
be preferred to Link-State.

598
00:34:57,950 --> 00:35:02,630
Here's the main reason, Distance Vector
Protocols are really easy to implement.

599
00:35:02,630 --> 00:35:07,670
They're super easy, so
if you're looking for a low-maintenance,

600
00:35:07,670 --> 00:35:11,320
easy way to implement dynamic
routing protocol, a distance vector,

601
00:35:11,320 --> 00:35:14,020
it's really just a matter of
turning it on, and you're done.

602
00:35:14,020 --> 00:35:17,430
A Link-State Protocol, on the other hand,
there are more complex.

603
00:35:17,430 --> 00:35:20,440
There's more to them, there's a little
bit more that we gotta get configured and

604
00:35:20,440 --> 00:35:24,000
set up on them, to get them operating,
and doing their job properly.

605
00:35:24,000 --> 00:35:29,120
So, because of that some people opt to
stick with a Distance Vector Protocol,

606
00:35:29,120 --> 00:35:30,859
even though it may not
make the best decision.

607
00:35:32,190 --> 00:35:35,850
That being said, in real life land, every
organization I've ever worked for, or

608
00:35:35,850 --> 00:35:38,610
set up a network for,
I've always gone on OSPF.

609
00:35:38,610 --> 00:35:43,340
It's an open standard,
almost all network gear supports it, and

610
00:35:43,340 --> 00:35:45,713
it makes really good decisions.

611
00:35:45,713 --> 00:35:48,900
But let's not talk about OSPF specifically
cuz we'll do that in the next episode.

612
00:35:48,900 --> 00:35:52,175
So, let's just talk about
Link-State Protocols in general.

613
00:35:52,175 --> 00:35:58,010
Link-State Protocols look at the actual
links in between our different routers,

614
00:35:58,010 --> 00:36:00,040
and the different networks
that are in place.

615
00:36:00,040 --> 00:36:04,947
So, if we take the connection between
router 1 and router 2 here for example,

616
00:36:04,947 --> 00:36:08,480
it'll look at that, and
it will see it as a 128k line.

617
00:36:08,480 --> 00:36:14,040
And then the link from router 1 to router
3, it sees that as a 1.544 megabit line.

618
00:36:14,040 --> 00:36:19,900
And the link from router 3, to router 2,
it sees that as 1.544 megabit.

619
00:36:19,900 --> 00:36:24,880
So, it's seeing these links, and
it's developing an understanding of

620
00:36:24,880 --> 00:36:28,990
what the bandwidth is,
which line would actually be preferred.

621
00:36:28,990 --> 00:36:34,550
And in the case of the Distance Vector,

622
00:36:34,550 --> 00:36:38,290
we know that the blue path
would have been preferred,

623
00:36:38,290 --> 00:36:42,646
because it was only 1 hop, versus
the green path which would be 2 hops.

624
00:36:42,646 --> 00:36:47,227
But that 2 hop path has an average

625
00:36:47,227 --> 00:36:52,137
bandwidth of 1.544 megabit,

626
00:36:52,137 --> 00:36:57,373
whereas that 1 hop path has an average

627
00:36:57,373 --> 00:37:01,312
bandwidth of 56 kilobit.

628
00:37:01,312 --> 00:37:05,433
So, when a Link-State Protocol looks
at this, it's gonna say, well,

629
00:37:05,433 --> 00:37:07,195
56k, that's pretty poor.

630
00:37:07,195 --> 00:37:10,310
1.544 megabit, now, that's business.

631
00:37:10,310 --> 00:37:12,000
We're gonna run with that.

632
00:37:12,000 --> 00:37:16,800
And so a Link-State Protocol would pick
the green path, and not the blue path.

633
00:37:16,800 --> 00:37:20,740
Now, that means we get nice, solid
bandwidth, reliable communication between

634
00:37:20,740 --> 00:37:25,280
the sides, if we have a failure, and
here we got multiple points of failure.

635
00:37:25,280 --> 00:37:29,204
So, we could have a failure here,
or here, or

636
00:37:29,204 --> 00:37:34,047
router 3 as a whole,
any one of those things could fail.

637
00:37:34,047 --> 00:37:38,589
If any any one of those fail
the Link-State Protocol would say, oh,

638
00:37:38,589 --> 00:37:41,190
well, you know what, that's 56k.

639
00:37:41,190 --> 00:37:44,986
I'd said, it's actually 128k,
it was dial-up originally, and

640
00:37:44,986 --> 00:37:47,720
then we changed it to ISDN,
I forgot, there we go.

641
00:37:48,773 --> 00:37:53,761
So, it's gonna say, 128k is better than
nothing, let's go over the ISDN line,

642
00:37:53,761 --> 00:37:57,321
and it'll flip over to that one,
and it'll move across it.

643
00:37:57,321 --> 00:38:01,996
So, deep down underneath the hood,
it the heart of the matter,

644
00:38:01,996 --> 00:38:07,107
Distance Vector Protocols rely on
hop count, Link-State Protocols

645
00:38:07,107 --> 00:38:12,320
use other metrics, specifically
bandwidth to make those decisions.

646
00:38:12,320 --> 00:38:13,201
And so between the two,

647
00:38:13,201 --> 00:38:16,210
Link-State Protocols typically make
smarter decisions based on our network.

648
00:38:17,720 --> 00:38:20,970
Now, there is a third type of routing

649
00:38:20,970 --> 00:38:25,640
protocol that they don't specifically call
out right here, or even in the objectives.

650
00:38:25,640 --> 00:38:30,360
There's a third type which is called
a Hybrid Distance Vector Protocol, and

651
00:38:30,360 --> 00:38:35,110
that's where some vendors take a Distance
Vector Protocol and they retrofit it.

652
00:38:35,110 --> 00:38:39,400
They add on to it to make it where's
an easy to implement protocol, but

653
00:38:39,400 --> 00:38:42,900
it takes into account other things,
and Cisco did this.

654
00:38:42,900 --> 00:38:46,550
Cisco created a protocol called EIGRP,
which is

655
00:38:46,550 --> 00:38:51,360
the Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing
Protocol, rolls right off the tongue.

656
00:38:51,360 --> 00:38:53,380
It's Cisco proprietary,
it's not a standard,

657
00:38:53,380 --> 00:38:57,040
nobody supports it other than Cisco,
so it's not very popular, but

658
00:38:57,040 --> 00:39:02,680
it is out there, and at its heart,
it's a Distance Vector Protocol.

659
00:39:02,680 --> 00:39:03,700
But, you know what?

660
00:39:03,700 --> 00:39:06,440
In the protocol itself,
it ignores the hop count.

661
00:39:06,440 --> 00:39:11,138
It's a Distance Vector Protocol it doesn't
even pay attention to the hop count, and

662
00:39:11,138 --> 00:39:13,170
it does look at bandwidth and delay.

663
00:39:13,170 --> 00:39:14,820
It looks at delay on the line too.

664
00:39:14,820 --> 00:39:16,970
So, it's even going more specific.

665
00:39:16,970 --> 00:39:18,620
So, it's an amazing protocol.

666
00:39:18,620 --> 00:39:20,800
Phenomenal, makes really good decisions.

667
00:39:20,800 --> 00:39:22,850
You guys will learn about
it in the CCNA show,

668
00:39:22,850 --> 00:39:26,440
when we get into that show
we'll tackle the EIGRP.

669
00:39:26,440 --> 00:39:28,310
But phenomenal protocol.

670
00:39:28,310 --> 00:39:31,370
But it is based on a Distance Vectors, so

671
00:39:31,370 --> 00:39:36,730
you will see that most protocols fall into
either Distance Vector, or Link-State.

672
00:39:36,730 --> 00:39:40,519
But just keep in mind, there can be some
that are called a hybrid, or sometimes,

673
00:39:40,519 --> 00:39:43,419
they call it a Hybrid Distance Vector,
or sometimes they call

674
00:39:43,419 --> 00:39:46,689
it an Advanced Distance Vector cuz
there's no official term for it.

675
00:39:46,689 --> 00:39:50,849
Cuz really, some vendor who's chosen
to bastardize one of the standards,

676
00:39:50,849 --> 00:39:53,400
that's basically what it comes down to.

677
00:39:53,400 --> 00:39:55,903
And so,
there's not really an official term.

678
00:39:55,903 --> 00:40:01,147
So, just keep in mind right here,
Distance Vector and

679
00:40:01,147 --> 00:40:06,850
Link-State, those are kind of
the two that we really see.

680
00:40:06,850 --> 00:40:07,500
All right.

00:40:07,500 --> 00:40:10,030
What was the other thing
that I wanted to mention.

00:40:10,030 --> 00:40:11,370
Let me check the objectives here.

00:40:11,370 --> 00:40:12,500
I think we've got to through most of it.

684
00:40:12,500 --> 00:40:16,700
Let's see, talk about next hops,
talked about the routing table.

685
00:40:18,530 --> 00:40:21,780
Oh the last thing I wanted to mention is

686
00:40:21,780 --> 00:40:24,800
what if I'm running more
than one routing protocol?

687
00:40:24,800 --> 00:40:25,950
Right?
It is possible.

688
00:40:25,950 --> 00:40:27,940
You could run both.

689
00:40:27,940 --> 00:40:30,820
Like a distance vector and
a link state protocol.

690
00:40:30,820 --> 00:40:35,790
So you can run more than one routing
protocol if you want, all right?

691
00:40:35,790 --> 00:40:39,590
If you do, it's possible that your router

692
00:40:39,590 --> 00:40:44,200
could learn the same route via
two different routing protocols.

693
00:40:44,200 --> 00:40:49,020
It could learn it via a distance vector
