694
00:40:49,020 --> 00:40:52,910
If it's learning the same route
through two different protocols,

695
00:40:52,910 --> 00:40:56,220
how does the router figure out
which one to prefer, all right?

696
00:40:56,220 --> 00:40:59,900
Well, earlier, I mentioned a metric.

697
00:40:59,900 --> 00:41:03,580
And the metric is used to
determine which route is the best.

698
00:41:03,580 --> 00:41:06,180
When it's the same routing protocol.

699
00:41:06,180 --> 00:41:08,140
But if they're different
routing protocols,

700
00:41:08,140 --> 00:41:10,990
there's another number,
the administrative distance.

701
00:41:10,990 --> 00:41:13,420
And when we looked at that routing table,
let me pull that routing table back up.

702
00:41:18,480 --> 00:41:24,260
When we look at that number in
the routing table, I can see here, 5/0.

703
00:41:24,260 --> 00:41:28,600
The first number is the administrative
distance, the second number is the metric.

704
00:41:29,870 --> 00:41:35,450
The metric is used as a tie-breaker when
we have two routes from the same protocol.

705
00:41:35,450 --> 00:41:40,710
The administrative distance is used as
the tie-breaker when I get the same

706
00:41:40,710 --> 00:41:44,100
route from two different protocols.

707
00:41:44,100 --> 00:41:44,710
All right.

708
00:41:44,710 --> 00:41:47,770
And Cisco has some arbitrary
numbers that they've assigned

709
00:41:47,770 --> 00:41:52,120
to help us decide which ones win and
which ones don't.

710
00:41:52,120 --> 00:41:54,240
Let me just kind of throw
those up here on the screen.

711
00:41:57,120 --> 00:41:58,120
So we have

712
00:42:05,539 --> 00:42:10,430
Any directly connected routes have
an administrative distance of zero.

713
00:42:12,250 --> 00:42:14,840
If it is an EIGRP, hang on.

714
00:42:14,840 --> 00:42:16,560
Let me do static.

715
00:42:16,560 --> 00:42:22,140
Static routes By default have
an administrative distance of one.

716
00:42:23,500 --> 00:42:28,360
And then we have CISCO's EIGRP,
that's their proprietary protocol.

717
00:42:28,360 --> 00:42:30,374
Has an administrative distance of 90.

718
00:42:32,080 --> 00:42:38,100
OSPF which is a link state protocol,
right.

719
00:42:38,100 --> 00:42:42,030
This one is a hybrid distance vector.

720
00:42:44,730 --> 00:42:46,600
And then 120 is RIP.

721
00:42:46,600 --> 00:42:50,228
Which is a distance vector protocol.

722
00:42:52,460 --> 00:42:56,610
Okay, so, these are the main ones.

723
00:42:56,610 --> 00:42:59,360
Let me make this font a little bit bigger.

724
00:43:02,690 --> 00:43:05,090
These are the main ones
that show up on the exam.

725
00:43:05,090 --> 00:43:09,820
A directly connected route is always
preferred over any other route.

726
00:43:09,820 --> 00:43:14,330
So, a directly connected route gets
an administrative distance of zero and

727
00:43:14,330 --> 00:43:18,585
let me just have that.

728
00:43:22,807 --> 00:43:23,690
Oh, that's cute.

729
00:43:27,500 --> 00:43:29,300
Why would I want that font size to match?

730
00:43:29,300 --> 00:43:33,540
That would be crazy talk.

731
00:43:33,540 --> 00:43:34,990
There we go.

732
00:43:34,990 --> 00:43:36,110
Zero is directly connected.

733
00:43:36,110 --> 00:43:38,040
Directly connected is always prefered.

734
00:43:38,040 --> 00:43:40,890
A one, that's a static route.

735
00:43:40,890 --> 00:43:43,090
That's one that we told the router, and

736
00:43:43,090 --> 00:43:45,280
the router assumes that
we know what we're doing.

737
00:43:45,280 --> 00:43:46,230
It might be wrong.

738
00:43:46,230 --> 00:43:48,430
But it assumes that we
know what we're doing.

739
00:43:48,430 --> 00:43:52,490
And so, if we manually put a route in
there, the router's going to prefer it.

740
00:43:52,490 --> 00:43:55,080
But after that,
it comes down to Cisco's choice.

741
00:43:55,080 --> 00:43:56,600
Now Cisco loves their own protocol.

742
00:43:56,600 --> 00:43:59,980
They love EIGRP, and so
they give it a metric of 90, all right?

743
00:44:01,070 --> 00:44:03,870
But after that look at OSPF and RIP.

744
00:44:03,870 --> 00:44:08,230
OSPF is the most popular
Link State Protocol and

745
00:44:08,230 --> 00:44:11,460
RIP is the most popular
Distance Vector Protocol.

746
00:44:11,460 --> 00:44:15,620
And see how they've arranged it, where
the Link State Protocol gets a 110 and

747
00:44:15,620 --> 00:44:17,770
the Distance Vector Protocol gets a 120.

748
00:44:17,770 --> 00:44:22,350
That means if your router learns,
the same route,

749
00:44:22,350 --> 00:44:29,000
if it learns 192.168.0.0/24, if it learns
that via RIP and it learns it via OSPF,

750
00:44:29,000 --> 00:44:33,340
it's going to prefer the route from
OSPF which is based on bandwidth

751
00:44:33,340 --> 00:44:37,930
over the route that was learned from
RIP which is based on hop count okay.

752
00:44:37,930 --> 00:44:42,740
So inside of the router,
there's like a pre built in or

753
00:44:42,740 --> 00:44:44,310
a built in predisposition, right.

754
00:44:44,310 --> 00:44:49,500
It's already biased to choose
link state over distance vector.

755
00:44:49,500 --> 00:44:50,130
Now for

756
00:44:50,130 --> 00:44:55,060
those of you that go on to the CCNP
we'll talk about how to override this.

757
00:44:55,060 --> 00:44:59,430
You can override it choose whatever the
heck you want, but in the router itself,

758
00:44:59,430 --> 00:45:03,670
what's built in there it
follows this order right here.

759
00:45:03,670 --> 00:45:05,050
And just remember its like a race.

760
00:45:05,050 --> 00:45:08,420
You know,
first place is better than 90th place.

761
00:45:08,420 --> 00:45:12,560
And so, a static route will be
preferred over EIGRP, right.

762
00:45:12,560 --> 00:45:15,760
Now, in a lot of the text books that you
find out there, if you go buy the Cisco

763
00:45:15,760 --> 00:45:20,850
press book for CCNT, which is a really
good book, if you need a book.

764
00:45:21,900 --> 00:45:25,850
But, if you pick one of those up they'll
usually have a few more entries in here

765
00:45:25,850 --> 00:45:32,230
like, they may have BGP and external
EIGRP and a few other entries in here.

766
00:45:32,230 --> 00:45:35,220
Those are good to know but these
are the ones that show up on the exam.

767
00:45:35,220 --> 00:45:36,290
These five right here.

768
00:45:36,290 --> 00:45:41,074
So you can memorize your giant table
if you want but these are the five that

769
00:45:41,074 --> 00:45:45,091
really turn up and the ones that
we really need to be aware of.

770
00:45:45,091 --> 00:45:48,449
All right, so
that pretty much wraps up all I've got,

771
00:45:48,449 --> 00:45:51,375
I'm kind of highlighting
these differences.

772
00:45:51,375 --> 00:45:55,077
I just wanted to make sure that all of
you guys out there in TV land had a good

773
00:45:55,077 --> 00:45:58,666
understanding of the ending of these
categories of routing protocols

774
00:45:58,666 --> 00:46:01,320
the distance vector verses link stay.

775
00:46:01,320 --> 00:46:06,070
These categories that kind of
describe the functionality of each

776
00:46:06,070 --> 00:46:09,980
protocol because in the next episode we're
going to dive right into OSPF, okay?

777
00:46:09,980 --> 00:46:13,380
It didn't used to be like that in
the old exam, we would do RIP first,

778
00:46:13,380 --> 00:46:16,530
which was distance vector,
and then we would do OSPF.

779
00:46:16,530 --> 00:46:19,190
But when Cisco updated the exam
objectives, they bumped RIP off.

780
00:46:19,190 --> 00:46:20,410
It's gone now.

781
00:46:20,410 --> 00:46:24,230
And so it's hard to put all this stuff
into context if you don't have that basic.

782
00:46:24,230 --> 00:46:27,420
So I wanted to take a little time and
make sure everybody had a good,

783
00:46:27,420 --> 00:46:29,080
firm understanding.

784
00:46:29,080 --> 00:46:33,140
If any of that is still confusing
to you always remember to jump

785
00:46:33,140 --> 00:46:37,670
over to our website at ITPro.TV and go to
the Q and A section and post a question.

786
00:46:37,670 --> 00:46:41,780
We monitor that, Ronnie, Nate,
Mike, Wes, Me all the hosts.

787
00:46:41,780 --> 00:46:43,560
Anybody you see in front of the camera.

788
00:46:43,560 --> 00:46:47,080
We all monitor that and we answer
the questions as you guys ask them so

789
00:46:47,080 --> 00:46:50,230
we can always explain it there and
remember, when we do live shows like this,

790
00:46:50,230 --> 00:46:54,660
just jump over to itpro.tv/live, you might
be watching from there right now and

791
00:46:54,660 --> 00:46:56,350
the chat screen is right at the bottom,

792
00:46:56,350 --> 00:46:59,730
you can post your chats you just
have to be logged in to chat and

793
00:46:59,730 --> 00:47:02,910
you can comment and
throw in whatever you want right there.

794
00:47:02,910 --> 00:47:03,950
So, pretty cool stuff.

795
00:47:06,540 --> 00:47:09,440
Lets see, other than that,
that's basically it.

796
00:47:09,440 --> 00:47:10,910
I hope you enjoyed the show today.

797
00:47:10,910 --> 00:47:15,180
It was a little unusual, a little
shorter episode at a different time, but

798
00:47:15,180 --> 00:47:17,590
stay tuned for next week.

799
00:47:17,590 --> 00:47:20,810
I think it's on Monday, I'll check the
schedule, that way we're jumping in and

800
00:47:20,810 --> 00:47:24,540
tackling the OSPF of our first
dynamic routing protocol.

801
00:47:24,540 --> 00:47:27,410
We'll take some routers, we'll have
them learn routes from each other.

802
00:47:27,410 --> 00:47:30,840
It's pretty cool, and you'll get
a chance to see how all that functions.

803
00:47:30,840 --> 00:47:33,440
So, that's about all I've got.

804
00:47:33,440 --> 00:47:38,180
Like I said, I hope you enjoyed
the show and signing off for ITProTV,

805
00:47:38,180 --> 00:47:39,337
I'm Don Pezet.

806
00:47:39,337 --> 00:47:40,799
We'll catch you next time around.

807
00:47:40,799 --> 00:47:50,799
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) protocol is a dynamic routing protocol that allows routers to communicate with each other. Viewers will hear about the properties of OSPF, how to configure it on a Cisco router, and also about configuring and implementing interVLAN routing on a Cisco router.
episodes.title: Intro to OSPF
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,044 --> 00:00:10,044
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,631 --> 00:00:35,127
Good morning, good afternoon, and

3
00:00:35,127 --> 00:00:37,740
good evening, and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:37,740 --> 00:00:39,450
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:39,450 --> 00:00:40,780
Accompanied today by Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:40,780 --> 00:00:41,830
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:41,830 --> 00:00:43,470
>> It is going so well.

8
00:00:43,470 --> 00:00:47,630
I cannot believe that I did not
make it to Saturday Night Live and

9
00:00:47,630 --> 00:00:48,980
Miley Cyrus being on there.

10
00:00:48,980 --> 00:00:50,830
>> You missed the Miley Cyrus thing?

11
00:00:50,830 --> 00:00:51,500
>> I missed it.

12
00:00:52,870 --> 00:00:55,170
>> That's the social event of the year.

13
00:00:55,170 --> 00:00:55,860
>> I've heard.

14
00:00:55,860 --> 00:00:57,430
>> Our society is crumbling, Ronnie.

15
00:00:57,430 --> 00:00:57,930
>> I know.

16
00:00:59,650 --> 00:01:01,270
>> All right.
Well ladies and gentleman,

17
00:01:01,270 --> 00:01:04,940
as shocking as Miley's appearance
on Saturday Night Live was,

18
00:01:04,940 --> 00:01:08,050
I assume cuz I didn't watch it either.

19
00:01:08,050 --> 00:01:10,570
We are going to be tackling
some neat stuff today.

20
00:01:10,570 --> 00:01:14,020
In our last episode,
we took a look at static routes and

21
00:01:14,020 --> 00:01:17,410
we talked about how we can set
up routes between routers.

22
00:01:17,410 --> 00:01:21,930
But one of the things that I had
mentioned was, the bigger a network gets,

23
00:01:21,930 --> 00:01:26,510
the more burdensome it becomes to try and
keep putting in all these static routes.

24
00:01:26,510 --> 00:01:29,930
So today, first, a network first.

25
00:01:29,930 --> 00:01:34,850
We're going to implement a dynamic
routing protocol so that our routers can

26
00:01:34,850 --> 00:01:38,670
talk to each other and they can learn
on their own without even knowing it.

27
00:01:38,670 --> 00:01:39,973
>> Learn without even knowing it.

28
00:01:39,973 --> 00:01:41,417
>> [LAUGH] Look at that.

29
00:01:41,417 --> 00:01:43,597
>> Wow, that's awesome.
>> I played it off our slogan.

30
00:01:43,597 --> 00:01:47,129
All right so, the sad jokes we make.

31
00:01:47,129 --> 00:01:48,244
>> So speaking about routing protocols.

32
00:01:48,244 --> 00:01:51,528
Let's see,
the routing protocol that we're gonna

33
00:01:51,528 --> 00:01:56,570
actually introduce today is one called
OSPF and I don't care what you say.

34
00:01:56,570 --> 00:01:58,490
For the longest time I
was calling OPF OPSF.

35
00:01:58,490 --> 00:01:59,170
>> [LAUGH].

36
00:01:59,170 --> 00:02:02,972
>> Don looks at me and goes, it's OSPF.

37
00:02:02,972 --> 00:02:03,970
I'm like, oh, okay.

38
00:02:03,970 --> 00:02:05,780
>> Oops.
>> Yeah oops.

39
00:02:05,780 --> 00:02:06,480
>> So stuff like that.

40
00:02:06,480 --> 00:02:09,760
But it stands for
open shortest path first.

41
00:02:09,760 --> 00:02:10,990
And this is, by far,

42
00:02:10,990 --> 00:02:13,700
the most popular routing protocol
that we have out there today.

43
00:02:13,700 --> 00:02:16,390
And so
we want to introduce you to that topic.

44
00:02:16,390 --> 00:02:17,619
>> Yeah.

45
00:02:17,619 --> 00:02:19,570
So, OSPF.
Very powerful protocol right?

46
00:02:19,570 --> 00:02:22,040
Let's talk about some of the benefits and
let me,

47
00:02:22,040 --> 00:02:25,680
I'll fire up a fancy dancy
Notepad window here.

48
00:02:25,680 --> 00:02:28,860
>> Nice, yes.
>> And let's see.

49
00:02:28,860 --> 00:02:30,470
Here we go.

50
00:02:30,470 --> 00:02:33,861
And, so what we're gonna do is we
are going to take a look at OSPF,

51
00:02:33,861 --> 00:02:38,010
kind of what the protocol is, what it
does, how it works, all that good stuff.

52
00:02:38,010 --> 00:02:39,322
And let me, I'm sorry.

53
00:02:39,322 --> 00:02:40,156
I didn't, there we go.

54
00:02:40,156 --> 00:02:42,060
>> So
as we're actually taking a look at this.

55
00:02:42,060 --> 00:02:43,818
Let's kind of do a basic review again.

56
00:02:43,818 --> 00:02:45,900
Just briefly, okay?

57
00:02:45,900 --> 00:02:47,860
For us, we have two different ways or

58
00:02:47,860 --> 00:02:52,450
actually I guess multiple ways that we
can have a router learn about routes.

59
00:02:52,450 --> 00:02:55,530
We can do it statically, where we can
actually manually assign the routes here.

60
00:02:55,530 --> 00:02:57,120
We can type them in.

61
00:02:57,120 --> 00:02:57,930
And we configure them.

62
00:02:57,930 --> 00:03:00,837
The downfall of that is that if
anything changes, we have to go in and

63
00:03:00,837 --> 00:03:03,242
change them for
every single router that we're doing.

64
00:03:03,242 --> 00:03:07,106
What we wanna focus in on is the idea
of dynamic routing protocols, and

65
00:03:07,106 --> 00:03:11,439
the one that we're focusing in on today
is the most popular one, called OSPF.

66
00:03:11,439 --> 00:03:14,787
And that one is, it allows us to
turn on that routing protocol and

67
00:03:14,787 --> 00:03:16,830
they can begin to learn routes.

68
00:03:16,830 --> 00:03:17,940
>> Yep.
Now the name,

69
00:03:17,940 --> 00:03:19,360
let's start with the name, right?

70
00:03:19,360 --> 00:03:21,350
>> Sure.
>> The o for open, right.

71
00:03:21,350 --> 00:03:24,060
That means it's an open standard.

72
00:03:24,060 --> 00:03:26,760
Any vendor can support it without
paying royalty fees to somebody else.

73
00:03:26,760 --> 00:03:33,388
So Cisco, 3Com, HP, Juniper,
you name it, they can all support OSPF.

74
00:03:33,388 --> 00:03:37,498
And they all operate to that standard so
they can interact, and you don't

75
00:03:37,498 --> 00:03:42,550
have to have a homogenous environment,
you can have a heterogeneous environment.

76
00:03:42,550 --> 00:03:43,620
And you can mix vendors.

77
00:03:43,620 --> 00:03:44,220
>> Wow, nice.
>> I know.

78
00:03:44,220 --> 00:03:45,100
There's a lot of big words.

79
00:03:45,100 --> 00:03:47,400
Everything I learned off a milk carton.

80
00:03:47,400 --> 00:03:50,980
So it is a dynamic routing protocol.

81
00:03:50,980 --> 00:03:56,440
It is an open standard, so
a lot of people support it.

82
00:03:56,440 --> 00:03:58,990
>> And nobody gets paid for it.

83
00:03:58,990 --> 00:04:00,360
>> Yeah, technically nobody gets paid.

84
00:04:00,360 --> 00:04:03,160
Somebody always gets paid right?

85
00:04:03,160 --> 00:04:07,970
The other part of the name shortest
path first SPF, that's the Algorithm.

86
00:04:09,130 --> 00:04:10,600
>> Spell the guy's name [LAUGH].

87
00:04:10,600 --> 00:04:17,188
>> And it is sometimes known as the-
>> Oh, very good.

88
00:04:17,188 --> 00:04:20,738
>> Djikstra Algorithm named after
the gentleman who wrote it who,

89
00:04:20,738 --> 00:04:24,890
I don't know Djikstra, what is that
like a Nordic or Icelandic last name.

90
00:04:24,890 --> 00:04:27,440
>> I'm going to say Chinese at this point.

91
00:04:27,440 --> 00:04:30,055
>> Chinese, not the traditional Chinese.

92
00:04:30,055 --> 00:04:33,950
[LAUGH] So, anyhow, it is sometimes
referred to as the Djikstra Algorithm,

93
00:04:33,950 --> 00:04:38,390
because the gentleman who wrote it, but
in the official standard it's called SPF,

94
00:04:38,390 --> 00:04:40,470
the Shortest Path First Algorithm.

95
00:04:40,470 --> 00:04:45,130
And it's a simple formula of figuring
out what's the best path to take,

96
00:04:45,130 --> 00:04:48,170
the best path being
considered the shortest path.

97
00:04:48,170 --> 00:04:53,070
Now don't be confused with
a distance vector protocol.

98
00:04:53,070 --> 00:04:55,980
A distance vector protocol
uses a metric of hop count.

99
00:04:55,980 --> 00:04:59,110
The less hops, the shorter the path,
the more it's preferred.

100
00:04:59,110 --> 00:05:02,155
The more hops, the longer the path,
the less it's preferred.

101
00:05:02,155 --> 00:05:07,325
In OSPF though, Bandwidth is the Metric.

102
00:05:08,895 --> 00:05:11,005
And which, I'm spelling completely wrong.

103
00:05:11,005 --> 00:05:12,605
There we go.
Bandwidth is the Metric yeah, okay.

104
00:05:13,710 --> 00:05:17,590
So when it goes to figure out a path
it doesn't really care about hops.

105
00:05:17,590 --> 00:05:19,340
It cares about bandwidth.

106
00:05:19,340 --> 00:05:21,500
What's the bandwidth between two links?

107
00:05:21,500 --> 00:05:23,535
So that it is very different, and

108
00:05:23,535 --> 00:05:28,950
that's because it is a link state
protocol not a distance vector protocol.

109
00:05:28,950 --> 00:05:30,770
It does not care about hop count at all.

110
00:05:32,230 --> 00:05:35,430
>> Yeah, and so in terms of the link
state protocol for us, right?

111
00:05:35,430 --> 00:05:38,770
Unlike what we were talking about in terms
of number of routers in between us and

112
00:05:38,770 --> 00:05:40,190
our destination here.

113
00:05:40,190 --> 00:05:44,010
Link state actually begins
to actually take a look at

114
00:05:44,010 --> 00:05:46,240
what they're directly connected to and

115
00:05:46,240 --> 00:05:49,770
the information that they get from
that picker connection right away.

116
00:05:49,770 --> 00:05:54,830
And so once you actually have that built
up here, then we're about ready to go.

117
00:05:55,900 --> 00:06:00,765
>> The other thing that I want to mention,
is with distance vector protocols,

118
00:06:00,765 --> 00:06:02,430
routers only see their neighbors.

119
00:06:02,430 --> 00:06:05,420
They just see their direct neighbors and
that's it.

120
00:06:05,420 --> 00:06:07,280
But with a link state protocol,

121
00:06:07,280 --> 00:06:11,385
the routers will actually communicate
between each other and through each other.

122
00:06:11,385 --> 00:06:19,160
And that means that routers have end
to end visibility of the network, okay.

123
00:06:19,160 --> 00:06:23,500
So our routers not only see the beginning
and their neighbor the next top,

124
00:06:23,500 --> 00:06:25,960
they see beyond that,
all the way to the destination.

125
00:06:25,960 --> 00:06:29,880
So they have a much bigger picture
of what's going on on the network.

126
00:06:29,880 --> 00:06:33,175
That means they can make more
intelligent decisions, better decisions,

127
00:06:33,175 --> 00:06:37,060
cuz they're not just seeing that one hop,
they're seeing all the way down the line.

128
00:06:37,060 --> 00:06:40,660
>> Usually the analogy that I like
using is the idea of like a road atlas.

129
00:06:40,660 --> 00:06:41,350
Right?

130
00:06:41,350 --> 00:06:42,850
You actually have where you are.

131
00:06:42,850 --> 00:06:43,960
And then you have a road atlas.

132
00:06:43,960 --> 00:06:45,990
And it means you can
find any path through it.

133
00:06:45,990 --> 00:06:46,750
And that's the way SPF works.

134
00:06:46,750 --> 00:06:49,990
Essentially is that we're
actually getting an entire atlas

135
00:06:49,990 --> 00:06:52,030
of the entire network
that we're connected to.

136
00:06:52,030 --> 00:06:54,080
>> I like your atlas example.

137
00:06:54,080 --> 00:06:55,010
I've never used that before.

138
00:06:55,010 --> 00:06:57,170
But if you think about it, all right?

139
00:06:57,170 --> 00:06:59,200
Let's say that you're in
the state of Florida, and

140
00:06:59,200 --> 00:07:01,960
you decide that you're gonna drive
to the state of Washington, right?

141
00:07:01,960 --> 00:07:03,720
So the southeast all the way to northwest.

142
00:07:04,748 --> 00:07:06,904
If you had a map of
the entire United States,

143
00:07:06,904 --> 00:07:09,300
you could probably plan
out a pretty good route.

144
00:07:09,300 --> 00:07:12,514
But what if while you were in Florida,
you just had a map of Florida?

145
00:07:12,514 --> 00:07:13,646
>> Yeah.

146
00:07:13,646 --> 00:07:16,784
>> And then when you got out of
Florida and into Alabama or whatever,

147
00:07:16,784 --> 00:07:18,660
you just had a map of Alabama.

148
00:07:18,660 --> 00:07:24,450
If you went state by state like that,
you might make a a decision or

149
00:07:24,450 --> 00:07:28,130
whatever that is not optimal because
you didn't have that big picture.

150
00:07:28,130 --> 00:07:31,060
Distance vector protocols
suffer from that quite often.

151
00:07:31,060 --> 00:07:32,210
Link state protocols don't.

152
00:07:32,210 --> 00:07:34,440
They see the end to end.

153
00:07:34,440 --> 00:07:35,950
Now the trade-off, right?

154
00:07:35,950 --> 00:07:36,910
So these are all positive things.

155
00:07:36,910 --> 00:07:38,117
>> Right [LAUGH].

156
00:07:38,117 --> 00:07:39,257
>> These are all good things about OSPF.

157
00:07:39,257 --> 00:07:40,230
But there are negatives.

158
00:07:40,230 --> 00:07:42,876
All right?
The biggest negative with OSPF Is that

159
00:07:42,876 --> 00:07:45,209
it's a little bit resource intensive.

160
00:07:45,209 --> 00:07:46,033
>> Right.

161
00:07:46,033 --> 00:07:47,066
>> The router has to see the big picture.

162
00:07:47,066 --> 00:07:51,450
It processes a lot of information that
a distance vector router wouldn't.

163
00:07:51,450 --> 00:07:54,600
So as a result it needs more memory,
more CPU.

164
00:07:54,600 --> 00:07:57,590
So let me just add that to my list.

165
00:07:57,590 --> 00:08:04,184
More Memory/CPU than Distance Vector.

166
00:08:04,184 --> 00:08:06,623
All right, the other negative.

167
00:08:06,623 --> 00:08:10,114
It can be complex to configure.

168
00:08:10,114 --> 00:08:13,088
We're gonna see the introduction
to OSPF today and

169
00:08:13,088 --> 00:08:16,560
you guys will see,
it's really not that hard to get set up.

170
00:08:17,620 --> 00:08:22,292
But for those of you who continue on to
the CCNA, you're gonna see there's a lot

171
00:08:22,292 --> 00:08:25,379
more to OSPF,
it's got a ton of bells and whistles.

172
00:08:25,379 --> 00:08:28,510
And it's pretty challenging
to set it up sometimes.

173
00:08:28,510 --> 00:08:30,330
So, it can be complex to configure.

174
00:08:30,330 --> 00:08:32,430
>> It's kind of interesting
in terms of the introduction,

175
00:08:32,430 --> 00:08:35,840
how easy this can be configured compared
to when you actually really get into it.

176
00:08:35,840 --> 00:08:37,820
How complex it can be.

177
00:08:37,820 --> 00:08:39,890
It's amazing once you get
into the other things.

178
00:08:41,780 --> 00:08:45,060
>> So, what we're gonna do is we're
gonna take a couple of routers, and

179
00:08:45,060 --> 00:08:46,960
we're gonna set up OSPF between them.

180
00:08:46,960 --> 00:08:50,210
Sometimes, seeing is easier than telling.

181
00:08:50,210 --> 00:08:55,760
So, our topology,
let me just bring this up, and

182
00:08:55,760 --> 00:08:58,970
Jason, can we full screen that, so
my head's not on top of that network?

183
00:08:58,970 --> 00:09:00,600
With my giant head in the way.

184
00:09:00,600 --> 00:09:03,020
So, basically,
we're gonna have three routers.

185
00:09:03,020 --> 00:09:04,490
Router one, router two and router three.

186
00:09:04,490 --> 00:09:05,155
Thank you, Jason.

187
00:09:05,155 --> 00:09:10,670
Router one, two and three, they're
gonna be configured just in a triangle.

188
00:09:10,670 --> 00:09:14,397
Each router has its own
private network attached.

189
00:09:14,397 --> 00:09:17,896
Router one has 192.168.1.0.

190
00:09:17,896 --> 00:09:19,570
It's just a Class C network.

191
00:09:19,570 --> 00:09:23,300
Router two is connected to 2.0 and
Router three is connected to 3.0.

192
00:09:23,300 --> 00:09:28,730
Now, each router is then connected to
each other via some various links.

193
00:09:28,730 --> 00:09:31,600
And we've got some hundred megabit links,
Ethernet links, and

194
00:09:31,600 --> 00:09:34,340
we've got a serial link or a T1 line.

195
00:09:34,340 --> 00:09:37,175
Ronnie, you set it up,
did you catch the bandwidth on it?

196
00:09:37,175 --> 00:09:38,460
Is it-
>> I did not.

197
00:09:38,460 --> 00:09:39,870
>> Well,
we'll look when we get onto the routers.

198
00:09:39,870 --> 00:09:43,380
It's probably, the Cisco routers
will default to 64k a lot of times.

199
00:09:43,380 --> 00:09:45,070
So, it's probably set really low.

200
00:09:45,070 --> 00:09:48,230
But the point is they are different
bandwidths and that's important for

201
00:09:48,230 --> 00:09:49,360
our example.

202
00:09:49,360 --> 00:09:54,700
Now, if I'm on router one, router one
does not know about 192.168.3 and it

203
00:09:54,700 --> 00:10:00,690
doesn't know about 192.168.2 because it's
not directly plugged into those networks.

204
00:10:00,690 --> 00:10:01,530
It's indirect.

205
00:10:01,530 --> 00:10:03,480
It's got to pass these other routers.

206
00:10:03,480 --> 00:10:07,980
So, in the last episode,
we saw how to do that with static routes.

207
00:10:09,092 --> 00:10:11,090
So, we put a static route in and tell it.

208
00:10:11,090 --> 00:10:14,280
Well, in this topology,
I have to put two static routes on

209
00:10:14,280 --> 00:10:16,760
each router to tell it
about the other networks.

210
00:10:16,760 --> 00:10:19,860
And that means six static
routes all together.

211
00:10:19,860 --> 00:10:22,980
And as the routes start to grow as
new networks get added, it's more and

212
00:10:22,980 --> 00:10:25,122
more routes, and more and more burden.

213
00:10:25,122 --> 00:10:30,200
We're gonna configure OSPF on these
three guys so they exchange information.

214
00:10:30,200 --> 00:10:33,203
And once that's done,
they come up, they're happy, and

215
00:10:33,203 --> 00:10:36,224
they learn the routes without
us having to influence them.

216
00:10:36,224 --> 00:10:38,987
>> Yep.

217
00:10:38,987 --> 00:10:41,090
>> So, let's tackle it.

218
00:10:41,090 --> 00:10:43,460
Let's jump in there and
see this for example.

219
00:10:43,460 --> 00:10:45,310
We'll start on router one.

220
00:10:45,310 --> 00:10:47,380
Let me fire that guy up.

00:10:47,380 --> 00:10:52,208
And actually, I'm already in router

222
00:10:52,208 --> 00:10:54,025

00:10:54,025 --> 00:10:56,787
[SOUND]

00:10:56,787 --> 00:11:02,864

225
00:11:02,864 --> 00:11:07,655
So, here I am on router one, and
if I do a show IP interface brief,

226
00:11:07,655 --> 00:11:13,430
I can see that it's connected
to the 192.168.1.1 network.

227
00:11:13,430 --> 00:11:16,500
So, I'm connected there, that's awesome.

228
00:11:16,500 --> 00:11:19,560
And I can see that I've
got some other networks.

229
00:11:19,560 --> 00:11:23,032
My Ethernet connections
to the other routers.

230
00:11:23,032 --> 00:11:26,870
Router one is at the top of that triangle,
so it's only got Ethernet connections.

231
00:11:26,870 --> 00:11:28,810
It doesn't have anything serial.

232
00:11:28,810 --> 00:11:30,340
So, it's up and it's happy.

233
00:11:31,520 --> 00:11:36,150
If I do a show IP route,
it's got some routes and the routes

234
00:11:36,150 --> 00:11:40,880
are all just regular IP based routes so
nothing too crazy or fancy there.

235
00:11:40,880 --> 00:11:43,460
And it's up and it's happy.

236
00:11:43,460 --> 00:11:47,320
Now, looking at this,
they are no dynamically learned routes.

237
00:11:47,320 --> 00:11:49,410
I'll see the Cs and the L.

238
00:11:49,410 --> 00:11:52,310
The C indicating a directly
connected network.

239
00:11:52,310 --> 00:11:56,370
The L indicating our local
IP on those networks.

240
00:11:56,370 --> 00:11:58,095
But I don't see any Os or Rs or Es,

241
00:11:58,095 --> 00:12:01,450
anything that indicates that
I'm running a dynamic protocol.

242
00:12:02,520 --> 00:12:06,940
>> So, whatever's not in the routing table
means that we can't actually get to it.

243
00:12:06,940 --> 00:12:09,500
So, one of the things wanna do,
of course, is make sure,

244
00:12:09,500 --> 00:12:15,420
that we wanna be able to reach
that 192.168.2 or .3 network here.

245
00:12:15,420 --> 00:12:17,400
We've got to get them
into this routing table.

246
00:12:17,400 --> 00:12:19,220
>> Yep.
And we could do it with statics,

247
00:12:19,220 --> 00:12:22,505
but that would kinda defeat
the purpose of this objective.

248
00:12:22,505 --> 00:12:24,450
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're gonna configure OSPF instead.

249
00:12:24,450 --> 00:12:29,503
Now, we're gonna start with IPv4, and then
we'll do it again with IPv6 afterwards.

250
00:12:29,503 --> 00:12:33,350
So, we're gonna start with IPv4 which
is what you'll usually see on the exam.

251
00:12:34,460 --> 00:12:38,450
So, step one, I need to turn on OSPF.

252
00:12:38,450 --> 00:12:43,475
Now, when you turn on OSPF,
the command is really easy, it's router,

253
00:12:43,475 --> 00:12:47,720
OSPF, followed by a process ID.

254
00:12:49,440 --> 00:12:50,895
Now, this is really important.

255
00:12:50,895 --> 00:12:54,930
>> [LAUGH]
>> The process ID is a unique number

256
00:12:54,930 --> 00:12:56,798
that identifies this instance of OSPF.

257
00:12:56,798 --> 00:13:01,795
You can actually run more than
one copy of OSPF if you want to.

258
00:13:01,795 --> 00:13:03,535
If you're an internet service provider and

259
00:13:03,535 --> 00:13:06,935
you've got a bunch of different customers
and you want them to run OSPF for

260
00:13:06,935 --> 00:13:10,965
whatever reason, you could run a separate
instance of OSPF for each customer.

261
00:13:10,965 --> 00:13:13,665
That way they don't learn
each others' routes.

262
00:13:13,665 --> 00:13:16,035
Most people will never have a need for
that and

263
00:13:16,035 --> 00:13:19,590
so, we just pick a number here and
assign it.

264
00:13:19,590 --> 00:13:22,560
The thing is, anytime you wanna go and
configure OSPF,

265
00:13:22,560 --> 00:13:25,860
you've got to remember
this process number.

266
00:13:25,860 --> 00:13:30,330
Now, the process number is
locally unique on this router.

267
00:13:30,330 --> 00:13:33,610
So, you could use a different process
number on every router if you wanted and

268
00:13:33,610 --> 00:13:34,750
it wouldn't make a difference.

269
00:13:36,240 --> 00:13:38,370
It's only locally unique to this system.

270
00:13:38,370 --> 00:13:40,780
It's just this one router
that cares about it.

271
00:13:40,780 --> 00:13:44,525
So, what I normally do to make it easy
on myself is I just say router OSPF one.

272
00:13:44,525 --> 00:13:47,150
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is my first instance of OSPF,

273
00:13:47,150 --> 00:13:49,730
and it's gonna run with process ID one.

274
00:13:49,730 --> 00:13:52,800
If I ever need a second instance,
I'll do two or three,

275
00:13:52,800 --> 00:13:54,610
but most of us don't have a need for that.

276
00:13:56,709 --> 00:14:00,558
>> So, now, that we've got the initial
configuration, essentially what we've

277
00:14:00,558 --> 00:14:03,680
done here on the Cisco router is
we've turned on the idea of OSPF.

278
00:14:03,680 --> 00:14:06,740
Once we've turned it on,
doesn't mean that it's actually ready yet.

279
00:14:06,740 --> 00:14:10,380
We now need to configure it,
it's what we actually need to do.

280
00:14:10,380 --> 00:14:14,010
Now, for the initial configuration for
us, we're gonna need a network statement.

281
00:14:14,010 --> 00:14:15,780
We're gonna need an IP address.

282
00:14:15,780 --> 00:14:19,444
And the one that's kinda tricky for
us that we haven't been practicing,

283
00:14:19,444 --> 00:14:21,583
is gonna be what we
call the wildcard mask.

284
00:14:21,583 --> 00:14:24,818
And then, we're gonna need
a weird thing at the end there,

285
00:14:24,818 --> 00:14:28,920
it's gonna be called area and
then whatever number that we're gonna use.

286
00:14:28,920 --> 00:14:31,940
>> So, when we go to advertise this,
when we go to turn on OSPF,

287
00:14:31,940 --> 00:14:33,720
we're not done with just this one command.

288
00:14:33,720 --> 00:14:36,215
In fact, if I exit out right now,
OSPF isn't even turned on.

289
00:14:36,215 --> 00:14:36,860
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

290
00:14:36,860 --> 00:14:39,780
the network command's still like, hey,
we need to advertise these networks.

291
00:14:39,780 --> 00:14:44,548
And just like Ronnie said, the command is
kind of a long one, we say network, and

292
00:14:44,548 --> 00:14:48,705
then we tell the router really what
interface is we want OSPF to run on.

293
00:14:48,705 --> 00:14:50,588
So, with the network command,

294
00:14:50,588 --> 00:14:54,372
I'm specifying networks that I
have interfaces connected to.

295
00:14:54,372 --> 00:15:01,160
So, one of my interfaces, for
example, is the 192.168.0 network,

296
00:15:01,160 --> 00:15:05,126
and it's a class C, 255 255 255 0.

297
00:15:05,126 --> 00:15:10,800
However, OSPF doesn't take a subnet mask.

298
00:15:10,800 --> 00:15:13,560
It takes what's called a wild card mask.

299
00:15:13,560 --> 00:15:17,840
And wild card masks are different
than some of the masks.

300
00:15:17,840 --> 00:15:20,760
In a subnet mask,
if you convert them to binary,

301
00:15:20,760 --> 00:15:25,330
the ones identify the network ID and
the zeroes identify the host ID.

302
00:15:25,330 --> 00:15:28,520
In a wildcard mask,
it's kind of the opposite.

303
00:15:28,520 --> 00:15:32,690
A zero identifies a number
that has to match.

304
00:15:32,690 --> 00:15:35,810
A one identifies a number
that doesn't have to match.

305
00:15:35,810 --> 00:15:39,650
So, if I'm saying I'm looking for
an interface to turn on OSPF.

306
00:15:39,650 --> 00:15:43,873
And I want that interface
to start with 192.168.1.

307
00:15:43,873 --> 00:15:46,130
And then, it can end with whatever.

308
00:15:46,130 --> 00:15:53,145
Then, my wild card mask would
be like this, 0.0.0.255.

309
00:15:53,145 --> 00:15:57,581
The first three zeros are saying
the first three octets have to match.

310
00:15:57,581 --> 00:16:02,015
I'm looking for
interfaces that start with 192.168.1.

311
00:16:02,015 --> 00:16:06,125
And then, the last octet,
where I've got this 255, can be whatever.

312
00:16:06,125 --> 00:16:11,530
Any interface that matches this pattern
will turn on OSPF for it [SOUND].

313
00:16:11,530 --> 00:16:16,315
So, it's kind of the opposite of a subnet
mask and we're gonna talk more about

314
00:16:16,315 --> 00:16:20,170
this in the CCNA show when we
start doing access control lists.

315
00:16:20,170 --> 00:16:22,315
We'll see wild card masks like crazy.

316
00:16:22,315 --> 00:16:26,700
For the CCENT exam,
they keep it pretty simple though.

317
00:16:26,700 --> 00:16:29,770
They usually don't go too much beyond
what we are seeing right here.

318
00:16:29,770 --> 00:16:31,870
Just kind of reversing of subnet mask.

319
00:16:33,410 --> 00:16:36,200
And the last thing Ronnie
mentioned was the area.

320
00:16:36,200 --> 00:16:40,830
On the CCENT exam,
you only deal with single area OSPF.

321
00:16:40,830 --> 00:16:44,890
And that means, you'll take all of your
routers, and put them in the same area.

322
00:16:44,890 --> 00:16:47,680
In the CCNA exam, you'll do multi-area.

323
00:16:47,680 --> 00:16:49,260
Now, what are areas?

324
00:16:49,260 --> 00:16:52,660
Well, remember how I said in OSPF
each router can see the whole

325
00:16:52,660 --> 00:16:54,740
path beginning to end?

326
00:16:54,740 --> 00:16:58,310
Well, that's really cool on a small
network or on a medium-sized network.

327
00:16:58,310 --> 00:17:02,840
But on a larger or an enterprise level
network, it becomes really burdensome, and

328
00:17:02,840 --> 00:17:04,710
your routers may not have enough juice for
that.

329
00:17:04,710 --> 00:17:06,500
They may not be powerful enough.

330
00:17:06,500 --> 00:17:10,420
So, you can divide your OSPF
environment up into areas.

331
00:17:10,420 --> 00:17:12,440
You can break it into pieces.

332
00:17:12,440 --> 00:17:16,240
And then, each router router gets
assigned to a different area.

333
00:17:16,240 --> 00:17:17,070
We're just gonna do one.

334
00:17:17,070 --> 00:17:22,160
And if you're doing single-area OSPF,
you'll want to do area zero.

335
00:17:22,160 --> 00:17:23,000
Go ahead.

336
00:17:23,000 --> 00:17:26,540
>> I have to say, that area of
zero is a special area for us.

337
00:17:26,540 --> 00:17:30,630
A lot of times, you hear about it
being called the backbone area.

338
00:17:30,630 --> 00:17:33,590
This area allows us to be
able to configure this for

339
00:17:33,590 --> 00:17:36,140
that end-end connectivity that we see.

340
00:17:36,140 --> 00:17:40,300
But at the same time, it also allows for
when we get into it, a little bit later

341
00:17:40,300 --> 00:17:46,680
on, where all the others must transit
their data through this area zero.

342
00:17:46,680 --> 00:17:49,640
And so, this is gonna be the important
one at the beginning that we all have to

343
00:17:49,640 --> 00:17:50,890
be able to configure.

344
00:17:50,890 --> 00:17:53,540
When we actually start right here,
these areas.

345
00:17:53,540 --> 00:17:57,350
Now, let's be clear,
area space zero is actually the key here.

346
00:17:57,350 --> 00:17:57,880
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

347
00:17:57,880 --> 00:18:01,950
If you do an area zero without the space-
>> It gets upset with you.

348
00:18:01,950 --> 00:18:03,020
>> It gets upset.

349
00:18:03,020 --> 00:18:05,920
>> If we did area one, or
area two, those would work also.

350
00:18:05,920 --> 00:18:09,230
This does need to match on the various
routers that I wanna talk to,

351
00:18:09,230 --> 00:18:11,040
that area number has to be the same.

352
00:18:11,040 --> 00:18:12,920
The process ID could be different.

353
00:18:12,920 --> 00:18:13,920
We don't care about that.

354
00:18:13,920 --> 00:18:19,450
But the area number does have to
match unless I'm doing multi area.

355
00:18:19,450 --> 00:18:21,940
So, that's gonna take care
of the 192.168 network.

356
00:18:21,940 --> 00:18:24,150
I've got two other networks
that I need to advertise.

357
00:18:24,150 --> 00:18:29,255
So, I can say network 172.16.1.0 [SOUND],

358
00:18:29,255 --> 00:18:32,324
which I'll put into area zero.

359
00:18:32,324 --> 00:18:38,988
And the other one which was 2.0 [SOUND].

360
00:18:38,988 --> 00:18:45,440
So, those are my three networks
that I'm putting into area zero.

361
00:18:45,440 --> 00:18:47,770
Now, OSPF is running.

362
00:18:47,770 --> 00:18:50,920
And I'm trying to discover other routers.

363
00:18:52,170 --> 00:18:56,200
The easiest way to verify
that OSPF is running is with

364
00:18:56,200 --> 00:18:59,050
a nice little command
show IP per protocols.

365
00:19:00,210 --> 00:19:05,340
If you're running any kind of dynamic
protocol, when you run show IP protocols,

366
00:19:05,340 --> 00:19:06,860
it gives you the status screen for

367
00:19:06,860 --> 00:19:08,840
each Because you might be
running more than one.

368
00:19:08,840 --> 00:19:11,470
I might run EIGRP and RIP also.

369
00:19:11,470 --> 00:19:13,540
And so, when I run it,
I can see that I am running OSPF.

370
00:19:13,540 --> 00:19:20,320
My OSPF process ID is one, and
I'm routing for these three networks.

371
00:19:20,320 --> 00:19:21,700
I'm up and I'm happy.

372
00:19:21,700 --> 00:19:22,280
>> Yeah.

373
00:19:22,280 --> 00:19:25,670
Every once and a while, I know that in
terms configuration, I've done this.

374
00:19:25,670 --> 00:19:29,000
When I thought I configured it perfectly,
everything should be working, and

375
00:19:29,000 --> 00:19:30,520
then one route don't show up.

376
00:19:30,520 --> 00:19:33,830
This is a great place for
me to actually verify that in OSPF,

377
00:19:33,830 --> 00:19:37,410
I can actually see if I did
configure all three routes or not.

378
00:19:38,900 --> 00:19:42,940
>> Now, the way that we just configured
it, it's up and it's running on this one

379
00:19:42,940 --> 00:19:46,610
router, but if I run show IP router,
I still don't have any special routes.

380
00:19:46,610 --> 00:19:49,250
And the reason is I'm not running
on any other routers yet.

381
00:19:50,270 --> 00:19:54,230
So, let's jump over to routers two and
three, and kind of repeat the process.

382
00:19:54,230 --> 00:19:58,100
Now, I did it here,
the full way, the long way.

383
00:20:00,940 --> 00:20:03,990
So, if I pull up that configuration again,
here it is.

384
00:20:03,990 --> 00:20:08,410
We did router OSPF 1, and then I
manually advertised the three networks.

385
00:20:08,410 --> 00:20:11,816
There's actually some shortcuts
we can use to advertise networks

386
00:20:11,816 --> 00:20:12,979
a little more simply.

387
00:20:12,979 --> 00:20:15,835
So, let me connect to some
of the other routers and

388
00:20:15,835 --> 00:20:19,040
we'll see some of the other
ways that we can set this up.

389
00:20:19,040 --> 00:20:26,117
[SOUND] So, here's router two and
if I look at it,

390
00:20:26,117 --> 00:20:33,025
it's got interfaces 172.16.1.2,

391
00:20:33,025 --> 00:20:37,343
192.68.2.1, and

392
00:20:37,343 --> 00:20:41,156
172.16.3.2.

393
00:20:41,156 --> 00:20:46,001
So, it's got several of them that

394
00:20:46,001 --> 00:20:49,430
And so, what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna cheat on this one.

395
00:20:49,430 --> 00:20:54,580
I'm gonna just turn on OSPF for

396
00:20:55,620 --> 00:20:59,263
What we can do is we can say router
OSPF and then our process ID, and

so what I can do is,

00:24:05,820 --> 00:24:09,595

00:24:09,595 --> 00:24:10,960

>> So one you need to be aware of.

00:24:10,960 --> 00:24:14,280
Allows you to turn off OSPF for

454
00:24:14,280 --> 00:24:17,270
Now, it stops you from learning
routes in that interface.

455
00:24:17,270 --> 00:24:21,440
But you are still advertising that
network's existence into your environment.

456
00:24:21,440 --> 00:24:25,365
You would use the passive interface
command on any interface that connects

457
00:24:25,365 --> 00:24:30,535
to an ISP, on any interface that connects
to a network with no other routers,

458
00:24:30,535 --> 00:24:33,535
or on any interface where
you specifically don't

459
00:24:33,535 --> 00:24:35,145
want to connect to other routers,
all right?

460
00:24:35,145 --> 00:24:38,920
Those are the three scenarios where
you use the passive interface command.

461
00:24:38,920 --> 00:24:43,960
And so I use it here cause I specifically

00:24:43,960 --> 00:24:44,570

00:24:46,110 --> 00:24:49,480

we've got one more objective that

465
00:24:53,310 --> 00:24:56,960
In that third line underneath there,

466
00:25:00,330 --> 00:25:02,380
How do we determine that number?

467
00:25:02,380 --> 00:25:04,310
That's what we want to
try to figure out here.

468
00:25:04,310 --> 00:25:07,790
>> OSPF uses router ID's to keep
track of which routers are which and

469
00:25:07,790 --> 00:25:11,770
that's important because, since you
have total visibility of the network.

470
00:25:11,770 --> 00:25:13,720
If you see two paths,

471
00:25:13,720 --> 00:25:16,460
how do you know whether those two paths
pass through the same router or not.

472
00:25:16,460 --> 00:25:17,670
It can be confusing.

473
00:25:17,670 --> 00:25:19,430
So the router ID is what tells that.

474
00:25:19,430 --> 00:25:21,990
The router ID is automatically
generated by OSPF.

475
00:25:21,990 --> 00:25:26,860
And what it does is it looks at all of
the interfaces that are involved in OSPF.

476
00:25:26,860 --> 00:25:29,760
And it picks the highest one, right?

477
00:25:29,760 --> 00:25:34,970
The highest IP address that's on
your system at the time OSPF starts.

478
00:25:34,970 --> 00:25:35,830
Right?
So usually it's

479
00:25:35,830 --> 00:25:38,100
when the router boots up that it does it.

480
00:25:38,100 --> 00:25:40,710
And so
that's how it's picking out that ID.

481
00:25:40,710 --> 00:25:43,960
Now if you're issuing network commands,

482
00:25:43,960 --> 00:25:47,440
usually the very first one you enter in,
it picks that up, and

483
00:25:47,440 --> 00:25:50,630
then your other network commands come
afterwards, the router ID is already set.

484
00:25:50,630 --> 00:25:53,470
So you may end up with it being in
a lower one, so it can get confusing.

485
00:25:53,470 --> 00:25:57,740
But if you reboot the router or restart
the OSPF process, when it starts up,

486
00:25:57,740 --> 00:26:02,010
it'll pick the highest IP on
the interfaces that are running OSPF.

487
00:26:02,010 --> 00:26:06,846
You can statically assign it, I like to
statically assign them sometimes just to

488
00:26:06,846 --> 00:26:11,466
be able to remember, it's really easy
to do, you can just say router-id and

489
00:26:11,466 --> 00:26:16,971
then specify what you want it to be, so
maybe I want this one to be 192.168.2.1.

490
00:26:16,971 --> 00:26:18,990
You might as yourself, wait a minute Don.

491
00:26:18,990 --> 00:26:21,350
That's already the router ID,
why would you do that?

492
00:26:21,350 --> 00:26:25,230
By manually putting it in, I can ensure
that this will always be the router ID.

493
00:26:25,230 --> 00:26:29,040
If I get a new higher IP or
something like that this one will stick.

494
00:26:29,040 --> 00:26:31,380
>> The only other way that
this is also done is.

495
00:26:31,380 --> 00:26:35,800
If you assign, we talked about
loop back interfaces before.

496
00:26:35,800 --> 00:26:38,480
It always actually takes a look
at a loop back interface and

497
00:26:38,480 --> 00:26:40,710
whatever the highest
loop back interface is.

498
00:26:40,710 --> 00:26:44,530
So, when a router reboots, usually
loop back interfaces are all ready on.

499
00:26:44,530 --> 00:26:48,830
So, that IP address is actually gonna
be there and a lot of times with OSPF.

500
00:26:48,830 --> 00:26:50,690
That means that's gonna
become your router ID.

501
00:26:50,690 --> 00:26:54,360
But by manually setting it, it makes
it easier for us to actually be able to

502
00:26:54,360 --> 00:26:57,140
identify, especially in a lab environment,
it really helps.

625
00:33:31,577 --> 00:33:32,641
There we go.
It tells me who the neighbor is.

626
00:33:32,641 --> 00:33:36,000
It tells me what their dead time is..

627
00:33:36,000 --> 00:33:38,970
In other words how long it's
been since I've heard from them.

628
00:33:38,970 --> 00:33:40,620
What their IP address is.

629
00:33:40,620 --> 00:33:43,000
And what interface I'm talking to them on.

630
00:33:43,000 --> 00:33:44,140
All right?

631
00:33:44,140 --> 00:33:48,350
There's also some other information
in here like a priority in state.

632
00:33:48,350 --> 00:33:50,540
And we don't really get into those for
the CCENT.

633
00:33:50,540 --> 00:33:53,070
In the CCNA you need to be aware of those.

634
00:33:53,070 --> 00:33:58,500
But basically on any kind of shared
link on an OSPF environment,

635
00:33:58,500 --> 00:34:01,890
somebody, some router,
has to be the master of that link.

636
00:34:01,890 --> 00:34:05,778
And so you have what's called a designated
router and a backup designated router and

637
00:34:05,778 --> 00:34:09,008
other routers, and so they get those
state names attached to them, so

638
00:34:09,008 --> 00:34:11,150
that's what we're seeing there.

639
00:34:11,150 --> 00:34:16,020
But the important part for CCENT is
this first part, when you see full.

640
00:34:16,020 --> 00:34:20,280
That means that you have a full adjacency
between you and the other router.

641
00:34:20,280 --> 00:34:22,630
You're exchanging routes and
everything's good.

642
00:34:22,630 --> 00:34:27,034
If you see other things in there
it usually indicates a problem.

643
00:34:27,034 --> 00:34:27,777
>> Right.

644
00:34:27,777 --> 00:34:31,020
>> All right, so
those are a couple of commands,

645
00:34:31,020 --> 00:34:35,000
there a few others that we could use but
those are the bulk of them.

646
00:34:35,000 --> 00:34:37,130
One I like to use.

647
00:34:37,130 --> 00:34:39,320
If you have a really big routing table,

648
00:34:39,320 --> 00:34:41,870
show IP route can show
you a ton of routes.

649
00:34:41,870 --> 00:34:45,810
You can add the keyword OSPF to
the end and when you do that,

650
00:34:45,810 --> 00:34:48,250
it will only show you the OSPF routes.

651
00:34:48,250 --> 00:34:51,700
So there's another little shortcut
that I use when verifying OSPF.

652
00:34:51,700 --> 00:34:55,190
>> Oh, and that actually brings us to a
nice little point just right here, right?

653
00:34:55,190 --> 00:34:59,520
We really were looking just for
the 2.and the 3.network.

654
00:34:59,520 --> 00:35:02,020
But notice the very first
line that we see in this, and

655
00:35:02,020 --> 00:35:04,630
it actually shows two different routes for
us and so

656
00:35:04,630 --> 00:35:08,650
OSPF also does what we call
equal cost load balancing, too.

657
00:35:08,650 --> 00:35:12,310
>> Yeah, if we go back to the diagram,
router one up here,

658
00:35:12,310 --> 00:35:15,140
what it's doing is it's seeing
this network down here.

659
00:35:15,140 --> 00:35:16,840
And there's two ways to get there.

660
00:35:16,840 --> 00:35:20,370
One way is to go through router two and
one way is to go through router three.

661
00:35:20,370 --> 00:35:22,580
Both of them are 100 megabit links.

662
00:35:22,580 --> 00:35:27,660
So at the end of the day it's got two
ways to get there and they're both equal.

663
00:35:27,660 --> 00:35:28,820
So what does it do?

664
00:35:28,820 --> 00:35:31,030
Sticks both routes in the routing table.

665
00:35:31,030 --> 00:35:34,010
And then the router can load balance,
and so it's load balancing

666
00:35:34,010 --> 00:35:37,210
half the traffic to the 172.16.3
network will go through router two.

667
00:35:37,210 --> 00:35:39,510
The other half will go
through router three.

668
00:35:39,510 --> 00:35:41,510
It takes advantage of
the links that are there.

669
00:35:41,510 --> 00:35:42,310
Really really cool stuff.

670
00:35:42,310 --> 00:35:43,010
>> Yeah, it is.

671
00:35:44,070 --> 00:35:48,920
>> All right, so OSPF is working
good here, it's up, we're happy.

672
00:35:48,920 --> 00:35:51,210
Now let's show the really cool stuff.

673
00:35:51,210 --> 00:35:54,870
OSPF is very, very fast.

674
00:35:54,870 --> 00:35:58,680
It will detect a failure
on the network and

675
00:35:58,680 --> 00:36:03,630
update to reflect that failure,
usually in under two seconds.

676
00:36:03,630 --> 00:36:05,490
Two seconds is extremely fast.

677
00:36:05,490 --> 00:36:10,736
So for example, right now I know
that I can get to the 192.168.2

678
00:36:10,736 --> 00:36:14,460
network by going through 172.16.1.2.

679
00:36:14,460 --> 00:36:16,635
That's router two.

680
00:36:16,635 --> 00:36:18,195
Let me go back to my topology.

681
00:36:18,195 --> 00:36:22,175
So if router one wants to get
to this network over here,

682
00:36:22,175 --> 00:36:26,745
it knows that it can go right across
this link and over to router two, right.

683
00:36:26,745 --> 00:36:28,425
So, it's got that path.

684
00:36:28,425 --> 00:36:29,789
The path is right there.

685
00:36:31,330 --> 00:36:32,260
And off we go.

686
00:36:32,260 --> 00:36:33,100
Okay.

687
00:36:33,100 --> 00:36:35,880
But what if this link were to fail?

688
00:36:35,880 --> 00:36:39,570
If that link were to go offline then

689
00:36:39,570 --> 00:36:44,770
OSPF will have to learn that it
can go the long way to get there.

690
00:36:44,770 --> 00:36:45,570
Okay?

691
00:36:45,570 --> 00:36:47,905
And it does that very, very quickly.

692
00:36:47,905 --> 00:36:48,800
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right?

693
00:36:48,800 --> 00:36:50,870
Let me jump back over to the routers,
and we'll make that happen.

694
00:36:50,870 --> 00:36:55,710
So router one is just gonna stay and
be happy.

695
00:36:55,710 --> 00:36:58,590
It's routing over that
171.116.1.2 interface.

696
00:36:58,590 --> 00:36:59,700
So let me get over to router two.

697
00:36:59,700 --> 00:37:01,190
That's not router two.

698
00:37:02,420 --> 00:37:02,920
That is.

699
00:37:06,090 --> 00:37:06,830
Okay.

700
00:37:06,830 --> 00:37:09,970
So router one is connecting via
this link right here on FA0/0,

701
00:37:09,970 --> 00:37:13,409
I'm gonna shut that interface down.

702
00:37:13,409 --> 00:37:14,737
All right.

703
00:37:14,737 --> 00:37:19,170
So I"m gonna run a shutdown and
that's gonna down that link.

704
00:37:19,170 --> 00:37:25,060
So now router one has lost it's
connection that was in the routing table.

705
00:37:25,060 --> 00:37:28,700
But if I pull up my routing table again,

706
00:37:28,700 --> 00:37:33,423
I can see 172.16.3.0 is still there,

707
00:37:33,423 --> 00:37:40,390
192.168.2.0 is still there and
now it's routed a different way, okay.

708
00:37:40,390 --> 00:37:41,060
>> All right.

709
00:37:41,060 --> 00:37:46,800
>> Just a moment ago,
192.168.2.0 was available

710
00:37:46,800 --> 00:37:52,020
via 172.16.1.2 out the FA0/0 interface.

711
00:37:52,020 --> 00:37:58,150
Now, after the failure, it's available
via 172.16.2.3 out the FA0/1 interface.

712
00:37:58,150 --> 00:38:02,550
It flipped over to the other link.

713
00:38:02,550 --> 00:38:03,790
To be able to get there.

714
00:38:03,790 --> 00:38:05,870
And I can see just now
the neighbors disappearing.

715
00:38:05,870 --> 00:38:07,780
So my dead timer expired.

716
00:38:07,780 --> 00:38:13,230
But if I try and ping that network,
there we go, I can still get to it.

717
00:38:13,230 --> 00:38:14,085
This was part of,

718
00:38:14,085 --> 00:38:18,310
Cisco did this huge marketing campaign
called the self healing network.

719
00:38:18,310 --> 00:38:19,220
And that's what this is.

720
00:38:19,220 --> 00:38:20,740
The network just healed itself.

721
00:38:20,740 --> 00:38:21,980
There's an outage.

722
00:38:21,980 --> 00:38:23,170
It routed around it.

723
00:38:23,170 --> 00:38:26,860
So your end user doesn't realize that
it happened and your system stays up.

724
00:38:26,860 --> 00:38:30,650
>> This is one of those big advantages of
doing this idea of that link state routing

725
00:38:30,650 --> 00:38:31,990
we were talking about.

726
00:38:31,990 --> 00:38:36,280
Where router one actually
already had the entire atlas,

727
00:38:36,280 --> 00:38:38,590
the entire network already in there.

728
00:38:38,590 --> 00:38:40,910
And so when it went down it was
actually able to go ahead and

729
00:38:40,910 --> 00:38:42,370
retrieve it right away.

730
00:38:42,370 --> 00:38:44,930
And able to put it back in and
we were ready to go.

731
00:38:44,930 --> 00:38:45,510
>> Yeah.

732
00:38:45,510 --> 00:38:48,780
And that's all done via what's
called the link state database.

733
00:38:48,780 --> 00:38:52,650
Each router is maintaining a database
of all the links that are out there.

734
00:38:52,650 --> 00:38:55,690
And it runs the shortest path first
algorithm against that database to

735
00:38:55,690 --> 00:38:57,440
construct a map.

736
00:38:57,440 --> 00:38:59,530
Where that router is
the center of the universe.

737
00:38:59,530 --> 00:39:02,740
And then it maps everything
out from its perspective.

738
00:39:02,740 --> 00:39:05,300
Each router in OSPF is doing that for
itself,

739
00:39:05,300 --> 00:39:07,510
making itself the center of the universe.

740
00:39:07,510 --> 00:39:10,840
So by doing that it gets
a better picture but

741
00:39:10,840 --> 00:39:13,650
it is a little more CPU intensive and
all that.

742
00:39:13,650 --> 00:39:17,070
If you're running a mid range or
higher router it does it no problem so

743
00:39:18,070 --> 00:39:20,480
it's not really something
that we have to sweat.

744
00:39:20,480 --> 00:39:22,730
But you can actually see
the link state database,

745
00:39:22,730 --> 00:39:25,320
it's not the easiest thing
in the world to read.

746
00:39:25,320 --> 00:39:28,370
By doing show IP OSPF Database.

747
00:39:28,370 --> 00:39:29,630
There it is.

748
00:39:29,630 --> 00:39:31,440
Whoops.
Datavase.

749
00:39:31,440 --> 00:39:33,430
It's a pot, it's got flowers in it.

750
00:39:33,430 --> 00:39:34,321
And there we go.

751
00:39:34,321 --> 00:39:39,243
So if I do a show IP OSPF database, here's
the various links that are in the network.

752
00:39:39,243 --> 00:39:42,808
And so as it goes down the line I can see
some of the routers that it's talked to

753
00:39:42,808 --> 00:39:44,444
and the links that it's learned.

754
00:39:44,444 --> 00:39:46,836
And so it's got unpopulated in here.

755
00:39:46,836 --> 00:39:52,100
So I can see the 192.168.1, 2, and
3 routers that are participating in OSPF.

756
00:39:52,100 --> 00:39:54,785
And if I jump to each
of the other routers.

757
00:39:54,785 --> 00:39:56,180
>> Hm-mm.
>> They should have the same thing.

758
00:39:56,180 --> 00:39:57,080
It should be converged.

759
00:39:57,080 --> 00:40:01,520
They should all have the same data.

760
00:40:01,520 --> 00:40:02,400
>> Yeah.
>> All right, let's see.

761
00:40:02,400 --> 00:40:03,530
What else do we have?

762
00:40:03,530 --> 00:40:07,340
Oh, and it'll recover from the outage so
on Router 2,

763
00:40:07,340 --> 00:40:12,620
if I bring that interface back up again,
the interface is gonna come up and

764
00:40:12,620 --> 00:40:17,550
Router 1 is going to
redirect back over it again.

765
00:40:17,550 --> 00:40:25,260
So when I do that show IP route OSPF,
right now it's routing that over Fa0/1.

766
00:40:25,260 --> 00:40:28,570
And if I give it just a moment,
it's going to detect that new route and

767
00:40:28,570 --> 00:40:32,140
it will flip back to being
over at phase 0/0 again.

768
00:40:32,140 --> 00:40:35,520
Now it doesn't do it instantly
because the routers have what's called

769
00:40:35,520 --> 00:40:36,810
flat protection.

770
00:40:36,810 --> 00:40:39,560
Sometimes you can have
a route that's unstable.

771
00:40:39,560 --> 00:40:42,220
It comes up and goes back down,
comes up and goes back down.

772
00:40:42,220 --> 00:40:44,020
So, it doesn't want to
fail over immediately.

773
00:40:44,020 --> 00:40:47,530
It uses a hold down timer to say
I'm gonna hold that route down.

774
00:40:47,530 --> 00:40:50,440
I'm gonna suppress it until
I'm sure it's stable.

775
00:40:50,440 --> 00:40:54,540
I don't remember, is it 30 seconds or
60 seconds on the default timer?

776
00:40:54,540 --> 00:40:56,370
I don't remember that one
on the default timer.

777
00:40:56,370 --> 00:40:57,120
>> I don't either.

778
00:40:57,120 --> 00:40:59,700
Let me see.

779
00:40:59,700 --> 00:41:03,430
I'm running a command here show ipospf1

780
00:41:03,430 --> 00:41:07,710
that gives you all the detailed
information about that OSPF process.

781
00:41:07,710 --> 00:41:10,160
And in here you can find the downtimers.

782
00:41:10,160 --> 00:41:16,103
And so you'll see, like, how often it runs
the algorithm, every 5 seconds, and so on.

783
00:41:16,103 --> 00:41:19,763
And in here somewhere,
we'll find the hold downtimers.

784
00:41:21,640 --> 00:41:22,860
It's buried in here somewhere.

785
00:41:22,860 --> 00:41:24,948
By the time I find it,
we'll have exceeded the timer.

786
00:41:24,948 --> 00:41:25,596
[LAUGH].

787
00:41:25,596 --> 00:41:26,244
>> [LAUGH].

788
00:41:26,244 --> 00:41:27,938
>> That's how it normally works at least.

789
00:41:27,938 --> 00:41:32,690
>> Is that 10,000 milliseconds,
was that what it was up above?

790
00:41:32,690 --> 00:41:33,930
>> Oh, did I go past it.

791
00:41:33,930 --> 00:41:35,963
>> I don't know.
>> Up there where it says,

792
00:41:35,963 --> 00:41:39,220
num hold town between 2 consecutive SPFs.

793
00:41:39,220 --> 00:41:40,740
>> That's just in between
running the algorithm.

794
00:41:40,740 --> 00:41:41,620
>> Okay.
>> Well running

795
00:41:41,620 --> 00:41:44,170
the algorithm is where it'll find it, so.

796
00:41:44,170 --> 00:41:45,870
Well anyhow, I'm sure it's done by now.

797
00:41:45,870 --> 00:41:47,300
Let's go ahead and look.

798
00:41:47,300 --> 00:41:48,140
And yup, sure enough.

799
00:41:48,140 --> 00:41:49,140
192, 168, flipped over to fa0/0.

800
00:41:49,140 --> 00:41:53,640
So just enough time passes to make

801
00:41:53,640 --> 00:41:58,310
sure that everything's stable, flips over,
and now we're routing back over that way.

802
00:41:58,310 --> 00:42:00,110
So the router heals itself.

803
00:42:00,110 --> 00:42:01,780
It works around the failure.

804
00:42:01,780 --> 00:42:04,580
And then when you fix the failure,
the router rights itself again.

805
00:42:04,580 --> 00:42:07,160
Puts it back to the way that it was,
and it's up and it's happy.

806
00:42:08,940 --> 00:42:14,670
All right now, all of that so
far has really all been IP version 4.

807
00:42:14,670 --> 00:42:21,130
But for the exam, Cisco does want us to
be familiar with IP version 6 also, okay?

808
00:42:21,130 --> 00:42:25,180
And IP version 6,
not very difficult to get configured,

809
00:42:25,180 --> 00:42:29,470
but we do need to assign some IP addresses
and some other things to get in place.

810
00:42:29,470 --> 00:42:32,680
So if we want to run IPv6 in our network,

811
00:42:32,680 --> 00:42:34,920
we are gonna have to
create some entries here.

812
00:42:36,420 --> 00:42:39,190
We don't have any IPv6 addresses
assigned to these routers.

813
00:42:39,190 --> 00:42:40,200
So we need to do that.

814
00:42:40,200 --> 00:42:43,930
Maybe we'll do that during the instead
of kinda drawing it out here.

815
00:42:43,930 --> 00:42:47,190
Have we tackled all the OSPF
stuff as far as IPv4?

816
00:42:47,190 --> 00:42:50,400
Let me just check my objectives here.

817
00:42:50,400 --> 00:42:54,700
We did router IDs, we did passive
interfaces, we talked about single area.

818
00:42:54,700 --> 00:42:58,220
The only thing we really didn't
mention was like debugging OSPF.

819
00:42:59,900 --> 00:43:04,850
If OSPF is working right, if everything
is working the way that it's supposed to,

820
00:43:04,850 --> 00:43:06,730
you don't really have to do much, right?

821
00:43:06,730 --> 00:43:08,570
But if something goes wrong and

822
00:43:08,570 --> 00:43:13,270
you have to troubleshoot it,
there's several debug commands we can run.

823
00:43:13,270 --> 00:43:17,860
And the debug commands are really
neat because it let's you see stuff

824
00:43:17,860 --> 00:43:22,520
that's going on in the background
that you don't normally see.

825
00:43:22,520 --> 00:43:26,800
So for example debug IP ospf.

826
00:43:26,800 --> 00:43:30,420
And then you can limit it by
process number if you want.

827
00:43:30,420 --> 00:43:33,010
ADJ this is the one that I normally use.

828
00:43:33,010 --> 00:43:36,380
If for some reason 2 routers
aren't talking to each other.

829
00:43:36,380 --> 00:43:42,160
If I debug their OSPF information and
I tell it to show me adjacency data.

830
00:43:42,160 --> 00:43:45,450
That'll show me what i'm trying to with
the neighbor and if there is an issue,

831
00:43:45,450 --> 00:43:49,540
it will usually tell me what the issue is,
so that I can fix it.

832
00:43:49,540 --> 00:43:53,640
So, for example,
I'm going to turn on that debugging and

833
00:43:53,640 --> 00:43:57,970
I'm going to create an issue,
let me jump over to router two and

834
00:43:59,960 --> 00:44:06,290
I need to mess with 00 [INAUDIBLE]
I'm

835
00:44:06,290 --> 00:44:08,800
gonna put this one in
a different area number.

836
00:44:08,800 --> 00:44:11,700
So I'm gonna take router 2 and
move it to area 5.

837
00:44:11,700 --> 00:44:13,720
All of our other routers are in area 0.

838
00:44:13,720 --> 00:44:16,910
So I'm gonna have an area mismatch, okay?

839
00:44:16,910 --> 00:44:19,750
So when I do that,
that link is gonna go down.

840
00:44:19,750 --> 00:44:22,869
And back over here,
where I'm doing my debugging.

841
00:44:25,350 --> 00:44:28,260
You know what I should do, I should shut
the interface down, well, there we go.

842
00:44:28,260 --> 00:44:34,690
I can see right here, I just received
a packet from 172.16.1.2, that's router 2.

843
00:44:34,690 --> 00:44:38,410
I'm in area 0 and I'm getting a mismatch.

844
00:44:38,410 --> 00:44:41,520
The area I'm receiving
is area 5 in the header.

845
00:44:41,520 --> 00:44:42,180
Okay?

846
00:44:42,180 --> 00:44:43,290
And so now I can see.

847
00:44:43,290 --> 00:44:46,840
So I might be saying, hey,
why am I not building up an adjacency?

848
00:44:46,840 --> 00:44:53,428
Why, when I pull up my OSPF neighbors,
do I not see router 2?

849
00:44:53,428 --> 00:44:54,039
>> Hm-mm.

850
00:44:54,039 --> 00:44:54,860
>> All right?

851
00:44:54,860 --> 00:44:59,170
I turn on my debug, and here, I can see
those packets coming in every 10 seconds.

852
00:44:59,170 --> 00:45:02,460
OSPF defaults sends hello
message every 10 seconds.

853
00:45:02,460 --> 00:45:06,550
So every 10 seconds I'm getting
a message from that other router and

854
00:45:06,550 --> 00:45:08,210
the header's not matching.

855
00:45:08,210 --> 00:45:11,400
So I can look right there,
I can see I've got this area mismatch.

856
00:45:11,400 --> 00:45:12,550
I can go and fix it.

00:46:08,400 --> 00:46:09,880
The hello timer, or

00:46:09,880 --> 00:46:14,430

often your router introduces itself.

877
00:46:14,430 --> 00:46:17,040
And by default OSPF does every 10 seconds.

878
00:46:17,040 --> 00:46:20,230

there that's set to something different,

879
00:46:20,230 --> 00:46:21,970

00:46:21,970 --> 00:46:24,050

00:46:24,050 --> 00:46:26,230

00:46:26,230 --> 00:46:30,870
the dead timer is normally three times
the hello interval and it basically just

883
00:46:30,870 --> 00:46:34,980
says if I miss 3 hello messages then
I'll consider the neighbor to be dead.

884
00:46:34,980 --> 00:46:35,900

00:46:35,900 --> 00:46:38,420

00:46:38,420 --> 00:46:41,380
So normally after 30 seconds we
flag the neighbor as being offline.

887
00:46:41,380 --> 00:46:43,680
Okay, so
that's kind of the way it happens.

00:46:43,680 --> 00:46:48,910

01:05:30,940 --> 01:05:34,669

01:05:39,280 --> 01:05:42,150

01:05:42,150 --> 01:05:46,020
It is a common thing for

01:05:46,020 --> 01:05:47,970
You wanna route between them.

01:05:47,970 --> 01:05:50,435
The best solution, a layer three switch.

1265
01:05:50,435 --> 01:05:53,780
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]
>> If you have a switch that has a router

01:05:53,780 --> 01:05:57,290

job routing between the VLANs.

01:05:58,570 --> 01:06:01,360

01:06:10,010 --> 01:06:14,110

01:06:14,110 --> 01:06:17,090
Remember, if we go back to

1273
01:06:17,090 --> 01:06:20,660

cannot communicate between each other

01:06:20,660 --> 01:06:22,840

01:06:22,840 --> 01:06:26,360
And we have a couple was that we can do

01:06:26,360 --> 01:06:29,320

01:06:29,320 --> 01:06:33,840
Which means instead of using multiple

01:06:33,840 --> 01:06:37,180

a router may only have two or

01:06:37,180 --> 01:06:38,130
three interfaces.

01:06:38,130 --> 01:06:38,860
>> Good point.

01:06:38,860 --> 01:06:40,770
what I may ask you to be able to do or

01:06:40,770 --> 01:06:45,210
what I can do, I should say,

01:06:45,210 --> 01:06:49,240
plug it into one port on the switch,
plug it in to the actual router and

1284
01:06:49,240 --> 01:06:52,240
be able to route between those VLANs

1285
01:06:52,240 --> 01:06:54,460

If you only had two VLANs,

1286
01:06:54,460 --> 01:06:57,520
you could take a router with two
interfaces, plug one into one VLAN,

1287
01:06:57,520 --> 01:06:59,090
plug one into the other and

01:06:59,090 --> 01:07:01,220
But what if you have 50 VLANs?

01:07:01,220 --> 01:07:02,650

1290
01:07:02,650 --> 01:07:03,570

1291
01:07:03,570 --> 01:07:06,360

1292
01:07:06,360 --> 01:07:10,103
Better would be to have a router

1293
01:07:10,103 --> 01:07:12,980

1294
01:07:12,980 --> 01:07:16,970
Now, Cisco routers are not
VLAN aware by default.

1295
01:07:16,970 --> 01:07:19,060
VLAN is a layer two thing,
it's a switch thing,

1296
01:07:19,060 --> 01:07:20,880
so routers don't get involved in that.

1297
01:07:20,880 --> 01:07:24,021
Routers don't run spanning three
protocol,they don't run VTP,

1298
01:07:24,021 --> 01:07:26,170
the virtual trunking protocol.

1299
01:07:26,170 --> 01:07:31,490
They don't run really any trunking
protocols at all by default.

1300
01:07:31,490 --> 01:07:35,230
But you can tell the router that it's
going to be participating in that kind of

1301
01:07:35,230 --> 01:07:37,070
