1312
01:08:11,940 --> 01:08:16,760
cable into the switch, every VLAN on
that single switch should be able to use

1313
01:08:16,760 --> 01:08:22,470
that same link going to the router to
be able to send information up there.

1314
01:08:22,470 --> 01:08:24,380
So, that is what we're
gonna spend our time doing.

1315
01:08:24,380 --> 01:08:27,680
And what we're talking about
now with inter VLAN routing,

1316
01:08:27,680 --> 01:08:32,180
is that we have two technologies that we
really actually have to think about here.

1317
01:08:32,180 --> 01:08:37,260
One by default, a router doesn't like to
actually have to send information to that

1318
01:08:37,260 --> 01:08:39,115
one physical interface, and

1319
01:08:39,115 --> 01:08:42,960
its destination come back out
that same interface as well.

1320
01:08:42,960 --> 01:08:46,840
So, we end up dealing with something
that we call split horizon.

1321
01:08:46,840 --> 01:08:49,320
I couldn't remember what it was called for
a moment here.

1322
01:08:49,320 --> 01:08:51,650
And so, we can overcome that,

1323
01:08:51,650 --> 01:08:56,630
and the way that we overcome that is by
logically dividing up a physical port.

1324
01:08:56,630 --> 01:09:00,490
So, we're not really taking one port and
then actually chopping it up here.

1325
01:09:00,490 --> 01:09:02,530
But what we're doing is
we're fooling the software.

1326
01:09:02,530 --> 01:09:04,640
We're actually saying hey,
we're gonna take this one port and

1327
01:09:04,640 --> 01:09:08,210
we're gonna treat it as multiple
ports here, is what we're gonna do.

1328
01:09:08,210 --> 01:09:13,570
>> So, what I've got right here is
router one and it's Fa1/1 interface.

1329
01:09:13,570 --> 01:09:17,030
I've got it with an IP
address of 192.168.1.1.

1330
01:09:17,030 --> 01:09:19,160
It's class C network, so
that's connection there.

1331
01:09:20,280 --> 01:09:22,130
This is what we would
normally see in a router,

1332
01:09:22,130 --> 01:09:24,130
configuration right on the interface.

1333
01:09:24,130 --> 01:09:28,890
But Ronnie mentioned breaking up
that interface into sub-interfaces.

1334
01:09:28,890 --> 01:09:32,990
If we do that, we can start attaching
the sub interfaces to different,

1335
01:09:32,990 --> 01:09:35,460
virtual networks, to different VLANs.

1336
01:09:35,460 --> 01:09:39,650
So, let's say, that this router was
plugged into a trunk port on a switch.

1337
01:09:39,650 --> 01:09:41,179
And it was connected to 192.168.2.0 or

1338
01:09:41,179 --> 01:09:44,660
192.168.3.0, it was
connected to all of those.

1339
01:09:44,660 --> 01:09:50,210
So, what we would do is on this router,

1340
01:09:50,210 --> 01:09:53,990
we would jump into that particular
interface and we would get it set up for

1341
01:09:53,990 --> 01:09:57,830
what's called the native VLAN,
the untagged VLAN.

1342
01:09:57,830 --> 01:10:00,170
Normally, VLAN1 for most people.

1343
01:10:00,170 --> 01:10:04,030
But then, every other VLAN,
I would set up on a sub interface.

1344
01:10:04,030 --> 01:10:11,000
So, I would say,
interface Fa1/1.2 for VLAN2.

1345
01:10:12,330 --> 01:10:16,280
The sub-interface number doesn't actually
matter, you pick whatever you want.

1346
01:10:16,280 --> 01:10:19,720
But it's a good idea to have it match the
VLAN number just to keep things straight.

1347
01:10:19,720 --> 01:10:22,670
So, you don't have to but
it is a good idea.

1348
01:10:22,670 --> 01:10:25,350
So, I'll get into interface Fa1/1.2.

1349
01:10:25,350 --> 01:10:28,460
If I try and assign an IP address,
it's not gonna let me.

1350
01:10:28,460 --> 01:10:29,750
>> Nope.
>> Or at least, it shouldn't.

1351
01:10:29,750 --> 01:10:33,816
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's try it here.

1352
01:10:33,816 --> 01:10:36,557
So, it's gonna get mad
because it's gonna say, hey,

1353
01:10:36,557 --> 01:10:38,900
you're not a trunk port or
anything like that.

1354
01:10:38,900 --> 01:10:43,030
You're just a regular sub-interface,
you can't assign an IP address.

1355
01:10:43,030 --> 01:10:45,470
So, what I have to do
is I have to tell it.

1356
01:10:45,470 --> 01:10:47,690
>> You have to spell encap.

1357
01:10:47,690 --> 01:10:50,690
>> Oh, well, I'm trying to save
money by typing less letters.

1358
01:10:50,690 --> 01:10:51,610
>> That's right.

1359
01:10:51,610 --> 01:10:55,505
>> So, you have to tell it that
it's connected to a switch

1360
01:10:55,505 --> 01:10:58,517
that's running 802.1q trunking.

1361
01:10:58,517 --> 01:11:03,300
Now, notice up here it says ISL,
very few systems support ISL anymore.

1362
01:11:03,300 --> 01:11:05,160
So, encapsulation dot 1q and

1363
01:11:05,160 --> 01:11:09,830
then you have to tell it which VLAN
is attached to this interface.

1364
01:11:09,830 --> 01:11:14,351
And this where I mention the sub-interface
number doesn't really matter because it's

1365
01:11:14,351 --> 01:11:16,890
this number right here
that determines the VLAN.

1366
01:11:16,890 --> 01:11:21,324
But really, you normally want them to
match just so you can keep them straight.

1367
01:11:21,324 --> 01:11:26,241
Now, it knows, this is going
to be attached to a trunk And

1368
01:11:26,241 --> 01:11:28,198
it's VLAN number 2.

1369
01:11:28,198 --> 01:11:31,833
>> Make sure you remember that last number
is going to be more important when you do

1370
01:11:31,833 --> 01:11:34,000
configure for inner VLAN routing.

1371
01:11:34,000 --> 01:11:36,655
If you forget it, the good thing is
that on a real router it will tell you,

1372
01:11:36,655 --> 01:11:38,370
you're not complete with it.

1373
01:11:38,370 --> 01:11:41,150
But, on the exam,
you may not get that opportunity.

1374
01:11:41,150 --> 01:11:43,830
So remember that last number's
going to be very important.

1375
01:11:43,830 --> 01:11:47,480
>> And now when I attach my
IP address to it, it's happy.

1376
01:11:47,480 --> 01:11:52,450
And I can keep going creating my
other interfaces the same way.

1377
01:11:52,450 --> 01:11:56,090
So however many VLAN's that I have,
I might have a ton of them.

1378
01:11:57,880 --> 01:11:59,670
And I'm just going to go through.

1379
01:11:59,670 --> 01:12:04,090
I'm basically creating the interface,
assigning the VLAN number, and

1380
01:12:04,090 --> 01:12:06,050
then assigning the IP address.

1381
01:12:06,050 --> 01:12:07,670
Then I just rinse and repeat.

1382
01:12:07,670 --> 01:12:10,370
Keep going through,
you can create as many as you need.

1383
01:12:10,370 --> 01:12:12,870
The virtual interface is
not physical interfaces,

1384
01:12:12,870 --> 01:12:15,230
these aren't costing us any money.

1385
01:12:15,230 --> 01:12:19,450
Just keep in mind that this is not
really for high performance networks.

1386
01:12:19,450 --> 01:12:23,300
Traffic has to go in the port,
get routed to the other VLAN,

1387
01:12:23,300 --> 01:12:25,290
and then come back out the port again.

1388
01:12:25,290 --> 01:12:30,100
So, it's kind of a whole up and
down the same cable process,

1389
01:12:30,100 --> 01:12:32,950
which is not all that efficient
at the end of the day.

1390
01:12:32,950 --> 01:12:40,420
So, as I create each one of these though,
I can see in a show IP interface brief.

1391
01:12:40,420 --> 01:12:41,936
Here's all those interfaces.

1392
01:12:41,936 --> 01:12:43,316
Whoops, that's not what I wanted.

1393
01:12:43,316 --> 01:12:49,240
All those interfaces that I'm
connected to, the VLAN 1, 2, 3 and 4.

1394
01:12:49,240 --> 01:12:51,220
They each have their own addresses.

1395
01:12:51,220 --> 01:12:54,520
But it's all splitting
that single interface.

1396
01:12:54,520 --> 01:13:00,240
And if I do a show IP route, I can see
all of those networks in there and I've

1397
01:13:00,240 --> 01:13:06,420
got microconnected, and let me filter that
down a little bit to just do connected.

1398
01:13:06,420 --> 01:13:10,750
Those local ones, oh,
shoot, let me do this.

1399
01:13:10,750 --> 01:13:15,990
Let me exclude anything
with a capital L in it.

1400
01:13:15,990 --> 01:13:16,850
There we go.

1401
01:13:16,850 --> 01:13:20,930
So now I can start to see those locals and

1402
01:13:20,930 --> 01:13:25,970
I can see each route right there and
they're all tied to those sub interfaces.

1403
01:13:25,970 --> 01:13:30,130
That lets us use that one router
to route for more than one VLAN.

1404
01:13:30,130 --> 01:13:31,010
Very, very cool stuff.

1405
01:13:31,010 --> 01:13:31,740
>> Yeah.

1406
01:13:31,740 --> 01:13:35,090
The only physical thing to remember here
is that we wanna make sure that this

1407
01:13:35,090 --> 01:13:38,820
particular port is at least a fast
ethernet port on the router.

1408
01:13:38,820 --> 01:13:40,740
If you try and do it on ethernet port,

1409
01:13:40,740 --> 01:13:43,260
you're probably gonna actually find
more problems than you realize.

1410
01:13:43,260 --> 01:13:46,710
So at least a fast ethernet,
a gigabit port if you can spare it.

1411
01:13:46,710 --> 01:13:50,270
>> Let me draw a picture here real quick
to kinda show what happens, right?

1412
01:13:50,270 --> 01:13:58,570
So we have a router and so
I'll just draw my router over here.

1413
01:13:58,570 --> 01:13:59,980
And this will be router 1.

1414
01:13:59,980 --> 01:14:03,830
And then the router,
it has to be plugged into a switch, right?

1415
01:14:03,830 --> 01:14:08,890
And so, whoops, and so that switch, it's
gonna have however many ports that your

1416
01:14:08,890 --> 01:14:13,990
various PCs are plugged into, so everybody
gets plugged into their various ports.

1417
01:14:15,040 --> 01:14:21,585
Now the router only has one connection,
one cable that runs over to it.

1418
01:14:21,585 --> 01:14:27,115
So if I start to divide my switch
up into VLAN, so if I have like,

1419
01:14:27,115 --> 01:14:31,185
this guy right here might be VLAN 1.

1420
01:14:31,185 --> 01:14:36,980
And then I might have, these guys
over here in VLAN 2, for example.

1421
01:14:39,240 --> 01:14:39,810
Okay.

1422
01:14:39,810 --> 01:14:44,200
So if I start to divide things up
like that, well, that's fine, and

1423
01:14:44,200 --> 01:14:48,590
my trunk cable right over here,
it can carry VLANs 1 and 2, so

1424
01:14:48,590 --> 01:14:50,870
I just create my sub
interfaces on the router.

1425
01:14:50,870 --> 01:14:51,740
All right.

1426
01:14:51,740 --> 01:14:58,086
But if a PC on VLAN 1 wants to talk to
a PC on VLAN 2, what's gonna happen?

1427
01:14:58,086 --> 01:15:02,300
Well, the PC sends it's data in on VLAN 1.

1428
01:15:02,300 --> 01:15:06,340
It then gets sent all
the way up to the router.

1429
01:15:06,340 --> 01:15:10,390
The router then routes it
over to the other VLAN.

1430
01:15:10,390 --> 01:15:12,170
And then it comes back down to that host.

1431
01:15:12,170 --> 01:15:16,034
So see how the data went up the cable and
back down the cable again and

1432
01:15:16,034 --> 01:15:20,592
then the reply from the other host is
doing the same thing when it replies back.

1433
01:15:20,592 --> 01:15:22,767
It's gotta go up the cable and

1434
01:15:22,767 --> 01:15:28,200
back down the cable so you end up
crossing up and down the same cable.

1435
01:15:28,200 --> 01:15:31,860
Ronnie said make sure it's at least
fast ethernet because if you do,

1436
01:15:31,860 --> 01:15:33,840
you can make sure that you do full duplex.

1437
01:15:33,840 --> 01:15:35,810
You can send and receive at the same time.

1438
01:15:35,810 --> 01:15:40,220
But, every host communicating between
the VLANs is gonna hit this bottleneck

1439
01:15:40,220 --> 01:15:41,150
right here.

1440
01:15:41,150 --> 01:15:44,600
So it's a big bottleneck,
it really hurts performance.

1441
01:15:44,600 --> 01:15:49,050
And so in an enterprise environment,
that is not ideal.

1442
01:15:49,050 --> 01:15:51,562
If you've got 10 machines or
20 machines, it's not a big deal.

1443
01:15:51,562 --> 01:15:55,400
But if you've got 1,000 machines,
it's a huge performance bottleneck.

1444
01:15:57,170 --> 01:15:58,880
So that is something we
need to keep in mind.

1445
01:15:58,880 --> 01:16:03,770
And that's where if this router right
here can be built into the switch,

1446
01:16:03,770 --> 01:16:07,220
right, if it's built in where
the switch is able to do its

1447
01:16:07,220 --> 01:16:10,830
own routing between those VLAN's,
that's a different story, right.

1448
01:16:10,830 --> 01:16:14,340
It can do that very fast, it can do that
right inside the hardware of the switch.

1449
01:16:14,340 --> 01:16:15,370
And it's not a performance hit.

1450
01:16:15,370 --> 01:16:19,780
And that's where layer 3 switches come in,
which we'll see in the CCNA show.

1451
01:16:19,780 --> 01:16:22,640
You know, the whole thing,
it's got a silly name.

1452
01:16:22,640 --> 01:16:24,000
It sounds like something we made up.

1453
01:16:24,000 --> 01:16:26,490
Router on a stick.

1454
01:16:26,490 --> 01:16:30,100
But that is the official name for
the technology, router on a stick.

1455
01:16:30,100 --> 01:16:33,600
And it just comes from the idea that
you've just one cable to the stick, so

1456
01:16:33,600 --> 01:16:36,530
that's it, from the one cable to
the router, so it's a single link.

1457
01:16:36,530 --> 01:16:39,340
>> It always reminds me of a lollipop,
is what it reminds me of.

1458
01:16:39,340 --> 01:16:41,000
>> Yes.
>> Sticking out of the switch.

1459
01:16:41,000 --> 01:16:43,220
When you draw a diagram of it.

1460
01:16:43,220 --> 01:16:44,990
>> Yes, and that is basically it, and

1461
01:16:44,990 --> 01:16:46,690
your router would just have
to have one interface.

1462
01:16:46,690 --> 01:16:49,120
Now I don't know that you can find
a router anywhere that just has one

1463
01:16:49,120 --> 01:16:51,610
interface, but
that is really all you would need.

1464
01:16:51,610 --> 01:16:52,440
Normally, we have more.

1465
01:16:52,440 --> 01:16:53,390
>> Right.
>> So,

1466
01:16:53,390 --> 01:16:55,830
let me go back to
the router that we setup.

1467
01:16:55,830 --> 01:16:58,280
And I just want to show everybody,
so that you can see it,

1468
01:16:58,280 --> 01:17:01,116
what the final configuration looks like,
and

1469
01:17:01,116 --> 01:17:05,660
kind of get an idea of that
more general application.

1470
01:17:05,660 --> 01:17:08,600
So, there it is.

1471
01:17:08,600 --> 01:17:12,590
So, basically, the final configuration for
the interfaces.

1472
01:17:12,590 --> 01:17:15,649
You know, let me, I'm gonna move it in to
Notepad where its a little easier to see.

1473
01:17:26,316 --> 01:17:27,400
There we go.

1474
01:17:27,400 --> 01:17:32,333
So basically,
we went into interface FA 1/1.

1475
01:17:32,333 --> 01:17:35,850
And this is where you assign the IP
address for your native VLAN,

1476
01:17:35,850 --> 01:17:37,489
your untagged VLAN, right?

1477
01:17:37,489 --> 01:17:40,590
So whatever is native, by default, it's 1.

1478
01:17:40,590 --> 01:17:44,330
But if you've changed to something else,
then that's what this would match.

1479
01:17:44,330 --> 01:17:47,722
And then down here are all your
tagged VLAN's, everything else.

1480
01:17:47,722 --> 01:17:52,200
VLAN 2, VLAN 3, VLAN 4,
we create a subinterface.

1481
01:17:52,200 --> 01:17:55,970
The encapsulation line is the most
important because it's what attaches

1482
01:17:55,970 --> 01:17:58,950
the VLAN,
this subinterface number is just a number.

1483
01:17:58,950 --> 01:18:00,440
You can pick whatever number you wanted.

1484
01:18:00,440 --> 01:18:04,100
I think it's got a maximum of like 4
million because it's a 32 bit number.

1485
01:18:04,100 --> 01:18:08,040
But there are four billion,
something like that.

1486
01:18:08,040 --> 01:18:09,670
But that's basically it.

1487
01:18:09,670 --> 01:18:10,980
Not all that much to it.

1488
01:18:10,980 --> 01:18:14,870
>> Now, the only thing to remember just in
general networking terms, is that these

1489
01:18:14,870 --> 01:18:18,460
particular numbers are these IP addresses
that we attached to the interfaces.

1490
01:18:18,460 --> 01:18:23,500
Sub interfaces here are typically
going to be the default gateway for

1491
01:18:23,500 --> 01:18:25,750
our internal devices here, okay?

1492
01:18:25,750 --> 01:18:29,020
If we have a different default gateway,
we're probably not actually be able to

1493
01:18:29,020 --> 01:18:31,850
route between our VLAN, so
make sure you remember that too.

episodes.description: Network address translation is a very widely used technology that allows packets to be routed across the network, even if one is using a private IP address. Viewers will hear about network address translation and the three possible implementations on Cisco equipment and when to use them.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation

translation helps us out.

It allows us to take those private

network address translation to translate

The ones that are registered

00:07:04,520 --> 00:07:10,240

135
00:07:27,266 --> 00:07:29,892

00:07:29,892 --> 00:07:34,347
So, for example, if my laptop

Now the Internet is gonna see traffic

144
00:08:08,330 --> 00:08:12,910
And when the host out on the Internet

00:08:12,910 --> 00:08:17,620
turn right back around and come to

00:08:17,620 --> 00:08:20,770
oh yeah, that's right,
I translated that from Don's laptop, and

send it the rest of the way in so

00:08:24,190 --> 00:08:26,790
Proper, full communications, right?

00:08:26,790 --> 00:08:32,500
So the actual definition of NAT

00:08:32,500 --> 00:08:38,822

All right so,

This isn't going to be the prettiest,

Which is gonna be the IP

Now the IP address, as the source IP and
the destination IP,

that's the layer three

Then we got our layer two information,

you know that's going to

When it passes through the router, the

All right, so NAT is going to

this is where we're NAT occurs,

so this is my NAT line.

In my head it looked a lot better,

That's where my NAT's happening.

And after NAT happens, well,
things are a little bit different.

00:10:45,540 --> 00:10:46,040
We.

Well, that didn't work at all.

We basically take our source IP here,
this, [LAUGH] oh,

my mastery of this tool is not where it

The source IP will become
209.251.133.187 and the destination IP.

00:11:14,718 --> 00:11:22,310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nice.

There we go.

00:11:23,270 --> 00:11:23,990
>> Will stay the same.

191

The destination IP stays

Amazon already has a public IP, right?

So it's a real registered IP,

That's what it gets turned into.

All right.

So now we go out on the Internet,

Data goes out, data comes back and

And it then does reverse net

It turns that public IP

I've got a private address and and my

if you're not a big fan of monkeys or

That's because I'm getting natted,

my address is being changed from

00:14:23,818 --> 00:14:27,369

244
00:14:27,369 --> 00:14:32,297
the packet leaves my particular computer
with my private IP address, the router

00:14:32,297 --> 00:14:36,791
itself is actually what translates
that into that public IP address, and

246
00:14:36,791 --> 00:14:39,850
then that web server that we just hit,

00:14:39,850 --> 00:14:41,275
When it returned it,

248
00:14:41,275 --> 00:14:46,160
it changed the destination to

249
00:14:46,160 --> 00:14:48,930
>> Yeah because it has no idea

250
00:14:48,930 --> 00:14:49,800
it never even saw that.

251
00:14:49,800 --> 00:14:50,630
>> Yeah.
And so,

252
00:14:50,630 --> 00:14:53,890
that's all due to the fact of

253
00:14:53,890 --> 00:14:57,090
So it makes our packets be able to be
router on the Internet even if I have

254
00:14:57,090 --> 00:15:01,150
that private IP address again it really
does help us out tremendously here.

255
00:15:01,150 --> 00:15:03,330
>> And what's really cool is
if you're like a home user and

256
00:15:03,330 --> 00:15:05,750
you've got 10 computers at home,
hopefully you don't.

257
00:15:05,750 --> 00:15:06,501
So,
>> Yeah.

258
00:15:06,501 --> 00:15:08,041
So we'll use me as an example.

259
00:15:08,041 --> 00:15:11,400
So I've got three Roku boxes at home and

260
00:15:11,400 --> 00:15:14,460
my laptop, and my wife's laptop and
our cell phones.

261
00:15:14,460 --> 00:15:19,140
So those are all devices so all in all I
guess I've got like seven devices at home.

262
00:15:19,140 --> 00:15:23,890
Well I have a service provider that's
our cable company so we have cable,

263
00:15:23,890 --> 00:15:28,390
high speed Internet and
they only give us one public IP.

264
00:15:28,390 --> 00:15:31,290
So I run that cable modem
into my firewall, and

265
00:15:31,290 --> 00:15:33,398
my firewall gets that one, public IP.

266
00:15:33,398 --> 00:15:37,595
Meanwhile my seven devices
are all behind the firewall.

267
00:15:37,595 --> 00:15:40,915
The firewall does network
address translation so

268
00:15:40,915 --> 00:15:44,215
that all of our devices get
translated into that one IP.

269
00:15:44,215 --> 00:15:46,895
And out on the Internet they just think
it's one computer, they think it's that

270
00:15:46,895 --> 00:15:49,665
one system, my firewall,
going out and browsing the Internet.

271
00:15:49,665 --> 00:15:55,887
When in reality, I've got several machines
that are sharing a single IP, all right?

272
00:15:55,887 --> 00:15:57,799
And that concept is called overloading.

273
00:15:57,799 --> 00:16:02,328
>> We're overloading the IP and IP
address is designed to carry traffic for

274
00:16:02,328 --> 00:16:04,705
one machine, and one machine only but

275
00:16:04,705 --> 00:16:07,838
when most people do NAT
they also do overloading.

276
00:16:07,838 --> 00:16:11,379
And they jam more than one
machine behind a single IP.

277
00:16:11,379 --> 00:16:14,928
So that's an important concept which we're
gonna take a look at a little bit later

278
00:16:14,928 --> 00:16:15,750
in the show.

279
00:16:15,750 --> 00:16:16,408
>> Yeah.

280
00:16:16,408 --> 00:16:19,150
We're also gonna end up seeing that
there's actually even more than just

281
00:16:19,150 --> 00:16:19,990
overloading.

282
00:16:19,990 --> 00:16:21,770
The earlier versions of NAT, for

283
00:16:21,770 --> 00:16:25,550
us, include what we just shown you
which is a one-to-one translation.

284
00:16:25,550 --> 00:16:29,480
I have one public IP address that was
assigned to me by my internet service

285
00:16:29,480 --> 00:16:30,580
provider, and

286
00:16:30,580 --> 00:16:35,000
inside I only have one particular device
that has that private IP address.

287
00:16:35,000 --> 00:16:38,700
Now there's even another one that's
out there, where, if you actually have

288
00:16:38,700 --> 00:16:43,200
a lot of devices inside, but let's say
you have a pool of public IP addresses.

289
00:16:43,200 --> 00:16:44,280
So let's say you have five or

290
00:16:44,280 --> 00:16:47,990
six IP addresses that
are available on the Internet.

291
00:16:47,990 --> 00:16:51,490
If you want to translate those into it,
we can also talk about that.

292
00:16:51,490 --> 00:16:54,835
So for most of us here, actually I
think that may be all that there is,

293
00:16:54,835 --> 00:16:58,350
there's what we call the idea
of static IP addressing,

294
00:16:58,350 --> 00:17:00,480
which is the one-to-one translation.

295
00:17:00,480 --> 00:17:04,960
Then there's what we call the idea of
dynamic addressing, which is the pool.

296
00:17:04,960 --> 00:17:08,920
You have many devices that you're gonna
translate into many public IP addresses.

297
00:17:08,920 --> 00:17:11,910
And then you have the one that Don was
talking about which we call overloading or

298
00:17:11,910 --> 00:17:15,655
NAT overloading, a lot of times, in which
you have many devices on the inside

299
00:17:15,655 --> 00:17:20,065
it's gonna get translated to one public
IP address on the outside as well.

300
00:17:21,485 --> 00:17:24,055
So we normally use the term mapping here,

301
00:17:24,055 --> 00:17:28,800
to actually show how that private IP
address is going to get link up or

302
00:17:28,800 --> 00:17:32,700
get translated into that
public IP address, as well.

303
00:17:32,700 --> 00:17:35,250
Now there's another term, I don't,
do we even use that in Cisco?

304
00:17:35,250 --> 00:17:37,330
Do we use port address
translation in Cisco?

305
00:17:37,330 --> 00:17:41,410
>> Yes, absolutely, they love to
throw that one in on the exam.

306
00:17:41,410 --> 00:17:45,480
It's kinda hard to explain right now
without having actually seen that.

307
00:17:45,480 --> 00:17:47,330
>> Right.
>> So I'm gonna add PAT.

308
00:17:47,330 --> 00:17:52,540
So PAT is really the technology
that makes NAT overloading work.

309
00:17:52,540 --> 00:17:54,400
So I'm gonna add that to my notes here,
and

310
00:17:54,400 --> 00:17:58,260
we'll tackle that one later in the show,
but basically this port address

311
00:17:58,260 --> 00:18:03,460
translation and what most of us
think is NAT is actually PAT.

312
00:18:03,460 --> 00:18:06,920
And most people never heard the term
PAT and don't care about it, but

313
00:18:06,920 --> 00:18:09,180
on the exam,
you need to have heard about it and

314
00:18:09,180 --> 00:18:11,860
you need to care about it because
they love to throw it on there.

315
00:18:11,860 --> 00:18:13,990
So we will tackle that one.

316
00:18:13,990 --> 00:18:14,700
>> Yeah.
>> All right, well Ronnie,

317
00:18:14,700 --> 00:18:15,690
let's start with the easy stuff.

318
00:18:15,690 --> 00:18:18,120
>> Okay.
>> Let's start with what's called a static

319
00:18:18,120 --> 00:18:19,410
NAT mapping.

320
00:18:19,410 --> 00:18:24,250
A static NAT mapping is when we
tell a router to take one internal

321
00:18:24,250 --> 00:18:28,770
host and
translate it into one external IP.

322
00:18:28,770 --> 00:18:30,010
All right.

323
00:18:30,010 --> 00:18:32,440
This does not involve sharing.

324
00:18:32,440 --> 00:18:35,180
So if I have 15 internal computers,

325
00:18:35,180 --> 00:18:39,730
I would have to do 15 separate
mappings to 15 public IPs.

326
00:18:39,730 --> 00:18:41,650
Most of the time we don't have that,
right?

327
00:18:41,650 --> 00:18:45,120
So static mapping is the most
basic of the options.

328
00:18:45,120 --> 00:18:46,790
And we really use it for servers.

329
00:18:46,790 --> 00:18:50,480
You might have a server on your
network that has an internal address.

330
00:18:50,480 --> 00:18:53,690
And you wanna map it to
one of your public IPs so

331
00:18:53,690 --> 00:18:56,340
you can expose it to the Internet and
allow people to get to it.

332
00:18:56,340 --> 00:18:59,000
So for
that you would do a one-to-one mapping.

333
00:18:59,000 --> 00:19:02,450
The internal server has full
control of that one IP.

334
00:19:03,870 --> 00:19:08,330
Well, let me bring up my router here,
now my machine,

335
00:19:08,330 --> 00:19:13,834
my laptop is 192.168.0.222,
and that is a private IP, so

336
00:19:13,834 --> 00:19:22,280
I already know that I can't get out
to the Internet with my current IP.

337
00:19:22,280 --> 00:19:25,360
And I can't get into the router
if I don't know the password.

338
00:19:25,360 --> 00:19:25,922
There we go.

339
00:19:25,922 --> 00:19:29,046
[LAUGH] All right.

340
00:19:29,046 --> 00:19:34,038
I'm just doing a show IP
interface brief here real quick.

341
00:19:34,038 --> 00:19:40,670
This router has 192.168.0.1,
which is what my laptop is plugged into.

342
00:19:40,670 --> 00:19:43,230
And then for it's internet connection,
it's got 10.1.230.15,

343
00:19:43,230 --> 00:19:47,890
now you might notice, you know,
hang on a second Don, that's a private IP.

344
00:19:47,890 --> 00:19:52,270
Well it's in our lab here, so
it doesn't actually have a public IP.

345
00:19:52,270 --> 00:19:53,735
So let's in our minds,

346
00:19:53,735 --> 00:19:57,800
just kind of pretend here,
that 10.1.230 was a public IP.

347
00:19:57,800 --> 00:20:00,150
You don't have to NAT between private and
public.

348
00:20:00,150 --> 00:20:02,650
You can NAT between private and
private like I'm about to.

349
00:20:02,650 --> 00:20:04,090
You can NAT between public and public.

350
00:20:04,090 --> 00:20:06,900
There's not a lot of reason to,
but you can.

351
00:20:06,900 --> 00:20:13,780
So, when my laptop passes through
192.168.0.1 and heads out to the Internet.

352
00:20:13,780 --> 00:20:19,387
By default, the router is
sending me out as 192.168.0.222.

353
00:20:19,387 --> 00:20:22,790
It's not changing my address at all.

354
00:20:22,790 --> 00:20:26,580
Cisco routers do not do NAT by default.

355
00:20:26,580 --> 00:20:31,770
We have to configure it, or
it's not going to do it.

356
00:20:31,770 --> 00:20:34,310
So I'm going to configure
a statement in here.

357
00:20:34,310 --> 00:20:36,400
And what I'm gonna do,
I'm going to say like right now,

358
00:20:36,400 --> 00:20:41,050
if my laptop passes through this system,
it's gonna pass through, and

359
00:20:41,050 --> 00:20:45,580
I will show up as being 192.168.0.222,
now how do I know that?

360
00:20:45,580 --> 00:20:48,218
Well, let me show you,
I'll remote into another system.

361
00:20:53,640 --> 00:20:54,208
All right.

362
00:20:54,208 --> 00:20:58,410
So I'm logging into another
system here through that router.

363
00:20:58,410 --> 00:21:05,260
And when I do a show user, it's gonna
show who's logged into this switch.

364
00:21:05,260 --> 00:21:05,970
Right?

365
00:21:05,970 --> 00:21:07,760
And that's me right there.

366
00:21:07,760 --> 00:21:11,030
I SSHed in, so I'm on VTY 0.

367
00:21:11,030 --> 00:21:14,990
I logged in as user admin, and
right there you can see my address.

368
00:21:14,990 --> 00:21:17,543
I'm 192.168.0.222.

369
00:21:17,543 --> 00:21:25,150
When I passed through that router, it did
not NAT me, it left me at 192.168.0.222.

370
00:21:25,150 --> 00:21:31,724
Now the problem here is, this switch has
to know how to get back to me, all right.

371
00:21:31,724 --> 00:21:39,615
And so before the show, I put in a route,

372
00:21:39,615 --> 00:21:45,854
and let's see if we can find it,
give it just a minute, there we go!

373
00:21:45,854 --> 00:21:49,630
I put in a route, so
it would know how to get to me.

374
00:21:49,630 --> 00:21:53,416
And I said, 192.168.0,
the class C is available

375
00:21:53,416 --> 00:21:57,900
through 10.1.230.15,
which is the router, router 1.

376
00:21:57,900 --> 00:22:01,580
So if I look back here,
see that is the IP in Router 1.

377
00:22:01,580 --> 00:22:08,150
So I told that switch how to get back
to me, but if it's an Internet router,

378
00:22:08,150 --> 00:22:11,710
like it's your ISP, it's not gonna
have any routes for 192.168.

379
00:22:11,710 --> 00:22:13,050
In fact, it's gonna have the opposite.

380
00:22:13,050 --> 00:22:15,770
It's gonna have blocked
rules that deny 192.168,

381
00:22:15,770 --> 00:22:19,250
cuz they're required to drop it
before passing into the Internet.

382
00:22:19,250 --> 00:22:21,961
So if I were to remove
this route statement,

383
00:22:21,961 --> 00:22:24,100
if I were to take that out of there.

384
00:22:26,561 --> 00:22:27,757
There we go.

385
00:22:27,757 --> 00:22:29,460
Well, what happens?

386
00:22:29,460 --> 00:22:31,530
I actually just lost my connection.

387
00:22:31,530 --> 00:22:34,940
I can't type, whatever,
I've lost my connection to the switch,

388
00:22:34,940 --> 00:22:38,270
cuz the switch has no way to
find its way back to me anymore.

389
00:22:38,270 --> 00:22:40,580
It doesn't know how to get to 192.168.

390
00:22:40,580 --> 00:22:43,340
And that's exactly what would
happen if you didn't NAT

391
00:22:43,340 --> 00:22:45,370
yourself on the way out to the Internet.

392
00:22:45,370 --> 00:22:46,800
The ISPs wouldn't know how to get to you,

393
00:22:46,800 --> 00:22:48,980
that would be the end
of your communication.

394
00:22:48,980 --> 00:22:50,343
There you go, my connection just went out.

395
00:22:50,343 --> 00:22:52,222
All right.

396
00:22:52,222 --> 00:22:55,380
So how can I fix that?

397
00:22:55,380 --> 00:22:56,720
How can I get around it?

398
00:22:56,720 --> 00:22:58,540
Well, we can do a translation.

399
00:23:00,290 --> 00:23:04,780
Now with a static NAT, we map one
internal address to one public address.

400
00:23:04,780 --> 00:23:11,904
I'm gonna map my 192.168.0.222
address to 10.1.230.16.

401
00:23:11,904 --> 00:23:13,205
Just the next available address.

402
00:23:13,205 --> 00:23:16,380
It's important that you
actually own that address.

403
00:23:16,380 --> 00:23:18,320
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can't take somebody else's address.

404
00:23:18,320 --> 00:23:19,560
That won't work either.

405
00:23:19,560 --> 00:23:21,870
All right.

406
00:23:21,870 --> 00:23:24,360
So here's gonna be our first
translation command, and

407
00:23:24,360 --> 00:23:28,090
this one is one of the shorter ones,
the syntax for NAT.

408
00:23:28,090 --> 00:23:32,280
You have to say IP NAT, so
we're turning that on, and

409
00:23:32,280 --> 00:23:36,270
then we have to tell it what
inside addresses we want to map.

410
00:23:36,270 --> 00:23:40,970
And I'm gonna say, the inside
source is going to be a static map.

411
00:23:40,970 --> 00:23:45,540
Okay, so the inside address is gonna
be something that I statically put in.

412
00:23:47,090 --> 00:23:49,970
So inside source static, and
then I need to put what it is.

413
00:23:49,970 --> 00:23:53,946
So, in my case, that guy right there,
that's my laptop.

414
00:23:53,946 --> 00:23:57,643
And then I need to tell it
the destination, right?

415
00:23:57,643 --> 00:23:59,152
What I want it to become.

416
00:23:59,152 --> 00:24:05,961
And I'm gonna tell it
to become 10.1.230.16.

417
00:24:05,961 --> 00:24:07,140
All right?

418
00:24:07,140 --> 00:24:11,912
So whenever it sees traffic
coming from 192.168.0.222,

419
00:24:11,912 --> 00:24:16,850
it will change the traffic to
show as being from 10.1.230.16.

420
00:24:16,850 --> 00:24:21,436
>> Now, a lot of times when we do this,
we think that at this point, we've got it

421
00:24:21,436 --> 00:24:26,180
made, we're done, we shouldn't
have to worry about anything else.

422
00:24:26,180 --> 00:24:30,880
So this is where, we as beginners, may
actually get a little bit frustrated here.

423
00:24:30,880 --> 00:24:33,460
What I would do right now,
just go ahead and ping.

424
00:24:33,460 --> 00:24:36,570
And when that happens, I'm gonna see that,
even though I think I've done it

425
00:24:36,570 --> 00:24:40,940
correctly, it is not gonna work anything
in like the way that I want it to.

426
00:24:40,940 --> 00:24:44,990
And that is because NAT,
like a couple of other things here,

427
00:24:44,990 --> 00:24:47,610
that we already talked about,
really access control list,

428
00:24:47,610 --> 00:24:51,180
there's two parts to the idea
of configuring that here.

429
00:24:51,180 --> 00:24:54,440
Not only do we need to configure
the rule to make it work, but

430
00:24:54,440 --> 00:24:57,600
we also have to configure
where it's gonna work as well.

431
00:24:57,600 --> 00:24:58,540
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

432
00:24:58,540 --> 00:25:05,510
>> In that command, I specified that
the inside source was a static address.

433
00:25:05,510 --> 00:25:09,130
Well the router doesn't know
what's inside and what's outside.

434
00:25:09,130 --> 00:25:10,700
We've got to tell it.

435
00:25:10,700 --> 00:25:15,239
So when I look at my

436
00:25:15,239 --> 00:25:20,209
interfaces, I can see that Gig

437
00:25:20,209 --> 00:25:25,750
0/1 is my inside, and Gig 0/0 is my
outside, so I need to go and tell it that.

438
00:25:25,750 --> 00:25:31,960
So I'm gonna get into interface Gi0/0,
where I will say IP net outside.

439
00:25:33,410 --> 00:25:40,120
And then I'll get into interface Gi0/1,
as soon as it gets happy again.

440
00:25:40,120 --> 00:25:40,620
There we go.

441
00:25:43,040 --> 00:25:46,140
Where I will say IP net inside.

442
00:25:46,140 --> 00:25:50,706
Okay, so now it knows,
when I pass from Gi0/1,

443
00:25:50,706 --> 00:25:56,210
over to Gi0/0,
that's when we're going to apply NAT.

444
00:25:56,210 --> 00:25:59,310
NAT only applies when you pass
from one interface to another, and

445
00:25:59,310 --> 00:26:02,750
when one is marked as inside and
one is marked as outside.

446
00:26:02,750 --> 00:26:04,330
>> Two very important configurations.

447
00:26:04,330 --> 00:26:08,430
The rule for what we just did, which was
the one that Don typed in there with

448
00:26:08,430 --> 00:26:11,690

01:01:31,470 --> 01:01:32,680
To go out.

Notice how we have the two

01:01:47,820 --> 01:01:51,545

01:01:51,545 --> 01:01:52,350
>> Mm-hm.
>> And so

01:01:52,350 --> 01:01:55,800

01:01:55,800 --> 01:01:59,630
>> So what it does is when

01:01:59,630 --> 01:02:03,960
When it changes 192.168.0.13 into

01:02:03,960 --> 01:02:10,310

01:02:12,160 --> 01:02:13,910

Sometimes it has to

01:02:17,206 --> 01:02:18,731

01:02:23,980 --> 01:02:26,490
That way when Amazon replies.

01:02:32,360 --> 01:02:36,990

01:02:53,910 --> 01:02:56,590

01:16:14,640 --> 01:16:19,110
whatever IP address was attached to our
outside interface, and we overloaded it so

1358
01:16:19,110 --> 01:16:23,240
we could have many machines
sharing a single IP.

1359
01:16:23,240 --> 01:16:27,220
>> And don't forget in each instance of
this we also have to make sure we define

1360
01:16:27,220 --> 01:16:30,730
the inside NAT interface and
the outside NAT interface, and

1361
01:16:30,730 --> 01:16:34,280
that's an important concept for us too.

1362
01:16:34,280 --> 01:16:39,463
It has two different parts to
actually making sure that NAT works.

1363
01:16:39,463 --> 01:16:40,750
>> All right.

1364
01:16:40,750 --> 01:16:43,610
Now, as far as NAT,

1365
01:16:43,610 --> 01:16:46,030
those are the three configurations
you need to know for the exam.

1366
01:16:46,030 --> 01:16:48,450
So for the exam, know the syntax.

1367
01:16:48,450 --> 01:16:50,690
Know these three different
ways of configuring it.

1368
01:16:50,690 --> 01:16:54,490
Also, make sure you can tell
the difference between the four terms:

1369
01:16:54,490 --> 01:16:58,470
inside local, inside global,
outside local, outside global, right?

1370
01:16:58,470 --> 01:17:01,560
Inside and outside is referring
to where the machine is.

1371
01:17:01,560 --> 01:17:04,170
Inside your network or
outside your network.

1372
01:17:04,170 --> 01:17:07,510
Global means its global
unique across the planet.

1373
01:17:07,510 --> 01:17:10,930
Local means its local unique
on your local network.

1374
01:17:10,930 --> 01:17:13,630
Right, so that's kind of how we
know which address is which.

1375
01:17:15,480 --> 01:17:18,150
The last thing that I wanna point out,
all right?

1376
01:17:18,150 --> 01:17:21,540
What we've done here is we've showed
you how to do NAT we've showed how to

1377
01:17:21,540 --> 01:17:25,270
verify it was working,
what if it doesn't work?

1378
01:17:25,270 --> 01:17:27,460
What if something goes wrong, all right?

1379
01:17:27,460 --> 01:17:32,640
There's a debug command you can use to
see the NAT translations as they happen.

1380
01:17:32,640 --> 01:17:33,820
Here's the problem.

1381
01:17:33,820 --> 01:17:39,280

with data, and I don't mean overwhelm

1382

your mind, and it will absolutely do that,
but it can overwhelm your session.

1383
01:17:42,990 --> 01:17:44,500
Your SSA, your telnet session,

1384
01:17:44,500 --> 01:17:46,420
and disconnect you from your router,
locking you out.

01:17:46,420 --> 01:17:47,790
That would be really bad.

1386
01:17:47,790 --> 01:17:51,140
So if you're going to de-bug NAT.

1387
01:17:51,140 --> 01:17:54,040
First off, you wanna be connected
to the console of the router.

1388
01:17:54,040 --> 01:17:58,130
I can do it here on this router because
it's just Ronnie and I and that's it.

1389
01:17:58,130 --> 01:18:00,760
But, in an enterprise network where
you might have several machines,

1390
01:18:00,760 --> 01:18:02,260
you'll get overwhelmed right away.

1391
01:18:02,260 --> 01:18:05,430
You need to make sure you connect to
the console of the router to debug it.

1392
01:18:05,430 --> 01:18:06,100
All right.

to debug your NAT sessions, all right?

1398
01:18:21,390 --> 01:18:24,240
You'll see when a session is created and
when a session is torn down.

1399
01:18:25,250 --> 01:18:28,230

and say debug IP NAT, and

actually seeing packets, frame fragments,

01:18:41,990 --> 01:18:43,480

01:18:52,530 --> 01:18:54,350
I can put a rule in.

Just for a standard ACL,
a source-based address list.

01:18:57,930 --> 01:19:01,076
I can specify who I wanna

1410
01:19:01,076 --> 01:19:02,540
In a busy network,

you'll wanna do that to trim down on
the amount of data you're gonna see.

01:19:07,380 --> 01:19:09,660
So, if I just run debug IP NAT.

01:19:09,660 --> 01:19:11,200
I'm gonna run that.

All right, and if I do something like

1429

Oops.
Do clear IP net translations star.

Oh.
You know, I'm doing

I'm using the do command and I'm not

There we go.
So I should see a message as it flushes it

out and
it starts to build our new sessions and so

That's what happens when that,

All right.

debug IP nets that last command,

episodes.description: Access control lists (ACLs) are a way for one to filter traffic passing over a network. Viewers will hear about the proper use and implementation of access control lists and the three involved syntaxes: standard, extended, and named ACLs.

You know another thing

00:13:15,800 --> 00:13:19,244

They are applied in order.

The directions?

00:23:28,920 --> 00:23:33,530

00:23:36,170 --> 00:23:41,633
So if I wanted to advertise out

00:23:41,633 --> 00:23:43,551
it was a class C a /24.

00:23:43,551 --> 00:23:49,896
If I wanted to advertise that out,

488
00:23:49,896 --> 00:23:53,456
And if I wanted to convert that
subnet mask to a wildcard mask,

489
00:23:53,456 --> 00:23:56,740
we just reversed the ones and
the zeros in binary.

490
00:23:56,740 --> 00:23:59,110
And so it ends up being 0.0.0.255,

491
00:23:59,110 --> 00:24:03,090
basically the exact opposite of

00:24:03,090 --> 00:24:05,910

00:24:05,910 --> 00:24:09,740

00:24:09,740 --> 00:24:10,780

00:24:10,780 --> 00:24:14,690
And the main reason is,
it's really important to convey

496
00:24:14,690 --> 00:24:18,920
that the wildcard mask and
the subnet mask are not tied together.

497
00:24:18,920 --> 00:24:21,080
They're actually
independent of each other.

498
00:24:21,080 --> 00:24:24,590
And a wildcard mask does

00:24:25,840 --> 00:24:29,550

00:24:29,550 --> 00:24:34,788

00:24:34,788 --> 00:24:38,790

502
00:24:38,790 --> 00:24:41,610
Those asterisks,
those serve as a wildcard.

503
00:24:41,610 --> 00:24:42,840
I'm saying give me a list,

504
00:24:42,840 --> 00:24:48,220
give me the directory listing of any file
that has the word itpro in the middle.

505
00:24:48,220 --> 00:24:50,390
It can have anything at the beginning,
anything at the end.

506
00:24:50,390 --> 00:24:53,290
But somewhere in the middle,
it's got itpro, that's a wildcard, right.

507
00:24:53,290 --> 00:24:56,460
So we use these in command lines and
searches all the time.

508
00:24:56,460 --> 00:24:59,350
But for networks, it's not like this.

00:25:19,768 --> 00:25:20,969

00:25:20,969 --> 00:25:28,495

515
00:25:28,495 --> 00:25:32,099
And when we write that
subnet mask like this.

516
00:25:39,994 --> 00:25:41,260
There we go.

517
00:25:41,260 --> 00:25:43,270
What we're saying is,

518
00:25:43,270 --> 00:25:49,540
any bit that has a one in the subnet
mask is part of the network ID.

519
00:25:49,540 --> 00:25:52,710
And any bit that has a zero is
part of the host ID, right.

520
00:25:52,710 --> 00:25:54,670
So that's what a subnet mask does,

521
00:25:54,670 --> 00:25:58,950
it's identifying what's part of
the network and what's part of the host.

522
00:25:58,950 --> 00:26:04,450
But with a wild card,
we're doing something different.

523
00:26:04,450 --> 00:26:09,550
With a wild card,
a zero says that this number

524
00:26:09,550 --> 00:26:15,000
has to match and a one says we
don't care what the number is.

525
00:26:15,000 --> 00:26:18,810
And so if I want to match every address
that starts with 192.168.0, but

526
00:26:18,810 --> 00:26:24,660
the last octet can be whatever we want,

527
00:26:24,660 --> 00:26:30,020
I would need to do zeroes for the first

528
00:26:31,270 --> 00:26:34,040
And then, 1s for the last octet saying,
I don't care what it is.

529
00:26:34,040 --> 00:26:36,580
It can be whatever,

00:26:36,580 --> 00:26:38,140
So that's what we're meant doing here,

00:26:38,140 --> 00:26:40,305
0, let me just kind of write that out.

00:26:49,035 --> 00:26:49,756
There.

533
00:26:49,756 --> 00:26:53,410
So 0, the bit has to match,
1, the bit can be any value.

00:26:53,410 --> 00:26:53,930
>> Yeah.

00:26:53,930 --> 00:26:56,840
Now, when you look at it, you might think,

In an wildcard mask though,

00:27:31,980 --> 00:27:36,130

00:27:41,860 --> 00:27:44,500
It's not just the opposite

00:27:44,500 --> 00:27:49,540
all the zeros are my network portion, and

00:27:49,540 --> 00:27:53,180
It's about the matching bits
versus the non-matching bits, and

00:27:53,180 --> 00:27:55,980
that's gotta be a clear concept

At the point that we're doing it right

963
00:50:23,920 --> 00:50:27,870
This is a little error,
commonly overlooked thing.

964
00:50:27,870 --> 00:50:29,340
>> Yeah.
>> It's standard ACLs,

965
00:50:29,340 --> 00:50:30,970
it will automatically assume,

966
00:50:30,970 --> 00:50:34,950
that you mean a host if you don't include
a wild card mask, and such was doing here.

967
00:50:34,950 --> 00:50:36,780
It would've also accepted
the host key word.

968
00:50:36,780 --> 00:50:37,480
>> Right.
>> It's kinda

969
00:50:37,480 --> 00:50:39,735
three different ways to write the same,
exact thing.

970
00:50:41,135 --> 00:50:43,995
>> Now,
just creating the access list itself, and

971
00:50:43,995 --> 00:50:46,585
if you take a look in the lower right
hand corner of the screen, you'll notice,

972
00:50:46,585 --> 00:50:49,575
that it's still continuing on here.

973
00:50:49,575 --> 00:50:53,180
That's because, creating the access
list is only half the battle.

974
00:50:53,180 --> 00:50:53,980
Remember the other part,

975
00:50:53,980 --> 00:50:56,480
that we talked about in the first
segment of our show here.

976
00:50:56,480 --> 00:50:59,590
It's also having to put
it on an interface, and

977
00:50:59,590 --> 00:51:02,990
a direction on interface,
that helps us out here too.

978
00:51:02,990 --> 00:51:06,590
>> Yeah, and normally I would want
to put it on the inside interface,

979
00:51:06,590 --> 00:51:09,780
to filter traffic, but if I do that, I'm
going to lock myself out of the router.

980
00:51:09,780 --> 00:51:11,360
Because I am inside of it.

981
00:51:11,360 --> 00:51:17,490
So, I could update the ACL to exclude
that particular connection, or whatever.

982
00:51:17,490 --> 00:51:20,190
But, for right now,
I'll just attach it to the outside.

983
00:51:20,190 --> 00:51:24,350
So, I'm gonna attach it to the router,
when my traffic is going out of it,

984
00:51:24,350 --> 00:51:27,990
on the way out to the Internet,
or wherever it is that I'm going.

985
00:51:27,990 --> 00:51:29,890
So I'm gonna get into interface gi0/0,

986
00:51:29,890 --> 00:51:34,190
which is the one that's
facing the Internet.

987
00:51:34,190 --> 00:51:40,125
And here, I'll just say,
access-group, which is kinda weird.

988
00:51:40,125 --> 00:51:41,540
The terminology changed, but it does.

989
00:51:41,540 --> 00:51:45,605
Access-group, and then I tell it the list,
which is list number 1,

990
00:51:45,605 --> 00:51:49,325
and then I give it a direction, in or out.

991
00:51:49,325 --> 00:51:54,240
And I'm gonna say, any traffic going out
this interface, run it through access list

992
00:51:54,240 --> 00:52:00,010
one, and then access list one will deny my
laptop, and it will allow everything else.

993
00:52:00,010 --> 00:52:01,980
So if I put that in place.

994
00:52:01,980 --> 00:52:03,524
Oops, did I leave off IP?

995
00:52:03,524 --> 00:52:05,080
>> IP, yep.
>> There we go.

996
00:52:05,080 --> 00:52:07,933
IP access-group,
I get my syntax, that helps.

997
00:52:07,933 --> 00:52:09,020
>> There it goes.

998
00:52:09,020 --> 00:52:14,530
>> And now in the background, here we go.

999
00:52:14,530 --> 00:52:18,830
I can see, that I am being blocked,
destination net unreachable.

1000
00:52:18,830 --> 00:52:22,360
I'm not getting through anymore,
because that list is in place.

1001
00:52:22,360 --> 00:52:25,130
And I know it's the list,
because if I turn it off again,

1002
00:52:26,380 --> 00:52:29,620
the instant I turn it off,
there's those pings again.

1003
00:52:29,620 --> 00:52:32,200
So it's the access list,
that's doing the filter.

1004
00:52:32,200 --> 00:52:35,080
That's one of the easiest ways to test,
is turning the list on and off.

1005
00:52:35,080 --> 00:52:36,210
There is another way.

1006
00:52:37,470 --> 00:52:41,900
You can use the show access-list command.

1007
00:52:41,900 --> 00:52:44,760
And I'm using the do modifier,
because I'm still in config.

1008
00:52:44,760 --> 00:52:47,970
If you're out of config,
you would just run show access-dash list.

1009
00:52:47,970 --> 00:52:53,570
And that'll show me a summary of the ACL,
and you can see if you're getting matches.

1010
00:52:53,570 --> 00:52:58,680
Matches are what tells us, that we
are actually getting caught by that ACL,

1011
00:52:58,680 --> 00:53:00,860
and not being passed through.

1012
00:53:00,860 --> 00:53:01,930
>> Yeah.
Now, Don,

1013
00:53:01,930 --> 00:53:05,610
let's do this as well to show
the importance of the direction, okay?

1014
00:53:05,610 --> 00:53:09,400
What if I change this, and
I put the idea of access,

1015
00:53:09,400 --> 00:53:13,420
IP access-group one,
inbound on that outbound interface?

1016
00:53:13,420 --> 00:53:18,560
>> All right, so here I'm gonna change it
from out to in, and so now it's in place,

1017
00:53:20,770 --> 00:53:24,820
and when I look over here,
pages are still going through.

1018
00:53:24,820 --> 00:53:27,370
And we need to think about,
what that traffic is doing.

1019
00:53:27,370 --> 00:53:29,130
Let's go back to my picture.

1020
00:53:29,130 --> 00:53:32,860
So here's my ping,
as I ping out to the Internet.

1021
00:53:32,860 --> 00:53:38,420
So I'm going in this interface, and
then out on the way to the internet.

1022
00:53:38,420 --> 00:53:43,130
And then the host that I'm pinging on, I'm
pinging a DNS server, it's gonna reply.

1023
00:53:43,130 --> 00:53:46,220
And that traffic is going come in,
this interface.

1024
00:53:46,220 --> 00:53:51,700
So when that traffic is a reply, the
source is, whoever is out on the Internet.

1025
00:53:51,700 --> 00:53:54,220
The destination is me.

1026
00:53:54,220 --> 00:53:58,760
But a standard ACL,
only filters on source, not destination.

1027
00:53:58,760 --> 00:54:00,130
So this ACL, no longer works.

1028
00:54:00,130 --> 00:54:00,830
>> Yeah.

1029
00:54:00,830 --> 00:54:03,400
So it's very important,
that we actually understand that.

1030
00:54:03,400 --> 00:54:05,930
The direction,
is just as important as anything else,

1031
00:54:05,930 --> 00:54:07,680
that we actually put here, okay?

1032
00:54:07,680 --> 00:54:10,117
So we have to make sure,
that when we apply the ACL,

1033
00:54:10,117 --> 00:54:13,520
that we apply it in the proper direction,
and we also want to make sure,

1034
00:54:13,520 --> 00:54:15,315
we applied in the proper interface.

1035
00:54:15,315 --> 00:54:18,065
I know at times, it's easy,
when you're trying to do it quickly.

1036
00:54:18,065 --> 00:54:22,691
The difference between GI0/0,
GI0/1, it doesn't feel like,

1037
00:54:22,691 --> 00:54:25,220
that it's that much of a difference.

1038
00:54:25,220 --> 00:54:28,420
But it is a big difference there, when you
don't put it on the right interface, and

1039
00:54:28,420 --> 00:54:30,450
you still wondering why
things are happening.

1040
00:54:30,450 --> 00:54:33,320
Or you got it in the wrong direction,
why things are happening.

1041
00:54:33,320 --> 00:54:34,970
So remember that, for us here.

1042
00:54:34,970 --> 00:54:39,960
Creating the access list, again half the
battle, putting it on the right interface,

1043
00:54:39,960 --> 00:54:42,830
in the right direction,
is the other part we have to actually do,

1044
00:54:42,830 --> 00:54:43,590
if we want it to apply.

1045
00:54:44,700 --> 00:54:48,370
>> Now, ACLs, or standard ACLs,
they're pretty simple.

1046
00:54:48,370 --> 00:54:50,398
That's the whole syntax of them.

1047
00:54:50,398 --> 00:54:56,360
So we've got access-list,
followed by a number, right?

1048
00:54:56,360 --> 00:55:03,380
And then we can permit or deny, and
then the IP, and wildcard mask.

1049
00:55:03,380 --> 00:55:08,257
Those are the components that make up
an entry, and then as you continue to

1050
00:55:08,257 --> 00:55:13,150
add entries, it's building that list,
and it's got to be put in order.

1051
00:55:13,150 --> 00:55:15,970
So here is the challenge
of the standard ACL.

1052
00:55:15,970 --> 00:55:18,340
What if you want to insert something
in the middle of the list, or

1053
00:55:18,340 --> 00:55:19,500
the beginning of the list?

1054
00:55:19,500 --> 00:55:20,490
You really can't.

1055
00:55:20,490 --> 00:55:24,020
You have to remove the list,
and rebuild it.

1056
00:55:24,020 --> 00:55:28,813
So what a lot of people will do, and
we'll show you a way around this, but

1057
00:55:28,813 --> 00:55:33,372
the old solution, was that,
if you pull up your running config, and

1058
00:55:33,372 --> 00:55:37,774
you find your access list in here,
it's usually towards the end,

1059
00:55:37,774 --> 00:55:42,919
there it is, that you can copy it, and
throw it into something like notepad.

1060
00:55:42,919 --> 00:55:46,920
And in notepad, you can paste it in,
and you can make your modifications.

1061
00:55:46,920 --> 00:55:49,332
So maybe I want to do a access-list.

1062
00:55:49,332 --> 00:55:54,480
1 deny, and maybe there's some
other host on here I wanna deny.

1063
00:55:54,480 --> 00:55:58,920
So I can add that in, and if I just add
a little entry here to the beginning, and

1064
00:55:58,920 --> 00:56:03,440
I'll say no access-list 1.

1065
00:56:03,440 --> 00:56:05,820
That will delete the access list, and

1066
00:56:05,820 --> 00:56:10,500
then recreate it this way in
the order that I want, okay?

1067
00:56:10,500 --> 00:56:13,300
If I just go and add this one line, right?

1068
00:56:13,300 --> 00:56:16,405
So, right now let me just do a,

1069
00:56:19,574 --> 00:56:22,580
All right, so
here's the access list as it is right now.

1070
00:56:22,580 --> 00:56:29,027
If I issue access-list
1 deny 192.168.0.100.

1071
00:56:29,027 --> 00:56:32,040
When I do that,
see the error that it gives me?

1072
00:56:32,040 --> 00:56:35,710
Access rule can't be configured at a
higher sequence number since it's part of

1073
00:56:35,710 --> 00:56:36,880
an existing rule.

1074
00:56:36,880 --> 00:56:38,989
And it's telling me that
if I were to do this,

1075
00:56:38,989 --> 00:56:42,443
it would have to stick it onto the end,
and it's not gonna work out right.

1076
00:56:42,443 --> 00:56:44,810
Okay, especially since I
got that permit any there.

1077
00:56:44,810 --> 00:56:46,690
So it's gonna complain.

1078
00:56:46,690 --> 00:56:51,611
But if we remove the ACL first,
and then reenter it, right,

1079
00:56:51,611 --> 00:56:54,796
so I'm just gonna copy and paste that,

1080
00:56:54,796 --> 00:57:00,860
now, Now it's got it in there and
it's got it in the order that I want.

1081
00:57:00,860 --> 00:57:03,440
Actually, oh,
this output kinda shuffles it a bit.

1082
00:57:03,440 --> 00:57:04,909
Let me pull it from the config.

1083
00:57:07,987 --> 00:57:09,460
It'll be right in here.

1084
00:57:09,460 --> 00:57:10,280
There we go.

1085
00:57:10,280 --> 00:57:11,630
And so I can see my entries.

1086
00:57:11,630 --> 00:57:14,237
Actually, did I write it that way?

1087
00:57:14,237 --> 00:57:17,000
>> No, it-
>> No, it has optimized the list.

1088
00:57:17,000 --> 00:57:21,208
So the router will do optimizations
to make the list apply faster.

1089
00:57:21,208 --> 00:57:27,750
And because 192.168.0.100 is lower
than 222, it's moving it up.

1090
00:57:27,750 --> 00:57:30,621
It knows that it doesn't make a difference
because these are both denies.

1091
00:57:30,621 --> 00:57:33,210
And so it's just optimizing it for
its own application.

1092
00:57:33,210 --> 00:57:35,200
Cisco calls that compilation,

1093
00:57:35,200 --> 00:57:39,760
that is compiles the access list to
make them run as optimal as possible.

1094
00:57:39,760 --> 00:57:41,680
So that's what's going on there.

1095
00:57:41,680 --> 00:57:43,860
But basically it's got it in place,
it's working.

1096
00:57:43,860 --> 00:57:45,590
My ping still should be getting blocked.

1097
00:57:45,590 --> 00:57:47,570
And yep, I'm still getting blocked.

1098
00:57:47,570 --> 00:57:48,530
And we're in.

1099
00:57:48,530 --> 00:57:54,440
And now, for a brief moment, the ACL
was gone, when we did no access-list 1.

1100
00:57:54,440 --> 00:57:55,696
So what happened there?

1101
00:57:55,696 --> 00:57:56,789
Technically I can get out, right?

1102
00:57:56,789 --> 00:57:59,341
And I wasn't paying attention,
so I didn't see, but

1103
00:57:59,341 --> 00:58:02,407
it's possible that a ping could
slip through when that happens.

1104
00:58:02,407 --> 00:58:05,399
So we do want to be careful in
a high security environment,

1105
00:58:05,399 --> 00:58:07,850
it's not a good idea to do it this way.

1106
00:58:07,850 --> 00:58:13,040
Instead you just create a second access
list, and then you attach it there.

1107
00:58:13,040 --> 00:58:17,658
So for example if I wanted to do
this by hand, so I might say no

1108
00:58:17,658 --> 00:58:23,000
access-list 1, and
then start to re-enter it.

1109
00:58:23,000 --> 00:58:24,761
And look in the background there.

1110
00:58:24,761 --> 00:58:25,402
>> There it is.

1111
00:58:25,402 --> 00:58:27,360
>> My pings are getting through, right?

1112
00:58:27,360 --> 00:58:29,693
And so that's a problem.

1113
00:58:34,372 --> 00:58:35,380
There.

1114
00:58:35,380 --> 00:58:36,290
So that's a problem.

1115
00:58:36,290 --> 00:58:37,780
A couple of pings got through.

1116
00:58:37,780 --> 00:58:39,366
So if I wanted to prevent that,

1117
00:58:39,366 --> 00:58:43,270
instead what I could have done is I could
have just created a new access list.

1118
00:58:43,270 --> 00:58:50,120
I could have said access-list 2, and then
put in whatever it was I was trying to do.

1119
00:58:50,120 --> 00:58:54,740
Right, and so maybe I got a few
different IPs that I wanna block

1120
00:58:54,740 --> 00:58:59,620
before I permit everything else, right.

1121
00:58:59,620 --> 00:59:01,660
So I write that access list
the way that I want it,

1122
00:59:01,660 --> 00:59:03,302
and then I just go to the interface.

1123
00:59:04,770 --> 00:59:09,570
And, on the interface, Remember I said

1124
00:59:09,570 --> 00:59:12,750
you can only have one
access list per direction?

1125
00:59:12,750 --> 00:59:16,160
So I've all ready got
access-list 1 going out.

1126
00:59:16,160 --> 00:59:21,830
When I say, access-group 2 out, that
one is going to replace the first one.

1127
00:59:21,830 --> 00:59:24,010
And when I do that,
the newest takes effect.

1128
00:59:24,010 --> 00:59:25,865
And see how no pings got through?

1129
00:59:25,865 --> 00:59:28,920
So in a high security environment,
this is what you wanna do.

1130
00:59:28,920 --> 00:59:31,980
Create a new ACL and
then just change it on the interface.

1131
00:59:31,980 --> 00:59:36,030
In a low security environment, you can
just blow away the old and put in the new,

1132
00:59:36,030 --> 00:59:42,630
and it normally happens so
fast that it's not even noticed.

1133
00:59:42,630 --> 00:59:45,290
So if I change this now to be 2,

1134
00:59:45,290 --> 00:59:49,650
so we remove the list, and
then we replace it like this.

1135
00:59:49,650 --> 00:59:53,490
When I cut and paste it'll happen so
fast I doubt any pings will get through.

1136
00:59:53,490 --> 00:59:54,861
Let's just test.

1137
00:59:54,861 --> 00:59:56,480
There we go.

1138
00:59:56,480 --> 00:59:58,890
So yeah, no pings made it through.

1139
00:59:58,890 --> 01:00:02,640
But if you're dealing with national
security, if this is a massive ACL or

1140
01:00:02,640 --> 01:00:05,390
whatever, you don't want
it to apply partially,

1141
01:00:05,390 --> 01:00:07,520
you want it to apply fully, right.

1142
01:00:07,520 --> 01:00:11,240
And so, don't just delete an existing ACL,
create a new one and

1143
01:00:11,240 --> 01:00:12,140
then swap them on the interface.

1144
01:00:12,140 --> 01:00:12,640
>> Yeah.
>> Yep.

1145
01:00:15,280 --> 01:00:18,190
All right, so
standard ACL's really cut and dry, right.

1146
01:00:18,190 --> 01:00:21,330
Let's summarize that syntax one
last time before we move on, right.

1147
01:00:21,330 --> 01:00:24,486
So the syntax for that for a standard ACL,

1148
01:00:27,824 --> 01:00:35,165
Was acces-list followed by a number,
and that number was what,

1149
01:00:35,165 --> 01:00:40,116
1-99, 1300-1799, right?

1150
01:00:40,116 --> 01:00:41,510
>> 1699.
>> 1699, shoot, there we go, all right.

1151
01:00:43,280 --> 01:00:47,157
A number, and
then basically permit or deny.

1152
01:00:49,981 --> 01:00:55,363
And then we have to do our SRC IP and

1153
01:00:55,363 --> 01:00:59,408
wildcard Mask, right.

1154
01:00:59,408 --> 01:01:02,620
>> Yeah, now remember that
the wildcard Mask here is important.

1155
01:01:04,100 --> 01:01:08,303
If you accidentally type in a subnet mask,
thinking that it's gonna work,

1156
01:01:08,303 --> 01:01:09,690
it's not gonna happen.

1157
01:01:09,690 --> 01:01:12,390
So make sure you do make sure again.

1158
01:01:12,390 --> 01:01:15,485
Verify that you actually did
make the wildcard Mask in there.

1159
01:01:15,485 --> 01:01:16,030
>> Yeah.

1160
01:01:16,030 --> 01:01:17,706
>> Yeah, it really does matter.

1161
01:01:17,706 --> 01:01:20,962
[LAUGH]
>> If you do a subnet mask, right,

1162
01:01:20,962 --> 01:01:25,440
so if I were to write this as
access-list 1 permit 192.168.0.1,

1163
01:01:25,440 --> 01:01:29,600
maybe I'm trying to allow
that whole network, right.

1164
01:01:29,600 --> 01:01:33,610
And, I put in the subnet mask,
what am I actually saying?

1165
01:01:33,610 --> 01:01:36,825
I'm saying the first three octets
can be whatever they want, and

1166
01:01:36,825 --> 01:01:38,239
the last octet has to match.

1167
01:01:38,239 --> 01:01:39,309
In this case the last octet-
>> Zero.

1168
01:01:39,309 --> 01:01:40,093
[LAUGH]
>> Would have to be zero,

1169
01:01:40,093 --> 01:01:40,909
which it never would be.

1170
01:01:40,909 --> 01:01:41,413
>> Right.

1171
01:01:41,413 --> 01:01:44,715
>> And so,
this would effectively not work.

1172
01:01:44,715 --> 01:01:46,025
>> Yeah.

1173
01:01:46,025 --> 01:01:49,125
So make sure you pay attention,
especially when you're typing this in.

1174
01:01:49,125 --> 01:01:52,895
So that's why it's always better to
actually type it out on paper or to write

1175
01:01:52,895 --> 01:01:58,135
it out and make sure that the logic makes
sense, make sure the syntax is correct.

1176
01:01:58,135 --> 01:02:01,575
And then if you're doing it in
Notepad you simply copy it, and

1177
01:02:01,575 --> 01:02:03,950
then you can paste it right in and
see how it works.

1178
01:02:03,950 --> 01:02:05,310
>> Yeah.
>> Better way to do it.

1179
01:02:05,310 --> 01:02:08,465
>> Now standard ACLs are cool
because they're extremely efficient.

1180
01:02:08,465 --> 01:02:11,810
Your router is already looking
at the layer 3 addresses.

1181
01:02:11,810 --> 01:02:15,120
And so being able to look at that source
doesn't really require the router to do

1182
01:02:15,120 --> 01:02:16,430
anything it wasn't doing already.

1183
01:02:16,430 --> 01:02:19,530
So extremely efficient,
doesn't create much burden on your router.

1184
01:02:19,530 --> 01:02:21,360
It does create a little, but not much.

1185
01:02:21,360 --> 01:02:24,810
On any Cisco router with four
digits in the model number,

1186
01:02:24,810 --> 01:02:26,300

If you have a really broad rule

01:20:19,140 --> 01:20:24,570
When we do filtering like this,

1508
01:20:24,570 --> 01:20:28,500
It's filtering certain traffic and
allowing other traffic through.

1509
01:20:30,550 --> 01:20:34,240
Now one word of caution, after watching
that you might say you know what?

1510
01:20:34,240 --> 01:20:36,860
That's pretty cool,
maybe I will use a router as a firewall.

1511
01:20:36,860 --> 01:20:39,230
All right,
let me tell you why it's a bad idea.

1512
01:20:40,260 --> 01:20:44,330
Most firewalls are what
are called stateful firewalls.

1513
01:20:44,330 --> 01:20:47,730
And what that means,
if I go back to my silly diagram,

1514
01:20:47,730 --> 01:20:53,400
is that when we see traffic going
out the router, so my traffic.

1515
01:20:53,400 --> 01:20:56,760
Starts here and it heads out the router.

1516
01:20:56,760 --> 01:20:59,710
I might have an access list that
allows that traffic or blocks it or

1517
01:20:59,710 --> 01:21:01,020
whatever, right.

1518
01:21:01,020 --> 01:21:03,120
But what about the return trip?

1519
01:21:03,120 --> 01:21:07,050
The traffic goes out to the internet and
it starts to come back in, right.

1520
01:21:07,050 --> 01:21:12,190
That return trip,
if I have a stateful firewall, it says

1521
01:21:12,190 --> 01:21:17,130
hey if I allow the traffic to go out I
should allow the response to come back in.

1522
01:21:17,130 --> 01:21:17,780
It knows that,

1523
01:21:17,780 --> 01:21:21,820
it's smart enough to know to allow
the return traffic to come back in.

1524
01:21:21,820 --> 01:21:23,080
Your router isn't.

1525
01:21:24,190 --> 01:21:27,880
The access control lists that
we write are not stateful.

1526
01:21:27,880 --> 01:21:30,360
Just because you allow something out

1527
01:21:30,360 --> 01:21:33,620
doesn't mean that it's
necessarily allowed back in.

1528
01:21:33,620 --> 01:21:34,340
And so,

1529
01:21:34,340 --> 01:21:38,410
if you're filtering both directions,
you'll have to double your rules.

1530
01:21:38,410 --> 01:21:40,560
For every outgoing rule,

1531
01:21:40,560 --> 01:21:43,260
you'll have to write an incoming
rule to allow them to come through.

1532
01:21:43,260 --> 01:21:44,580
If you're filtering both directions.

1533
01:21:44,580 --> 01:21:46,070
Most people only filter incoming.

1534
01:21:46,070 --> 01:21:47,290
They never filter outgoing.

1535
01:21:47,290 --> 01:21:48,670
And so it's not a big deal.

1536
01:21:48,670 --> 01:21:50,320
>> Hm-mm.
>> But if you filter both directions,

1537
01:21:50,320 --> 01:21:52,010
you will have to double up your rules.

1538
01:21:52,010 --> 01:21:54,200
On a firewall,
a staple firewall, you won't.

1539
01:21:54,200 --> 01:21:55,240
It's automatic.

1540
01:21:55,240 --> 01:21:56,690
>> Uh-huh.

01:21:56,690 --> 01:21:57,310

01:22:18,610 --> 01:22:24,120

01:22:29,200 --> 01:22:33,160
how specific I want to get here, asics,

01:22:33,160 --> 01:22:37,300
It's got circuitry on the motherboard

01:22:37,300 --> 01:22:38,090

01:22:38,090 --> 01:22:39,300

01:22:39,300 --> 01:22:41,160

On your router it's just using

01:22:44,850 --> 01:22:46,310

01:22:49,670 --> 01:22:53,250

a firewall, don't do it on the router.
