when you go to the interface, if they

2080
01:50:51,907 --> 01:50:57,555
are talking about configuring it to
the path of the traffic passing through.

2081
01:50:57,555 --> 01:51:02,705
You can use access-group to actually
put it on the interface there.

2082
01:51:02,705 --> 01:51:07,495
If you are controlling traffic going
to the router or from the router,

2083
01:51:07,495 --> 01:51:11,315
you're gonna go to the VTY lines and
you're gonna use access-class.

2084
01:51:11,315 --> 01:51:12,805
I mean, why not change it?

2085
01:51:12,805 --> 01:51:15,180
You know, it makes sense.

2086
01:51:15,180 --> 01:51:18,740
But you have to remember those too,
because they may show you an access list

2087
01:51:18,740 --> 01:51:22,830
and say you need to actually stop
traffic from getting into the router.

2088
01:51:22,830 --> 01:51:26,940
Well, if you choose access-group and that
number, it's not going to work for you.

2089
01:51:26,940 --> 01:51:29,050
It has to be access-class.

2090
01:51:29,050 --> 01:51:32,237
Make sure you remember that.

2091
01:51:32,237 --> 01:51:35,549
>> So for the exam, as you start
trying to buckle down on this,

2092
01:51:35,549 --> 01:51:40,122
couple of key things to focus on, always
remember the direction of your traffic,

2093
01:51:40,122 --> 01:51:43,328
whether that traffic is coming
in an interface, or out.

2094
01:51:43,328 --> 01:51:47,582
On the exam, what I recommend you do,
if you get to any ACL questions,

2095
01:51:47,582 --> 01:51:48,604
draw a picture.

2096
01:51:48,604 --> 01:51:51,440
You'll get a little dry erase board
that you can write on during the exam,

2097
01:51:51,440 --> 01:51:52,280
just draw a picture.

2098
01:51:52,280 --> 01:51:56,370
Cuz then you can draw arrows to say here's
my traffic going this way and that way.

2099
01:51:56,370 --> 01:51:59,490
And you can see where it's going in and
where it's going out, and

2100
01:51:59,490 --> 01:52:01,560
build your ACLs appropriately.

2101
01:52:01,560 --> 01:52:05,000
The other thing, syntax, syntax, syntax.

2102
01:52:05,000 --> 01:52:06,060
These are long commands.

2103
01:52:06,060 --> 01:52:08,060
There's a lot of room for typos.

2104
01:52:08,060 --> 01:52:12,150
On the exam, they may show you a pre-built
access list and ask you questions about

2105
01:52:12,150 --> 01:52:15,320
it, or to spot errors, or
they may give you a simulation and

2106
01:52:15,320 --> 01:52:20,920
tell you to write an access list that
will filter based on x, y, z criteria.

2107
01:52:20,920 --> 01:52:23,200
So make sure you know that syntax.

2108
01:52:23,200 --> 01:52:23,850
>> Yeah.

2109
01:52:23,850 --> 01:52:27,990
Also remember that creating the access
control list is only half the battle.

2110
01:52:27,990 --> 01:52:30,960
Applying it to the interface
is the other part.

2111
01:52:30,960 --> 01:52:32,670
Applying it in the proper direction.

2112
01:52:32,670 --> 01:52:36,280
Applying that picker access list
to whatever interface they say.

2113
01:52:36,280 --> 01:52:38,630
Now there's a couple of other,
what we call.

2114
01:52:38,630 --> 01:52:40,140
I guess.
I don't know if they're best practices or

2115
01:52:40,140 --> 01:52:42,810
not, but general rules of thumb
>> [LAUGH]

2116
01:52:42,810 --> 01:52:45,120
>> Whatever you wanna call them,

2117
01:52:45,120 --> 01:52:46,490
I can't remember those phrases.

2118
01:52:46,490 --> 01:52:47,140
>> Guidelines, or something?

2119
01:52:47,140 --> 01:52:48,370
>> Guidelines, whatever.

2120
01:52:48,370 --> 01:52:52,460
Whenever you create the idea
of an extended access list,

2121
01:52:52,460 --> 01:52:55,650
normal best practices,
you want to actually make sure that you

2122
01:52:55,650 --> 01:52:59,330
put it on the interface as close
to the source as possible.

2123
01:52:59,330 --> 01:53:03,290
So as close as from when you actually
sending it out, as possible.

2124
01:53:03,290 --> 01:53:08,010
On a standard access list, usually as
close to the destination as possible

2125
01:53:08,010 --> 01:53:11,290
is what you want to do, because you want
to allow that traffic to get to wherever

2126
01:53:11,290 --> 01:53:14,920
it actually needs to go except for
blocking that one particular source.

2127
01:53:14,920 --> 01:53:16,070
So usually that's a two.

2128
01:53:16,070 --> 01:53:19,620
So source as close to destination as
possible, extended or not extended.

2129
01:53:19,620 --> 01:53:21,308
Yeah.
Extended access list as close to

2130
01:53:21,308 --> 01:53:23,701
the source as,
I'm gonna say that wrong, I know.

2131
01:53:23,701 --> 01:53:24,642
>> Yeah.

2132
01:53:24,642 --> 01:53:26,233
>> It's gonna happen.

2133
01:53:26,233 --> 01:53:28,703
>> The way that I remember it,
extended ACLs can be very specific,

2134
01:53:28,703 --> 01:53:29,980
can be very granular.

2135
01:53:29,980 --> 01:53:32,910
So you can put them really
close to the source and

2136
01:53:32,910 --> 01:53:35,640
still allow the source
to get to other places.

2137
01:53:35,640 --> 01:53:39,990
But a standard ACL is so broad because
it's just based on a source IP and

2138
01:53:39,990 --> 01:53:42,308
that's it,
that if you put it close to the source,

2139
01:53:42,308 --> 01:53:44,640
you're gonna kill off that source for
everything.

2140
01:53:44,640 --> 01:53:47,270
So you put it as close to the destination,
so

2141
01:53:47,270 --> 01:53:49,570
the source will still be able
to get wherever it goes.

2142
01:53:49,570 --> 01:53:50,900
Now that is just a rule of thumb.

2143
01:53:50,900 --> 01:53:51,740
>> Yep.
>> You will see it

2144
01:53:51,740 --> 01:53:53,400
mentioned on the Cisco website.

2145
01:53:53,400 --> 01:53:56,410
>> Don't let that taint
your decisions on the exam.

2146
01:53:56,410 --> 01:53:59,160
On the exam they're gonna give you
requirements you need to look for

2147
01:53:59,160 --> 01:54:02,390
those regardless of what
the guidelines are.

2148
01:54:02,390 --> 01:54:05,670
So keep that in mind, but in the real
world you are absolutely right.

2149
01:54:05,670 --> 01:54:08,641
Standard ACLs typically
close to the destination,

2150
01:54:08,641 --> 01:54:12,297
extended ACLs are typically close
to the source of the traffic.

2151
01:54:12,297 --> 01:54:17,382
>> Remember the guidelines
about wildcard mask as well.

2152
01:54:17,382 --> 01:54:22,174
Don't let the idea of a subnet mask
fool you into thinking that's what you

2153
01:54:22,174 --> 01:54:22,955
have to do.

2154
01:54:22,955 --> 01:54:25,081
Usually that's what you're
gonna end up seeing,

2155
01:54:25,081 --> 01:54:28,048
especially on the exam because
they're not gonna get that technical,

2156
01:54:28,048 --> 01:54:31,230
but it is something that you don't want
to confuse even at this early stage.

2157
01:54:33,210 --> 01:54:35,420
>> Well Ronnie,
I think that's pretty good coverage.

2158
01:54:35,420 --> 01:54:39,760
We are gonna have another episode that'll
touch on ACLs as we get into like

2159
01:54:39,760 --> 01:54:41,800
troubleshooting ACLs and stuff.

2160
01:54:41,800 --> 01:54:45,390
But I think as far as the basics of just
kinda what they are, how they work and

2161
01:54:45,390 --> 01:54:48,370
what their syntax is, we've pretty
much covered all our bases haven't we?

2162
01:54:48,370 --> 01:54:48,910
>> I believe so.

2163
01:54:50,190 --> 01:54:51,608
>> So let's wrap it up here.

2164
01:54:51,608 --> 01:54:54,930
I do wanna remind you guys that
if you ever have any questions

2165
01:54:54,930 --> 01:54:59,070
live during the show you can
jump on over to ITPro.TV/live.

2166
01:54:59,070 --> 01:55:01,050
Right underneath the live
feed you'll see our chatroom.

2167
01:55:01,050 --> 01:55:02,050
You can post your questions.

2168
01:55:02,050 --> 01:55:04,240
We monitor and answer during the show.

2169
01:55:04,240 --> 01:55:07,980
Also if you're watching this
recorded later on down the road at

2170
01:55:07,980 --> 01:55:10,110
the top of every ITProTV page.

2171
01:55:10,110 --> 01:55:11,090
There is a Q and A link.

2172
01:55:11,090 --> 01:55:13,480
You can go into the Q and
A, post your questions.

2173
01:55:13,480 --> 01:55:15,100
We monitor it and answer.

2174
01:55:15,100 --> 01:55:18,390
We get your questions taken care of,
so that you are ready to go and

2175
01:55:18,390 --> 01:55:21,070
take that exam when you choose to do that.

2176
01:55:21,070 --> 01:55:21,660
>> That's right.
>> So.

2177
01:55:22,850 --> 01:55:24,021
Well I hope you guys
enjoyed the show today.

2178
01:55:24,021 --> 01:55:26,738
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

2179
01:55:26,738 --> 01:55:27,620
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

2180
01:55:27,620 --> 01:55:29,095
>> And we'll see you next time around.

2181
01:55:29,095 --> 01:55:39,095
[MUSIC]

2182
01:55:41,157 --> 01:55:47,810
[SOUND]

episodes.description: When troubleshooting ACLs, one can take a look at the statistics to see where a hit count is being generated and see if any hits are coming up on any of ones statements to figure out if they are properly configured. Viewers will see demonstrations on various troubleshooting scenarios such as IP addressing and host configuration, VLAN and trunking problems as well as resolving ACL issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,216 --> 00:00:10,216
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,912 --> 00:00:22,652
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,652 --> 00:00:33,606
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,606 --> 00:00:36,530
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back!

5
00:00:36,530 --> 00:00:39,390
To another episode of ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

6
00:00:39,390 --> 00:00:41,529
Today back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:41,529 --> 00:00:42,610
>> Thank you very much.

8
00:00:42,610 --> 00:00:45,896
Glad to be back for
our final episode in CCENT.

9
00:00:45,896 --> 00:00:48,060
>> Unless we ramble on too much.

10
00:00:48,060 --> 00:00:50,230
>> No, we wouldn't do that, never.

11
00:00:50,230 --> 00:00:52,430
We'll never ramble.

12
00:00:52,430 --> 00:00:54,360
>> But, yeah, you know, like Ronnie said,

13
00:00:54,360 --> 00:00:56,500
this should be the one that wraps it up,
right?

14
00:00:56,500 --> 00:00:59,760
We're down to the last little bit here,
troubleshooting some of the topics,

15
00:00:59,760 --> 00:01:03,800
and you know, I say it's like the last
one, what do we do when this is over?

16
00:01:03,800 --> 00:01:05,182
See you next time!
>> Yup!

17
00:01:05,182 --> 00:01:06,910
>> So, yeah!

18
00:01:06,910 --> 00:01:08,880
So we got some good troubleshooting
topics lined up today,

19
00:01:08,880 --> 00:01:10,830
we're going to troubleshoot
some host things,

20
00:01:10,830 --> 00:01:14,180
some switch things, some outer things,
some stuff in general.

21
00:01:14,180 --> 00:01:17,130
And we've kind of, already been doing
this throughout the entire show.

22
00:01:17,130 --> 00:01:20,790
We're really just bringing that back and
wrapping up in one area.

23
00:01:20,790 --> 00:01:24,510
>> It's more of a review for us,
making sure that we, before the exam,

24
00:01:24,510 --> 00:01:27,930
that we get all the concepts
in that we need to.

25
00:01:27,930 --> 00:01:29,490
As we actually go back and review these,

26
00:01:29,490 --> 00:01:32,480
these are things, once again, and
you may have actually gone, okay.

27
00:01:32,480 --> 00:01:34,250
Gone through so much stuff.

28
00:01:34,250 --> 00:01:34,830
Oh yeah.

29
00:01:34,830 --> 00:01:36,632
Let's remind ourselves of this.

30
00:01:36,632 --> 00:01:39,240
And so,
what it actually helps us do, again,

31
00:01:39,240 --> 00:01:42,910
is wrap everything back up for
us and get ready now for CCNA.

32
00:01:42,910 --> 00:01:47,340
>> Yeah, and speaking of troubleshooting,
I don't know if you've even heard it,

33
00:01:47,340 --> 00:01:51,020
Ronnie, but we have a 20 100 series
routers and two 3560s behind us, and

34
00:01:51,020 --> 00:01:54,180
I have heard some clicking noise
like twice now and so we might

35
00:01:54,180 --> 00:01:58,100
have some troubleshooting to do here or
the equipment might burst into flame.

36
00:01:58,100 --> 00:01:58,998
>> That would be exciting.

37
00:01:58,998 --> 00:02:00,106
It's very possible.

38
00:02:00,106 --> 00:02:02,585
>> This could be the cliffhanger
conclusion to CCENT.

39
00:02:02,585 --> 00:02:05,660
They see the fire out there and
they're like, did they make it?

40
00:02:05,660 --> 00:02:06,648
Did they survive?

41
00:02:06,648 --> 00:02:08,190
>> What in the world is going on?

42
00:02:08,190 --> 00:02:10,352
>> Stay tuned next season.
>> That's right.

43
00:02:10,352 --> 00:02:12,888
>> All right, so
let's go ahead and get started.

44
00:02:12,888 --> 00:02:17,842
Objective 7.1 is troubleshooting and
correcting common problems associated with

45
00:02:17,842 --> 00:02:21,360
IP addressing and
host configurations, all right?

46
00:02:21,360 --> 00:02:25,400
Now, the first thing we need to realize
when we talk about IP addressing is,

47
00:02:25,400 --> 00:02:28,170
our clients will get addresses,
Two different ways.

48
00:02:28,170 --> 00:02:33,052
They can get it via the DHCP,
dynamic host configuration protocol or

49
00:02:33,052 --> 00:02:35,166
they can get it via static IP.

50
00:02:35,166 --> 00:02:37,897
And if they do it statically,
there's a lot of room for typos and

51
00:02:37,897 --> 00:02:40,570
that's normally what
the problem is going to be.

52
00:02:40,570 --> 00:02:41,940
But if you get it via DHCP,

53
00:02:41,940 --> 00:02:44,504
there is a whole different set
of problems that you can have.

54
00:02:44,504 --> 00:02:45,050
>> Yes.

55
00:02:45,050 --> 00:02:47,640
With IP addressing, for us,
remember that every device

56
00:02:47,640 --> 00:02:51,640
is gonna be communicating on our network,
needs to have an IP address.

57
00:02:51,640 --> 00:02:54,090
One of the things we want to make sure of,
of course,

58
00:02:54,090 --> 00:02:56,050
is that they're properly formatted.

59
00:02:56,050 --> 00:02:59,950
And on Cisco equipment we generally also
have to include in that subnet mask and

60
00:02:59,950 --> 00:03:02,190
make sure that we also
type that out as well.

61
00:03:02,190 --> 00:03:05,070
So configuration things that
we want to make sure we

62
00:03:05,070 --> 00:03:06,540
really do keep at the forefront.

63
00:03:06,540 --> 00:03:10,760
>> And subnet masks, right, let's
talk about subnet masks for a minute.

64
00:03:10,760 --> 00:03:13,260
So we've got this little set up here,
let me bring up my diagram,

65
00:03:13,260 --> 00:03:14,218
where did that thing go.

66
00:03:14,218 --> 00:03:15,194
Here we go.

67
00:03:15,194 --> 00:03:19,720
So my PC is 192.168.0.222, right?

68
00:03:20,880 --> 00:03:26,278
And I'm plugged into a switch, and router
one, this router behind me, it's 192.

69
00:03:26,278 --> 00:03:26,850
168.0.1.

70
00:03:26,850 --> 00:03:30,440
Now, if we have a class C subnet mask.

71
00:03:30,440 --> 00:03:35,910
255.255.255.0, then both of
us are on the same network.

72
00:03:35,910 --> 00:03:40,150
We can communicate to each other and I can
talk directly to that router, all right.

73
00:03:40,150 --> 00:03:45,185
But, let's say I'm typing in here and
I mess up my subnet mask.

74
00:03:45,185 --> 00:03:46,900
And I put in something wrong?

75
00:03:46,900 --> 00:03:49,390
It's possible that we can
split our network and

76
00:03:49,390 --> 00:03:52,570
make it where my PC can't
contact that router.

77
00:03:52,570 --> 00:03:54,120
So let me show an example of that.

78
00:03:54,120 --> 00:03:57,924
I'm gonna just open up
a command prompt here, and

79
00:03:57,924 --> 00:04:02,040
I'm gonna start a ping to 192.168.0.1.

80
00:04:02,040 --> 00:04:04,390
And I can ping it right now.

81
00:04:04,390 --> 00:04:05,300
Everything is happy.

82
00:04:05,300 --> 00:04:08,790
You know, I do a broadcast and
the router here,

83
00:04:08,790 --> 00:04:13,250
it responds back because we did our
process address resolution protocol.

84
00:04:13,250 --> 00:04:15,170
So we do that look up, I find the router.

85
00:04:15,170 --> 00:04:17,910
I know it's on the same network as me and
I know I can get to it.

86
00:04:17,910 --> 00:04:18,720
All right.

87
00:04:18,720 --> 00:04:21,927
But, if I go in and
pull up my network properties.

88
00:04:24,504 --> 00:04:28,170
And I go in here and
modify my network card.

89
00:04:28,170 --> 00:04:32,467
My IP address is 192.168.0.222 and

90
00:04:32,467 --> 00:04:38,330
the router 192.168.01 is
on the same network as me.

91
00:04:38,330 --> 00:04:41,990
If I put in an incorrect subnet mask,
like 128 for example.

92
00:04:41,990 --> 00:04:45,992
128 will divide this network in half.

93
00:04:45,992 --> 00:04:50,730
So we'll have 192.168.0.1 through 126.

94
00:04:50,730 --> 00:04:58,430
And you'll have 192.168.0.129
all the way through 120, or 254.

95
00:04:58,430 --> 00:05:02,300
So those are the the two
ranges that would be created.

96
00:05:02,300 --> 00:05:05,690
Technically, my computer
would be in the upper range.

97
00:05:05,690 --> 00:05:07,790
The router would be in the lower range.

98
00:05:07,790 --> 00:05:11,780
And when I say okay to that, see
the complaint that Windows is giving me.

99
00:05:11,780 --> 00:05:16,800
It's saying the default gateway is
not on the same network segment,

100
00:05:16,800 --> 00:05:18,670
are you sure you wanna save that.

101
00:05:18,670 --> 00:05:23,030
Usually, you're operating system
will warn you, not all of them do.

102
00:05:23,030 --> 00:05:24,760
Like Linux, Linux will let you do it.

103
00:05:24,760 --> 00:05:29,220
Whatever, you're dumb, and
it's not my problem to fix it for you.

104
00:05:29,220 --> 00:05:34,190
So if you save that,
it's technically wrong.

105
00:05:34,190 --> 00:05:40,790
And if I look at my output here,
it'll let me put in that incorrect value.

106
00:05:40,790 --> 00:05:44,650
Now, if I try and ping the router,
I still get there.

107
00:05:44,650 --> 00:05:45,300
Okay?

108
00:05:45,300 --> 00:05:47,670
Now, why do I get there?

109
00:05:47,670 --> 00:05:51,670
Because it's ARP cached and
it is still on my local network, right?

110
00:05:51,670 --> 00:05:55,000
In fact, let me, I didn't open this
with administrative privileges.

111
00:05:55,000 --> 00:05:57,112
We'll see if I can clear the ARP cache,
if that'll go away.

112
00:06:03,732 --> 00:06:05,000
That's still making it.

113
00:06:05,000 --> 00:06:09,310
So I'm doing a broadcast and
I'm finding that machine locally, but

114
00:06:09,310 --> 00:06:12,500
if this was actually on a separate
network I wouldn't be able to get there.

115
00:06:12,500 --> 00:06:14,320
I wouldn't be able to
contact my default gateway,

116
00:06:14,320 --> 00:06:18,340
my subnet mask wouldn't be telling
me that I'm on a different network.

117
00:06:18,340 --> 00:06:20,870
>> And this is very important to us,
especially when facing the exam.

118
00:06:21,870 --> 00:06:22,680
Don't put it pass

119
00:06:22,680 --> 00:06:25,540
them on the exam to actually give
you a configuration like this.

120
00:06:25,540 --> 00:06:26,520
And say, hey.

121
00:06:26,520 --> 00:06:32,020
What is the issue that you cannot reach
out to Amazon.com or whatever it might be.

122
00:06:32,020 --> 00:06:36,120
And it could be something just as simple
as looking at the default gateway.

123
00:06:36,120 --> 00:06:37,480
So usually when we start taking.

124
00:06:37,480 --> 00:06:38,020
Look at that.

125

another common one would be something,

00:08:32,890 --> 00:08:38,580

well the addresses are made of 10.1.11,

00:08:53,980 --> 00:08:58,450
Really easy to mix and not notice that

So, when you have a PC that's not able to

And remember that,

one of the first things that we have

everything on there has to be configured

00:14:43,970 --> 00:14:49,053
So, I might assign let's

00:15:11,754 --> 00:15:12,810

00:15:17,650 --> 00:15:22,910

00:15:22,910 --> 00:15:28,420

00:15:31,490 --> 00:15:34,750
They still won't be able to see each

00:15:35,950 --> 00:15:39,730
So, if you're troubleshooting some kind

00:15:39,730 --> 00:15:43,510

make sure whatever device is

00:16:06,297 --> 00:16:10,480

00:16:10,480 --> 00:16:12,270

The interface range command.

The interface range command is

Sometimes they ask you to configure

00:16:58,820 --> 00:17:01,260
And, this is the one that

00:17:01,260 --> 00:17:06,230

00:17:06,230 --> 00:17:07,050

00:17:10,770 --> 00:17:12,240

Pay attention, and remember, if you here

When they start doing that,

remember they're expecting

00:18:43,350 --> 00:18:48,615
So it's possible that if you have a PC
that's not communicating, and you look

353
00:18:48,615 --> 00:18:52,535
at you say, it's supposed to be on vlan 3,
it is on vlan 3 why isn't it talking?

354
00:18:52,535 --> 00:18:54,125
The port looks fine.

355
00:18:54,125 --> 00:18:57,665
Well the port might be fine,
but the vlan might be broken.

356
00:18:57,665 --> 00:18:59,685
And that's exactly what we're seeing here.

357
00:18:59,685 --> 00:19:02,065
It's easy to spot when you
know what you're looking for.

358
00:19:02,065 --> 00:19:04,965
If you're just looking at the interfaces,
they look fine.

359
00:19:04,965 --> 00:19:08,030
Switch board access vlan 3,
that's the command.

360
00:19:08,030 --> 00:19:10,407
And if vlan 3 didn’t exist,

361
00:19:10,407 --> 00:19:14,790
when you assign a port to it
that would create the vlan.

362
00:19:14,790 --> 00:19:17,960
So by all means this should be fine.

363
00:19:17,960 --> 00:19:19,090
But it isn’t.

364
00:19:19,090 --> 00:19:21,600
Instead it’s now basically
in a broken state.

365
00:19:21,600 --> 00:19:25,140
Now if we were to reboot
the switch it would fix itself.

366
00:19:25,140 --> 00:19:29,310
When it re ran these commands it
would recreate vlan 3 and be fine.

367
00:19:29,310 --> 00:19:34,270
But as it stands right now,
at this moment, ports 25 or

368
00:19:34,270 --> 00:19:40,380
24 thru 35 are basically broken
until I go in and I recreate vlan 3.

369
00:19:40,380 --> 00:19:44,600
Now that is the easy fix
if I just say vlan 3.

370
00:19:44,600 --> 00:19:45,850
What have we called it?

371
00:19:45,850 --> 00:19:50,120
Like RONNIE VLAN or something like that.

372
00:19:50,120 --> 00:19:51,720
>> It should be named.

373
00:19:51,720 --> 00:19:53,050
>> Oh, shoot, not a description.

374
00:19:53,050 --> 00:19:54,860
I'm thinking interfaces.

375
00:19:54,860 --> 00:19:55,530
>> Thank you.

376
00:19:55,530 --> 00:19:57,140
There we go.

377
00:19:57,140 --> 00:20:01,820
So we can create that VLAN, and
now, when I pull up the VLAN data,

378
00:20:01,820 --> 00:20:05,330
see how ports 24 through 35
jump right back on that VLAN.

379
00:20:05,330 --> 00:20:07,380
And now they're functional and
happy again.

380
00:20:07,380 --> 00:20:11,400
>> Yeah, very important for
us at some point for us here.

381
00:20:11,400 --> 00:20:14,500
But making sure that our ports are in the
correct VLAN, making sure that the VLANs

382
00:20:14,500 --> 00:20:19,370
exist are pretty much a good part of us
understanding the troubleshooting there.

383
00:20:19,370 --> 00:20:22,270
Now, there's other things
that could go wrong, but

384
00:20:22,270 --> 00:20:24,370
they're not the kind of things
that happen accidentally.

385
00:20:24,370 --> 00:20:26,260
Somebody could disable a VLAN, right?

386
00:20:26,260 --> 00:20:29,040
In the VLAN status, you can disable it.

387
00:20:29,040 --> 00:20:31,980
Let's see, how do you do that?

388
00:20:31,980 --> 00:20:33,730
It's shut down?

389
00:20:33,730 --> 00:20:34,520
Oh no, that shuts down.

390
00:20:34,520 --> 00:20:37,270
I don't remember the actual.

391
00:20:38,630 --> 00:20:40,060
Actually that may well be it.

392
00:20:40,060 --> 00:20:42,500
Let's see here.

393
00:20:42,500 --> 00:20:48,080
No, there's a different command that
will actually deactivate the VLAN and

394
00:20:48,080 --> 00:20:51,200
I thought it was deactivate but
I don't see that command on my list here.

395
00:20:51,200 --> 00:20:55,120
But you can actually deactivate it,
state that's it.

396
00:20:55,120 --> 00:20:57,660
State suspend, there we go.

397
00:20:58,950 --> 00:21:00,420
See, question mark, that's really helpful.

398
00:21:00,420 --> 00:21:05,160
So somebody could suspend the VLAN, and
when you do that, oh I have to get out.

399
00:21:08,690 --> 00:21:09,700
There we go.

400
00:21:09,700 --> 00:21:12,960
See how VLAN 3 shows as suspended?

401
00:21:12,960 --> 00:21:15,750
So, all of these machines that are plugged
into these ports are no longer

402
00:21:15,750 --> 00:21:16,440
gonna be active.

403
00:21:16,440 --> 00:21:18,880
But, that's not something that's gonna
show up on the exam because you have to

404
00:21:18,880 --> 00:21:19,910
manually do that.

405
00:21:19,910 --> 00:21:22,630
I can't think of any way that they
would accidentally get flagged and

406
00:21:22,630 --> 00:21:25,680
suspended, but that is a possibility.

407
00:21:25,680 --> 00:21:31,390
The tricky part about a problem like that,
is that you don't see it in the config,

408
00:21:31,390 --> 00:21:33,630
and that's because your
VLAN configuration,

409
00:21:33,630 --> 00:21:37,900
aside from your port assignments,
does not show up in configuration,

410
00:21:37,900 --> 00:21:41,950
it's actually all stored
in a separate file,

411
00:21:41,950 --> 00:21:47,220
stored in this vlan.dat file and, there's
no good way to see what's in there.

412
00:21:47,220 --> 00:21:47,720
>> Yep.

413
00:21:49,040 --> 00:21:53,410
>> So, you really are left
with the show VLAN command and

414
00:21:53,410 --> 00:21:56,260
you can see it's suspended right there,
so I'll just go in and fix that.

415
00:21:58,660 --> 00:21:59,160
And put it back.

416
00:22:01,558 --> 00:22:05,430
Now, actually, I did have a problem
a second ago, and let me that out.

417
00:22:05,430 --> 00:22:09,470
A lot of our VLAN commands
don't take effect until you get

418
00:22:09,470 --> 00:22:12,190
out of the VLAN prompt.

419
00:22:12,190 --> 00:22:14,680
So when I disable that VLAN,
it didn't disable right away,

420
00:22:14,680 --> 00:22:16,830
I had to get out of the prompt first.

421
00:22:16,830 --> 00:22:18,910
So when you fix the problems,
you may need to do that also.

422
00:22:18,910 --> 00:22:21,830
If you test and it's not working,
[COUGH] excuse me.

423
00:22:21,830 --> 00:22:25,040
You gotta get outta that vlan prompt
first and then you should see it fixed.

424
00:22:27,350 --> 00:22:28,260
All right.

425
00:22:28,260 --> 00:22:31,970
So, those are some
examples of vlan problems.

426
00:22:31,970 --> 00:22:34,910
And it could even be simply more
simple like you get two pc's that

427
00:22:34,910 --> 00:22:36,870
are supposed to be talking to each other.

428
00:22:36,870 --> 00:22:42,620
One's on port 23 and one's on port 24,
and they can't talk to each other.

429
00:22:42,620 --> 00:22:47,270
So you pull up the running config,
and we jump down and

430
00:22:47,270 --> 00:22:54,060
we take a look at port 0/23 and 0/24, why
can't these two PCs talk to each other?

431
00:22:54,060 --> 00:23:00,120
Two different VLANs, the first one's
on VLAN 2, the second one's on VLAN 3.

432
00:23:00,120 --> 00:23:01,840
And, they're not gonna be able to talk.

433
00:23:01,840 --> 00:23:04,180
So it could be as simple as that.

434
00:23:04,180 --> 00:23:06,650
This is one where it would be pretty
easy for us to go in and fix.

435
00:23:06,650 --> 00:23:09,800
We could move one of them to vlan 3 or
the other to vlan 2 or

436
00:23:09,800 --> 00:23:10,830
however we wanted to go.

437
00:23:12,050 --> 00:23:12,700
Don't forget that,

438
00:23:12,700 --> 00:23:17,680
even if you do have multiple hosts
on the same VLAN, remember that.

439
00:23:17,680 --> 00:23:21,180
Unless you're using DHCP and
you're statically assigning IP addresses.

440
00:23:21,180 --> 00:23:26,230
If they're not in the same subnet, they're
also not gonna be able to communicate.

441
00:23:26,230 --> 00:23:29,430
If you statically assign one to one
network and one to another network.

442
00:23:29,430 --> 00:23:31,340
But, you put them both in vlan 3.

443
00:23:31,340 --> 00:23:33,380
You're gonna see that you're still
gonna have some communication

444
00:23:33,380 --> 00:23:34,650
problems there too.

445
00:23:34,650 --> 00:23:35,160
>> Absolutely.

446
00:23:37,050 --> 00:23:40,620
So, those are some examples
of basic VLAN issues.

447
00:23:40,620 --> 00:23:41,720
And they call out,

448
00:23:41,720 --> 00:23:45,900
basically checking your port membership,
checking that your VLANs are configured.

449
00:23:45,900 --> 00:23:48,410
Checking that your IP
addresses are configured.

450
00:23:48,410 --> 00:23:50,871
Each VLAN is typically gonna
have its own IP subnet, so

451
00:23:50,871 --> 00:23:54,417
if you have a PC plugged into a VLAN it's
gotta have the right IP for that range.

452
00:23:54,417 --> 00:23:56,247
So, these are all things
that we need to verify, and

453
00:23:56,247 --> 00:23:57,922
it really does just come
down to verification.

454
00:23:57,922 --> 00:24:03,087
Double checking to make sure that we
didn't make typos and other crazy, Yeah,

455
00:24:03,087 --> 00:24:08,327
and there's no getting around the very
fact that for both the CCENT and the CCNA,

456
00:24:08,327 --> 00:24:13,417
that knowing the IP addressing schemes,
knowing the basics of subnetting and

457
00:24:13,417 --> 00:24:17,850
actually becoming good at it,
is a key to you passing the exam.

458
00:24:17,850 --> 00:24:21,280
You should, again, be able to do some
of things we talked about earlier,

459
00:24:21,280 --> 00:24:25,930
such as being able to identify the
broadcast address, as well as network ID.

460
00:24:25,930 --> 00:24:28,330
Being able to verify whether or

461
00:24:28,330 --> 00:24:31,950
not a computer is within the range
that they show you or not.

462
00:24:31,950 --> 00:24:35,860
All of those again are very important
concepts, especially when it comes to

463
00:24:35,860 --> 00:24:39,700
troubleshooting, just like we saw in the
very beginning here when we actually had

464
00:24:39,700 --> 00:24:44,260
our default gateway on one network and
our host on another network.

465
00:24:44,260 --> 00:24:45,100
>> Yep, absolutely.

466
00:24:45,100 --> 00:24:47,310
>> So make sure you go over those.

467
00:24:47,310 --> 00:24:48,750
>> All right.
So let's see.

468
00:24:48,750 --> 00:24:51,505
For the next part we're gonna
take a look at VLAN trunking.

469
00:24:51,505 --> 00:24:52,770
>> Mm-hm.
>> Now there is a lot that

470
00:24:52,770 --> 00:24:53,270
can go wrong
>> Right.

471
00:24:53,270 --> 00:24:56,040
>> When it comes to VLAN trunking so
we definitely want to tackle that.

472
00:24:56,040 --> 00:24:58,770
But before we do it we are getting
pretty close to our break time.

473
00:24:58,770 --> 00:25:01,080
So, let's stop here and take a break.

474
00:25:01,080 --> 00:25:04,000
When we get back we're gonna use
some more trouble shooting we'll

475
00:25:04,000 --> 00:25:07,590
creat some problems on these switches and
get to see some entertaining stuff and

476
00:25:07,590 --> 00:25:10,982
then we'll continue on to our ACL's and
some other stuff.

477
00:25:10,982 --> 00:25:13,706
All right, so ladies and gentleman
stay tuned, we'll be back after this.

478
00:25:13,706 --> 00:25:17,623
[SOUND] All right,

479
00:25:17,623 --> 00:25:23,373
welcome back everybody.

480
00:25:23,373 --> 00:25:26,881
So, let's see, so we left off
talking about some troubleshooting,

481
00:25:26,881 --> 00:25:30,480
we troubleshoot IP addressing or
whatever, and a little bit of VLANS.

482
00:25:30,480 --> 00:25:34,550
We want to take a look at trunks now,
so when we're trunking between switches,

483
00:25:34,550 --> 00:25:37,660
there are a number of different
problems that can creep up.

484
00:25:37,660 --> 00:25:39,110
And I want to show that.

485
00:25:39,110 --> 00:25:42,870
What I've got is,
I've basically got two switches, and

486
00:25:42,870 --> 00:25:45,360
I've got an uplink cable
run in between them.

487
00:25:45,360 --> 00:25:46,350
Port three.

488
00:25:46,350 --> 00:25:49,800
So, port three on one switch is run
to port three on the other switch and

489
00:25:49,800 --> 00:25:55,020
I can verify that real quick with
a show CDP neighbors command.

490
00:25:55,020 --> 00:25:59,760
So I can see that port 3 right there,
connected to port 3 on the other side.

491
00:25:59,760 --> 00:26:02,980
So it's just a crossover cable and
it's run between them.

492
00:26:02,980 --> 00:26:08,290
Now, these two switches are both
Cisco 3560s, all right?

493
00:26:08,290 --> 00:26:13,128
And with Cisco 3560s, when you plug
a crossover cable from one switch into

494
00:26:13,128 --> 00:26:16,400
another switch switch what happens, right?

495
00:26:16,400 --> 00:26:21,920
It's important to understand the default
state of trunking on a Cisco switch.

496
00:26:21,920 --> 00:26:26,230
Almost every Cisco switch supports DTP,
dynamic trunking protocol.

497
00:26:26,230 --> 00:26:29,450
And that means that even if
we don't configure a trunk,

498
00:26:29,450 --> 00:26:32,430
there are certain scenarios
>> Where a trunk will be built up,

499
00:26:32,430 --> 00:26:33,390
all right?

500
00:26:34,790 --> 00:26:39,640
But if I take a look at this,
if I say show interface trunk, all right?

501
00:26:39,640 --> 00:26:44,400
And I look at it, well sure enough
right there I can see port fa0/3,

502
00:26:44,400 --> 00:26:47,990
trunking is on and
capsulation is 802.1q, I'm trunking.

503
00:26:47,990 --> 00:26:51,610
If I look at the other switch.

504
00:26:51,610 --> 00:26:52,690
Show interface trunk.

505
00:26:53,690 --> 00:26:54,260
What'll I get?

506
00:26:55,270 --> 00:26:56,020
Nothing.
>> [LAUGH]

507
00:26:56,020 --> 00:26:57,778
>> Right? No interfaces >> Right.

508
00:26:57,778 --> 00:26:58,471
>> Are trunking in the other

509
00:26:58,471 --> 00:26:59,540
switch.
>> Hmm.

510
00:26:59,540 --> 00:27:00,930
Yeah.
>> Why is there a disparity?

511
00:27:00,930 --> 00:27:02,780
Why is one side thinking
that it's trunking?

512
00:27:02,780 --> 00:27:06,670
Well, let's look at the actual
interface configuration, so

513
00:27:06,670 --> 00:27:13,430
I'm gonna do a show
running-config interface fa0/3.

514
00:27:13,430 --> 00:27:14,380
All right.

515
00:27:14,380 --> 00:27:18,300
This one is hard set as a trunk.

516
00:27:18,300 --> 00:27:19,960
Switch board access Vlan 333.

517
00:27:19,960 --> 00:27:24,020
Switchboard trunk encapsulation .1q,
and switch board mode trunk,

518
00:27:24,020 --> 00:27:25,030
switch board no negotiate.

519
00:27:26,360 --> 00:27:27,880
If I look at this other switch...

520
00:27:31,350 --> 00:27:32,831
It's got the default config.

521
00:27:32,831 --> 00:27:35,748
Interface, FA 0/3, and that's it.

522
00:27:35,748 --> 00:27:36,290
>> Yeah.

523
00:27:36,290 --> 00:27:37,140
>> All right.

524
00:27:37,140 --> 00:27:40,060
So, what's going on here?

525
00:27:40,060 --> 00:27:41,800
How does dynamic trunking protocol work.

526
00:27:41,800 --> 00:27:43,950
First, that's kind of what
we need to understand.

527
00:27:43,950 --> 00:27:46,950
With dynamic chunking protocol,
there's really three states, all right?

528
00:27:46,950 --> 00:27:48,990
And one of those states
is being turned off.

529
00:27:48,990 --> 00:27:52,690
When we say switchport nonegotiate,

530
00:27:52,690 --> 00:27:56,990
that turns off dynamic chunking protocol,
DTP.

531
00:27:56,990 --> 00:28:02,990
So DTP is off on the top switch,
but DTP is on on the bottom switch.

532
00:28:02,990 --> 00:28:05,410
It's a default command, so
it just doesn't show up here.

533
00:28:05,410 --> 00:28:07,000
So it is on.

534
00:28:07,000 --> 00:28:09,380
So Dynamic Trunking Protocol says,

535
00:28:09,380 --> 00:28:14,560
we can automatically create a trunk
even if it's not configured.

536
00:28:14,560 --> 00:28:16,310
The top part is configured.

537
00:28:16,310 --> 00:28:17,305
The bottom part isn't.

538
00:28:17,305 --> 00:28:21,145
>> Mm-hm.
>> And the bottom part, the bottom switch,

539
00:28:21,145 --> 00:28:25,425
switch one is set to the default and
on Cisco switches

540
00:28:25,425 --> 00:28:30,498
the default is either going to
be DTP set to auto or desirable.

541
00:28:30,498 --> 00:28:33,000
Those are our two modes,
auto or desirable.

542
00:28:33,000 --> 00:28:38,880
When you're in auto mode,
in auto mode it says, if someone else

543
00:28:38,880 --> 00:28:44,060
asks us to become a trunk, we'll become
a trunk, but if nobody asks us, we won't.

544
00:28:45,470 --> 00:28:49,770
With auto, I'm sorry that was auto,

545
00:28:49,770 --> 00:28:54,860
with desirable, that says we will
actively ask somebody to be a trunk.

546
00:28:54,860 --> 00:28:56,570
And if they say yes we'll
build up a trunk and

547
00:28:56,570 --> 00:28:58,435
if they say no we'll
just be an access port.

548
00:28:58,435 --> 00:28:59,650
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right.

549
00:28:59,650 --> 00:29:03,270
But when you've got one
side with DTP turned off,

550
00:29:03,270 --> 00:29:05,635
even if the trunk is manually defined.

551
00:29:05,635 --> 00:29:06,320
>> Mm-hm.

552
00:29:06,320 --> 00:29:09,440
>> The other side is not going to
trunk with you unless you manually

553
00:29:09,440 --> 00:29:10,228
define it there also.

554
00:29:10,228 --> 00:29:12,930
If you're gonna manually define it on
one end you've got to do it on the other

555
00:29:12,930 --> 00:29:14,220
when you're disabling DTP.

556
00:29:14,220 --> 00:29:14,720
All right.

557
00:29:16,790 --> 00:29:19,280
Now I personally always disable DTP.

558
00:29:19,280 --> 00:29:21,430
I hate it, I hate dynamic things.

559
00:29:21,430 --> 00:29:24,830
I like to know that it's
gonna trunk all the time.

560
00:29:24,830 --> 00:29:28,960
So this top one, that's how I normally
configure my trunks right there.

561
00:29:28,960 --> 00:29:33,640
But you don't have to, so for
example if I go up here into switch 2, and

562
00:29:33,640 --> 00:29:37,210
into FA0/3, I can say,

563
00:29:39,310 --> 00:29:44,250
switchboard access vLan 1, that's the
default right here, normally on vLan 1,

564
00:29:44,250 --> 00:29:49,300
I can say switch port mode.

565
00:29:49,300 --> 00:29:54,570
And then I can just set it to dynamic.

566
00:29:54,570 --> 00:29:59,450
Let's see, on a 3560 the default is auto,
dynamic auto.

567
00:29:59,450 --> 00:30:05,320
Now that's important because on the 3550,
the default was desirable.

568
00:30:05,320 --> 00:30:08,010
So you get different settings
between different switches.

569
00:30:08,010 --> 00:30:13,900
So, if you take two 3560s, that are set to
default and you plug it in to each other,

570
00:30:13,900 --> 00:30:19,060
it's not gonna build a trunk because
they're both set to auto by default.

571
00:30:19,060 --> 00:30:23,700
But if you take a 3550, and plug it
in to a 3560 it will build a trunk.

572
00:30:23,700 --> 00:30:26,800
Because one is set to auto and
the other is set to desirable and

573
00:30:26,800 --> 00:30:28,330
they'll build up that session.

574
00:30:28,330 --> 00:30:33,050
Now it's complaining here that I tried
to flip it to dynamic when I have DTP

575
00:30:33,050 --> 00:30:39,200
disabled, so I do need to say
no switchport nonegotiate,

576
00:30:39,200 --> 00:30:43,360
that will turn DTP back on and
then I can put us back in to auto mode.

577
00:30:45,470 --> 00:30:50,100
And then I can say switchport
trunk encapsulation,

578
00:30:50,100 --> 00:30:53,200
and you'll see that I can set
that one to negotiate also.

579
00:30:54,660 --> 00:30:55,480
All right.

580
00:30:55,480 --> 00:30:57,140
And now let's take a look
at that interface.

581
00:30:58,490 --> 00:30:59,081
All right.

582
00:30:59,081 --> 00:31:06,207
Now, oh minus the let me
duplex auto there, all right.

So at this point, if I take a look at

00:34:42,727 --> 00:34:45,460
My two interfaces,

00:34:45,460 --> 00:34:49,930
So all I see is interface FastInternet0/3,

646
00:35:04,020 --> 00:35:11,850
With Dynamic Trunking Protocol,
if both ends are set to auto, nobody asks.

647
00:35:11,850 --> 00:35:15,000
They're both sitting there saying,
hey, if somebody else asks me,

648
00:35:15,000 --> 00:35:16,410

649
00:35:16,410 --> 00:35:18,870
But if nobody asks,
we'll stay an access port.

00:35:18,870 --> 00:35:20,420
And that's exactly what
they're doing right now.

651
00:35:20,420 --> 00:35:22,020
They're staying access ports.

652
00:35:22,020 --> 00:35:23,290
All right.

00:35:23,290 --> 00:35:29,220
The easiest way to fix this is to simply

654
00:35:29,220 --> 00:35:31,990
if both ends are desirable, they'll
both ask and they'll build a trunk.

655
00:35:31,990 --> 00:35:35,380
But at least one end is
gonna be set to desirable.

656
00:35:35,380 --> 00:35:39,050
If you've got a 35 50 switch,
they're desirable by default.

657
00:35:39,050 --> 00:35:41,720
On a 35 60, they're auto by default.

658
00:35:41,720 --> 00:35:42,480
It changes.

00:35:42,480 --> 00:35:44,440

So on switch two here,

00:36:49,471 --> 00:36:50,055
Mode.

00:36:50,055 --> 00:36:52,240

00:36:52,240 --> 00:36:53,764

00:36:53,764 --> 00:36:56,162

If they're both desirable,
or if one is desirable and

the other is auto,
they will build a trunk.

00:37:10,795 --> 00:37:15,275

00:37:25,070 --> 00:37:26,710

I can see fa0/3 mode is auto.

00:37:34,750 --> 00:37:35,310
>> Auto.

00:37:35,310 --> 00:37:37,640

00:37:37,640 --> 00:37:39,160
They built out a trunk.

00:37:39,160 --> 00:37:40,428
It's up and it's happy.

00:37:40,428 --> 00:37:41,060
>> Mm-hm.

702
00:37:41,060 --> 00:37:42,630

00:37:42,630 --> 00:37:44,600
Now there is one interesting thing.

00:37:44,600 --> 00:37:49,767
Notice under the encapsulation type here,

00:37:49,767 --> 00:37:52,320
The n means it was negotiated.

706
00:37:52,320 --> 00:37:56,238
It negotiated out to use

707
00:37:56,238 --> 00:37:58,613
ISL is Inter Switch Link, and

00:37:58,613 --> 00:38:04,400
it's a proprietary trunking
protocol from Cisco, all right?

709
00:38:04,400 --> 00:38:09,230
Not every switch supports it, and
no third party switch support it, right?

710
00:38:09,230 --> 00:38:15,270
Almost everyone on the entire planet
using 802.1QV land tagging instead.

711
00:38:16,300 --> 00:38:20,710
But when you use negotiation like

712
00:38:22,550 --> 00:38:24,335
Not if we take one end of the cable.

00:38:24,335 --> 00:38:27,947

00:38:33,470 --> 00:38:34,740

when they go to negotiate out,

00:38:45,400 --> 00:38:50,230
this time they'll negotiate out 802.1Q

00:38:50,230 --> 00:38:52,890
So we can influence

721
00:38:52,890 --> 00:38:58,760
it should come up pretty quick,

00:38:58,760 --> 00:38:59,260

00:39:00,440 --> 00:39:02,760

Down at the bottom,

00:39:12,482 --> 00:39:13,270

00:39:13,270 --> 00:39:15,370

00:39:15,370 --> 00:39:16,705

00:39:28,470 --> 00:39:31,730

encapsulation.1Q,

00:39:36,460 --> 00:39:40,378
that tells it you will be a trunk,

00:39:40,378 --> 00:39:44,490
Switchboard, no negotiate,

738
00:39:44,490 --> 00:39:46,250
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah no negotiate.

739
00:39:46,250 --> 00:39:50,790
That says don't do any kind of
dynamic trunking protocol stuff.

740
00:39:50,790 --> 00:39:52,260
You are going to be a trunk.

741
00:39:52,260 --> 00:39:56,600
You are gonna need your .1q and you don't

742
00:39:56,600 --> 00:39:59,080
This is how it's gonna be, all right?

00:39:59,080 --> 00:40:02,060
I like this configuration
because I know I can rely on it.

00:40:02,060 --> 00:40:04,350
I know exactly what it is gonna
be at the end of the day.

745
00:40:04,350 --> 00:40:09,955
And as long as we follow the same set up

746
00:40:09,955 --> 00:40:10,721
All right.

00:40:10,721 --> 00:40:15,680

And, I guess,

00:40:16,460 --> 00:40:19,060

00:40:19,060 --> 00:40:20,000

00:40:21,250 --> 00:40:24,801
I'm hard setting it to dot1q,

00:40:24,801 --> 00:40:27,455

00:40:29,735 --> 00:40:31,625

755
00:40:31,625 --> 00:40:34,675
You don't normally have to reset the port,

756
00:40:34,675 --> 00:40:37,645
In fact, in a lot of the Cisco
manuals from the big guys,

757
00:40:37,645 --> 00:40:39,220
like the CCIEs and stuff.

758
00:40:39,220 --> 00:40:42,100
They'll tell you whenever
you're changing trunk settings,

759
00:40:42,100 --> 00:40:46,370
it's a good idea to just shut down one end
of the trunk, make all of your changes and

760
00:40:46,370 --> 00:40:47,890
then turn the trunk back on.

761
00:40:47,890 --> 00:40:51,010
Otherwise, it can send partial data
while you're doing the configuration and

762
00:40:51,010 --> 00:40:53,050
you can get some data
corruption on the network.

763
00:40:53,050 --> 00:40:56,260
So it's better to shut one end down,

00:40:58,318 --> 00:41:02,080

00:41:02,080 --> 00:41:05,700

00:41:05,700 --> 00:41:09,010
So remember that by default our

00:41:09,010 --> 00:41:11,010

00:41:11,010 --> 00:41:13,690
In terms of the dynamic trunking protocol.

00:41:13,690 --> 00:41:16,517
And so when we have the idea

00:41:19,652 --> 00:41:20,440

772
00:41:20,440 --> 00:41:21,680

00:41:21,680 --> 00:41:23,830
So trunking is not going to occur there.

774
00:41:23,830 --> 00:41:25,660
But if we have one side set at auto and

775
00:41:25,660 --> 00:41:29,530
the other side set as desirable,
we should be able to trunk there.

776
00:41:30,750 --> 00:41:33,780
For us, though,
we like the idea of actually doing what?

777
00:41:33,780 --> 00:41:36,420
Hard setting it is pretty much the key.

778
00:41:36,420 --> 00:41:39,684
That's the way that actually helps
you to not have to worry about, hey,

779
00:41:39,684 --> 00:41:40,605
is that set to auto?

780
00:41:40,605 --> 00:41:43,650
Is this a 3550, 3560 here?

781
00:41:43,650 --> 00:41:48,260
By hard coding it, at least on one side,
and then on the other side

782
00:41:48,260 --> 00:41:51,720
setting it to whatever you want to, is
probably going to actually help you out.

783
00:41:51,720 --> 00:41:55,710
But normally we want to take both
sides and hard set them as well, okay?

784
00:41:55,710 --> 00:41:58,330
That's the only way we know that
we don't have to worry about it,

785
00:41:58,330 --> 00:41:59,450
we know what we put in it.

786
00:41:59,450 --> 00:42:00,190
>> Yep.

00:42:00,190 --> 00:42:03,280
So now when I look at it I

00:42:03,280 --> 00:42:06,227

00:42:08,690 --> 00:42:12,490

791
00:42:12,490 --> 00:42:16,430

00:42:31,155 --> 00:42:32,470

like show interface trunk,
and even then using the do

817
00:43:42,760 --> 00:43:43,500
All right.

818
00:43:43,500 --> 00:43:44,840
And then bring it back online.

819
00:43:47,780 --> 00:43:51,350
Well, we have to wait our 30 seconds for
spanning through protocol but

820
00:43:51,350 --> 00:43:52,940
it is going to come back up.

821
00:43:52,940 --> 00:43:57,020
And when it does come back up, it's going
to think that it's trunking, all right?

822
00:43:57,020 --> 00:43:58,400
And that's because when it's hard set,

823
00:43:58,400 --> 00:44:00,710
it doesn't do any verification
on the other end.

824
00:44:00,710 --> 00:44:04,240
So you could have a trunk that
on both ends says its trunking.

825
00:44:04,240 --> 00:44:07,200
It looks happy, but
data is not flowing over it.

826
00:44:07,200 --> 00:44:11,070
If one end is set to isl and
the other end is set to 802.1q,

827
00:44:11,070 --> 00:44:12,900
they're not going to match up.

828
00:44:12,900 --> 00:44:15,860
So what I like to do is exactly
what I've done here on the screen.

829
00:44:15,860 --> 00:44:20,780
I like to get my two switches open at
the same time so I can do a nice little

830
00:44:24,500 --> 00:44:26,260
output of the command.

831
00:44:27,430 --> 00:44:32,170
And I can pull up
the configuration of one end, and

832
00:44:32,170 --> 00:44:34,950
pull up the configuration of the other
end and then just compare them, right?

833
00:44:34,950 --> 00:44:36,620
They're both set to mode trunk.

834
00:44:36,620 --> 00:44:38,440
They're both set to no negotiate.

835
00:44:38,440 --> 00:44:39,580
This one's set to isl.

836
00:44:39,580 --> 00:44:41,350
This one's set to dot1q.

837
00:44:41,350 --> 00:44:43,702
Real easy to spot when they're
side by side like this.

838
00:44:43,702 --> 00:44:45,740
Or I guess top and bottom.

839
00:44:45,740 --> 00:44:48,920
>> And Don, this is a good
example of maybe a simulate or

840
00:44:48,920 --> 00:44:50,680
a simulation that we might have.

841
00:44:50,680 --> 00:44:53,920
Where they show one particular
point on the top and

842
00:44:53,920 --> 00:44:56,710
then they show you the other one and
they ask you to fix it.

843
00:44:56,710 --> 00:45:01,277
Not going to be too much that you're gonna
fix, but at least they'll actually maybe

844
00:45:01,277 --> 00:45:04,772
show you the encapsulation.isl and
the encapsulation.1q.

845
00:45:04,772 --> 00:45:06,073
And they're asking you to correct it.

846
00:45:06,073 --> 00:45:10,360
So it's very possible that you might get
something very close to that as well.

847
00:45:10,360 --> 00:45:13,580
>> Yeah, this is a hard one to
troubleshoot because there's no error

848
00:45:13,580 --> 00:45:17,480
message, there's nothing in the logs,
even CDP isn't warning us about this.

849
00:45:17,480 --> 00:45:20,230
All we can do is we can go in and

850
00:45:20,230 --> 00:45:24,340
we can look, compare the configuration
side by side, and then we'll spot it.

851
00:45:24,340 --> 00:45:28,850
We'll set that problem where it's set
to isl, we can reset it to dot1q,

852
00:45:28,850 --> 00:45:31,140
the interface will go down,
>> Mm-hm.

853
00:45:31,140 --> 00:45:32,320
>> The interface will come back up, and

854
00:45:32,320 --> 00:45:34,310
then traffic will begin to
flow across that line again.

855
00:45:36,500 --> 00:45:38,540
All right, so keep that in mind.

856
00:45:38,540 --> 00:45:41,330
Those are some of the issues that we
can have that can cause the entire

857
00:45:41,330 --> 00:45:42,739
trunk to just fail to come up.

858
00:45:44,580 --> 00:45:46,300
Let's see a couple of other things.

859
00:45:46,300 --> 00:45:52,140
They don't mention it in the objectives,
but you could have a native VLAN mismatch.

860
00:45:52,140 --> 00:45:57,030
Notice when I do the show
interface trunk command

861
00:45:57,030 --> 00:46:00,670
that one of the things that it
outputs is what the native VLAN is.

862
00:46:00,670 --> 00:46:03,040
And now I'm getting word wrap or whatever.

863
00:46:03,040 --> 00:46:05,840
The native VLAN on
the right side is a one.

864
00:46:05,840 --> 00:46:10,790
The native VLAN on the left
side is also a one.

865
00:46:10,790 --> 00:46:13,570
Then if the native VLAN were
wrong on the two sides,

866
00:46:13,570 --> 00:46:15,390
if they were different,
that would be problem also.

867
00:46:15,390 --> 00:46:19,933
It would cause VLAN bleeding, traffic from
one VLAN bleeding over to another VLAN.

868
00:46:19,933 --> 00:46:25,480
Now CDP usually discovers this one and
warns us about it.

869
00:46:25,480 --> 00:46:29,083
So for example, if I were to change it,

870
00:46:29,083 --> 00:46:33,684
if I were to say switchboard
trunk native VLAN 2.

871
00:46:33,684 --> 00:46:34,541
Okay.

872
00:46:34,541 --> 00:46:37,010
So now, on the left side, it's VLAN 1.

873
00:46:37,010 --> 00:46:39,320
On the right side, it's VLAN 2.

874
00:46:39,320 --> 00:46:40,650
Look what I get, right.

875
00:46:40,650 --> 00:46:44,820
CDP immediately starts warning me saying,
you got some issues, right.

876
00:46:44,820 --> 00:46:46,950
Actually, this is spanning
tree warning me here.

877
00:46:46,950 --> 00:46:51,160
So, spanning tree is telling me,
we're getting BPDU's on the wrong VLAN and

878
00:46:51,160 --> 00:46:53,150
eventually CDP will warn us also.

879
00:46:53,150 --> 00:46:54,570
There's CDP right there.

880
00:46:54,570 --> 00:46:56,030
So native VLAN mismatch.

881
00:46:56,030 --> 00:46:59,310
So I'm actually getting warned
from multiple systems, CDP and

882
00:46:59,310 --> 00:47:01,480
spanning tree all letting us know.

883
00:47:01,480 --> 00:47:05,845
A mismatched native VLAN is a big deal
when you're connecting one VLAN to

884
00:47:05,845 --> 00:47:07,479
different VLAN, which you shouldn't do.

885
00:47:08,530 --> 00:47:10,450
It's pretty hard to make
that mistake though, right?

886
00:47:10,450 --> 00:47:13,610
Look at my screen,
it's just smattered with garbage now.

887
00:47:13,610 --> 00:47:15,001
So it's pretty easy to
spot that happening.

888
00:47:18,902 --> 00:47:19,933
All right.

889
00:47:19,933 --> 00:47:24,226
Ronnie, looking at the timer,
we're starting to run a little low,

890
00:47:24,226 --> 00:47:26,827
I know we still have the allowed VLAN's.

891
00:47:26,827 --> 00:47:29,480
Which actually we probably have enough
time to tackle that one don't we?

892
00:47:29,480 --> 00:47:31,490
>> Yep.
>> And then we still have ACLs for

893
00:47:31,490 --> 00:47:32,020
after the break.

894
00:47:33,420 --> 00:47:35,190
All right, there we go.

895
00:47:35,190 --> 00:47:38,210
Notice when I fix the problem we actually
get a message that their saying,

896
00:47:38,210 --> 00:47:40,130
consistency restored.

897
00:47:40,130 --> 00:47:45,260
Letting us know that that was it's fixed,
so it's happy again.

898
00:47:45,260 --> 00:47:50,350
All right, so the last one on the list for
VLANS is the allowed VLANS.

899
00:47:50,350 --> 00:47:54,235
When you configure VLAN
trunking by default, and

900
00:47:54,235 --> 00:47:56,959
I'm going to make this full sized again.

901
00:47:56,959 --> 00:47:57,459
There.

902
00:48:01,178 --> 00:48:03,523
By default it will allow.

903
00:48:03,523 --> 00:48:07,586
Every VLAN, VLANs 1-4,094.

904
00:48:07,586 --> 00:48:09,259
But you might not want that,

905
00:48:09,259 --> 00:48:13,980
you might want only a couple of VLANs
to be allowed to pass over that trunk.

906
00:48:13,980 --> 00:48:16,810
If this trunk is running
to another building, and

907
00:48:16,810 --> 00:48:19,570
over in that other building you
just have VLANs 1, 2, and 3,

908
00:48:19,570 --> 00:48:24,460
there's no sense in sending
the broadcasts for all these

909
00:48:24,460 --> 00:48:29,100
other VLANs across that other building,
if those don't exist at the other end.

910
00:48:29,100 --> 00:48:30,610
So we can prune them off.

911
00:48:30,610 --> 00:48:32,620
They call it pruning the VLANs.

912
00:48:32,620 --> 00:48:35,010
It's great for optimizing bandwidth.

913
00:48:35,010 --> 00:48:38,150
But down the road,
maybe we make a change and

914
00:48:38,150 --> 00:48:41,350
originally just VLANs 1 through
3 were in the other building.

915
00:48:41,350 --> 00:48:44,280
But now I need VLANs 10 and
11 in the other building.

916
00:48:44,280 --> 00:48:47,090
And so we might make that
where we add some ports, but

917
00:48:47,090 --> 00:48:49,530
they're not going to able to communicate
because they've been pruned off.

918
00:48:49,530 --> 00:48:50,130
All right.

919
00:48:50,130 --> 00:48:51,270
So how do we prune them off?

920
00:48:51,270 --> 00:48:52,320
Well, let me just show you.

921
00:48:53,430 --> 00:48:55,936
So if I get into interface fa0/3

922
00:48:58,817 --> 00:49:02,640
If I say switchport trunk allowed and

923
00:49:02,640 --> 00:49:08,290
then I can specify my VLAN
ranges that we allow.

924
00:49:08,290 --> 00:49:11,964
And so I can specify and
maybe I'll say vlan 1 through 3.

925
00:49:13,260 --> 00:49:14,010
All right.

926
00:49:14,010 --> 00:49:15,320
And just to be on the safe side,

927
00:49:15,320 --> 00:49:17,690
I'm gonna do that same
configuration on the other side.

928
00:49:17,690 --> 00:49:24,820
I'll say switchport
trunk allowed vlan 1-3.

929
00:49:24,820 --> 00:49:27,650
So there we go, I'm allowing those VLANs.

930
00:49:28,660 --> 00:49:29,430
All right?

931
00:49:29,430 --> 00:49:34,410
Now when I look in my config, that
makes it into the config, and if I, so

932
00:49:34,410 --> 00:49:40,170
if I do like this, I'll see those
allowed VLAN's right there and

933
00:49:40,170 --> 00:49:45,780
if I do a show interface trunk,
I'll see VLAN's allowed on the network and

934
00:49:45,780 --> 00:49:49,120
active and see how all the other
VLAN's just disappeared.

935
00:49:49,120 --> 00:49:49,950
Okay.

936
00:49:49,950 --> 00:49:52,960
And down here I should be
able to see the same thing.

937
00:49:52,960 --> 00:49:53,827
All the other VLAN's disappeared.

938
00:49:53,827 --> 00:49:54,327
All right.

939
00:49:55,740 --> 00:49:59,300
But now I changed my mind and I say,
you know what, I need VLAN 10 and

940
00:49:59,300 --> 00:50:01,210
11 to make it over to the other side.

941
00:50:01,210 --> 00:50:08,940
Well, up here I can say, switchport trunk
allowed vlan and then I can say add 10-11.

942
00:50:08,940 --> 00:50:13,110
Okay?
That means keep the existing list and

943
00:50:13,110 --> 00:50:14,740
just add 10 through 11 to it.

944
00:50:14,740 --> 00:50:16,460
All right?

945
00:50:16,460 --> 00:50:21,260
So now I can look at it and
there it is, 1 through 3, and

946
00:50:21,260 --> 00:50:24,320
10 through 11 all right there and
they're allowed.

947
00:50:24,320 --> 00:50:24,890
I'm done.

948
00:50:24,890 --> 00:50:27,220
>> Now on to the side problem.

949
00:50:27,220 --> 00:50:28,850
>> Side problem.

950
00:50:28,850 --> 00:50:32,470
If I look at if from the other side,
I just have one, two, three.

951
00:50:32,470 --> 00:50:33,220
>> Yeah.

952
00:50:33,220 --> 00:50:36,610
>> So I'm allowing 10 through
11 to go to the other side, but

953
00:50:36,610 --> 00:50:39,090
I'm not allowing ten to 11 to come back.

954
00:50:39,090 --> 00:50:42,470
I've just created uni-directional traffic.

955
00:50:42,470 --> 00:50:43,980
>> Yeah.
>> I can send traffic out to that

956
00:50:43,980 --> 00:50:44,648
remote building.

957
00:50:44,648 --> 00:50:48,140
I'm not gonna receive it
back on VLANs ten and 11.

958
00:50:48,140 --> 00:50:51,860
Alright, so it's really hard to pick up
uni-directional routing, because it really

959
00:50:51,860 --> 00:50:54,610
just looks like it times out, you know,
your traffic never gets there.

960
00:50:54,610 --> 00:50:58,270
But, it's always important to
check the two ends of the VLAN.

961
00:50:58,270 --> 00:51:00,689
And this is another one where if,
we just do it side-by-side.

962
00:51:09,465 --> 00:51:10,893
[SOUND] If we just do a side by side,
it's easy to spot.

963
00:51:10,893 --> 00:51:13,210
There's the difference.

964
00:51:13,210 --> 00:51:14,260
I've got a ,ten or 11 there.

965
00:51:14,260 --> 00:51:15,160
I don't have it there.

966
00:51:15,160 --> 00:51:17,990
I just need to fix it, right?

967
00:51:17,990 --> 00:51:21,640
But this is where I've seen
people where they do switchport

968
00:51:21,640 --> 00:51:26,000
trunk allowed vlan 10-11, like that.

969
00:51:26,000 --> 00:51:28,090
All right, and
then we'll take a look at it.

970
00:51:28,090 --> 00:51:29,560
>> Oops.
>> See what it did?

971
00:51:29,560 --> 00:51:35,070
It replaced the list, and so if we look at
it now, I've, whoops, where's the, there.

972
00:51:36,230 --> 00:51:40,102
I've killed off one through three
with that simple command, so

973
00:51:40,102 --> 00:51:42,328
we gotta make sure when we go to fix it,

974
00:51:42,328 --> 00:51:46,855
that we do the add, and now for
me I've gotta add one through three.

975
00:51:46,855 --> 00:51:53,030
And funny little side note here,

976
00:51:53,030 --> 00:51:57,775
technically I excluded
the native VLAN there in

977
00:51:57,775 --> 00:52:02,210
802.1q VLAN tagging on a Cisco switch,
it actually won't let you prune VLAN one.

978
00:52:02,210 --> 00:52:04,350
It won't let you prune the native VLAN.

979
00:52:04,350 --> 00:52:05,910
I shouldn't say VLAN one.

980
00:52:05,910 --> 00:52:08,890
Because you can change your
native VLAN to whatever.

981
00:52:08,890 --> 00:52:12,031
So whatever is your native VLAN
will always pass over the line,

982
00:52:12,031 --> 00:52:15,601
there is a special command you can run,
let's see if I can remember it.

983
00:52:19,327 --> 00:52:23,152
It is actually I don't even
think it's in the interface,

984
00:52:23,152 --> 00:52:25,270
I think it's a global command.

985
00:52:25,270 --> 00:52:31,732
Let's see if I can find it here, not.1x.

986
00:52:31,732 --> 00:52:36,782
You know what, I can't remember it off
hand, but there is a special command that

987
00:52:36,782 --> 00:52:41,685
allows you to prune off the native VLAN,
and boy I don't remember what it was,

988
00:52:41,685 --> 00:52:45,270
but it's not something that
many people would ever do.

989
00:52:45,270 --> 00:52:50,869
You don't normally prune off your native
VLAN, but there is a way to do it.

990
00:52:51,960 --> 00:52:55,190
It's gonna eat at me too, cause I know
I've seen the command before, but

991
00:52:55,190 --> 00:52:58,510
by default even if you tell it
to exclude the native VLAN,

992
00:52:58,510 --> 00:52:59,680
it's still going to pass it along.

993
00:52:59,680 --> 00:53:03,100
Because the native VLAN's untagged,
it's really gotta be set across the line.

994
00:53:05,080 --> 00:53:06,640
All right, so
definitely keep an eye out for

995
00:53:06,640 --> 00:53:10,070
that, any time you deal with
allow VLANs or disallow VLANs or

996
00:53:10,070 --> 00:53:13,380
whatever you've got to make sure you match
the two sides and everything lines up.

997
00:53:13,380 --> 00:53:14,630
>> Yep.
>> All right, Ronnie,

can you think of anything else to

I think this a good point for
