will help a little bit with this list.

1046
00:56:00,540 --> 00:56:01,150
>> [LAUGH]

1047
00:56:10,672 --> 00:56:11,760
There.

1048
00:56:11,760 --> 00:56:12,460
Okay.

1049
00:56:12,460 --> 00:56:15,060
So there's my access list that I made,
all right?

1050
00:56:15,060 --> 00:56:20,530
I'm permitting me to ping 4.2.2.2,
I'm denying me pinging 4.2.2.1,

1051
00:56:20,530 --> 00:56:24,120
and I'm permitting everything else, right?

1052
00:56:24,120 --> 00:56:27,220
IP which is TZP and UDP as well as ICMP.

1053
00:56:27,220 --> 00:56:29,110
So allowing all that to go through.

1054
00:56:29,110 --> 00:56:29,910
All right.

1055
00:56:29,910 --> 00:56:32,860
So then,
I go on a test on my work station.

1056
00:56:32,860 --> 00:56:37,990
And I say, all right well, let me ping,
4.2.2.2, I should be able to ping, right?

1057
00:56:37,990 --> 00:56:38,638
And I can.

1058
00:56:38,638 --> 00:56:41,850
And then 4.2.2.1,
I shouldn't be able to ping.

1059
00:56:42,850 --> 00:56:46,110
And I can't.
I mean and I can, shoot.

1060
00:56:46,110 --> 00:56:50,980
So I have to ask myself,
did that access list even work?

1061
00:56:50,980 --> 00:56:51,880
>> Right.

1062
00:56:51,880 --> 00:56:55,390
>> And this is where the access list
statistics come in really handy.

1063
00:56:55,390 --> 00:56:58,701
You can run show Access-list.

1064
00:56:58,701 --> 00:57:02,710
That command right there, show access
dash list will give you a list of all

1065
00:57:02,710 --> 00:57:07,740
your access lists and you will see
what's called a hit count, right?

1066
00:57:07,740 --> 00:57:10,355
>> Yep.
>> How many matches your traffic has?

1067
00:57:10,355 --> 00:57:15,951
So I have an ACL up here for doing network
address translation, and I can see on it,

1068
00:57:15,951 --> 00:57:21,875
it's got 25,000 matches, I know that it
is working and running and doing its job.

1069
00:57:22,915 --> 00:57:26,235
Look at how many matches I
have on the ACL I just wrote.

1070
00:57:26,235 --> 00:57:28,015
>> Yes.
None.

1071
00:57:28,015 --> 00:57:28,705
>> Why not?

1072
00:57:28,705 --> 00:57:31,555
Why don't I have any matches on this list?

1073
00:57:31,555 --> 00:57:34,130
Well, I made the list.

1074
00:57:34,130 --> 00:57:36,020
I never attached it to an interface,
did I?

1075
00:57:36,020 --> 00:57:37,758
>> Nope.
>> I just kind of left it out there.

1076
00:57:37,758 --> 00:57:42,092
So it's hard for an access list for work
when it's not attached to an interface.

1077
00:57:42,092 --> 00:57:43,338
>> Yep.

1078
00:57:43,338 --> 00:57:45,987
And this is where it goes back to that
same troubleshooting skill we were talking

1079
00:57:45,987 --> 00:57:47,020
about, right?

1080
00:57:47,020 --> 00:57:50,310
Making sure that we know how
these things basically work.

1081
00:57:50,310 --> 00:57:52,880
Proper configuration of
the access list itself.

1082
00:57:52,880 --> 00:57:54,750
But also that we have to
attach it to the interface.

1083
00:57:54,750 --> 00:57:57,960
So that is also key for
us as we come back here.

1084
00:57:57,960 --> 00:58:00,520
So Don is actually
showing us now a drawing.

1085
00:58:00,520 --> 00:58:02,070
>> Yeah, let's go to my drawing here.

1086
00:58:02,070 --> 00:58:05,590
So when I am on PC1, and

1087
00:58:05,590 --> 00:58:10,780
I'm going out to the internet
like to ping 4.2.2.1 or

1088
00:58:10,780 --> 00:58:16,140
4.2.2.2, I'm passing through Router 1,
and I need to attach that access list.

1089
00:58:16,140 --> 00:58:18,344
On either gigabit 0/1 or

1090
00:58:18,344 --> 00:58:23,420
gigabit 0/0 to be able to stop
that traffic from passing through.

1091
00:58:23,420 --> 00:58:24,870
So I just need to attach it.

1092
00:58:24,870 --> 00:58:26,105
And I can attach it to either interface.

1093
00:58:26,105 --> 00:58:26,810
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right?

1094
00:58:26,810 --> 00:58:29,440
And attach it, get it in place,
and off we go.

1095
00:58:29,440 --> 00:58:29,940
Right?
>> Yep.

1096
00:58:31,170 --> 00:58:32,592
>> So let me go and do that.

1097
00:58:32,592 --> 00:58:36,223
I'm gonna get into interface gi0/0,

1098
00:58:36,223 --> 00:58:41,213
where I will say IP access-group,
what number did I do?

1099
00:58:41,213 --> 00:58:42,080
101?

1100
00:58:42,080 --> 00:58:44,291
>> 101.
>> 101 in.

1101
00:58:44,291 --> 00:58:45,750
Okay.
All right.

1102
00:58:45,750 --> 00:58:48,790
So now the access list is attached,

1103
00:58:48,790 --> 00:58:51,690
I'm filtering that traffic
now we should be blocked.

1104
00:58:51,690 --> 00:58:52,910
Right?

1105
00:58:52,910 --> 00:58:54,840
Well, let's do a test.

1106
00:58:54,840 --> 00:58:59,414
So I should be able to
ping forward at 2.2.2, and

1107
00:58:59,414 --> 00:59:03,998
I can and
I should not be able to ping 4.2.2.1.

1108
00:59:03,998 --> 00:59:05,170
But I can.
>> Oh.

1109
00:59:05,170 --> 00:59:06,295
Oh dear.

1110
00:59:06,295 --> 00:59:08,645
>> What the heck is going on here?

1111
00:59:08,645 --> 00:59:10,575
>> Yeah.
Now, when we take a look at it, remember.

1112
00:59:10,575 --> 00:59:14,495
It's not only that we have to attach
the access list to the interface.

1113
00:59:14,495 --> 00:59:17,955
We also have to pick the proper
direction as we take a look.

1114
00:59:17,955 --> 00:59:24,480
So Don showed us that he did attach it to
gigabit 0/0 here, which is perfectly fine.

1115
00:59:24,480 --> 00:59:28,690
But notice the last word there that
we have, which is the word in.

1116
00:59:28,690 --> 00:59:31,930
Now, this is where I would actually run in
from I have to go check to take a look at

1117
00:59:31,930 --> 00:59:36,030
my diagram again, but I would actually
do here is actually take a look.

1118
00:59:36,030 --> 00:59:38,220
When I take a look at that
particular direction,

1119
00:59:38,220 --> 00:59:44,170
I'm saying coming back into the interface
itself, is the way that I attached it.

1120
00:59:44,170 --> 00:59:46,930
Now notice that the way that
Don drew the arrow though,

1121
00:59:46,930 --> 00:59:49,490
it's actually leaving the interface.

1122
00:59:49,490 --> 00:59:55,299
Instead, and so when it's leaving
the interface it's not gonna block it,

1123
00:59:55,299 --> 01:00:00,019
it's actually blocking the idea
of the data going the other,

1124
01:00:00,019 --> 01:00:02,591
or coming in the other side here.

1125
01:00:02,591 --> 01:00:09,600
>> So when we attach this interface,
it should have been IN GI 01 or OUT GI 00.

1126
01:00:09,600 --> 01:00:14,180
Since I did it IN GI 00,
what's happening is my

1127
01:00:14,180 --> 01:00:18,830
traffic is going out to the internet,
and then I get my reply back,

1128
01:00:20,710 --> 01:00:25,040
and here is where it's
going in that interface.

1129
01:00:25,040 --> 01:00:25,839
The reply back.

1130
01:00:25,839 --> 01:00:30,207
The reply that's coming from,
in my example it was 4.2.2.1, right?

1131
01:00:30,207 --> 01:00:34,053
It's coming from there and it's not gonna
match my ACL, and I've got that permit any

1132
01:00:34,053 --> 01:00:37,250
in there so it's gonna clear it and
come right through, right?

1133
01:00:37,250 --> 01:00:38,880
So, it's the wrong direction.

1134
01:00:38,880 --> 01:00:41,200
It's easy to spot if you draw a diagram.

1135
01:00:41,200 --> 01:00:44,310
If you draw a picture you can see
that you did the wrong direction.

1136
01:00:44,310 --> 01:00:46,910
The other thing is, if I go back and

1137
01:00:46,910 --> 01:00:52,450
I look at my statistics,
I'll see my statistics hitting,

1138
01:00:52,450 --> 01:00:57,280
here on this permit IP any any,
see how I've got 1213 matches.

1139
01:00:57,280 --> 01:01:00,080
I'm getting hits on this ACL, but

1140
01:01:00,080 --> 01:01:06,350
I'm not getting any hits on these
other entries, and I should be, right?

1141
01:01:06,350 --> 01:01:08,410
So that's my first hint
that I've got a problem.

1142
01:01:08,410 --> 01:01:11,800
These statistics are really helpful for
kind of figuring that out and

1143
01:01:11,800 --> 01:01:13,220
getting it tagged.

1144
01:01:13,220 --> 01:01:19,450
So if I go and fix that,
if I say, no to turn that off,

1145
01:01:20,700 --> 01:01:24,856
and I change it to an outbound list,
right?

1146
01:01:24,856 --> 01:01:25,421
>> Yeah.

1147
01:01:25,421 --> 01:01:29,666
>> Now going back here to
my super messy diagram now.

1148
01:01:29,666 --> 01:01:32,400
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me clean this up a bit.

1149
01:01:32,400 --> 01:01:34,062
Now when we take a look at this.

1150
01:01:34,062 --> 01:01:39,620
My traffic is passing into GI0/1
out of GI0/0, and when we pass out,

1151
01:01:39,620 --> 01:01:44,649
that's when that ACL is going to apply and
I'm gonna get filtered,

1152
01:01:44,649 --> 01:01:49,879
even before I make it out to the internet,
which is definitely ideal.

1153
01:01:49,879 --> 01:01:53,085
We'll see if it works.

1154
01:01:53,085 --> 01:01:58,633
So, 4.2.2.2 I should be able to ping and

1155
01:01:58,633 --> 01:02:02,612
I can and 4.2.2.1.

1156
01:02:02,612 --> 01:02:04,180
Oh.

1157
01:02:04,180 --> 01:02:06,570
I shouldn't be able to ping that one but
I sure did.

1158
01:02:06,570 --> 01:02:10,160
So let's go double check our ACL and
make sure that's right.

1159
01:02:10,160 --> 01:02:13,250
Let me just jump back here and
we'll take a look at our statistics.

1160
01:02:13,250 --> 01:02:15,499
I thought we had it fixed that time but
maybe we missed something else.

1161
01:02:18,040 --> 01:02:21,540
All right, so taking a look at
it here on these ICM statements,

1162
01:02:21,540 --> 01:02:23,480
I still don't have any matches.

1163
01:02:23,480 --> 01:02:26,960
You know what,
I have seen something like this before.

1164
01:02:28,300 --> 01:02:31,436
Let me just verify one thing, GI0/0,

1165
01:02:31,436 --> 01:02:37,720
that is our outside we got IP access
group 101 out, that is the right ACL.

1166
01:02:37,720 --> 01:02:42,700
It is applying to outside, so
we should be good there and,

1167
01:02:42,700 --> 01:02:49,530
let me just double check
one more time our syntax.

1168
01:02:49,530 --> 01:02:55,210
So I've got permit ICNP coming from
host 192.168.0.222, so that's me.

1169
01:02:55,210 --> 01:02:57,530
Or, you know what, let me verify that,
that should be me.

1170
01:02:57,530 --> 01:03:00,840
That would be funny if
I had my address wrong.

1171
01:03:00,840 --> 01:03:01,820
Nope that is!

1172
01:03:01,820 --> 01:03:04,990
And then my default gateway is the router,
that's the way that I'm getting there.

1173
01:03:07,330 --> 01:03:08,970
We'll let that run in the background.

1174
01:03:08,970 --> 01:03:11,070
And so I should have hit on one of those.

1175
01:03:11,070 --> 01:03:14,650
I was doing ICMP traffic
to one of those hosts.

1176
01:03:18,550 --> 01:03:23,249
So I'm gonna do the old trusty and
we'll shut down that interface for

1177
01:03:23,249 --> 01:03:26,257
a second, and
then we'll do a no shut down.

1178
01:03:28,674 --> 01:03:29,300
And there we go.

1179
01:03:29,300 --> 01:03:32,510
I have seen before where you
make a change to an interface.

1180
01:03:32,510 --> 01:03:35,230
And the ACL doesn't apply
until you exit the interface.

1181
01:03:35,230 --> 01:03:37,730
So that may actually be
what's going on here.

1182
01:03:37,730 --> 01:03:42,030
Not exactly what Cisco is calling out of
their objectives, but it can happen so

1183
01:03:42,030 --> 01:03:42,870
let's try this again.

1184
01:03:45,880 --> 01:03:47,464
Oh, gee it's always complaining.

1185
01:03:47,464 --> 01:03:51,350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good old Windows protecting me from

1186
01:03:51,350 --> 01:03:52,570
myself there.

1187
01:03:52,570 --> 01:03:55,540
So I was doing a trace route real quick,

1188
01:03:55,540 --> 01:03:58,150
just to verify that I am
passing through that router.

1189
01:03:58,150 --> 01:03:59,443
If I'm passing through a different router,

1190
01:03:59,443 --> 01:04:01,393
if I have a different default gateway,
then it's not gonna apply.

1191
01:04:01,393 --> 01:04:03,795
But I can see right there,
I am passing through that router.

1192
01:04:03,795 --> 01:04:08,886
And if I ping 4.2.2.2, I should get there.

1193
01:04:08,886 --> 01:04:12,073
And if I ping 4.2.2.1,
I should be getting blocked.

1194
01:04:12,073 --> 01:04:15,040
>> Yeah.
>> I'm not, so that's pretty interesting.

1195
01:04:15,040 --> 01:04:19,330
Now when we have a communication like
this, where it's getting through and

1196
01:04:19,330 --> 01:04:23,020
it's not matching, that means we've
got a bit of a problem, okay?

1197
01:04:23,020 --> 01:04:26,630
And we can take a look at our config to
try and find out what that problem is.

1198
01:04:26,630 --> 01:04:28,425
Now, I'm doing pings.

1199
01:04:28,425 --> 01:04:32,399
And pings are ICMP echo requests.

1200
01:04:32,399 --> 01:04:38,080
I send an echo request out to
the Internet, and they send back to me.

1201
01:04:38,080 --> 01:04:38,820
>> Echo reply.

1202
01:04:38,820 --> 01:04:39,880
>> An echo reply, yeah.

1203
01:04:39,880 --> 01:04:44,360
So when we do a protocol suite like this,
ICMP, that's

1204
01:04:44,360 --> 01:04:49,130
supposed to get the whole thing, but
it is possible that in this case it's not.

1205
01:04:49,130 --> 01:04:51,060
That it's not including what I want.

1206
01:04:51,060 --> 01:04:54,250
I can't imagine it is, but
that could be our case.

1207
01:04:54,250 --> 01:04:58,150
So, the other problem is I'm not
handling this very efficiently.

1208
01:04:58,150 --> 01:05:02,760
If I look at the router,
my traffic is going in this interface and

1209
01:05:02,760 --> 01:05:04,620
then out the other.

1210
01:05:04,620 --> 01:05:08,488
And so I'm filtering it on the way out,
after I've done the routing table look

1211
01:05:08,488 --> 01:05:11,417
ups and after I'm ready to send
it along on that interface,

1212
01:05:11,417 --> 01:05:13,428
which is not really the best way to do it.

1213
01:05:13,428 --> 01:05:16,860
You usually you wanna do it closer to
the source if you're doing an extended ACL

1214
01:05:16,860 --> 01:05:19,080
like this, it's very specific.

1215
01:05:19,080 --> 01:05:21,660
So we can move it over
to this other interface,

1216
01:05:21,660 --> 01:05:24,121
that shouldn't make a difference though.

1217
01:05:24,121 --> 01:05:27,152
It's the same ACL, shouldn't influence it.

1218
01:05:27,152 --> 01:05:29,810
And then the other thing is we can
kinda tweak the way that ACL is written

1219
01:05:29,810 --> 01:05:32,230
to try and be a little more
specific to find out our problem,

1220
01:05:32,230 --> 01:05:36,667
to find out why this ACL isn't applying,
right?

1221
01:05:38,070 --> 01:05:40,974
I didn't intend for
this example to be a difficult one, but

1222
01:05:40,974 --> 01:05:43,247
it actually turned out
to be a pretty good one.

1223
01:05:43,247 --> 01:05:44,179
So let's move the ACL first.

1224
01:05:44,179 --> 01:05:45,827
So I'll get into gi0/0.

1225
01:05:51,958 --> 01:05:54,456
And I'm just gonna remove that ACL, and

1226
01:05:54,456 --> 01:05:59,450
I'm just gonna make sure that there's
no access control list applied to it.

1227
01:05:59,450 --> 01:06:01,360
Oh, shoot, there's my problem.

1228
01:06:02,530 --> 01:06:03,420
I'm doing NAT.

1229
01:06:03,420 --> 01:06:06,510
I'm doing Network Address Translation.

1230
01:06:06,510 --> 01:06:11,900
By the time my traffic makes it to that
second port, I've already been translated.

1231
01:06:11,900 --> 01:06:16,910
My source address is no
longer 192.168.0222.

1232
01:06:16,910 --> 01:06:19,630
My source address is now
what I've been NATed to.

1233
01:06:19,630 --> 01:06:21,927
Now that's a good thing,
I'm glad that came up,

1234
01:06:21,927 --> 01:06:24,947
is that when you don't understand
the order that things happen.

1235
01:06:24,947 --> 01:06:31,907
Your incoming ACL is applied first, then
NAT is applied, then you're outgoing ACL.

1236
01:06:31,907 --> 01:06:35,294
So it's the outgoing ACL is applied
after NAT you've got to plan for

1237
01:06:35,294 --> 01:06:36,611
that in your access list.

1238
01:06:36,611 --> 01:06:38,639
>> Yeah.
>> And I didn't do that so

1239
01:06:38,639 --> 01:06:41,340
that's why that ACLdidn't apply.

1240
01:06:41,340 --> 01:06:43,980
So if I wanted to filter here I could
filter based on the NAT address.

1241
01:06:43,980 --> 01:06:45,700
>> Right.
>> Which is pretty hard to do.

1242
01:06:45,700 --> 01:06:49,380
In this case, I'm gonna have to
apply it on the incoming interface.

1243
01:06:49,380 --> 01:06:53,996
So I'll get into interface gi0/1 and
apply it.

1244
01:06:56,308 --> 01:06:57,440
There we go.

1245
01:06:57,440 --> 01:06:59,060
And so now it's attached there.

1246
01:07:00,130 --> 01:07:02,910
And I will jump back over.

1247
01:07:02,910 --> 01:07:07,749
And I'm gonna try and ping 4.2.2.2,
which I should be able to do,

1248
01:07:07,749 --> 01:07:13,270
there we go, and I'll try and
ping 4.2.2.1, and we don't, right?

1249
01:07:13,270 --> 01:07:17,840
So, did I use a crazy show command or
whatever to solve that problem?

1250
01:07:17,840 --> 01:07:20,690
No, I used show running-config, right?

1251
01:07:20,690 --> 01:07:23,670
I looked at the running config
of that interface, and saw

1252
01:07:23,670 --> 01:07:28,200
the IP NAT outside command and that was my
warning, to say oh, shoot that's right!

1253
01:07:28,200 --> 01:07:31,200
We're doing NST, my address is changing,
there's my problem.

1254
01:07:32,692 --> 01:07:36,530
All right,
now if I go back here I can do a show

1255
01:07:39,710 --> 01:07:45,120
access- list, and now I can see that
I'm getting matches on those two lines,

1256
01:07:45,120 --> 01:07:50,170
right, so I've got matches here
on the one that permits, and

1257
01:07:50,170 --> 01:07:52,370
I've got matches on the one that denies.

1258
01:07:52,370 --> 01:07:56,350
Those are the pings you know Microsoft
sends four with each ping attempt and so

1259
01:07:56,350 --> 01:07:58,210
we can see that they're going through and
they're hitting.

1260
01:07:58,210 --> 01:07:58,710
>> Yep.

1261
01:07:59,800 --> 01:08:01,600
Yeah.
A good example for us.

1262
01:08:01,600 --> 01:08:03,620
>> Yeah.
>> Actually see what's going on here.

1263
01:08:03,620 --> 01:08:07,710
And the other thing, let's do that show
run on that interface again, and let's

1264
01:08:07,710 --> 01:08:15,920
talk about the idea of the way that we
apply that command there on the interface.

1265
01:08:15,920 --> 01:08:21,220
So notice that the way that we have
it is access-group if you type

1266
01:08:21,220 --> 01:08:26,170
in IP access-list,
Ii's not gonna be correct here, but

1267
01:08:26,170 --> 01:08:29,530
remember that there's also two
really tricky ones here too.

1268
01:08:29,530 --> 01:08:33,090
On the physical interface,
it's always access-group, but

1269
01:08:33,090 --> 01:08:37,310
what if you were doing this
going into the router itself?

1270
01:08:37,310 --> 01:08:40,980
In other words, on the VTY lines, you
gotta remember that if you take a look at

1271
01:08:40,980 --> 01:08:47,100
that, that should be access-class and
that's something important to remember.

1272
01:08:47,100 --> 01:08:48,120
So if you're saying that, hey,

1273
01:08:48,120 --> 01:08:53,330
it's still not blocking traffic going into
the interface or into the router itself,

1274
01:08:53,330 --> 01:08:55,760
and you see access-group,
it's probably not gonna work.

1275
01:08:55,760 --> 01:08:58,720
If you see access-class, that's your key.

1276
01:08:58,720 --> 01:08:59,420
>> Yep.
Yeah,

1277
01:08:59,420 --> 01:09:02,930
I don't know why they didn't maintain
consistency there, but it is different.

1278
01:09:02,930 --> 01:09:05,850
Now, what i we hadn't figured
out what our problem was?

1279
01:09:05,850 --> 01:09:09,170
What if it still wasn't blocking it?

1280
01:09:09,170 --> 01:09:13,430
One of the neat things that you can do
is you can redefine your access list

1281
01:09:13,430 --> 01:09:15,850
with the log option turned on.

1282
01:09:15,850 --> 01:09:18,200
So you can do some logging and

1283

find out a little bit better about
why that traffic didn't match up.

1284
01:09:21,640 --> 01:09:27,290
And so one of the things that I like to do
is if we do like a do show access-list,

1285
01:09:27,290 --> 01:09:31,650
you've got your sequence numbers
on the ACL and so we can try and

1286
01:09:31,650 --> 01:09:34,600
edit the ACL and inject a line in there.

1287
01:09:34,600 --> 01:09:39,000
So, if I still wasn't hitting on those
first two entries and I was still just

1288
01:09:39,000 --> 01:09:43,820
really super mega confused, we could
get really specific about this ACL.

1289
01:09:43,820 --> 01:09:46,700
Let's break it again, I'm gonna move it.

1290
01:09:52,742 --> 01:09:56,800
And I'm gonna get into GI 0/0 and
I'm gonna put it back here.

1291
01:09:59,420 --> 01:10:01,460
So that's how it was before,

1292
01:10:01,460 --> 01:10:04,020
when it should have been blocking me but
it wasn't.

1293
01:10:04,020 --> 01:10:05,575
Right?
I was still able to ping

1294
01:10:05,575 --> 01:10:09,360
4.2.2.1 even though I shouldn't

1295
01:10:09,360 --> 01:10:10,680
So if I start troubleshooting this,

1296
01:10:10,680 --> 01:10:14,120
I'm just scratching my head going
good gosh, why isn't this working?

1297
01:10:14,120 --> 01:10:19,740
All right, one of the things we can do is
we can write a very general ACL entry and

1298
01:10:19,740 --> 01:10:22,630
turn logging on for
it to be able to troubleshoot.

1299
01:10:22,630 --> 01:10:28,770
So, I might say, ip access-list 101,

01:10:28,770 --> 01:10:32,280
do I have to say extended after that?

01:10:32,280 --> 01:10:36,090
Oh, it's not gonna let me do a number,

1302
01:10:36,090 --> 01:10:38,650
If it was a named ACL we
could edit it since it's

1303

not a named ACL I gotta do

1304
01:10:46,186 --> 01:10:47,880
Hang on let me pull out this ACL.

01:10:47,880 --> 01:10:53,070
All right so here's what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna take ACL 101 that we wrote

01:10:53,070 --> 01:10:57,460
at the beginning of the show, and

01:10:57,460 --> 01:11:01,020
Okay, and I'm gonna add,
no access-list 101.

1308
01:11:01,020 --> 01:11:05,370
That's gonna delete it and
then we're gonna recreate it and for

1309
01:11:05,370 --> 01:11:07,200
the very first line

01:11:13,905 --> 01:11:19,024
I'm going to say access-list
101 permit IP any,

01:11:19,024 --> 01:11:26,345
so any IP traffic going to host 4.2.2.1,
and I want to we'll log it.

1312
01:11:26,345 --> 01:11:29,416
And that actually includes ICMP like

01:11:29,416 --> 01:11:29,945
at the end.

01:11:29,945 --> 01:11:31,585
We can leave that off.

1315
01:11:31,585 --> 01:11:35,975
Permit IP any just pretty much lets any

1316
01:11:35,975 --> 01:11:41,415
So, by putting this log up here I'm
going to say if anybody tries to send

1317
01:11:41,415 --> 01:11:45,250

1318
01:11:45,250 --> 01:11:48,980
This will let me look at the traffic and

1319
01:11:48,980 --> 01:11:54,988
So my problem was that my source was no

01:11:54,988 --> 01:11:58,284
I'm gonna go put this back into

01:11:58,284 --> 01:12:02,928
So the first line is gonna delete

01:12:06,147 --> 01:12:10,030

1324
01:12:10,030 --> 01:12:12,600
So it deleted access list 101, and

01:12:12,600 --> 01:12:17,000
then it recreated it, putting my log

01:12:17,000 --> 01:12:21,910
Now I could go back to my client,
and I could say all right,

01:12:21,910 --> 01:12:23,720
I shouldn't be able to ping 4.2.2.1.

01:12:23,720 --> 01:12:24,620
Let me try it.

1329
01:12:24,620 --> 01:12:26,140
See there, I'm trying it.

1330
01:12:26,140 --> 01:12:27,660
And back here, here's the message.

1331
01:12:28,830 --> 01:12:35,110
And look what it says, access list 101

1332
01:12:35,110 --> 01:12:42,500
And the source, 10.1.230.15, that would

1333
01:12:42,500 --> 01:12:44,470
Oh, shoot, I'm getting NAT-ed, right?

1334
01:12:44,470 --> 01:12:48,830
And I could say show IP net translations,
and

1335
01:12:48,830 --> 01:12:51,949
right there I would see-

1336
01:12:51,949 --> 01:12:57,045
>> 192.168.222 getting

01:12:57,045 --> 01:13:00,358
So even if we didn't spot

01:13:00,358 --> 01:13:03,680
we still could have seen

1339
01:13:05,040 --> 01:13:08,230
>> Now, Don, if we take a look
at that show access list again,

1340
01:13:08,230 --> 01:13:11,840
here's another troubleshooting thing
that can kinda get us as well.

1341
01:13:11,840 --> 01:13:13,400
Let's see if we can bring it back up.

1342
01:13:14,710 --> 01:13:17,380
Because Don has added in
that first entry in there,

1343
01:13:17,380 --> 01:13:21,990
in the permit ip any to this host, right?

1344
01:13:21,990 --> 01:13:25,630
Remember that when we build access
control list, we normally wanna start at

1345
01:13:25,630 --> 01:13:30,770
the most specific statements that we
can and end with the most general here.

1346
01:13:30,770 --> 01:13:35,560
What is actually happening here is that
Don has put inside of that list here that,

1347
01:13:35,560 --> 01:13:37,160
hey, allow anything to go through.

1348
01:13:37,160 --> 01:13:40,920
But notice now what Don's highlighted,
which is that the deny here,

1349
01:13:40,920 --> 01:13:43,390
this statement will never get a match

1350
01:13:43,390 --> 01:13:47,180
because that very first one is
already allowing it to go through.

1351
01:13:47,180 --> 01:13:50,660
Not uncommon for
you to be able to spot this or

1352
01:13:50,660 --> 01:13:52,460
to be given this scenario
here that says hey,

1353
01:13:52,460 --> 01:13:57,380
why is this still not working,
just like in the situation that we had.

1354
01:13:57,380 --> 01:14:01,600
And one of the key aspects, of course
is understanding that very concept.

1355
01:14:01,600 --> 01:14:05,670
Most specific up at top, to the more
general statements down at the bottom.

1356
01:14:07,300 --> 01:14:11,640
>> So we would either need to rearrange
this or now that I'm done testing,

1357
01:14:11,640 --> 01:14:13,090
I can remove that line up there.

1358
01:14:13,090 --> 01:14:17,760
So I can go back to this, and I can say
all right, we figured out our problem

1359
01:14:17,760 --> 01:14:22,670
I can remove that log line and
then go back to this way here.

1360
01:14:22,670 --> 01:14:26,200
Which would put everything back
to the way it's supposed to be.

1361
01:14:26,200 --> 01:14:30,732
Now the only thing is I need to go and
re-attach it to the right place.

1362
01:14:35,300 --> 01:14:39,804
So instead of doing a one on one out here,

1363
01:14:39,804 --> 01:14:45,520
I would get in here and
do a one on one in, like that.

1364
01:14:45,520 --> 01:14:50,425
And now we should be back in business, the
logging is turned off, and there we go.

1365
01:14:50,425 --> 01:14:53,525
You do want to turn logging off
when you're not using it because

1366
01:14:53,525 --> 01:14:58,365
if you're logging like a high traffic line
it's going to generate a ton of messages.

1367
01:14:58,365 --> 01:15:02,375
And you definitely don't want that, it
does get messy fast, your log files will

1368
01:15:02,375 --> 01:15:05,635
fill out, they'll start overwriting
themselves and it's a mess.

1369
01:15:07,440 --> 01:15:08,110
All right.

1370
01:15:08,110 --> 01:15:11,350
Now Ronnie mentioned access
classes on the VTY lines.

1371
01:15:11,350 --> 01:15:12,520
That's another important one.

1372
01:15:12,520 --> 01:15:14,150
It might turn up on the exam.

1373
01:15:14,150 --> 01:15:18,940
Let's say you wanna control who's
allowed to Telnet into your router.

1374
01:15:18,940 --> 01:15:19,480
All right?

1375
01:15:19,480 --> 01:15:24,615
So right now if I fire up a PuTTY session,
I can Telnet into

1376
01:15:24,615 --> 01:15:29,910
192.168.0.1 that's that router.

1377
01:15:29,910 --> 01:15:33,642
I can Telnet in, and
I can log in, here we go.

1378
01:15:33,642 --> 01:15:37,419
Okay?.
If I want to control that, I might come in

1379
01:15:37,419 --> 01:15:42,465
here and write an access
list that says access-list,

1380
01:15:42,465 --> 01:15:46,220
we'll just say it's access-list 5.

1381
01:15:46,220 --> 01:15:51,004
And I'll say permit 192.16,

1382
01:15:51,004 --> 01:15:55,631
well, let's do this, let's deny

1383
01:15:55,631 --> 01:16:00,416
192.168.0.222, and

1384
01:16:00,416 --> 01:16:06,910
then permit 192.168.00, like that.

1385
01:16:06,910 --> 01:16:07,490
Okay?

1386
01:16:07,490 --> 01:16:12,310
So I'm denying my laptop and
I'm permitting everybody else.

1387
01:16:13,590 --> 01:16:19,299
And I get into interface gi0/1 and

1388
01:16:19,299 --> 01:16:24,020
I say access-group 5 in.

1389
01:16:24,020 --> 01:16:31,440
So going back over to my window here, my
PC, if I try and Telnet into the router.

1390
01:16:31,440 --> 01:16:34,491
I'm passing in gi0/1, right?

1391
01:16:34,491 --> 01:16:38,952
And that's the ACL that I just wrote here,
going in gi0/1,

1392
01:16:38,952 --> 01:16:44,439
192.168.0.222 is specifically
in the list to not be allowed.

1393
01:16:44,439 --> 01:16:47,650
I should have done a log on there,
shouldn't I?

1394
01:16:47,650 --> 01:16:51,200
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyhow, we'll leave it be.

1395
01:16:51,200 --> 01:16:54,670
I should not be able to
Telnet into that router.

1396
01:16:54,670 --> 01:17:01,080
So, if I fire up A Telnet
session to that router.

1397
01:17:03,106 --> 01:17:07,550
>> I can try and connect and oh shoot.

1398
01:17:07,550 --> 01:17:09,266
You know I'm forgetting
something dag gummit.

1399
01:17:09,266 --> 01:17:12,805
>> [LAUGH]
>> So [LAUGH] we've updated this router.

1400
01:17:12,805 --> 01:17:13,360
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

1401
01:17:13,360 --> 01:17:18,380
this router is running the latest iOS and
Cisco finally fixed this.

1402
01:17:18,380 --> 01:17:19,900
On the exam, it's not this way.

1403
01:17:19,900 --> 01:17:22,430
This is our pain for
running the latest iOS.

1404
01:17:22,430 --> 01:17:28,030
So they finally fixed this in the newer
iOS's, but in the iOS's from like 12.4 and

1405
01:17:28,030 --> 01:17:33,040
earlier, if you attempted to do this,
you would actually get in just fine.

1406
01:17:33,040 --> 01:17:35,930
And that's because ACLs
really only apply to traffic

1407
01:17:35,930 --> 01:17:38,390
that passes from one interface to another.

1408
01:17:38,390 --> 01:17:40,050
We're not passing from
one interface to another,

1409
01:17:40,050 --> 01:17:42,560
we're passing into one interface,
and going into a VTY.

1410
01:17:43,800 --> 01:17:48,050
And so on system running the older iOS's,

1411
01:17:48,050 --> 01:17:53,510
you had to take this older ACL and
apply directly to the VTY lines.

1412
01:17:53,510 --> 01:17:57,110
And even today, that's still a better
practice than attaching it the interface.

1413
01:17:57,110 --> 01:17:58,590
So here it actually worked as expected.

1414
01:17:58,590 --> 01:18:01,131
I am now locked out, so let me
switch over to a console connection.

1415
01:18:01,131 --> 01:18:03,907
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then I'll be able to kind of

1416
01:18:03,907 --> 01:18:08,870
straighten that out, but
where is the console port, there we go.

1417
01:18:08,870 --> 01:18:11,530
All right, so
I'm gonna just plug into that one.

1418
01:18:11,530 --> 01:18:12,670
That's funny.

1419
01:18:12,670 --> 01:18:14,860
I thought about that after I turned it on,
I was like oh shoot,

1420
01:18:14,860 --> 01:18:16,250
I updated this router.

1421
01:18:16,250 --> 01:18:20,260
But that's the price we pay for
having the latest and greatest.

1422
01:18:20,260 --> 01:18:27,810
So in real life land, it's not so much of
a problem but the exam is still based on.

1423
01:18:27,810 --> 01:18:28,570
You know what?

1424
01:18:28,570 --> 01:18:31,070
Actually the exam they've
updated to 15 now, haven't they?

1425
01:18:31,070 --> 01:18:33,130
They've updated to the 15 iOSs.

1426
01:18:33,130 --> 01:18:39,650
So, on the exam, the problem will
be fixed there too, but it is

1427
01:18:39,650 --> 01:18:45,150
still the best practice to attach the ACL
to the VTY lines and not the interface.

1428
01:18:45,150 --> 01:18:51,737
So I need to get into gi0/1

1429
01:18:51,737 --> 01:18:56,260
and say, I need to remove it from there.

1430
01:18:56,260 --> 01:18:59,300
And instead go into my VTY lines and

1431
01:18:59,300 --> 01:19:05,230
here's where just like Ronnie said we do
access-class 5 in and attach it there now.

1432
01:19:05,230 --> 01:19:11,630
And here's another little trick, notice
how up here there was IP access-group,

1433
01:19:11,630 --> 01:19:17,150
here it's just straight up
access-class no IP before it.

1434
01:19:17,150 --> 01:19:21,780
The other thing is,
it only supports a standard ACL,

1435
01:19:21,780 --> 01:19:24,590
no extended ACLs,
it's gotta be a standard.

1436
01:19:27,120 --> 01:19:31,990
So those are kinda what we're seeing,
and what might creep up there.

1437
01:19:31,990 --> 01:19:34,930
So in the newer iOS's,
that little problem is fixed, but

1438
01:19:34,930 --> 01:19:37,930
it's still the best practice
to attach the VTY lines.

1439
01:19:37,930 --> 01:19:40,240
A lot of people don't even realize
that you can attach the VTY lines.

1440
01:19:40,240 --> 01:19:44,330
The nice thing about attaching it here,
regardless of whether somebody comes in

1441
01:19:44,330 --> 01:19:47,380
your LAN interface your WAN
interface your other interfaces,

1442
01:19:47,380 --> 01:19:49,220
this ACL will always apply.

1443
01:19:49,220 --> 01:19:50,219
Otherwise you have to apply,

1444
01:19:50,219 --> 01:19:53,125
a different ACL to each
interface to secure the router.

1445
01:19:53,125 --> 01:19:54,445
This takes care of it all in one place.

1446
01:19:54,445 --> 01:19:57,504
And I guess, I could have shown that.

1447
01:19:57,504 --> 01:20:00,964
Let me kinda, repeat this example here.

1448
01:20:00,964 --> 01:20:08,400
If I do So I'm gonna remove it there.

1449
01:20:08,400 --> 01:20:15,871
And I'll get into, let me write a new one.

1450
01:20:15,871 --> 01:20:17,659
So I'm gonna create an access list,

1451
01:20:21,256 --> 01:20:26,891
That's gonna specifically block my host

1452
01:20:26,891 --> 01:20:31,883
going to 192.168.0.1,

1453
01:20:31,883 --> 01:20:35,752
where the port equals 23.

1454
01:20:35,752 --> 01:20:40,857
So I'm gonna deny my laptop
telnetting into this router and

1455
01:20:40,857 --> 01:20:44,031
then I'll permit everything else.

1456
01:20:48,369 --> 01:20:51,173
And what did I do?

1457
01:20:51,173 --> 01:20:53,038
Access-list 15.

1458
01:20:53,038 --> 01:20:55,620
>> Oh!
>> 15 instead of 105, shoot.

1459
01:20:55,620 --> 01:20:59,704
There we go.

1460
01:20:59,704 --> 01:21:04,621
So I'm specifically denying my laptop
the ability to telnet into this router.

1461
01:21:04,621 --> 01:21:06,490
I'm permitting everything else.

1462
01:21:06,490 --> 01:21:12,744
And then I'm gonna get into interface
GI0/1 and attach this access list.

1463
01:21:12,744 --> 01:21:17,549
I'll say ipaccess-group 105 in.

1464
01:21:17,549 --> 01:21:21,369
So now I will not be able
to Telnet into this system.

1465
01:21:21,369 --> 01:21:22,493
In theory.

1466
01:21:22,493 --> 01:21:27,548
If I fire up my PuTTY window,
and I try in Telnet into

1467
01:21:27,548 --> 01:21:33,789
192.168.0.1, I'm gonna Telnet,
and I can't.

1468
01:21:33,789 --> 01:21:34,740
Good.

1469
01:21:34,740 --> 01:21:40,093
But if I know the IP address of
another interface if I try and

1470
01:21:40,093 --> 01:21:44,690
Telnet into the outside
interface of the router.

1471
01:21:46,510 --> 01:21:47,640
There I am.

1472
01:21:47,640 --> 01:21:48,420
And I can get right in.

1473
01:21:49,660 --> 01:21:53,610
That's why we don't wanna write these
ACLs and attach them to interfaces.

1474
01:21:53,610 --> 01:21:56,690
When you're securing the router itself,
if you were to do it that way,

1475
01:21:56,690 --> 01:22:00,950
you'd have to write one ACL for
each of your interface IPs to secure it.

1476
01:22:00,950 --> 01:22:05,450
If you just attach it to the VTYs,
it's not a problem, you can't get in.

1477
01:22:07,490 --> 01:22:09,370
So let's recap, Ronnie.

1478
01:22:09,370 --> 01:22:12,640
So when we troubleshoot the ACLs,
what are the things we need to look at?

1479
01:22:12,640 --> 01:22:13,275
>> Yeah.

1480
01:22:13,275 --> 01:22:17,555
We take a look at the ACLs themselves,
make sure that we begin with understanding

1481
01:22:17,555 --> 01:22:20,185
the proper configuration
of the ACL itself.

1482
01:22:20,185 --> 01:22:23,725
Standard versus the idea of
the extended access control list.

1483
01:22:23,725 --> 01:22:26,555
We start off with the most
specific statements up top and

1484
01:22:26,555 --> 01:22:29,795
work to the most general
statements down at the bottom.

1485
01:22:29,795 --> 01:22:35,130
Remember that every ACL has to have at
least one permit statement is the key.

1486
01:22:35,130 --> 01:22:39,750
